fields.headline: Morrison halts Rangers' play-off surge
fields.trailText: QPR 0 - 1 Crystal Palace
fields.body:
Although he is unlikely to admit it, Gerry Francis must sense last night's narrow defeat to impoverished Palace has sounded the death knell for his side's play-off hopes. Clinton Morrison's second-half goal for the visitors inflicted Rangers' first defeat in nine and only their second at home all season. They paid the price for a distinctly off-colour display.

Recent matches between the sides have been feisty affairs: Rangers had two men sent off at Selhurst Park in November, and two Palace defenders saw red the last time they visited Loftus Road. That was on the final day of last season when a rampant QPR won 6-0, stayed up and have hardly looked back since.

But though Francis's side began the evening nine points off the play-offs, that romp in the May sun remained their only derby win since 1996. In five games against London opposition this season they had mustered two points without scoring a goal.

Their start suggested as much, a dawdling defence inviting Mikael Forssell, on loan from Chelsea, and Hayden Mullins to try their luck from distance. Somewhat unnerved, Rangers creaked into action, Mikkel Beck heading a Richard Langley cross wide of the post. The Danish striker was presented with an almost identical chance midway through the half, but succeeded only in a repeat performance as Fraser Digby lay sprawled on the turf.

The Eagles' financial problems rumble on and a mass exodus of key players is expected before today's five o'clock transfer deadline. Mullins and Clinton Morrison remain the likely candidates, but it was another of the visitors' bright young things who created their best chance five minutes before the break. Wayne Carlisle's deep cross was dropped by Lee Harper and Forssell prodded wide of the open goal.

The stalemate was almost broken on the hour as Ready capitalised on Digby's weak punch but blazed over a gaping goal. Rangers continued to press, but were increasingly wary of the visitors' speed on the break. Their concern seemed well-founded when McKenzie darted in for Thomson's through ball and crossed for Morrison, but his shot was caught by Harper.

The warnings were not heeded. After 68 minutes, Thomson's pass down the flank sent Carlisle away and the winger's cross was headed across goal by Dean Austin. With the home defenders' static, Morrison gleefully atoned for his earlier miss.

fields.headline: Ipswich bounce back to second
fields.trailText: Tranmere 0 - 2 Ipswich
fields.body:
The footballing maxim that "second place is nowhere" has been taken a little too literally in the First Division in recent weeks. Following a series of laughable failures by virtually all the contenders for the second place behind Charlton Athletic, however, Ipswich Town finally seem to have realised that the play-offs are not all they are cracked up to be and that the anonymity of second place might not be so bad after all.

Failure in the play-offs in the last three seasons has made Ipswich something of a joke, in Norfolk at least, but George Burley's team are finally smiling themselves now after a worrying sequence of five matches without a win cast serious doubts about their promotion credentials.

They could scarcely have asked for more accommodating hosts than Tranmere and it was hardly a surprise when Ipswich, having already gone close twice through Jamie Scowcroft, opened the scoring on 19 minutes.

Jermaine Wright's fierce drive was parried by the home goalkeeper Joe Murphy but only into the path of Matt Holland, who hooked the ball into the net from six yards.

It was no less than Ipswich Town deserved as they made an enterprising start following a potentially morale-sapping recent sequence of results.

Mark Venus shaved the Tranmere crossbar with a free-kick and Jamie Clapham forced a fine save from Murphy, whose team-mates produced precisely zilch in reply until Gary Jones volleyed over just before the interval.

The second half was even more one-sided and Ipswich would not have been unduly flattered had they run up a tally of half a dozen goals.

Scowcroft twice headed against the woodwork before inadvertently clearing another effort off the line from his team-mate Clapham.

David Johnson, the striker whose baffling early-season dalliance with Scotland and Jamaica make him the only man in football who can understand the current nationality crisis in Welsh and Scottish rugby union, wasted two opportunities before finally making his mark with a scrambled overhead kick that settled the match on 57 minutes.

fields.headline: Dunn saves the Souness parade
fields.trailText: Blackburn 1 - 0 Birmingham
fields.body:
Graeme Souness's inaugural home match as manager gave some indication of the passion and commitment the fans at Ewood Park can expect from his team with David Dunn striking the winner deep into injury-time.

The Birmingham players, hands on their knees and heads bowed, lingered on the pitch as if they could not bear to believe what had happened. They were that close to a precious point that would have stoked their hopes of reaching the play-offs.

The pre-match applause for Souness was warm rather than effusive, and he acknowledged it with a brief wave of his right arm. It was about as animated as the home supporters became until deep into the first half, when a challenge by Darren Purse flattened Egil Ostenstad.

Birmingham were largely in control without ever looking particularly threatening. They explored the width of the pitch on both sides looking for their strikers Dele Adebola and Isiah Rankin but Rovers' three-man defensive wedge of Craig Short, Christian Dailly and Steve Harkness was never unduly troubled.

Purse's foul on Ostenstad finally put a little fire in the home side's collective belly. Short's header skimmed the bar from Keith Gillespie's corner and then Matt Jansen's long-range left-foot shot caused Ian Bennett to back-pedal rapidly, although once again the ball narrowly cleared the bar.

Birmingham were well off the pace at the beginning of the year, their progress stalled by a seemingly never-ending litany of injuries, but in recent weeks they have come on strongly and before this set-back last night had won eight of their previous 10 games.

Their confidence was immediately apparent against a Blackburn side striving to impress, but for all of Birmingham's initial possession and general dominance they created disappointingly few chances.

The second half was altogether more animated with Martin Grainger, on the stretch, just failing to connect properly with a cross from Stan Lazaridis and then Matt Jansen failing to take advantage of Keith Gillespie's electric run and cross by heading straight at Bennett.

With both sides now believing in victory a previously pallid match became decidedly lively, interspersed with moments of tetchiness that the referee handled with quiet authority.

Marcelo, a hulking Brazilian and one of a clutch of second-half substitutes, came the closest to scoring and giving Birmingham three vital points until that final minute of injury-time, when Dunn's fiercely hit low right-foot shot brought Birmingham to their knees.

fields.headline: Charlton head into the sunset
fields.trailText: Charlton 4 - 0 Grimsby
fields.body:
It has been known for some time that Charlton are head and shoulders above the rest of the division. Last night, as if to emphasise that fact, they put four headers past a Grimsby Town defence who will be relieved not to have to face them again next season.

Considering that Charlton had scored five at Blundell Park in November, the Valley faithful had grounds for thinking they were short changed after Carl Tiler had made it four. If so, they did not express it. There is only pleasure to be associated with a promotion run-in during which there is not the slightest need to look over their shoulders.

Charlton's handsome points advantage over their pursuers, even though it was reduced to 10 on Tuesday with Barnsley's victory against Fulham, is such that Alan Curbishley is running out of new ways to motivate his players.

It led him, in his programme notes, to ponder the meaning of the word "gap". The Charlton manager, clearly one of the game's deeper thinkers, said it was really there as a "safety net", it could easily be whittled away and if they didn't get across "the finishing line" in May then it would become "just a statistic".

So, any thoughts of comfort having been dispelled, Charlton set about doing to Grimsby what, peculiarly, they could not do here against the bottom club Swindon 10 days ago. They were ahead after seven minutes when Mathias Svensson, in an interesting role reversal, crossed from the right and Newton, normally the one serving from out wide, rose to put away a header.

It should not have stood alone as long as it did; Svensson volleyed over, Newton shot hard against a defender and another Newton header produced a tip-over save.

Richard Rufus then sent his header off target from a corner kick.

Grimsby could hardly get out of their own half to make a game of it. A free-kick just before half-time gave Kingsley Black the chance to rouse Dean Kiely into activity. But in the event the goalkeeper was happy to allow the ubiquitous Newton to clear from the line with yet another thrust of his forehead.

Svensson's goal-making favour was returned nine minutes into the second-half, Newton surging well clear of his marker before sending a perfect cross towards the Swede's head. It was his first goal since a £600,000 move from Crystal Palace. And the same player was also in at the start of the move that saw Charlton score again six minutes later, Andy Hunt glancing in a high ball that John Robinson had sent over from the left.

Only now were Charlton discovering a sharper edge to reward their powerful, incisive approach-play, and just to lower Grimsby's morale a shade more they then sent on a Premiership player in the shape of West Ham's Paul Kitson, who has just begun a loan spell at the Valley.

webTitle: Prior joins up with the Royle family

fields.headline: Prior joins up with the Royle family
fields.trailText: Manchester City have taken steps to shore up their defence before today's transfer deadline, signing Spencer Prior from Derby for £500,000.
fields.body:
Manchester City have taken steps to shore up their defence before today's transfer deadline, signing Spencer Prior from Derby for £500,000.

"This is a Premiership set-up and I am glad to be part of it. I don't consider I have stepped down," said the 28-year-old, who will cost City more if he plays enough games. Derby paid Leicester £700,000 for him 19 months ago.

"Martin O'Neill has signed him for Leicester and Norwich and that speaks volumes," said Joe Royle, his new manager.

Subject to work permits Sunderland are hoping to agree a £2.7m deal for Paok Salonika's Honduras striker Milton Nunez, 27, and Middlesbrough are expecting to sign the 17-year-old Brazilian trialist Arthur Enrique Bernard from Novo Hamburgo.

The Hearts defender Paul Ritchie, who has been on loan at Bolton, has signed for a nominal fee until the end of the season, when he will be able to move on a Bosman-inspired free transfer, and Watford's Des Lyttle has joined West Brom until May.

 Uefa will sell 20,000 tickets for the Champions League final in Paris on May 24 through the internet from tomorrow: www.clubfinals.uefa.com

webTitle: Cole strikes gold on £20,000 a week

fields.headline: Cole strikes gold on £20,000 a week
fields.trailText: Joe Cole, who has yet to prove his worth for England, is valued so highly by West Ham that they have made him the highest-paid teenager in British football.
fields.body:
Joe Cole, who has yet to prove his worth for England, is valued so highly by West Ham that they have made him the highest-paid teenager in British football.

The 18-year-old's two-year extension to his contract, tying him to the club until 2004, will bring him £20,000 a week rising to £30,000 if he plays at senior international level.

Though that is the price West Ham must pay to keep one of the most precocious talents in the land, it vindicates their youth policy; they almost certainly could not afford a player of his ability on the open market.

Another highly rated West Ham midfielder, the 18-year-old Michael Carrick, has also signed a three-year extension keeping him at Upton Park until 2005. With two more home-grown England players, Frank Lampard and Rio Ferdinand, also recently agreeing long-term deals, the Hammers' future looks bright.

So does Cole's, on and off the pitch. In addition to his salary the youngster is expected to make over £1m a year in endorsements. Until being rested recently he was a regular in the first team and it is only a matter of time before he plays for England.

"It is so important for us, and to keep faith with the fans, that we made these signings," said the West Ham manager Harry Redknapp. "Joe Cole's talent is mind-boggling. It is a pleasure to watch him."

Redknapp also revealed he was offered the chance to take Real Madrid's unsettled French striker Nicolas Anelka on loan for the rest of the season. Such is Real's desire to offload the former Arsenal star, whom they recently fined for failing to train, that the Spanish club offered to pay the bulk of Anelka's £60,000-a-week salary. Redknapp declined the offer. "We were asked if we were interested but it was over before it happened."

Instead he has signed the Lyon striker Frédéric Kanoute, 22, on loan for the rest of the season with a view to a permanent deal.

fields.headline: Seaman still No1 says Wenger
fields.standfirst: Werder Bremen v Arsenal
fields.trailText: It was fitting that Arsène Wenger took time yesterday to discuss his goalkeepers. If Arsenal are to retain their 2-0 lead tonight, the man between the sticks will play an important role.
fields.body:
It was fitting that Arsène Wenger took time yesterday to discuss his goalkeepers, pondering how long David Seaman could go on, wondering what Alex Manninger's future held. If Arsenal are to retain their 2-0 lead tonight, the man between the sticks will play an important role.

Wenger sounded hopeful that Seaman will recover from a neck injury but his goalkeeping conundrum is increasingly complex. Seaman has looked below his best at times; Manninger has been advised by Austria's coach to leave Highbury after being dropped from the national side.

"As long as David is at his best he will be the No1," said the Arsenal manager, who believes Seaman has recently produced his finest form for three years. But he made it clear the 36-year-old will not be offered a lengthy deal when his contract expires after next season.

"Nigel Winterburn and Lee Dixon have accepted that, when you reach a certain age, it's from year to year," said Wenger. He feels Seaman could become a club goalkeeping coach, and he has high hopes of Manninger.

The 22-year-old will go on loan next season if necessary but Wenger said: "I know Alex will one day be the goalkeeper at Arsenal. When I bought him he was 19 and I thought he would benefit from a long apprenticeship. I don't think he will lose patience."

Bremen are not to be underestimated, having already overturned deficits against Lyon and Parma. But Arsenal should be strengthened by the return of Emmanuel Petit, and Wenger said: "The concern is to win the battle in midfield, not to think we just have to defend but to play our normal game."

Thierry Henry's pace should ensure chances, though Arsenal will be without Dennis Bergkamp. He offered to travel by road but was told to rest for Coventry on Sunday. Wenger's priority seems to be reaching the Champions League.

Arsenal (probable, 4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Luzhny, Adams, Silvinho; Parlour, Vieira, Petit, Ljungberg; Kanu, Henry.

fields.headline: Werder Bremen 2 - 4 Arsenal
fields.trailText:
Werder Bremen: Rost, Eilts, Baumann, Trares, Pizarro, Wiedener, Bode, Herzog, Frings, Ailton, Barten.
Substitutes: Flock, Maximow, Bogdanovic, Dabrowski, Tjikuzu, Schierenbeck, Brasas.
fields.body:
Werder Bremen: Rost, Eilts, Baumann, Trares, Pizarro, Wiedener, Bode, Herzog, Frings, Ailton, Barten.
Substitutes: Flock, Maximow, Bogdanovic, Dabrowski, Tjikuzu, Schierenbeck, Brasas.

Arsenal: Manninger, Dixon, Luzhny, Adams, Silvinho, Parlour, Vieira, Grimandi, Ljungberg, Kanu, Henry.
Substitutes: Winterburn, Keown, Suker, Overmars, Petit, Malz, Lukic.

Referee: K Nielsen (Denmark)

Bremen have fielded a very attacking line-up - they may start with three up front. Horrible at away games but masters of the aggregate win, the German side will also need to prevent Arsenal from scoring, and not many teams have managed that in recent weeks. Arsenal have only lost three-nil once in Europe.

1 min Bremen start the match and surrender possession to Adams. A cacophony of whistles greets every Arsenal players touch - Bremen have crowded the midfield early and are looking to control the action through the middle.
2 A bad error from Luzhny lets Ailton in for a dig at Manninger from the left of the area. the effort is a poor one, but a good chance gone begging for the home side - Dixon was well out of position and Adams lets him know about it.
6 Bremen are looking to get the ball to the forwards as quickly as possible - Arsenal will have to weather the storm during the opening moments. A free kick to Bremen after Adams 'fouled' Ailton. Wiedener looks to test Manninger with his left boot. The shot clears the wall but Manninger saves well.
8 GOAL Werder Bremen 0 - 1 Arsenal Manninger's clearance finds Kanu on the right. The Nigerian takes the ball to the corner flag, drawing two defenders with him. His clever pass finds Ray Parlour on the right of the area. The Arsenal midfielder drives a rising shot from 20 yards with the outside of his right boot. The left upright does its part, making the goal aesthetically all the more pleasing. A great away goal that has knocked the stuffing out of the home side.
12 Kanu played through again. This time, the Arsenal playmaker drives a good, low shot at Rost and the Bremen keeper does well to turn the effort round his right-hand post. The corner is swung into the near post and Bremen clear well upfield.
16 Freddie Ljundberg refuses to bear false witness as another great through ball from Kanu sends the Swede through on Rost. Baumann appears to shove Freddie in the back, but Ljundberg stays on his feet and tries to finish the job. The push has disturbed his equilibrium and Bremen are able to clear.
19 Ljundberg breaking forward for Arsenal with Kanu and Henry advancing with intent on the Bremen goal. Freddie can't pick either of them out and Bremen tidy up.
20 Bremen drive upfield and win a corner. Arsenal clear as far as Herzog, who volleys but the connection is a poor one. The ball falls invitingly for Barten, who slides the ball goalwards with Manniger well beaten, but Ray Parlour, scourge of Bremen, clears off the line.
23 Trares rounds off a promising Bremen move by slicing his shot so far wide of the Arsenal goal that Manninger stopped watching it the moment it left his boot.
25 GOAL Werder Bremen 0 - 2 Arsenal Same guy, same post. Ray beats three (count 'em - three!) Werder defenders before sliding the ball home past Rost and off his favourite post. If he gets a hat-trick off the same upright does he get to keep it? The 34,000 Bremen fans cannot believe it - Ray Parlour?!
28 Werder are still plugging away, trying to find a way through. Their challenges are beginning to border on the agricultural. Referee Nielsen may have a busy night.
32 The more Werder push up, the larger the gaps in their defence must appear to this Arsenal side. Ljundberg almost through again and a good challenge from Pizarro spares Bremen's blushes.
35 Ljundberg beats Frings and plays in Kanu, who lays it back for Henry. His shot is destined for the bottom corner but somehow Rost turns it around the post. The corner is a poor one, but this Bremen side look like they have been instructed to haemorrhage goals.
39 Silvinhno fancies his chances from a set-piece 25 yards out. His effort clears the six-man wall and Rost is a picture of cool as the Arsenal midfielder's shot cannons off the post. The supporters don't know whether to cheer or cry.
42 GOAL Werder Bremen 1 - 2 Arsenal A tiny glimmer of hope for Bremen as a corner to the near post is met by Bode, who has managed to slip Vieira. Manninger has also come for the centre and his positioning gives him no chance after the forward had deflected it goalwards.
44 Bremen press forward with a little more purpose, lifted by the goal. Weidener meets Parlour on the left and flings himself to the ground. The ball rolls dead and the referee awards... a goal kick. Weidener is on a yellow and has to watch his deportment. Manninger is booked for taking his time over the goal kick.
46 Kanu flicks a Parlour free kick goalwards. The effort is deflected and the ricochet falls to Ljundberg, who draws a great save from Rost. Adams collects the keeper's parry and seems to have rounded Rost and only has to punt the ball into an empty net, but Rost travels through time and space to deny the Arsenal skipper.
47 Half time comes not a moment too soon for the home side.

45 Big reshuffle for the home side as Bogdanovic is on and Bremen look like they're playing... five up front? Well, maybe not, but a very attacking line up for the home side an only mean more chances for Arsenal.
48 Arsenal have started very brightly. Already they're on their second corner of the half. Parlour takes and Grimandi flicks on to Vieira at the far post. A Bremen defender deflects his effort and another corner results. This time Bremen are able to clear.
50 Kanu played through but the Nigerian takes an age to drag back his right foot and drive the ball goalwards. Pizarro manages to block the effort for yet another corner. Again, the delivery is disappointing and the home side are happy to hoof the ball upfield.
52 Ailton looks to have beaten the offside trap as Arsenal hold the line. The linesman's flag rises as Ailton's drive rises over Manninger's crossbar. Nothing going right for Bremen tonight.
53 Vieira loses the ball to Ailton on the right, but the Brazilian's cross aimed at two unmarked teammates is too low and Manninger gathers easily. A let off for Arsenal, who have Overmars and Petit warming up on the sidelines, to add to Bremen's woes.
55 Henry uncharacteristically profligate in front of goal. With only Rost to beat from 15 yards, his shot is a soft one straight into the keeper's arms. Parlour should jog over and give the French international striker some tips.
59 GOAL Werder Bremen 1 - 3 Arsenal If he doesn't score them, he makes them. Kanu spots Parlour ghosting through the offside trap and the carrot-topped goal machine shows his unselfish side in squaring to Henry who cannot miss from 10 yards. Game over.
60 GOAL Werder Bremen 2 - 3 Arsenal A nice goal for the home side scored pretty much from the restart. Ailton looks to get on the end of a Pizarro centre. Arsenal get it clear, but only as far as Rade Bogdanovic, who beats Manninger from 15 yards with a good volley but this is all academic and the celebrations are muted.
61 Arsenal substitution: Petit for Adams.
63 Sent off: Henry (serious foul play) sent from the pitch for a poor challenge on Barten. The Bremen forward has rolled over nine times after the badly-timed tackle. Referee Nielsen immediately shows the red card to the Frenchman. As soon as the Danish ref wields the red, Barten springs to his feet like Lazarus. He cannot believe it and neither can Wenger, who is going ballistic on the touchline. Even the partisan German crowd seem embarrassed with this farcical dismissal.
70 GOAL Werder Bremen 2 - 4 Arsenal A hat-trick for Parlour as he gets the better of Rost on a one-on-one. This must be one of the new Officially Sanctioned UEFA Crazy Games and Arsenal look to contribute a little more to the mayhem by bringing on Overmars immediately after the goal.
73 A free kick to Bremen 25 yards out centre-left. Pizarro takes and blasts the ball over the Arsenal crossbar. Missing chances has been desperately unfashionable for the last 73 minutes.
77 Arsenal substitution: Winterburn for Vieira. Just about enough time for the veteran defender to grab a brace...
79 Bogdanovic feeds Bode on the edge of the box - his volley is sweet and Manninger manages to parry the effort wide of his right-hand post. The corner is aimed at the far post and Manninger comes to claim it at his near post and misses it by a matter of metres. A shot comes in from Pizarro and Manninger saves well again.
83 So the question on everyone's lips is can Werder score five in eight minutes? I'll stick my neck out here and say... no. Barten (boo, hiss, behind you etc.) obstructs Ljundberg in front of goal and under the nose of referee Neilsen. The Danish official has seen enough incident for one evening and lets play continue.
86 No-one has told Manninger that this is now a formality. He saves well from Bode and Bremen win another corner. The delivery is good - a whipped in centre that Manninger does well to claim.
89 Ljundberg is fouled and needs treatment on his ribs. As the Swede is tended to off the field, Arsenal press forward through Parlour (who else?) who only just fails to find Overmars when the flying Dutchman would have been through on Rost.
91 Werder are still game, flooding forward. Pizarro sets himself 20 yards out but can only blaze his shot over Manninger's crossbar. The crowd appreciate his efforts, though.
93 Full time: Werder Bremen 2 - 4 Arsenal. The Gunners go through to their fifth European semi-final.

fields.headline: Weblife: beat the office
fields.standfirst: Email message frenzies have replaced phone bashing as the best way to pass time in the office - and  Paul Trueman revels in it
fields.trailText: Email message frenzies have replaced phone bashing as the best way to pass time in the office - and Paul Trueman revels in it
fields.body:
The internet has transformed the way we work. Too right. I don't think I've done a proper day's work since the dawning of the internet age. How can I? I have email. And so do all my friends :-)

The old days of knowing who the time-wasters were by hearing them on the phone all day are long gone. Email is silent, immediate, and best of all, indistinguishable from proper work. Or is it? A recent survey by ISP zoom.co.uk showed that 87% of average wired up employees avoid sending personal emails in work for fear of censure.

To what extent your company is freaking out about email abuse though, largely depends on its attitude to IT. Your average small business usually has its IT department manned solely by a large, pasty-faced Buffy fan called Nigel. It's hardly likely that Nigel, with his ongoing attempts to stage the world premiere of King Lear in Klingon, has the time for complex email surveillance.

The frightening truth, however, is that to get a copy of every email speeding in and out your office email account is the work of a few minutes for any half-decent IT administrator. Most businesses have their email set up so it goes via a central server, and it can be set up so that a copy of incoming mail will hit your bosses' inbox before it hits yours; similarly anything you send out will be copied prior to leaving the company.

There are numerous ways for the average cubicle drone like you and me to fight back and reclaim our companies' expensive IT infrastructure for own petty ends though. For example, the chances are that your boss isn't really receiving a copy of every email you send; most systems are set up to filter keywords on the subject line of the email, like "porn" or "joke", and of course, that giveaway email subject line: "Painful!". It's best, then, to avoid making your email sound remotely interesting; try using worthless corporate platitudes in the subject line like "Way to go team!", or "Congrats to the sales boys on making those Q3 targets!". They should slide right by.

You could of course, try encrypting your email. There are a few problems with this, however, the least of which is that you are probably breaking every single one of your company laws. More importantly, you might get caught doing it. You are most likely to use some form of PGP (Pretty Good Privacy) software, and an IT department can spot an encrypted email a mile away. They will either catch it before it gets encrypted, or you will be hauled into scary offices to explain why encrypted emails are leaving the company.

The simplest way to evade spying eyes is to set up a web-based email account using your office internet connection. Hotmail ) is probably the most popular, along with Yahoo , simply roll up to their sites and sign up. Emails are kept in your own inbox out on the internet, and you can access them from any internet connected PC. The disadvantage is that you are completely at the mercy of webmail servers, which can be hacked, or simply fall over from the strain.

If your company is really kicking up a fuss about the number of employees downloading Toy Story 2 trailers, then they may have licensed some monitoring equipment from companies like SurfControl. This is very bad for you. It means that your boss can see what you're seeing on the internet with just a click of his mouse, rendering the web-based approach to email a no-no.

In which case it's time to play hardball. Sign up with a free ISP on your PC at home (this is the Online section - I'm allowed to make these kind of hardware assumptions). Note down your basic email settings then replicate them in your email client at work. With the software wizards that programs like Outlook have built into them, this may sound a bit tricky, but it isn't really. All you are doing is simply importing the settings for an existing email account. You will need to know your incoming (POP3 probably) and outgoing (SMTP) mail server addresses, and your email address and password.

Alternately, access your email completely independently of the company by buying a mobile phone with an in-built digital modem, and hook it up to a handheld device like a Revo, using the an infra-red connection. Set the handheld's email client with your email settings and bob's your uncle.

You'll need a newer, expensive phone, and the connection rate of 9.6kbps isn't perfect, but who knows, your company may even pay your phone bill!

My personal favourite though, as suggested to me by an IT administrator who shall remain nameless, is to install a modem card into your PC (strictly the work of after-office hours). Then simply unplug your phone, plug in your modem and hook yourself up with a free ISP. Pure genius. You will, of course, have to suddenly develop a chesty cough whenever you dial-up, as nothing breaks busy office silence more raucously than modem-screech.

If anyone checks the phone bill, they will simply see an anonymous-looking ISP dial-up number, and since it only takes seconds to send and receive emails, nothing should look too out of place.

Don't use this as a means to surf the internet though; you will rack up an enormous phone bill that is sure to be detected. Oh dear, is that the sound of sirens approaching?

webTitle: Fitba' daft and still desperate to be taken seriously

fields.headline: Fitba' daft and still desperate to be taken seriously
fields.trailText: Scotland is deeply impressive country. In fact there is only one thing I can't take seriously in Scotland: its football.
fields.body:
Scotland, once you have recovered from feeling underdressed without a snowplough, is a deeply impressive country.

The standard of living seems higher, the education superior, the laws invariably wiser and the roads better. Prudence, like heather, sprouts everywhere. They also make matchless malts, peerless James Bonds and do a nifty line in chancellors of the exchequer.

In fact there is only one thing I can't take seriously in Scotland: its football. It has always represented a gigglefest, whether it's Jimmy Johnstone cast adrift in a boat before a big game, the hyperbole of Ally MacLeod, a goalkeeper swinging from the crossbar with his back to the pitch while a goal is scored, or a sequence of gormless results against teams from countries you couldn't find in an atlas with a strong magnifying glass.

Whereas it is possible to watch shinty, a tough, physical and skilful game, and such activities as caber tossing with real admiration, there are some of us who find it difficult to watch the football without clutching our tummies while tears of mirth drip merrily from our chins. Which is precisely why I will be watching Scotland's match against France next Wednesday.

Nationally the obsession is to beat England, which is a classic case of aiming low. Domestically the game revolves around the Old Firm battle, a four-times-a-season re-enactment of the Battle of the Boyne on the banks of the Clyde.

I say this at the risk of being slit open with a skean-dhu on my next venture north of Hadrian's Wall because in Scotland, it seems, there are a lot of people who take football very seriously indeed.

The place, in fact, is fitba' daft. I know this because I have just disinterred my nose from We'll Support You Evermore, which will be re-published next week.

It is a ribald read, a heartfelt collection of reminiscences about games, after-match celebrations and growing up in the streets of Glasgow.

This gem was first published 24 years ago after a friendly pub argument between our own Ian Archer and Trevor Royle, then the literary director of the Scottish Arts Council. Archer argued that football correspondents made the best writers on football; Royle said novelists were better. So here they are combined.

Royle said yesterday: "The book was a sell-out and was due to be reprinted in 1978. But Scotland fared so badly in the World Cup in Argentina, with bad results against Peru and Iran, that the idea was dropped."

fields.headline: Luc Besson
fields.standfirst: Besson on: His promise to make only 10 films | Working with Natalie Portman | Jacques Mayol | directing |
fields.trailText: Besson on: His promise to make only 10 films | Working with Natalie Portman | Jacques Mayol | directing |
fields.body:
[At Besson's request, the more usual format of half an hour of one-on-one interview then questions from the audience for the remaining 45 minutes was abandoned, and the interview consisted entirely of questions from the audience, with Richard Jobson managing proceedings. The transcript has been edited for clarity]

Question: A couple of years ago you were reported to have said you were only going to make ten feature films and now you're on eight. Is this true?

Luc Besson: I promise I will do two more.

Richard Jobson: Won't you change your mind?

LB: No, that's it. I mean come on, I'm tired! I'm exhausted just watching. (To audience) you are in the best place.

RJ: What are you going to do? Are you going to go back to being a diver?

LB: I'm still wet...no, no...I want to produce. I produce about three or four films a year. I love that because I work one hour per day. And I see the director at the end of the day and I just say: "Oh yes, change this, and that's good, fine..." It's great, I love that.

Q: I'm intrigued why you're only going to make 10 films only? How serious were you when you made that remark?

LB: There are a few directors that I really loved who made like five, six great movies, but are still shooting and they're not good anymore and I'm sad. I want to tell them: "Stop, please." You watch everything in nature - even us, or sports people - you grow and have a lot of things to say. And then one day you just say the same thing over and over, so I think it's just natural and elegant at a certain point to say: "I've said it already...and goodbye."

In my head, the fact that I have only two more films to make is pushing me. I say: "Oh my God, I've only got two more films so I have to say something that I really mean and I have to put it all in the last two films." The last two will be very good, I hope.

Q: But why 10?

LB: Because 10 is good, you know, the 10 commandments, it's good in a library - 10 DVDs...and Snow-white and the 10 Dwarfs.

Q: Can actors and actresses actually help with the writing? I remember reading the original notes for Leon and there was a lot of conflict with Natalie Portman's parents wanting things changed. Is it collaborative or do you just go in and change what you want?

RJ: So is it collaborative experience, or is Luc a fascist?

LB: I think that I am a collaborative fascist. With Natalie it was different, she was only 11-years-old and Leon was her first film. And it's about a young girl who takes guns and shoots everywhere, so her parents were very scared, they didn't know me very well. So I think that's why they were on my back for a few weeks.

Later, the relationship was good and they trusted me so it was fine. The funny thing was Natalie. Obviously at 11 she didn't smoke, she was against it. She was already responsible. She said: "I don't want to show kids that I am smoking."

So I said: OK, what about showing them that you quit?" She said: "OK." And I said: "But to show that you quit, you have to show that you were smoking." So we made this deal were we showed her smoking at the beginning and then she quit for Leon.

RJ: I remember interviewing you at the time of the film and you got really pissed off with me because I kept on at you about subject of the relationship between the Jean Reno character and Natalie's character and you said to me: "Well it's your interpretation that there's something sexual there, it's not in the film." Do you still stand by that?

LB: Yes.

RJ: And is that why you felt you needed to change the film with the director's cut?

LB: No, I'm not responsible for what people think. The story is about two kids, a girl and a boy. They're both 12 years old, in their minds, and they're both lost and they love each other. And the rest is just your problem.The most important line for me in Léon is the one we've just seen where her conscience says to her "you didn't see what it was, you saw what you wanted to see".

That's always the dilemma. Either you believe her or you don't. Maybe she has seen something but nobody else has seen it? You can ask yourself questions all night like: "If God wants to stop the war why doesn't he just show up in the middle of the battlefield? " That would be perfect. He's just shown up, he's saying: "I'm here, don't fight." I think that no one would fight, everyone would be down on their knees saying "oh my God".

RJ: And the idea that small people can change things. Small people can become big people?

LB: It's always the small people who change things. It's never the politicians or the big guys. I mean, who pulled down the Berlin wall? It was all the people in the streets. The specialists didn't have a clue the day before. If you read the newspaper a few days before...nothing...no one was talking about it. And even the French revolution, we just said "That's enough", and took the king.

The famous line about the French king was that he didn't even know what was going on. He said: "Is it a revolt?" And the other guy said: "No, it's a revolution." The king was thinking it was nothing.

RJ: Something we've never had here.

Q: What do you think of directors repeating themselves, and why did you feel the need to do a director's cut?

LB: Let me remember why...I was happy with the first one, it was mine, my director's cut, no one asked me to cut it. But at the same time you still have 25 minutes that nobody has seen. I think it was the beginning of the summer; in the summer France is like a desert, the people are on the beach, but there are some poor guys who stay in the cities to work, so we decided to make a long version, an extended version, to play in a just a few theatres for the people who stayed. Why are you laughing? It's true!

RJ: It's totally ridiculous.

LB: No, it's true. So we had like five screens and people loved it and sent their friends and then the Japanese called and said: "We want the long version, please."

Q: Have you ever met the real Jacques Mayol? He's in London this weekend.

LB: He's in London? Yes, of course I've met him. That's the first thing I did when I wanted to make the Big Blue, I contacted him and met him in Marseille. And I said: "I'd love to make a film about you."

Q: Is he quite a different person in real life from how he is portrayed in the film?

LB: I've not seen him for a few years but a big part was really inspired by him.

Q: He's at the London International Dive Show at Olympia this weekend.

RJ: (to audience member) What did you like about the Big Blue?

Q: It was very inspiring. Inspiring character. Visually, totally incredible. Amazing person, the whole sort of man association with the sea and whether that can really be embodied in a person or not. I don't know how much of a fantasy it is or whether somebody can really be like that.

RJ: He's good Luc. Why don't you go and sit there and get him up here?

Q: Why did you decide you wanted to be a film director?

LB: Originally I wanted to be a diver and take care of dolphins, but then I had an accident and couldn't dive anymore. I was 17 and I wondered what I was going to do. You know sometimes you're in a position of risk and you feel that you can turn good or bad, or you can do all kinds of stupid things? You're 17. So I tried to concentrate on what I could do.

So I took a piece of paper and on the left I put everything I could do, or had skills for, and all the things I couldn't do. The first line was shorter and I could see that I loved writing, I loved images, I was taking a lot of pictures. So I thought maybe movies would be good. But I thought that to really know I should go to a set. And a friend of mine knew a guy whose brother was a third assistant on a short film. It's true.

So, I said: "OK, let's go on the set." So I went on the set and the first thing that I remember is that there was this big truck outside and then I saw the cables which were like, umbilical, and you found the set by following the cables and it was like..."wow". And then you arrived in a room and it was full of light and I fell in love. I was living 60km from Paris in a small city. The day after I went back to see my mum and told her that I was going to make films and stop school and 'bye. And I did it! Very soon after I made a short film and it was very, very bad. I wanted to prove that I could do something, so I made a short film. That was in fact my main concern, to be able to show that I could do one.

A very good friend of mine watched the film and said: "Luc, there is one thing you have to learn and that is when you have nothing to say - shut up!" So I decided not to make films any more and to be an assistant. So I started as a third and then a second and then a first. The funny thing is the farther I went, the longer I thought it would take to become a director. Because the more you know, the more you see. After two years I was thinking: "It's going to take me ten years to be a director." The confidence? It came two years ago.

Q: Why did you chose to do the story of Joan of Arc?

RJ: I guess if you look at your career, it's been urban thrillers, nature films, sci-fi pictures, suddenly there you are doing a huge historical drama, an epic. Why did you choose to go into that area?

LB: I'm always guided by the characters. The character. Joan of Arc's story, it's insane. So that's maybe the relationship between the characters that we were talking about. I'm always attracted by people who are lost in their time. I think it helps us. We see this is her life and it should not be like this. I learn something from that all the time.

Q: Is there a consistency in female characterisation of the female characters in your films? From Nikita all the way through to Joan of Arc.

LB: I'm more attracted by a female character because I think that now for 30 or 40 years the image of the male actor has been as a strong man, and is most of the time about force and strength. And I'm attracted by the weakness, how they (women) can fight when they don't have that. And the ways they have to find to be able to fight for something or say something - it's richer. It's much more interesting.

RJ: Your male characters have been a lot softer too, haven't they? They haven't been typically macho, French characters.

LB: The problem I think is that I like the feminine part of the male character and the male part of the female character.

RJ: So film number nine might be a transsexual awakening?

LB: From space.

webTitle: No new Villa deal for Carbone

fields.headline: No new Villa deal for Carbone
fields.trailText: Aston Villa have failed to reach agreement with striker Benito Carbone over a new long-term contract before today's transfer deadline.
fields.body:
Aston Villa have failed to reach agreement with striker Benito Carbone over a new long-term contract before today's transfer deadline.

Villa had been hoping they could tie up the services of Carbone, whose current short-term arrangement ends in June, for another three years.

But they will now have to wait until the summer to try and conclude any deal for the Italian.

It means they run the risk of the former Sheffield Wednesday player signing a pre-contract agreement with another European club.

Villa were unable to satisfy Carbone's personal demands which are reported to be close to £40,000 a week.

fields.headline: Summerhill survives after Ofsted mauling
fields.trailText: The threat of closure hanging over Summerhill school was raised today when agreement was reached between the libertarian Suffolk establishment and the Department of Education.
fields.body:
The threat of closure hanging over Summerhill school was raised today when agreement was reached between the libertarian Suffolk establishment and the Department of Education.

Pupils from the school, which encourages them to develop in the free-thinking philosophy of its founder AS Neill, took over court 40 at the royal courts of justice to discuss the deal. Amid extraordinary scenes, the agreement was unanimously approved.

The agreement brought to an end Summerhill's three-day appeal at an independent schools tribunal against a notice of complaint issued by the education secretary, David Blunkett last summer. A highly critical Ofsted report had said pupils were allowed to "mistake idleness for the exercise of personal liberty". If the notice had been upheld, the school would have closed.

Carman Cordwell, who chaired the pupil meeting, hailed the statement agreed between the school and education officials. "This is our charter for freedom," she said. "It gives us the space we need to live and breathe and learn into the future. After 79 years, this is the first official recognition that AS Neill's philosophy of education provides an acceptable alternative to compulsory lessons and the tyranny of compulsory exams. With this one bound, we are free at last."

During the hearing, the school's QC, Geoffrey Robertson said that it was a fundamental feature of Summerhill that there must be no coercion of pupils, who would learn and learn well when they chose. "If you destroy that, you destroy Summerhill and tear up the legacy of our most renowned educator," he said. Closing the school would be an act of "educational vandalism".

The Department for Education and Employment said its notice of complaint had been withdrawn after Summerhill agreed to changes in education and improved accommodation. Mr Robertson described the agreement as a "historic document".

The school's proprietor Zoe Readhead, Neill's daughter, said in the agreed statement that the school should continue to provide a stimulating environment both within and outwith timetabled lessons. The education department accepted that Ofsted inspections would take account of the school's philosophy.

There were unique scenes in court as government lawyers, the tribunal panel, press and public left the courtroom to allow Summerhillians, past and present, to discuss whether to hold their discussion in public.

After a vote supervised by Miss Cordwell and two male pupils, who sat in the tribunal's chairs, the courtroom doors were opened and Mr Robertson read out the agreed statement. There was a burst of spontaneous applause at its conclusion which was rapidly hushed by Miss Cordwell before the floor was thrown open to questions from Summerhillians. When the pupils voted on whether to accept the statement, every hand was raised in favour. On a wave of euphoria, pupils and staff hugged and wept before spilling out onto the Strand to open bottles of champagne.

Outside court, Mrs Readhead hugged pupils and staff and said: "This is the most wonderful triumph for us; my father always had faith in the law, and he would be delighted at how it has brought him victory and vindication over a bureaucracy which could never cope with his ideas."

She added: "We have lived for a year under the Ofsted falsehood that we have mistaken idleness for liberty. Today's verdict refutes that defamation and shows that liberty and learning go hand in hand at Summerhill. We can now put all the pettiness and incomprehension to which we have been subjected behind us, and look forward to a sensible and productive relationship with Ofsted and the Department of Education."

webTitle: M&S has bags of ideas but too few facts

fields.headline: M&S has bags of ideas but too few facts
fields.standfirst:
Sales figures are the real test

www.marks-and-spencer.co.uk
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer's Baker Street bunker is pumping out details of its thrusting new strategy like a machine gun. Take just the past two days. While the rest of the UK was focused on the Budget, 1,400 M&S staff received top-level briefings about the company's new "customer business units" (inspirationally set up to ensure the company sells what its customers want) and invited to apply for new jobs in them. The company hopes staff and jobs will fit neatly and there will be no compulsory redundancies.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer's Baker Street bunker is pumping out details of its thrusting new strategy like a machine gun. Take just the past two days. While the rest of the UK was focused on the Budget, 1,400 M&S staff received top-level briefings about the company's new "customer business units" (inspirationally set up to ensure the company sells what its customers want) and invited to apply for new jobs in them. The company hopes staff and jobs will fit neatly and there will be no compulsory redundancies.

Yesterday there was more. The marketing director's hunt for a new advertising agency is down to a shortlist of four. Two shopping centre investments, in Edinburgh and Newcastle, have been sold, bringing in a handy £220m.

And - the big ones - trendy new carrier bags and the death of St Michael as a brand to be proud of. The patron saint of pants has been relegated to a mere quality pledge on the packaging.

The new range of bags, insists marketing director Alan McWalter, is not the answer to the chain's problems. But when a brand has become as naff as M&S has to some shoppers, it is not a bag one wants to be seen carrying. The new cool green and transparent numbers - including eco-friendly paper sacks and Gap-style duffel bags - should help.

But there are one or two pieces of news that M&S is not yet trumpeting. It seems almost picky to mention it when the management is so busy addressing the multiple issues and problems, but what we need to hear about is sales.

Are the new spring ranges pulling in more shoppers? Is the new Autograph designer range winning back the high-spending posh shoppers? And how is the new-look boardroom working out? Will chief executive Peter Salsbury survive now that Mr Vandevelde is working full time in the chairman's suite?

This is the news needed before it will be possible to decide whether M&S is back in the big time.

A shoe out

In the finger-in-the-wind world of internet share price valuations, there are certain touchstones for investors trying to evaluate risk - such as the quality of a company's financial advisers.

The bulge bracket firms of Wall Street, such as Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, have reputations to protect. They do not want to put their own investment clients into dud stocks and when they float companies the presence of a name such as Morgan Stanley on the prospectus acts as a quality seal.

To protect the reputation of the bank and the floating company further, technical tricks are increasingly used to make sure that, when share trading begins, the price goes up. The most common is known as a "green shoe". It is officially referred to as stabilisation, but is in effect share price support, allowing an investment bank to sweep up any shares being sold by speculators in a new issue.

Companies pay handsomely for all this. In the case of Lastminute.com, the online retailer which joined the market just last week, the bill for using Morgan Stanley's services amounted to almost £9m.

But the company does not appear to be getting value for money. After the first day of hectic trading, which saw the price soar to 555p, the shares crashed below the 380p issue price on Budget day and then crashed again yesterday, ending at a miserable 287p.

Punters and pundits the length of the country are now laughing at the company. The flotation was botched. Lastminute's relationship with its shareholders is badly damaged and it is a fair bet that the company's commercial reputation has been hurt.

Morgan Stanley's reaction to all this has been uniform: it has said nothing whatsoever, publicly or privately.

Before the onset of radio silence, this investment bank used to swagger round the world, brandishing statistics on how 31 of its 32 internet initial public offerings were all sitting comfortably above the flotation price. Now it is 31 out of 33 and in the world of investment banking, like so many things, corporate financiers are really only as good as their last deal.

Strangely, the green shoe price support mechanism, which should have allowed Morgan Stanley to buy up to 15% of the entire issue, has either been blown away or simply not used.

More importantly, Morgan Stanley has Mary Meeker, reputed to be the world's number one internet analyst, sitting in New York. She and her colleagues in London thought Lastminute was a fine investment at 380p, but they seem to be having trouble stating that it is even finer value sitting at a 25% discount to the offer price.

So perhaps we should do if for them. Sure, some of the overall market's techno-froth is being blown away, but Lastminute has a great business model and a talented management team. Among consumer internet businesses it looks like a bargain.

webTitle: Marks unveils new look in effort to revive sales

fields.headline: Marks unveils new look in effort to revive sales
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer yesterday unveiled the new look it hopes will shake off its dowdy image and help it to start rebuilding its reputation as Britain's premier retailer.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer yesterday unveiled the new look it hopes will shake off its dowdy image and help it to start rebuilding its reputation as Britain's premier retailer.

The overhaul includes scrapping the famous St Michael label - it will now only appear as a seal of quality - and revamping the exterior of all 297 M&S stores.

The trademark green and gold carrier bags the store has used for nearly 20 years are to be axed in favour of a range of trendy green and clear plastic versions and the store's traditional window displays - of cardboard photos and rows of mannequins - will also be updated and made more creative.

The brand overhaul has been masterminded by consultants Interbrand Newell & Sorrell, the company which devised the ethnic tailfins which proved such an embarrassment for British Airways. They have been working at the ailing M&S group for over a year.

New marketing director Alan McWalter described the image as "a refreshed, updated look which will give a strong, coherent and consistent identity to the great brand of Marks & Spencer".

The decision to drop the St Michael label is a major break with the past. The brand was invented in 1928 when Simon Marks, the son of co-founder Michael Marks, suggested the label as a tribute to his father.

St Michael rapidly became known as the "patron saint of women's underwear" and the label is synonymous with Marks & Spencer. But from now on it will appear only on a quality pledge to be known as the "St Michael promise" which will appear on clothing and food lines.

Other changes planned which will start to appear in the summer include an updated staff uniform and uncluttered shop floors with helpdesks and better designed store plans.

Three test stores are being given a new look, both inside and out, and the group will study the impact the changes make before deciding which version to roll out nationwide.

The radical rethink has been forced on the chain by plunging sales and profits as once loyal customers have deserted in their droves. Investors liked the look of the proposed changes and the shares closed up 16.75p at 265p last night.

In the past three months alone the store chain has installed a new chairman, Luc Vandevelde, as well as Mr McWalter as marketing director. Yesterday the marketing chief said M&S had only just woken up to the fact that it was managing a brand, and not just "a series of stores".

He is in the process of recruiting a new advertising agency expected to mount a huge TV campaign to win back shoppers. Earlier this week some 1,400 mainly head office staff were invited to apply for jobs in seven new customer business units. The company has refused to rule out redundancies for staff who cannot be accommodated .

Mr McWalter conceded, however, that "we won't change M&S just by changing the bags".

fields.headline: The quiet equaliser
fields.standfirst:
Leading tax experts read between the
           lines and find subtle moves towards wealth redistribution
fields.trailText:
Britain's leading team of independent tax experts yesterday added weight to Gordon Brown's reputation
           as a believer in quiet wealth redistribution when it said that the poorest people in Britain were the biggest
           winners from Tuesday's Budget .
fields.body:
Britain's leading team of independent tax experts yesterday added weight to Gordon Brown's reputation as a believer in quiet wealth redistribution when it said that the poorest people in Britain were the biggest winners from Tuesday's Budget .

The Institute for Fiscal Studies said that the new tax and benefit alterations announced in the Budget reinforced the impact of the three previous packages by targeting most of the government's help on those on low incomes while top earners had been left relatively unscathed.

Although Gordon Brown said in his Budget speech that Labour's actions had helped to take 1.2m children out of poverty, the chancellor was reluctant to concede yesterday that he had embarked on a redistribution of wealth and rejected claims that his Budget was a return to the old Labour values of 20 years ago.

`We are New Labour and we are pursuing New Labour policies, as everybody knows,' he told BBC Radio 2's Jimmy Young programme.

However, the detailed breakdown of the Budget by the IFS showed that there has been no evidence of the Blair government's pandering to the rich, with the top 40% of earners left untouched by changes.

The impact of higher stamp duty to be imposed on the purchase of luxury homes was not taken into account by the IFS in its analysis, but with the levy on a pounds 500,000 house sale due to rise by pounds 2,500 to pounds 20,000, those planning to put their properties on the market will feel the pinch.

According to the IFS figures, the most important changes in the Budget were the increased support for children, worth pounds 4.35 for each child under 16 the increased generosity of the yet to be introduced children's tax credit help for people making the transition from welfare to work - including a pounds 100 jobs grant and an extension of the New Deal options to all adults support for pensioners via a 50% increase in the winter fuel allowance and the decision to increase the rate only on cigarette duties by more than the rate of inflation.

The overall impact of these measures meant that the poorest tenth of the population saw their weekly income rise by 3% - worth around pounds 3 per week.

The next poorest decile was the second most favoured group, seeing a gain of some 2.5% a week. The IFS said this was worth slightly more than the increase to the poorest group in cash terms.

By family type, the IFS said that the biggest beneficiaries of the Budget had been a non-earning couple with no children, who would see their weekly income rise by around 4% as a result of the changes.

Single parents were the next most generously treated group, with a single earner couple with children and both single pensioners and pensioner couples modest gainers.

While the cut in the top rate of income tax from 83% to 40% and the reduction in the basic rate of income tax from 33% to 23% meant that high earners gained most from Conservative tax policies, the IFS said that the cumulative effect of the four Labour budgets since 1997 had been to help the poorest groups.

The two deciles at the bottom of the income scale have seen by far the biggest increases in their weekly incomes with rises of more than 8%. The next two poorest groups have seen smaller increases, while the fifth, sixth and seventh income deciles have enjoyed only negligible increases as a result of Budget changes. The richest decile has seen its weekly income reduced slightly as a result of fiscal measures which have in cluded the abolition of mortgage interest relief and the married couples' allowance - as well as the introduction of new means-tested tax credits aimed at the working poor and their families.

By family type, non-earning families with children have seen their weekly incomes rise by 10% while single parents have had an increase of 6%-plus. Single pensioners and single earning couples with children are the next most favoured groups, gaining around 4-5% a week.

Further down the pipeline, the IFS said that there were more redistributive measures to come. These included the possible tax credit for pensioners, which is just about to go out to consultation, the integrated child credit - which replaces the child element in income support, the working families tax credit, child tax credit and the disabled persons tax credit from 2003.

On top of all that, the chancellor is planning a new employment tax credit which is designed to extend the principle of giving in-work support to families with children to all low-paid workers.

Mr Brown admitted the government was redistributing wealth through the Budget , saying: `We're redistributing to entrepreneurs by the capital gains tax cut ... We're putting money into entrepreneurs, we're putting money into tackling child poverty.

`We're giving a balance that is right, so that there is fairness and enterprise in our society,' Mr Brown said.

Challenged on his acknowledgment of wealth redistribution - which he seldom mentions - Mr Brown stressed that nobody was being harmed by the government's policies. `There is nobody suffering from what we are doing because we have managed to make great advances on unemployment,' he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

fields.body:
Darren Anderton agreed a one-year extension to his contract today and put an end, for now, to speculation over his future at Tottenham Hotspur.

Anderton's previous contract at White Hart Lane was to have run out this summer, and there were fears that the 28-year-old England international would leave the club under the Bosman ruling.

Spurs' director of football David Pleat announced the deal this afternoon and hoped it would allow Anderton to concentrate on his football once more. "We are now looking to him to put in a closing run until the end of the season and regain his England place," he said.

"Darren knows that to achieve those ends he must play regularly and play well. He is in a very positive mood about the future."

Anderton joined Tottenham from Portsmouth eight years ago but, thanks to a series of serious injuries, has made less than 250 appearances for the club. Both George Graham and Spurs chairman Alan Sugar will be hoping they get to see the best of Anderton over the next 12 months.

webTitle: Nasa chief admits agency cut too many workers

fields.headline: Nasa chief admits agency cut too many workers
fields.trailText: Nasa, trying to do more missions with less money and fewer people, made management mistakes that contributed to a string of recent failures in space, the chief of the agency said.
fields.body:
Nasa, trying to do more missions with less money and fewer people, made management mistakes that contributed to a string of recent failures in space, the chief of the agency said.

"We probably cut too tight" in reducing the Nasa work force from 25,000 to 18,500 over the last seven years, Daniel S. Goldin, Nasa's administrator, told the US Senate Commerce subcommittee on space Wednesday. "We found we were really too thin."

Goldin said the agency lost many veteran engineers over those years, and there was inadequate training and mentoring for young, inexperienced workers who were hired.

Additionally, he said, there was a failure in communication between engineers and technicians doing the work and the management personnel overseeing it.

"There was no good communication feedback," Goldin said. "People were talking and we weren't hearing them."

Sen. Bill Frist, chairman of the subcommittee, said he called the hearing to get an explanation for what he called a "very difficult" year for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

During 1999, two Nasa probes to Mars were lost without a trace; shuttle missions were delayed because of damaged or troublesome equipment; workers accidentally threw away tanks built for the International Space Station, and an urgent mission to repair the Hubble Space Telescope was required.

"For $14 billion a year, the American taxpayers deserve better," said Frist.

Sen. John McCain said that in reports examining the 1999 problems of Nasa "the extent of mismanagement... is very startling. Over the past year, I have continually been amazed by the reports coming out of Nasa about mission failures and program delays."

In his response, Goldin said that since 1992 Nasa has launched 146 payloads valued at $18 billion and experienced only 10 failures, worth about $500 million.

He acknowledged that Nasa had "some severe disappointments and problems" in 1999, but added: "We are paying close attention to these failures, examining them, searching for root causes, and recommending changes."

One reason for the problems, said Goldin, is a change in the culture at Nasa. Whereas once the agency mounted only a few missions at great expense, it is now emphasizing a "faster, better, cheaper" philosophy that calls for more, but smaller and less costly missions.

In earlier years, Nasa launched two planetary probes a decade, each costing billions of dollars, he said. Now the agency is sending missions to other planets each year at a fraction of the cost.

But the new management philosophy does have flaws, including stressed, overworked employees who lack the experience or the time to do jobs properly, said Goldin.

"Somehow, it is not working," said Frist.

"I agree," said Goldin.

The administrator said Nasa is in the process of hiring 2,000 new workers, establishing a formal training program for young engineers, and conducting a top-to-bottom evaluation of the space agency systems.

Goldin was repeatedly asked about a published report that Nasa engineers knew of a rocket engine flaw in a Mars-bound probe. The report said that Nasa conducted flawed tests on ground models of the rocket engines, and then tried to cover up information about the problems. The Mars probe disappeared after firing its braking rockets while approaching the Red Planet.

"There are very, very great irregularities in that press report," said Goldin. He said the rocket problems were identified and discussed publicly a month before the mission failure. He said that engineers conducted honest tests, and that they believed the problem was solved.

The subcommittee also asked Goldin about a press story that a report critical of the agency was being withheld until it could be evaluated by the White House.

Goldin denied this, saying that the report will be released next week. He said the report has not been changed by Nasa and that the White House is not involved.

webTitle: Pope remembers Holocaust but offers no apology

fields.headline: Pope remembers Holocaust but offers no apology
fields.standfirst: Full text: the Pope's speech at Yad Vashem
fields.trailText: The Pope today paid homage to the six million Jews who died in the Holocaust but stopped short of an apology for what has been seen as the Vatican's complicity over the killing.
fields.body:
The Pope today paid homage to the six million Jews who died in the Holocaust but stopped short of an apology for what has been seen as the Vatican's complicity over the killing.

He said the Catholic church was "deeply saddened" by Christian persecution of Jews throughout history, and called for a new relationship between the two faiths based on their common roots. But the Pope did not assign any blame to the church hierarchy or mention Pope Pius XII, accused by many Jews of staying silent while their brethren were killed.

In a ceremony at the dark, candlelit Hall of Remembrance at the Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial the pontiff laid a wreath in memory of the six million Jews who perished in the Nazi genocide - among them childhood friends from the small Polish town of Wadowice where the young Karol Wojtyla grew up.

John Paul himself witnessed the persecution of Jews as a young seminary student and said time had not erased the terrible memories. "I remember my Jewish friends and neighbors, some of whom perished, while others survived. I have come to Yad Vashem to pay homage to the millions of Jewish people who, stripped of everything, especially of their human dignity, were murdered in the Holocaust," he said.

"We wish to remember. But we wish to remember for a purpose, namely to ensure that never again will evil prevail, as it did for the millions of innocent victims of Nazism," he said.

The visit capped a morning of remarkable gestures to Israel and the Jewish people. In a meeting with President Ezer Weizman, the pontiff blessed Israel, an act seen by many Israelis as final church recognition of their state.

For centuries, the Catholic Church taught that the Jews' exile was punishment for the death of Jesus. Pope Paul VI, the last pontiff to visit the Holy Land in 1964, refused to say the word "Israel" and would not address the Israeli president at the time, Zalman Shazar, by his title.

Addressing the role of the church through the centuries, he said: "As Bishop of Rome and successor of the Apostle Peter, I assure the Jewish people that the Catholic church, motivated by the Gospel law of truth and love, and by no political considerations, is deeply saddened by the hatred, acts of persecution and displays of anti-Semitism directed against the Jews by Christians at any time and in any place."

Rabbi David Rosen, who has strong ties to the Vatican, praised the pontiff's words as a "powerful demonstration of ... solidarity with the victims of the Shoah" (Holocaust). At one point in the somber ceremony at Yad Vashem a letter was read from a Polish Jew to her gentile friend who she asked to look after her 7-year-old son in hopes of protecting him from the Nazis. The pope stood with his head bowed. He then walked across the stone floor, taking small steps and leaning on his cane, to greet Polish Holocaust survivors, including a longtime friend from Wadowice, Jerzy Kluger. In his speech, the pontiff said that words were not strong enough to depore "the terrible tragedy of the Shoah." Addressing continuous attempts since second world war to deny the Holocaust, the pontiff said that "no one can diminish its scale."

The pope stressed the common roots of Judaism and Christian, a recurring theme in his ministry. "Let us build a new future in which there will be no more anti-Jewish feeling among Christians or anti-Christian feeling among Jews, but rather the mutual espect required of those who adore the one Creator and Lord, and look to Abraham as our common father in faith," he said.

The speech marked the climax of John Paul's efforts to reconcile Christians and Jews. He was the first pope to visit the Nazi death camp of Auschwitz and attend services at a Rome synagogue.

In 1998, the Vatican issued a document on the Holocaust, and two weeks ago, the pontiff apologized for the sins of Christians throughout history, including against Jews, though he did not mention the Holocaust specifically.
