fields.headline: Drama, Scandal and Slander
fields.trailText: DEADLINE DAY DRAMA
fields.body:
DEADLINE DAY DRAMA

Carl Cort joins Leeds for £5m. Arsenal swoop for West Ham's Trevor Sinclair in a £6m deal. Bradford boost their fight against relegation by signing Fabrizio Ravanelli on loan until the end of the season. If transfer deadline day had any self-respect those would be the kind of stories the Fiver would be bringing you this afternoon. Sadly, that is not the case, and the Fiver must instead try to get excited about Spencer Prior's move to Man City. Even though it happened yesterday.

"This is a Premiership setup and I am glad to be part of it," said Prior on joining First Division Ci... oh, forget it. Let's try this angle instead: Portsmouth made transfer deadline day's biggest splash when they signed Sheffield United midfielder Shaun Derry for an astonishing £700,000. Nah. Or how about this? Barry Horne faces a race against time to complete a free transfer move from Huddersfield to Sheffield Wednesday before this evening's 5pm cut-off. Thought not.

Transfer deadline day: (very) brief highlights

Tony Vaughan - Manchester City to Nottingham Forest (£350,000); Matty Lawrence - Wycombe to Millwall (£250,000); Raymond de Waard - SC Cambuur to Norwich City (£225,000); Neil Redfearn - Bradford to Wigan (£112,500); Bob Taylor - Bolton to WBA (£100,000); Kurt Nogan - Preston to Cardiff (£100,000); Paul Hughes - Chelsea to Southampton (Free); Arturo Bernhard - Nuvo Hamburgo to Middlesbrough (undisclosed fee); Stuart Campbell - Leicester to Birmingham (loan); Martijn Reuser - Ajax to Ipswich (loan).

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

POLITICS CAN BE FUN. COME SEE!

Economist.com - Forthright opinion and lively analysis of global politics and business, plus handy summaries of the week's news. www.economist.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

AN OLD FLETCH

Freddie Fletcher this morning stepped down as chief executive of Newcastle United plc. Fletch, as he's known to Chevy Chase fans all over the North East, is moving on after eight years at the club. He leaves behind him an impressive list of achievements: a team of Premiership quality, a string of top-name managers, a spanking new stadium, and sizeable investment which has secured the club's future. Pity no-one will remember him for it.

Fletcher is widely blamed for the recent Save Our Seats scandal which saw Toon fans booted out of seats they believed they had secured for 10 years to make way for more corporate hospitality. He emerged victorious from the subsequent legal battle - he was carried out of court by jubilant freeloading executives and had a new kind of mushroom vol-au-vent named after him. He will be replaced by David Stonehouse who, as Sunderland's Finance Director, helped establish the Wearside club's rather more enlightened ticketing policy.

Not that Fletcher was repentant this morning. The 59-year-old Scot told tAlKSporT: "I think we handled it badly and we've said that publicly, but I think the decision was right. When [the new St James' Park] opens in August, £75m will have been spent on it in the last eight years. That's not because the board despise the fans." No, but neither does it prove that they love them. "What I want to do," Fletch went on, "is to urge the fans to heal any breach there's been and get behind everybody." And that includes Silvio Maric.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I feel disgusted when a homosexual shares the same shower and stares at one's bum with desire, and even gets emotional when you are naked. Disgusting." - Totally heterosexual Argentinian international Eduardo Berizzo summons up the atmosphere that forced him to leave Olympique Marseille.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SCOTLAND'S BOOZE AND FAGS SHAME

Scottish football players? They're rubbish. All they do is jink about aimlessly while smoking filterless fags, munching on fried stomach-lining-and-Snickers sandwiches and drinking as many 'nippy sweeties' as they can before they fall over sick on the touchline. No wonder they can't control the ball. That's not the opinion of the Fiver, by the way - that's what French football agents have been saying in a magazine which has just been published across the Channel.

"In Scotland... well, you know what the Scots are like. They booze, they smoke and they eat anything that comes to hand," schmoozed charming Jean-Luc Witzel. His offensive offensive was kept up by envoy extraordinaire Pape Diouf. "Markets such as Scotland are interesting for players who are not highly rated," he chuckled. "A great advantage for them is that directors are completely ignorant about what is happening elsewhere. As far as they are concerned there is no difference between Robert Pires and Mr Nobody from Chateauroux."

It's a diplomatic tour de force sure to earn the French national team a warm reception when they step out at Hampden to play Scotland next week. Luckily, the Scots are a calm race, and have declined to get into a war of words. "They are entitled to say what they want and it doesn't bother me," began ex-Rangers striker Gordon Smith very reasonably. "The comments about food and drink are just an old-fashioned idea," he continued, getting a little bit hot under the collar despite himself. "It's easy for them to say these things but we could say the same about Czech football," threatened a fully-riled Smith, lashing out indiscriminately at innocent bystanders.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Manchester United are lining up a big-money bid for Internazionale's Alvaro Recoba. The Uruguayan international has scored eight goals in nine Serie A starts this season.

Bryne defender Ragnvald Soma is a £600,000 target for Middlesbrough. Bryan Robson may also move for Torquay United defender Wayne Thomas.

Liverpool are ready to pay £3m for Tranmere's 18-year-old goalkeeper Joe Murphy.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Darren Anderton has signed a one-year extension to his contract at Spurs.

Aston Villa midfielder Ian Taylor has signed a new three-year contract at Villa Park

Coventry have offered defender David Burrows a new two-year contract.

Bolton defender Dean Holden will miss the rest of the season after breaking his leg in Tuesday's 2-0 win over Sheffield United.

France have recalled Arsenal striker Thierry Henry for next week's friendly international with Scotland at Hampden. There is no place in the squad for lonely Nic Anelka, Stephane Guivarc'h or David Trezeguet. The squad: Barthez (Monaco), Rame (Bordeaux), Blanc (Inter Milan), Desailly (Chelsea), Leboeuf (Chelsea), Lizarazu (Bayern Munich), Thuram (Parma), Candela (Roma), Deschamps (Chelsea), Vieira (Arsenal), Zidane (Juventus), Pires (Marseille), Petit (Arsenal), Wiltord (Bordeaux), Djorkaeff (Kaiserslautern), Dugarry (Bordeaux), Giuly (Monaco), Henry (Arsenal).

German international Jens Jeremies has agreed to stay with Bayern Munich until 2003.

Scotland's women's national squad are to receive £66,000 of Lottery funding. The 22 players will get £3,000 each, allowing them, through the Talented Athlete Programme, to develop their skills and compete in tournaments such as the acclaimed Albena Cup and Pacific Cup in Australia.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (2.35am)

You mean to say you get this confused with Sky's World Football Show? Idiot.

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.35am)

You mean to say you get this confused with Chelsea's of Chelsea? Idiot.

Channel 5: Uefa Cup Football - Live (6.30pm)

Jonathan Pearce shouts and shouts and shouts and shouts and shouts and shouts as Leeds take on Slavia Prague.

Dutch Football (1.05am)

He's stopped shouting. You can go to sleep now.

Argentinian Football (2.45am)

Velez Sarsfield play Matt Lorenzo. We think.

1999 US Major League Soccer Cup Final (4.25am)

Football from America and not a Lionel Bienvenu in sight.

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm)

Sepp Blatter the Bear's my name, never call me Jack or James, I will sing my way to fame, Sepp Blatter the Bear's my name.

Spanish Football (8pm, 12.45am)

Listen to presenter David Bobin struggle to pronounce words like 'Compostela', 'Valladolid', 'Gijon' and 'Gerry Armstrong'.

***'** ** *** ******! (10.15pm, 2.45am)

"Dave, knight to F6. Checkmate. Got you, you swine. Shaun Brown." Contact the Message Board - the McCaff that listens - at the.boss@theguardian.com.

Sky Sports 3: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 11.30pm SS1)

Richard Dryden on how the killing of Candy's old dog foreshadowed Lennie's death in Steinbeck's Of Mice and Men.

World Cup Classics (10pm)

A refreshing change in the 1974 World Cup as Capitalism is beaten 1-0 by Communism.

Sky Super Sporty Sport Sports: Werder Bremen v Arsenal - Live! (7.30pm)

Live Uefa Cup action on a digital channel only four people are subscribed to. But don't worry - we've been told that it's on German channel ARD, so simply tune your dish into frequency 1486 Horizontal and see it for nowt.

British Eurosport: Uefa Cup Football (7pm)

Giving two consecutive programmes the same title...

Uefa Cup Football (9pm)

... is not very helpful you know.

Football (11pm)

There! That's much clearer.

Sky One: Dream Team (6.30pm, 11pm)

Mac wins ten pounds off Wack. Robbo buys some gear off Bobbo. Dazza and Bazza fall out over Spazza.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (6.55pm)

The view from the commentary box is so poor that an incensed Alan Green has taken to speaking in tongues. "Dfguyb sodirtb sdriuyts fgyhu opuwrdv siodf! Hallelujah!"

fields.headline: EC hampers Microsoft's cable ambitions
fields.standfirst:
The European Commission: special report
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft's ambitions in the UK cable television industry were dealt a blow yesterday when the European Commission announced a further investigation into the software group's bid for a large stake in Telewest Communications.
fields.body:
Microsoft's ambitions in the UK cable television industry were dealt a blow yesterday when the European Commission announced a further investigation into the software group's bid for a large stake in Telewest Communications.

Mario Monti, the EU competition commissioner, referred to fears that Microsoft would use its 29.7% stake in the UK's second-largest cable television operator to increase sales of its own set-top box operating system.

"We will make a detailed assessment of the impact of the transaction on competition conditions in various areas of the digital cable industry... in particular the provision of software for digital set-top boxes in the UK and its impact for the choice of British cable subscribers," he said.

Microsoft had offered to make several concessions, including safeguarding Telewest's ability to choose other set-top box operating systems and allowing other content providers and software developers to make products compatible with its system.

These were rejected by the commission as inadequate. Microsoft, already under fire from an anti-trust action in the US, would take joint control of Telewest as part of last year's $5bn investment in AT&T, the US telecoms group.

Microsoft said it would "continue to work very hard with authorities to reach acceptable terms for an agreement". However, it would fight any condition which weakened its position in the sector. "The market for set-top boxes is very, very competitive," a Microsoft spokesman said.

The EU is likely to make a final decision by early August. Although it rarely rejects a deal outright, it is expected to insist on more concessions to ensure consumers can choose different operating systems for the boxes, which control cable access to the internet.

webTitle: How much can you pay for...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: ...a bottle opener
fields.trailText: ...a bottle opener.
fields.body:
It is no longer good enough to behave like students, drink loads of alcohol and get up when the sun sets. If you haven't bought a pair of Miu Miu shoes, sent hundreds of emails and opened a website company by the end of the day, you might as well be dead, frankly. Or live in Bromley, which is clearly the same thing. You have to spend your fast-earned cash (before your website is taken over by the receivers) on ditsy little items like a beer bottle opener for £35, and thus demonstrate that you have so much theoretical money swilling around the place ("The shares just keep climbing, it's an absolute scream!"), that you're starting to feel like Martha Lane Fox, and that you just don't know what to do with it.

Got it? Good. Go forth and shop.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Gifts for Mother's Day
fields.trailText: Gifts for Mother's Day.
fields.body:
Now that just about every luxury known to man is available over the net, there are no excuses for arriving at your mum's on April 2 bearing nothing more than a pot plant.

The handmade chocolates (450g, £22) at www.billetdoux.co.uk won't disappoint, nor will the chocolate cake (£17) with Belgian chocolate, ground almonds and brandy-soaked raisins, room fragrances (£18 each) and sweet orange body lotion (£14). Last date to order for guaranteed delivery is Wednesday March 29.

Gourmet food and wine service www.lobster.co.uk has hampers to suit all tastes and purses. The champagne and caviar deluxe is a little extravagant at £223.25, but the Taittinger champagne and chocs (£30) or afternoon tea gift pack (£20) will make a nice treat. For guaranteed delivery outside London, you need to order by 2pm on Thursday March 30 (if you live in London, you have until noon on Saturday April 1).

Fashion-conscious mums will appreciate the polka dot Wbag (£109) or the blue brolly with orange gerberas (£25.50) at www.grimesco.ie, while www.browns-fashion.co.uk has pampering gifts, such as the silk kimono eye rest (£18), made from antique fabric and filled with lavender.

If you can't resist sending flowers, then you'll find sophisticated blooms at www.anniekhan.com.

fields.headline: Last but not least
fields.standfirst:
Never mind that shares frenzy and the photogenic Martha Lane Fox - does Lastminute.com deliver? Sam Wollaston goes bargain hunting (and tries to adopt an otter)
Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Never mind that shares frenzy and the photogenic Martha Lane Fox - does Lastminute.com deliver? Sam Wollaston goes bargain hunting (and tries to adopt an otter).
fields.body:
Lastminute.com is currently worth £481m - well down on the £845m it was worth last week, but still a healthy figure. Well done Martha Lane Fox and the other one who's a bloke so doesn't get his picture in the paper much. You've done really brilliantly, both of you (and if you're reading, Martha, I wondered if you'd be interested in marrying me?). Lastminute.com must be pretty good, to be worth all that money. So let's give it a go...

OK, so this is the home page and here's a guided tour, which seems like a good idea. "Our Mission!" declares that "Lastminute.com encourages spontaneous, romantic and sometimes adventurous behaviour by offering people the chance to live their dreams at unbeatable prices! If you're the kind of person who likes to seize the day, this is the place to seize it!" Yep, that's me. "Everything on the site has been carefully selected by our experts, who make sure that everything we offer is excellent and great value - so at the last minute, the prices drop but the quality doesn't!" Good news, and I guess we'll just have to get used to every sentence ending with an exclamation mark!

Now I'm ready to buy something, cinema tickets perhaps. Ah, here's Magnolia with Tom Cruise: "Exclusive screenings for one week only. Click here! See Magnolia before anybody else in the UK for one week only. This is a lastminute.com exclusive!"

OK, so Friday, 8pm would be good, Go for it! First, I need to register. No problem, pick a password . . . watch the spinning wheel . . . event details . . . one ticket . . . spinning wheel. £9.

I wonder if there are any additional charges; better check with Live Customer Service. But Natasha, Alex, Dan, Louisa, Nicky, Richard and Wavinya are all answering other callers; I'll be told when one is free. Now Alex is free and apologises for the delay though, to be fair, I didn't wait very long. There aren't any additional charges to the £9 if I'm collecting the ticket at the cinema, says Alex. I've got my credit card in my hand, I'll go ahead with it then. Buy now!

Oh dear. "Security Failure. A secure connection could not be established." I'm not given the choice to continue and am still ticketless, after 17 minutes - though of course a lot of that was because I was new to Lastminute.com, having to register and speak to Alex. And the security failure was the probably the fault of the computer system, so it would be unfair to blame Martha and the other bloke personally. But still, 17 minutes to not buy a ticket . . .

A call to the cinema produces a ticket in three-and-a-half minutes for the same screening (what was all that about it being a Lastminute.com exclusive then?). It cost £9.78 with the booking charge so Lastminute.com was cheaper - or would have been had I been able to get a ticket.

I'm not going to give up though. Let's have a browse around the site. "Do you really want to impress?" I think I do. Here's a nice-looking island for rent in Sri Lanka: $500 a day - I don't think Guardian expenses would run to that. I need something cheaper, something for the garden perhaps.

A lazy frog, "a cool amphibian addition to any garden" is £19.99. Perfect: go for it! "We are sorry the product you are looking for has just been sold to another eager customer. Don't worry we have lots of other cool stuff." Oh no you don't - the Christmas Geese (£135), the brass cranes (£225), the frog duet (£29.95), the large ratten reindeer (£34), the perfect plant protector (£39.99), the mini greenhouse (£295), the hen and chick set (£149), the reclining cat (£84.99) have all just been sold to another eager customer. Only the flowering keyring (£14.95) and the ornamental stone balls (£74) are available, and I don't much fancy either.

I decide to design and send myself a birthday card instead. It won't let me change the picture, but that's OK, I'll run with tulips. I like tulips. It does let me write my own message: "Happy Birthday. Hope it's a good one." I fill out the form, credit card still ready . . . No, nothing doing. It doesn't let me send it. And nothing happens when I press the help button. The "spontaneous behaviour" I can feel coming on isn't the sort Martha and her friend had in mind in that mission statement.

Perhaps I need a break from all this non-purchasing. Here's a celebrity interview to read, Jenny Frost, singer in the band Precious. Oh that Jenny Frost. Her favourite designer is G Armarni and no, spelling isn't listed as one of her hobbies. But I'm not here to criticise Lastminute.com's spelling or fondness for exclamation marks. I'm here to find out if it's any good.

Flights then. Lastminute.com is famous for its flights. Let's try New York next weekend, coming back a week later. The fare is £174 - not bad, and a bloke called Harry congratulates me on my choice and wishes me a brilliant vacation. Thanks Harry, but I'm actually going for a funeral. Well, I might have been, for all you know.

Let's go a little further afield - Quito on April 8 for three weeks. A business class ticket is all they come up with: £1,823. That's hardly living my dreams at unbeatable prices is it? Condor Travel on 020 7373 8477 on the other hand can get me there and back with Avianca on the same dates for £369. Economy class of course, but £1,454 cheaper than Lastminute.com's best offer.

Sydney, on May 15, produces this response: "Sorry, even working at the speed of light we couldn't find any thing that meets your exact needs." As does Alicante and Venice on May 15, and Johannesburg on May 1. Perhaps this is all a little too far in the future; this is Lastminute.com after all.

But I need to do something on lastminute.com. Here we go, adopt an otter for £22. Now a big-eyed whiskered face is staring out of my screen - how could I not. Go for it! "We are sorry the product you are looking for has just been sold to another eager customer . . ." No! Another eager customer has just that minute adopted Hector, Hector's twin sister Cally, Buckie, Glen with his injured leg, and Sushi, the young smooth-coated otter from India (funny name for an Indian otter, Sushi; I wonder what they call Japanese otters? Papadom? Or Tarka Dhal possibly).

Right, that's enough. In my three sessions on lastminute.com I've failed to buy cinema tickets or send myself a birthday card. I've been unimpressed by the range of things for my garden, the calibre of celebratory interview, and the over-use of exclamation marks. I've found cheaper flights at the end of a phone, and although I've fallen for an Indian otter, I am unable to help her. Lastminute.com? Lastminute.con more like. (Obviously none of this in any way affects that marriage proposal, Martha).

Why it's often better to do it yourself

FLIGHTS: return fare to Sydney.

Lastminute: £702.44, (minimum stay of seven nights).

Bucket shop: Avian Travel International (0171 793 8900), £540 with Japan Airlines - no minimum or maximum stay - or £501 with Creative Tours, official agent for Japan Airlines (0171 495 1775), coming back before July 30.

FLOWERS

Lastminute: £52.50 for the Elizabethan Rose Posy - "If you like roses the old-fashioned way this Elizabeth Rose Posy could be the one".

Branching Out, agents for Interflora (01628 666687): £55.50 gets you 25 red roses but they are prepared to negotiate a bit to compete with Lastminute prices. Plus £4.50 "transmission fee".

HOTELS

Four Seasons, Canary Wharf, London. Lastminute: £228.13 for a double.

Directly through the hotel: £235 including free bottle of champagne and car-parking.

ENTERTAINMENT

Copenhagen at The Duchess Theatre, London.

Lastminute: £34.50.

Duchess Theatre: £30.

By credit card through the Stoll-Moss Group: £31.

RESTAURANTS

La Tante Claire, Knightsbridge ("Delightfully extravagant and terrifyingly hard to get into," according to Lastminute).

Lastminute: No tables available for the following night.

A call to the restaurant got a table for two at 9pm the following evening.

webTitle: Britain and Spain near deal on Gibraltar

fields.headline: Britain and Spain near deal on Gibraltar
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lisbon summit
fields.trailText: Britain and Spain are close to finalising a deal over Gibraltar which is seen as a first step to ending a dispute which has lasted almost 300 years.
fields.body:
Britain and Spain are close to finalising a deal over Gibraltar which is seen as a first step to ending a dispute which has lasted almost 300 years.

If agreement is reached, it will bring to an end the semi-official Spanish blockades and enforced delays at Spain's land frontier with the Rock which have caused frequent diplomatic rows. The deal could lead eventually to the creation of an open border without passport controls or identity checks of any kind.

Britain captured Gibraltar in 1704 during the War of the Spanish Succession and Spain ceded it under the Treaty of Utrecht in 1713. It became a key British naval base commanding the entrance to the Mediterranean in the 19th and 20th centuries.

But Spain later resurrected its claim to sovereignty. In 1969, the Spanish dictator, General Francisco Franco, sealed the border, and it was not reopened until 1985.

Even though Spain embraced democracy after Franco's death and later joined the EU, Gibraltarians have consistently expressed the wish to keep their status as a British overseas territory. Some want outright independence - but both Britain and Spain oppose that.

In recent years, Spain has complained that Gibraltar had become a haven for smugglers and money-laundering. But these concerns have been allayed by Gibraltar's current chief minister, Peter Caruana, who led a campaign to clean up the Rock's image.

Britain's decision to join part of the EU's Schengen Agreement, which promotes open borders between member states, was also seen as a positive signal in Madrid. In the past Spain has vetoed EU legislation favourable to Britain in order to force the Gibraltar issue.

The deal, if and when it happens, is likely to be sealed by Tony Blair and the Spanish prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar. It will undoubtedly be seen as a product of the close relationship which has developed between the two leaders despite their different political backgrounds.

Mr Aznar is a conservative whose Popular Party, elected earlier this month for a second term, has embraced the political centre-ground. Mr Blair has reached the same place, but from the Left.

Both now seem to feel that the old Gibraltar problem should not be allowed to obstruct progress on more important, pan-European issues like job creation, e-commerce, and market deregulation - the agenda of this week's EU summit in Lisbon - as well in bilateral relations.

But expectations that an agreement would be ready for the two men to sign in Lisbon faded after both sides said technical details were still being worked out.

fields.bodyText: Britain and Spain are close to finalising a deal over Gibraltar which is seen as a first step to ending a dispute which has lasted almost 300 years. If agreement is reached, it will bring to an end the semi-official Spanish blockades and enforced delays at Spain's land frontier with the Rock which have caused frequent diplomatic rows. The deal could lead eventually to the creation of an open border without passport controls or identity checks of any kind. Britain captured Gibraltar in 1704 during the War of the Spanish Succession and Spain ceded it under the Treaty of Utrecht in 1713. It became a key British naval base commanding the entrance to the Mediterranean in the 19th and 20th centuries. But Spain later resurrected its claim to sovereignty. In 1969, the Spanish dictator, General Francisco Franco, sealed the border, and it was not reopened until 1985. Even though Spain embraced democracy after Franco's death and later joined the EU, Gibraltarians have consistently expressed the wish to keep their status as a British overseas territory. Some want outright independence - but both Britain and Spain oppose that. In recent years, Spain has complained that Gibraltar had become a haven for smugglers and money-laundering. But these concerns have been allayed by Gibraltar's current chief minister, Peter Caruana, who led a campaign to clean up the Rock's image. Britain's decision to join part of the EU's Schengen Agreement, which promotes open borders between member states, was also seen as a positive signal in Madrid. In the past Spain has vetoed EU legislation favourable to Britain in order to force the Gibraltar issue. The deal, if and when it happens, is likely to be sealed by Tony Blair and the Spanish prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar. It will undoubtedly be seen as a product of the close relationship which has developed between the two leaders despite their different political backgrounds. fields.headline: Pride online
fields.standfirst: Gays and lesbians are building new communities on the web, writes Mylene van Noort
fields.trailText: Gays and lesbians are building new communities on the web, writes Mylene van Noort
fields.body:
The community spirit of gays and lesbians seems to be waning. Fewer balloons go up on Aids memorial day, and pride marches suffer from lack of organisation. Is the whole community model old hat? Are gays and lesbians finally dissolving happily into society at large? No, they have just moved to another place.

Log on to one of the portals and you'll be surprised to see that the gay and lesbian community is celebrating a rebirth. It has become an incredibly welcoming, supportive, vibrant and amusing place. But confusing as well. Of the two now leading US community portals, Planet Out was the first to lure gay users away from busy bulletin boards and newsgroups in 1995. A year later Gay.com was launched.

On the EU side, a private investor made it possible for three journalists who had run the Eurogay website from Hamburg as a hobby to turn it into a professional community in 1998. These virtual commercial communities differ fundamentally from the real life ones in that they have owners. This is were the confusion starts. For when the members of any minority group log on to a commercial virtual community, they enter the digital transformation of their real life community, with its rich history of troubles and triumphs, martyrs and heroes.

Their virtual community may have a familiar face but it also has a business model. Owners of virtual communities are at pains to say they are gays and lesbians themselves. "To me, the Gay Financial Network is my family table," writes Walter Schubert in his founders' message of 1995. "I hope that by bringing my family together, and pooling our collective resources, the GFN home will reverse trends of gay hate, and stop the soul killing disease of homophobia." By bringing this family together GFN raised $6m in its second round of investment deals last October.

"Virtual communities will have the opportunity to create very substantial economic wealth for organisers", say John Hagel and Arthur Armstrong, the writers of the much acclaimed "Net Gain: Expanding markets through virtual communities, in an interview on Amazon.com.

'Market research has shown that gays and lesbians have a higher disposable income, log on more frequently and for longer and buy more via the net than any other demographic group", wrote the Industry Standard, last February. Advertisers and investors are rushing in as Planet Out, Gay.com and GFN run to bring more content to this lucrative market. It shows: their splash pages are filled to the brim and it is difficult to choose where to click first. In their haste for net presence, many start-ups present themselves being half-ready, developing their community on the fly.

Eurogay.co.uk for instance, the English version of the German Eurogay. At its UK start on March 3, parts of the content were copied from the German site. Eurogay also has a French and Spanish version underway. The most prominent features of Eurogay are an extensive shop and sleazy news items mostly about celebrities. Another of the four new European communities started over the last six months is Sonow.net. It is owned by the publishers of BoyzNow and the Pink Paper and includes Dykesworld.

Its hit rate is already higher than that of Time Out or The Independent sites. This promises to become the overall site for UK lesbians. For the moment it asks dykes for feedback on what they want the community to be like without offering them a significant format. A sophisticated start-up of 1999 is Queerlondon.com, which targets well-off tourists with private screenings, luxury accommodation and quarterly meetups. Posh Queerlondoners smile at you in stylish pictures and declare their love of champagne and being happy. They announce sponsorship delights for "our community".

A huge part of their site is also still under construction but questions about their ambitions are met with panic stricken silence. In contrast to run-of-the mill Eurogay and other competitors with work-in-progress, Rainbownetwork stands out as an original. Launched last September, it is the most playful with fun categories like Fluff and a Quizz Heaven. They signed up Bank of Scotland as an advertiser shortly after Outrage! highlighted the bank's anti-gay remarks. Cheekily, Peter Tetchell's first column was placed next to their Java driven ad. Mark Fullalove, managing director, boasts that the British financial press reported on the £1m investment from New Media Spark, the high profile internet venture capitalists.

This net adventurer is also one of the founders of a leisure company running some of Soho's most thriving venues. How confused gays and lesbians are about the nature of online communities is shown by the fact that people volunteer to host a chat or write reviews. Would any gay in his right mind volunteer in one of Fullalove's successful bars?

Rainbownetwork, though, like most virtual communities, has a network of volunteers who are recruited with texts like: "It is through you that we'll become the premier gay and lesbian website online" or "By volunteering you empower our community".

An Amsterdam portal will start on Queensday, April 29. It is built by a small net company run by gay twentysomethings called Guts. Annoyed by the lack of interest from gay rights organisations like COC, they decided to tie together some software they had in stock to build Queer.nl. FaceBase, a popular database for gay contacts which they developed, will be integrated in Queer.nl. The company is pretty open about its motives. "We want to build community software for all sorts of groups. A busy queer community portal will be an excellent showcase for that," says Bram Heerink, one of the founders.

Whereas communities for gay men are mostly for profit, those exclusively for dykes are not. A well known, huge and wonderfully designed German portal, Dykesworld.de (1995), not to be confused with the UK Dykeworld, is the brainchild of Indina Beuche, a desktop publishing specialist of 41 who doesn't want to make a penny from it, out of "love and respect for the global dyke community". As cyberspace is now awash with global communities oozing love and respect, even her authentic support sounds suspect.

Community portals are praised by their grass roots organisations for their good works: making coming out easier, offering a smooth ride through hundreds of webpages, ploughing money back into the real-world community through sponsorships, and raising the visibility of gays and lesbians by sitting at the table with venture capitalists and blue chip organisations like Marks & Spencer, who were never associated with the gay and lesbian community before. By embracing everything gay and lesbian on the net (except hard core porn), they attract clicks as fast as possible and hope for world domination. Is that great or is that simply greed?

Gays wallow in a wonderland to check out Irish jokes here and offers of gentle kissing in a Soho fumoir there with their own gay visa card at hand. Political issues do seem to lose credibility in a banner-plastered context. Or would gays take Peter Tatchell just as seriously if he stormed Canterbury cathedral wearing a T-shirt with a Bank of Scotland logo? In commercial communities, gays are offered the alluring possibility of being connected to an enormous range of likeminded people. With such huge numbers of members however, the gay community becomes a commodity.

www.gay.com
www.eurogay.co.uk
www.sonow.net
www.rainbownetwork.com
www.queerlondon.com
www.queer.nl
www.dykesworld.de

fields.headline: Challenge took Trimble by surprise
fields.trailText: Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble said today he was "somewhat surprised and a little bit disappointed" by the challenge to his leadership of the party.
fields.body:
Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble said today he was "somewhat surprised and a little bit disappointed" by the challenge to his leadership of the party.

His deputy in the Northern Ireland assembly, Seamus Mallon, declared that the Ulster Unionist party (UUP) had to decide whether it was in favour of the Good Friday agreement.

The Reverend Martin Smyth, who opposes the agreement, announced that he intended to contest the leadership at a meeting of the UUP's ruling council earlier today.

Mr Trimble, who has led the party since 1995, told reporters at Stormont that it was Mr Smyth's prerogative to challenge him, but he hoped that whoever emerged victorious would be able to lead the party as a united party. He added: "Of course the matter will be decided by the Ulster Unionist council on Saturday.

"I think what Martin needs to do is to explain to people clearly what the objective is and what policy is being pursued." Mr Trimble said he had no problems with the decision being left with the delegates and he hoped the leadership contest "would finally help clear the air".

The Ulster Unionist leader added he trusted any decision by the council of his party would be in line with previous decisions on party policy.

Mr Mallon, the deputy leader of the nationalist SDLP and Mr Trimble's deputy first minister in the now suspended power-sharing executive, said he suspected that, within unionism, there was relief that the issue was finally being put to the test.

"I would suspect that Saturday will, one way or the other, clear the air. I think that would be in the interests of strengthening unionism in terms of its own party political position and hopefully rid the wider political process of the tensions within unionism," he added.

He said he was not going to try and pre-empt the decision but said: "I do believe that the attitudes within unionism which are looking towards the future - and there are some - those attitudes will prevail."

The deputy first minister said it was not for him to enter into the internal affairs of the Unionist party but added: "In the wider terms ... unionism owes it to itself and to everybody else to finally sort out whether it is in favour of this agreement."

Sinn Fein President Gerry Adams refused to take questions about the leadership challenge, but in a speech said: "Those who meet on Saturday need to reflect that while change can be delayed, it cannot be prevented.

"They need to be reflecting that the only way that change can be stopped is if people like us, that want change, give up. We need to be very, very clear that we are not going to let that happen, that we are not prepared to accept second-class citizenship and we're going to be relentless in campaigning and agitating, organising and struggling for change."

William Thompson, the Ulster Unionist MP for West Tyrone, made it clear that he would be supporting a challenge to Mr Trimble's leadership. He was sanguine about the possibility that the Good Friday agreement would not survive a change of leadership in the UUP.

"I think ... the Belfast agreement is dead anyway. And I don't really see that it will succeed. I think at the end of the day, it was built on sand and it is going to fall," Mr Thompson told BBC Radio 4's The World at One programme. Mr Thompson said he wanted to see a devolved assembly in Northern Ireland, but only if all parties involved in it had put aside arms.

Launching his challenge today, Mr Smyth, who has already contested the leadership against Mr Trimble in 1995, said it was "time for a more vigorous promotion of Ulster Unionist policies".

"Many people in Northern Ireland are concerned [about the issue of decommissioning] and they want an opportunity to express that in a democratic way," he said. "I'm not a stalking horse. I have no real desire to be leader of a party. But on the other hand, if a call comes from the party through this vote on Saturday, then I'm prepared to serve the party and the people."

fields.headline: The land that forgot time
fields.trailText: The aircraft is banking for its final approach, and as the seatbelt sign  comes on the chief steward says over the tannoy: "Ladies and gentlemen, we  will shortly be landing at Belfast International. Please set your watches to  local time: 1689."
fields.body:
The aircraft is banking for its final approach, and as the seatbelt sign comes on the chief steward says over the tannoy: "Ladies and gentlemen, we will shortly be landing at Belfast International. Please set your watches to local time: 1689."

That joke - a reference to the year before the Battle of the Boyne - was already old and tired in the early 1970s, when I was one of the small army of British correspondents trying, and for the most part failing, to unravel the mysteries of the erupting Troubles.

One of the first truths to hit home was the extraordinary grip of history on Irish thinking. The gabled walls of Protestant Belfast were plastered with the slogan "Remember 1690", and it was no idle instruction. In Catholic West Belfast, some wag countered with a neatly painted daub 'Remember 1169' (the year the Welsh-Norman warlord Strongbow invaded Leinster).

Loyalists talked of Fenian rebellion and partition as a fresh memory. Nationalists spoke of the great famine of the 1840s as if it had struck yesterday. Every voice, it seemed, was infused with a sense of ancient grievance.

There was another sense in which events were being tugged along by history. It seemed that all the people at the cutting edge were rooted in the past. Many leaders of the unionist establishment were the sons of men who had taken control of the six-county statelet in the early 1920s.

Many of the republicans oiling their pathetic arsenal of rusty guns were the same men who had last fired in anger in the 1940s.

It wasn't long, of course, before the old guards were swallowed up in the cauldron of violence and political change. The unionist gentry were dispatched to their estates and a new hard-nosed breed of young politicians took over. The ineffective Nationalist party evaporated, as its role was taken over by the brash new Social Democratic and Labour party.

The old IRA stuttered on for a few years, but the dynamic and deadly new force of republicanism was the Provisional movement. In less than four years, from the first flaring of the Troubles in 1969, the political and security landscape had changed forever.

Northern Ireland's problem today is that its has regeneration proved not to be a continuous process, but a redrawing of the boundaries and a reshuffling of the personnel. Those who replaced the old order in the 70s are there still today.

Today's announcement that the Rev Martin Smyth will challenge David Trimble for the Unionist party leadership is eerily redolent of that long-ago era. For Mr Smith and Mr Trimble were rivals, of a sort, even then.

Mr Smith was the jutting-jawed, outspoken Grand Master of the Grand Orange Lodge of Ireland. Mr Trimble was an excitable young acolyte of William Craig, leader of the late and unlamented Vanguard party. Both were, and remain, ambitious men.

Another youngish Unionist, a minister in the old one-party-rule government of Northern Ireland, was John Taylor. He's there still, undoubtedly nursing his 30-year ambition to lead the party, and calculating the odds for Saturday's contest at the annual party council meeting.

Of the 10 Ulster Unionist MPs in the Commons, six were already active politicians in the early 1970s. And it's not just the Unionists. Founding father John Hume is still leader of the SDLP. The deputy leader Seamus Mallon was a bit of a young firebrand too.

The great panjandrums of today's republican movement, Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness, were handy with a quote all those years ago.

And the biggest dinosaur of all, Ian Paisley, has been roaring insults at the Pope since the 1950s. His mouthpiece role in the Democratic Unionist party has now been taken over by his son, Ian Junior, but the eminence grise of the party is still Peter Robinson MP, another 30-year veteran.

Though the context of their endless argument has changed beyond recognition (thank goodness) the language is often disturbingly familiar to anyone who witnessed or remembers the turbulence of Northern Ireland at the height of the Troubles.

For example, the hardline Unionists are now all for making a return to power-sharing dependent on the retention of the Royal Ulster Constabulary's name and badge - an action strongly reminiscent of the campaign in the 1970s to retain the old sectarian B Special constabulary.

The author of the RUC motion to be debated by the Unionists on Saturday is, incidentally, David Burnside, high-flying London-based practitioner of the black art of public relations. In the early 1970s, he was an eager young whippersnapper, spinning out press releases for the Unionist faction which included Mr Taylor and, later, Mr Trimble.

And so the wheel keeps turning in the same old groove, tugged along by the same cast of characters, mouthing the same mantras. Northern Ireland has come tantalisingly close to breaking out of the straitjacket of history, but the human ties that bind it to the past are alive, and kicking.

The great panjandrums of today's republican movement, Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness, were handy with a quote all those years ago. And the biggest dinosaur of all, Ian Paisley, has been roaring insults at the Pope since the 1950s. His mouthpiece role in the Democratic Unionist party has now been taken over by his son, Ian Junior, but the eminence grise of the party is still Peter Robinson MP, another 30-year veteran. Though the context of their endless argument has changed beyond recognition (thank goodness) the language is often disturbingly familiar to anyone who witnessed or remembers the turbulence of Northern Ireland at the height of the Troubles. For example, the hardline Unionists are now all for making a return to power-sharing dependent on the retention of the Royal Ulster Constabulary's name and badge - an action strongly reminiscent of the campaign in the 1970s to retain the old sectarian B Special constabulary. The author of the RUC motion to be debated by the Unionists on Saturday is, incidentally, David Burnside, high-flying London-based practitioner of the black art of public relations. In the early 1970s, he was an eager young whippersnapper, spinning out press releases for the Unionist faction which included Mr Taylor and, later, Mr Trimble. And so the wheel keeps turning in the same old groove, tugged along by the same cast of characters, mouthing the same mantras. Northern Ireland has come tantalisingly close to breaking out of the straitjacket of history, but the human ties that bind it to the past are alive, and kicking. fields.headline: US puts squeeze on BNFL
fields.standfirst: £6bn contracts at risk as team is sent to check Sellafield
fields.trailText: British Nuclear Fuels suffered another body blow last night when contracts with the US worth £6bn were put in jeopardy as the US energy secretary, Bill Richardson, sent a team to Sellafield to investigate the company's safety record.
fields.body:
British Nuclear Fuels suffered another body blow last night when contracts with the US worth £6bn were put in jeopardy as the US energy secretary, Bill Richardson, sent a team to Sellafield to investigate the company's safety record.

Mr Richardson said: "Business as usual is over with BNFL." The company, already reeling after rows with Japan and Germany over falsified safety documents for plutonium fuel it supplied to both countries, now faces losing potential US business worth around £55bn.

BNFL has staked its future on becoming the world leader in cleaning up nuclear sites and the US military bases it is working on could provide 50 years of work for the beleaguered company. A decision on a further contract also worth around £6bn is due in August.

In an interview with the New York Times, Mr Richardson said he had ordered his department to send a team to England to meet British investigators to discuss the falsified documents and nuclear inspectors' reports demanding safety improvements at BNFL's main plant in Cumbria.

"We are now placing BNFL under extra scrutiny because of these problems," he said. "I have been uneasy about some of their operations in the US. If we uncover anything, I will take swift and strong action."

He added: "Business as usual is over with BNFL and with all our contractors, but especially with BNFL." The situation was "itching for stronger management review".

Concerns about safety lapses at former military sites in the US have been heightened in recent weeks by the fact that BNFL - the main contractor brought in to clean them up - is also perceived to have a bad management record.

There is also criticism because four officials from the Department of Energy involved in awarding BNFL three separate contracts had since joined the company as executives. One was awarded without competitive tender.

A coalition of American groups that has been pressing the US energy deparment for years to clean up its old weapons facilities plan to file a petition with the department today urging that BNFL be barred from government contracts, for lack of integrity and competence. "We think clearly a case can be made, and that the case is self-evident, that this is a company that does not possess those qualities," said Thomas Carpenter, a lawyer with the government accountability project in Seattle.

No evidence of wrongdoing has been found in BNFL's American operations and director David Bonser yesterday said BNFL's problems were caused by five workers in Cumbria who had falsified documents.

Criticism of company management by the UK nuclear safety watchdog, the nuclear installations inspectorate, has however already cost the chief executive, John Taylor, his job.

The latest blow comes as Japan is demanding that plutonium fuel sent there with falsified documentation should be returned to Sellafield. Britain would have to send armed ships to collect it.

Last month Germany suspended fuel shipments to its own reactors after finding that fuel already loaded into one of its plants also had false documents. The nuclear installations inspectorate is appearing before MEPs at the European parliament today to answer questions about the company's record.

fields.headline: Luc Besson - part two
fields.standfirst: Working on Nil by Mouth | Choosing his films' music | Actors | The British film industry | Atlantis | Making films in English | Fifth Element | The future
fields.trailText: Part two of the Luc Besson interview at BFI Southbank
fields.body:
Q: When did you know that you had become a good director?

LB: Not through the press. I don't know if I'm a good director. You realise that you progress but you progress from your own point of view. I can see now that it's much easier for me to work with the actors, I'm much more confident and I feel better. I go further with them. Camera also, I'm not scared of the camera anymore. The [?] editing system gives you much greater opportunities and time. It fits well with me. And then piece by piece you watch your film over a few months and then you say: "This one is better." It doesn't mean that people like it better, but I know that for me my last film (Joan of Arc) is the best work I've done.

RJ: In what sense? Technically, story-telling, working with the actors?

LB: Everything. Working with the actors, story-telling, the complexity of it all. To take the people one way for half of the film and then to switch to, like: "I believe the sword was a sign." And to realise that it's just a point of view and to twist everything and see how she (Joan) has to pay for that. It's difficult to follow through five months of shooting, you need to really concentrate.

RJ: Does that sometimes get in the way of your story-telling, the sheer epic nature of the films you've made in recent years? From The Fifth Element to Joan of Arc, these are big, big films.

LB: No, on Joan, I was concentrating for five months. That's why people sometimes said: "He's very hard on people." But the problem is that you can't smile for five months because you now when you shoot one shot to a certain level of emotion and rhythm and then you have to link that to another one on the film that will be the next second but in real time it could be two or three days. It's very difficult to remember to have the feeling of it unless you really are with it all the time.

RJ: Is that why it's sometimes easier to do a film that isn't wrapped up in so much emotion? It's much more of an action film or a comedy action film where you don't have to link those kind of emotions.

LB: Yes, it's much easier. Action is the easy part. Battle is fun, it's easy.

RJ: When you arrived on the scene your own country didn't take to you probably as well as this country did. Critically, I mean - the public certainly did. Why do you think that was?

LB: The films are made for people, so who cares really what the critics say?

RJ: You came at a time when there was a very rich intellectual backdrop to French film making, or at least that's the way it communicated itself to the rest of the world.

LB: It's always very funny - these people tell you what you should do. "Oh, this is not the type of film for him." I don't understand, I just don't get it. What I love is when people go to a theatre and there are six movies and they say: "I want to go to this one." And that's it. And if they don't see yours it's because they don't want to, that's fine.

And the thing is, if they chose your film, then I feel guilty because I'm scared, I want to them to come out and say: "Yes it was good. Cool." That's my responsibility, I don't want to disappoint the people who come. A critic is whatever he's paid to say.

Q: What attracted you to the script of Nil By Mouth?

LB: Well, I've worked with Gary (Oldman) twice and I love him -

RJ: Luc Besson was the executive producer on Gary Oldman's directorial debut Nil By Mouth.

LB: I really like him a lot as an actor and you can see and tell on the set that he has the skill and the eye of a director. You can feel it. Not all the actors have it. But with Gary you can tell, he's here, he's watching everything and you can feel that. And then when he said to me: "I want to do a film, I want to direct," and I said: "Yes." Even before we'd discussed the subject of Nil By Mouth I was very proud to produce whatever it was, just for the pleasure of seeing him. That's why I helped him. Then afterwards I got the script, but it didn't change anything.

RJ: What do you think of the story?

LB: It's hard. What I like about the way he made it is sometimes you think it's improvised or caught, just like that, but then I was standing on the deluge and I watched this take and I thought: "Ah, the actor's just doing something instant," but then the take after he did exactly the same thing. And I said: "OK, you caught me. He's an actor!" He (Oldman) did a wonderful job for a first film. The film is difficult to go all around the world because it's very dark and difficult but he can be very proud of his film.

Q: When you're shooting a scene, do you think of music that might work with it?

LB: Most of the time, yes. Usually I take one CD and I always have the same CD in my CD player and I put it on every morning because it gives you the rhythm and then you go back to the same rhythm. So I get tired, after a while, of the CD. It's not necessarily a good CD it's just a feeling, but that's a good link to have.

Q: So does the CD tend to inspire the shooting when you listen to the music?

LB: Yes, it inspires, but also helps in the rhythm of everything, to go back to the same place every day. And you have the music of the film . And then after, when we start to edit the scene and it's made a little better I listen to a lot of music. And then if I pick up something I like we give it a try and if it fits then we edit the scene again, with the music. And we go to see Eric Serra (music arranger) and we put him in a shed because now we have something perfect but it can't be used yet- he has to do something else to it. So he hates me! That's how we work.

Q: Would you consider casting an unknown again as you did with Natalie Portman in Léon?

LB: Do you mean by "unknown" someone who has never played before, or someone who is an actor but who has never been in a film?

Q: Someone who has never played before.

LB: There are always people in my film who've never played before, who are not actors, always. Always five, 10 or 12, and you can't tell which ones. It depends. It can't be big. Sometimes you see a guy with a face and you think: "Oh that face is great," so you give him a part. For those of you who have seen Joan of Arc for example, the two English guys who come at the beginning -

RJ: The big ugly ones, you mean?

LB: The guys that come at the beginning and want to rape her (Joan's) sister. The one at the front is an actor, the two at the back are not. I sent someone to Scotland to every stadium where they play rugby and she took pictures of all the ugly ones. So I picked one, who was great, and this man was so sweet, he took his bus from his village with his pre-paid ticket, he'd never been on a plane before, landed in Paris and he put the costume on - he was great this guy. When he shook your hand you'd think he had seven fingers, his hands were very big.

Q: What are your feelings about the state of the British film industry?

LB: I think you're very lucky, in one way, because your language is international so you have an open door to lots of countries like the US or Canada or South Africa and that's a big advantage that we don't have. You can feel the energy. The British never give up, you've always got actors coming, and stories and things.

From my point of view, from France, it's a good example, in fact it's probably the best example in Europe. We have lots of good people but we spend a lot of time complaining - it's very French. If you do something that works, people hate you and if you do something very intellectual everybody will cry for you. It's strange, I think you're much more united. We see good films coming from here. Lots of good actors. I've worked with a lot of British actors and their level is ten times better than the French.

RJ: Why?

LB: You can feel that they watched TV, they went to the theatre, when they come on the set. Those three guys who played in Joan of Arc, the three captains that you saw in the scene, that was their first day shooting. They arrived in the middle of 1500 guys, in costume. I talked with them; I had 13 cameras so I didn't have a lot of time. They were like so cool. Do you want a funny story about them?

The three English were on the top of the wall, so I explained the scene and said: "Pretend that there is a camera on you all the time." So they said: "Great, OK." When you watched the beginning of the take they are really in, and it's great. The first few guys who arrive on the ladders are French stuntmen or actors, so they pretend and its great. After a few minutes the Czech stuntmen come in and they just go, and you can see on the tape that the English guys are looking a little worried that these guys are going to massacre them. You can feel the difference. At the end of the tape they look really scared.

Q: What was the inspiration behind Atlantis and did you expect the audience to have a knowledge of underwater sea life?

LB: On the version you have seen do you have credits at the end with all the animals one by one and their names? Because I did that.

Q: I'd like to know if the lizard was actually in the sea or if you put it there for the film?

LB: Everything was real. Six hundred dives, two years, everything is real. There are no tricks. None. And why it inspired me? At the end of Big Blue I was kind of frustrated because we were always in the blue and there is so much life in it and I wanted to show that. And it was funny to show that the life came from the sea and not just life but everything we learnt came from the sea. In the first 10 minutes you are a human being watching animals but by the end of the film you feel like a fish. And you feel home.

Q: How did you go about feeding the sharks in order to get the photographs?

LB: It's the only way to attract them in fact, so you put some blood in the water every ten minutes for two days and as soon as they cross the ribbon of blood they come back and they come and visit you and then they stay. There were four Great White sharks. The problem was that the cage was too close and the camera was too big so you couldn't film through it, you had to get out. And you had someone on your back like this, holding you, just in case. We put a kind of lead on the camera - it was expensive and I didn't want him to go away with it. A few times they grabbed the camera.

There was one lens which had a hole 1cm deep from the teeth. But they are nice. They always have the same speed, they're not vicious at all. They're so old, like a million years and they are the kings. The White Tips are more impressive - they're smaller, only two or three metres, but there are 100 of them there. And we had no cage so that is why it was more impressive. And I put ten kilos of meat all around the camera.

RJ: Jacques Cousteau was a smash hit in this country. Was he a big influence on you when you were a kid?

LB: When I was a kid, yes. And then Big Blue came and he said: "This is bullshit," and then Atlantis came and he said: "I won't see it." So I don't know, maybe he thinks that I am going to buy a red hat and take his place.

Q: Why are you making films in English? Is it for the big bucks? At the start you made several films in French and since Léon they've all been made in English for the international market.

LB: That's not true, because Big Blue was in English, and right after I made Nikita in French.

Q: When you made it in French it played in the art houses.

LB: And then, after Nikita, I made Atlantis, which is in bubbles.

RJ: But are they French bubbles or are they English bubbles? That is the question.

LB: No, honestly, I don't care. It depends on the story. With Joan of Arc, the reality is that she was speaking a dialect from Lorraine, half of France was speaking English at this time - north of the Loire they had been speaking English for eighty years. South of the Loire they were speaking Old French and she was speaking Lorraine. And why English? Because most of the actors I wanted to work with, the good ones, spoke English. Milla (Jovovich) was perfect for the part and as you know she speaks English, so I made the film in English.

Q: Carrying on with the idea of Joan of Arc being your best film and your first being your worst. Subway was one of my favourite films. I was just wondering what the film before that, The Last Battle, is about and where you can watch it?

RJ: The Last Battle has been actually part of the season here at the NFT. You can buy it - there's an American DVD available now.

LB: They're on sale, do you want some?

RJ: What do you think of the Last Battle now?

LB: It's my first baby, I love it. It's great.

RJ: You've said that The Fifth Element has been in your head since you were 16, how did you get it out of your head and on to the screen?

LB: It's pretty common really. I was living 65km from Paris and 11km from the nearest city with no theatres and no TV at home, I had just my little moped. So if I wanted to do the 11km, if the wind was against me it took me half an hour, so you know what, you create another world.

Q: What are you doing just now?

LB: I don't want to shoot right now.

RJ: You're doing the follow-up to Taxi right now.

LB: The next two films I'm doing are two that I produce, not direct. Taxi 2 will be in five days in France.

RJ: Have you written anything that you would like to shoot?

LB: No.

Q: Like you, I have swum with dolphins. Will you be returning to nature and the sea after your film-making career ends with number ten?

LB: You know, sometimes there are two attitudes. You see the most wonderful place in the world, with perfect beaches, and you say: "Wow, I'm going to build a hotel here." Or, you're just going to shut your mouth and go there once in a while. I'm so jealous of the freedom of the dolphins. They really are the kings of the sea. The way they integrate, because as you know they are not fish, they are mammals, they are strangers in the sea.

It's true as soon as fish sees a dolphin, they're scared to death. But they respect the environment totally - they totally integrate. They eat, they play, they make love and that's it. They don't build anything, they don't need anything and they're happy. The spend their time playing. And I'm very happy when I go over there once every two years or so - I know where they are, the wild ones - and I go swimming with them. I love this appointment with them. But that's it. I don't want to build a hotel and I'm so happy for them.

Q: Is the death of Joan of Arc's sister at the hands of the English based on true fact?

LB: Not really. The reality is that her sister died but no-one knows how. Some historians say that maybe she was killed during an attack so it could have happened in fact. We know that some members of the family were raped and killed in an attack on the village so a few elements are true. The film would be four hours long if we took all the real details so we tried to say something wrong but with an idea of the truth of it. It's delicate but that's why movies are made.

RJ: It would be quite interesting to ask the audience, since I presume most of them are English, what they think of Luc's representation of the English in Joan of Arc as vicious thugs, lunatics, hoodlums and drunkards who go over to France and go over to France and cause lots of problems. It's unthinkable isn't it?

LB: I'm not well parked, and I've got to go.

You can feel the difference. At the end of the tape they look really scared. Q: What was the inspiration behind Atlantis and did you expect the audience to have a knowledge of underwater sea life? LB: On the version you have seen do you have credits at the end with all the animals one by one and their names? Because I did that. Q: I'd like to know if the lizard was actually in the sea or if you put it there for the film? LB: Everything was real. Six hundred dives, two years, everything is real. There are no tricks. None. And why it inspired me? At the end of Big Blue I was kind of frustrated because we were always in the blue and there is so much life in it and I wanted to show that. And it was funny to show that the life came from the sea and not just life but everything we learnt came from the sea. In the first 10 minutes you are a human being watching animals but by the end of the film you feel like a fish. And you feel home. Q: How did you go about feeding the sharks in order to get the photographs? LB: It's the only way to attract them in fact, so you put some blood in the water every ten minutes for two days and as soon as they cross the ribbon of blood they come back and they come and visit you and then they stay. There were four Great White sharks. The problem was that the cage was too close and the camera was too big so you couldn't film through it, you had to get out. And you had someone on your back like this, holding you, just in case. We put a kind of lead on the camera - it was expensive and I didn't want him to go away with it. A few times they grabbed the camera. There was one lens which had a hole 1cm deep from the teeth. But they are nice. They always have the same speed, they're not vicious at all. They're so old, like a million years and they are the kings. The White Tips are more impressive - they're smaller, only two or three metres, but there are 100 of them there. And we had no cage so that is why it was more impressive. And I put ten kilos of meat all around the camera. RJ: Jacques Cousteau was a smash hit in this country. Was he a big influence on you when you were a kid? LB: When I was a kid, yes. And then Big Blue came and he said: "This is bullshit," and then Atlantis came and he said: "I won't see it." So I don't know, maybe he thinks that I am going to buy a red hat and take his place. Q: Why are you making films in English? Is it for the big bucks? At the start you made several films in French and since Léon they've all been made in English for the international market. LB: That's not true, because Big Blue was in English, and right after I made Nikita in French. Q: When you made it in French it played in the art houses. LB: And then, after Nikita, I made Atlantis, which is in bubbles. RJ: But are they French bubbles or are they English bubbles? That is the question. LB: No, honestly, I don't care. It depends on the story. With Joan of Arc, the reality is that she was speaking a dialect from Lorraine, half of France was speaking English at this time - north of the Loire they had been speaking English for eighty years. South of the Loire they were speaking Old French and she was speaking Lorraine. And why English? Because most of the actors I wanted to work with, the good ones, spoke English. Milla (Jovovich) was perfect for the part and as you know she speaks English, so I made the film in English. Q: Carrying on with the idea of Joan of Arc being your best film and your first being your worst. Subway was one of my favourite films. I was just wondering what the film before that, The Last Battle, is about and where you can watch it? RJ: The Last Battle has been actually part of the season here at the NFT. You can buy it - there's an American DVD available now. LB: They're on sale, do you want some? RJ: What do you think of the Last Battle now? LB: It's my first baby, I love it. It's great. RJ: You've said that The Fifth Element has been in your head since you were 16, how did you get it out of your head and on to the screen? LB: It's pretty common really. I was living 65km from Paris and 11km from the nearest city with no theatres and no TV at home, I had just my little moped. So if I wanted to do the 11km, if the wind was against me it took me half an hour, so you know what, you create another world. Q: What are you doing just now? LB: I don't want to shoot right now. RJ: You're doing the follow-up to Taxi right now. LB: The next two films I'm doing are two that I produce, not direct. Taxi 2 will be in five days in France. RJ: Have you written anything that you would like to shoot? LB: No. Q: Like you, I have swum with dolphins. Will you be returning to nature and the sea after your film-making career ends with number ten? LB: You know, sometimes there are two attitudes. You see the most wonderful place in the world, with perfect beaches, and you say: "Wow, I'm going to build a hotel here." Or, you're just going to shut your mouth and go there once in a while. I'm so jealous of the freedom of the dolphins. They really are the kings of the sea. The way they integrate, because as you know they are not fish, they are mammals, they are strangers in the sea. It's true as soon as fish sees a dolphin, they're scared to death. But they respect the environment totally - they totally integrate. They eat, they play, they make love and that's it. They don't build anything, they don't need anything and they're happy. The spend their time playing. And I'm very happy when I go over there once every two years or so - I know where they are, the wild ones - and I go swimming with them. I love this appointment with them. But that's it. I don't want to build a hotel and I'm so happy for them. Q: Is the death of Joan of Arc's sister at the hands of the English based on true fact? LB: Not really. The reality is that her sister died but no-one knows how. Some historians say that maybe she was killed during an attack so it could have happened in fact. We know that some members of the family were raped and killed in an attack on the village so a few elements are true. The film would be four hours long if we took all the real details so we tried to say something wrong but with an idea of the truth of it. It's delicate but that's why movies are made. RJ: It would be quite interesting to ask the audience, since I presume most of them are English, what they think of Luc's representation of the English in Joan of Arc as vicious thugs, lunatics, hoodlums and drunkards who go over to France and go over to France and cause lots of problems. It's unthinkable isn't it? LB: I'm not well parked, and I've got to go.

webTitle: Good in the bad and the ugly

fields.headline: Good in the bad and the ugly
fields.standfirst: The benefits of teenage angst | Money for nothing | The man who sold his soul on the net
fields.trailText: Last week I had a strange regressive experience: I watched Clockwork Orange for the second time. The first had been when it was on general release. I was about 13 and a group of us sneaked in through the emergency exit of our local cinema. In the intervening years of the film's enforced absence, I thought I had remembered it all in forensic detail. But it turned out the scenes that had stuck with me in the 27-year hiatus were exclusively the moments of ultra-violence, the passages of rape and torture. Everything else had, apparently, gone in one ear and out the other.
fields.body:
Last week I had a strange regressive experience: I watched Clockwork Orange for the second time. The first had been when it was on general release. I was about 13 and a group of us sneaked in through the emergency exit of our local cinema. In the intervening years of the film's enforced absence, I thought I had remembered it all in forensic detail. But it turned out the scenes that had stuck with me in the 27-year hiatus were exclusively the moments of ultra-violence, the passages of rape and torture. Everything else had, apparently, gone in one ear and out the other.

Second time round, what struck me about the intensity of those images was how they revealed Stanley Kubrick's intoxication with the power of the teenager. Potent, energetic, firm-limbed, charismatic: young Alex represents everything a flabby, middle-aged film director has lost. Kubrick's vision of the future was one in which amoral youths ruled with rods of iron and toe- caps of steel, inflicting all sorts of cruelties on their fellow citizens, forcing the over-20s to cower behind locked doors, tut-tutting at the decline in society. He was clearly terrified by the teens.

Nearly three decades on, while Kubrick's prediction has proved to be largely fanciful, not much has changed in the wider view of the young. Many of us remain, it seems, scared stiff of them. This week, an EU study exposed the behavioural patterns of teenagers in community countries. The Daily Mail reported it under the headline "Our teens top the league of drink, drugs and sex".

"Teenagers in Britain are the most feckless and badly behaved in Europe," is how the piece starts, a line that might have been randomly plucked from the paper at any time in the past 50 years. Meanwhile, accom panying the article, a table detailing statistics about drug use, alcohol consumption and abortion rates is headlined: "Youth in disgrace". Just in case readers fail to realise that the young are leading us all to hell in a handcart, the words "traditional values" are dropped into the text in bold type. Apparently it is the erosion of traditional values that has led to 71% of 15-year-old boys in Wales admitting to having been drunk at least twice in their lives, whereas in Belgium only 33% have.

Which is odd. It seems to me that the urge to get bladdered and get your leg over have been the traditional values of teenagers since hormones were invented. Indeed this traditional keenness to experiment is the one vital natural resource in which this country remains a world leader. In Tuesday's Budget, Gordon Brown made great play of the need to encourage job-creating enterprise. Since Britain is no longer a place to manufacture anything, much of the new economy will be based on thin-air businesses. Pop, fashion, style, design: these are our future. And they are all enterprises that draw their edge and inspiration from youthful preparedness to take risks.

This is not to suggest that the economy will grow like topsy if tax breaks are introduced for teenage mothers or if enterprise grants are handed out for public displays of drunkenness by youths in Welsh market towns. But it is to make the claim that no one has ever come up with anything worthwhile by sitting at home being sensible. Teenage pregnancies and drug-dependency are the depressing flip side of a coin we will increasingly need to cash. And if you need convincing, check out the opinion of Madonna, the one economic migrant seeking asylum on these shores welcomed by the tabloids. The former wild child turned role model Anglophile has stated she has settled here because our street culture, fashion, architecture and club life are so inventive. Even if the kids are 40% more sober, she didn't, it seems, want to go to Belgium.

In the middle of a chain reaction

Readers of a certain age will remember a scam that briefly excited the spivvier elements among us back in the mid-80s. Called, as far as I remember, the Golden Circle, it was a chain letter with a cash incentive.

Letters whizzed through the yuppie orbit, from ad agency to City trading desks through to the newly fashionable independent television production offices, offering the delicious possibility of unearned wealth. On receiving the letter, all you had to do was send a cheque for £50 to the person at the top of an enclosed list of names and addresses, remove their details and add your own at the bottom, then photocopy the list and forward it to a dozen friends. Within a fortnight, instead of the postcards from around the world that were alleged to cascade through the letter boxes of those who entered into the spirit of more conventional chain letters, it was promised several thousand quid would plop on to your doormat.

Inevitably, the Golden Circle turned out to be more of a Golden Shower. No one got rich, either quick or slow. Although my flat-mate did manage to land himself one cheque by dint of cheating and adding his name to the top, rather than the bottom of the list.

Now, some 15 years on, there is, inevitably, an email version of the Golden Circle. Apparently it originated in Canada and has been spinning round Britain this last week or so, promising wealth indeed. But brilliantly reflecting the dot.com bubble age, this e-chain does not require any capital outlay whatsoever. It promises the ultimate in e-commerce: money for nothing. No need to send any cash to anyone: the chain claims that senders are entitled to a commission from Microsoft which is tracking the correspondence round the globe and is prepared to fork out some of Bill Gates's ludicrous fortune every time the email is forwarded.

Some might dismiss this out of hand as a pitiful reflection on our greed, a pathetic amalgam of urban legend and internet conspiracy fantasy, and that merely to entertain the thing is to delude yourself. But in the meantime, if anyone would like to send me their email address, I would be more than willing to forward the chain to them so they can make up their own mind.

 Following the lead of Bart Simpson who flogged his on to his chum Millhouse with disastrous consequences, Kembrew McLeod, a researcher at the University of Massachusetts, this week successfully sold his soul. According to the Boston Herald, McLeod posted his soul as an item for sale on the internet auction site e-bay some months ago. Thirty potential buyers slugged it out, until the price reached a tidy $1,325 (£800). For that, the lucky winner of the auction receives a four-ounce jar labelled "Kembrew's Soul" plus a deed of ownership.

"The reason I've been selling my soul is to make money," the now soul-free McLeod told the paper. "In America you can metaphorically and literally sell your soul and be rewarded for it. That's what makes this country great."

The new owner of the soul prefers to remain anonymous, but has revealed one telling detail about his life: his occupation. In the absence of the devil picking up his soul at auction, Kembrew McLeod can be reassured it is now in the hands of the next best thing. The purchaser is a New York real estate agent.

 Catherine Bennett is away.
