webTitle: Pope fans the flames of Palestinian resentment

fields.headline: Pope fans the flames of Palestinian resentment
fields.standfirst: Papal polemic: Demands seen as snub to Israeli hosts
fields.trailText: The Pope yesterday delivered a searing rebuke to his Israeli hosts, demanding a homeland for Palestinian refugees and an end to the torment they have endured for half a century.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Deheishe refugee camp, West Bank
fields.body:
The Pope yesterday delivered a searing rebuke to his Israeli hosts, demanding a homeland for Palestinian refugees and an end to the torment they have endured for half a century.

He made the comments at Deheishe camp, a cluster of shacks that is home to about 10,000 Palestinians. The effect of his foray into the politics of the Middle East - less than 24 hours after kissing the soil of the Holy Land at the start of what was to have been a spiritual journey - was immediate and explosive.

As the helicopter returning the Pope to Jerusalem climbed into the air, some 200 young Palestinians poured on to the main road, hurling stones and bits of scaffolding at the Palestinian police.

The eruption followed a day of festivity during which the overwhelmingly Muslim population of Deheishe received the Pope as a saviour. If Jesus, said to have been born just three miles away in Bethlehem, was a Palestinian, as many in Deheishe believe, then at least for a day they were prepared to embrace the Pope as a native son.

"No one can ignore how much the Palestinian people have had to suffer in recent decades," the Pope said on arrival in Bethlehem, one of the West Bank towns under the control of the Palestinian Authority. "Your torment is before the eyes of the world. And it has gone on for too long."

He added: "My hope is that my visit today to Deheishe refugee camp will serve to remind the international community that decisive action is needed to improve the situation of the Palestinian people."

Israeli reaction was subdued. For days officials have been hailing the Pope as a man who has done more than any of his predecessors to heal the rift between Jews and Catholics, and have portrayed his visit as a sign of the Vatican's friendship with the Jewish state.

"I do not see anything new in the Vatican position," said Shlomo Ben Ami, the public security minister, who is responsible for the huge police operation during the Pope's stay here. "We will not look at the petty details of the visit through a microscope."

In Deheishe, where the Pope's reception was a ragged version of a state welcome from a country which has yet to be born, the muddled versions of his speech that spread through the narrow lanes had an electrifying effect.

"He is only one man but one billion people believe in him, and now he is our hero too," said Ali Khalaf, an engineering student.

By late afternoon, when the papal cavalcade arrived waving the Palestinian tricolour, and amid the competing blare of brass bands and folk choirs, it was like a carnival. Thousands strained against the barricades for a glimpse of their new champion, many wearing t-shirts made for the occasion showing the Pope in intimate conversation with their leader, Yasser Arafat.

"There is an atmosphere of appreciation spreading through the camp because he mentioned our suffering," said Amjad Abu Laban, one of the organisers of the visit to Deheishe.

The Pope rewarded them - and nearly 3m other Palestinians dispersed in camps across the Middle East - with a speech that was an even harsher indictment of the Israeli authorities than his morning address.

"You have been deprived of many things that represent the basic needs of human persons: proper housing, healthcare, education and work. Above all, you bear the sad memory of what you were forced to leave behind, not just material possessions, but your freedom, the closeness of relatives and the familiar surroundings and cultural traditions which nourished your personal and family life."

There was more.

"The degrading conditions in which refugees often have to live, the continuation over long periods of situations that are barely tolerable in emergencies or for a brief time of transit; the fact that displaced persons are obliged to remain for years in settlement camps: these are the measure of the urgent need for a just solution to the underlying causes of the problem."

In political terms, the two speeches - which invoked UN resolutions calling on Israel to end its occupation over territories captured during the 1967 war and to allow the Palestinians to return to their homes - could hardly be more explicit.

They are bound to reverberate on the remainder of his six-day pilgrimage, which is to be spent entirely in Israel. They could also carry over to the Israeli-Palestinian negotiations which resumed in Washington this week, and which have seen only 40% of the West Bank turned over to Palestinian control in a slow and grudging carve-up.

But there was no mistaking the significance of such a strong expression of sympathy for the Palestinian cause.

"By highlighting our situation, the Pope is helping to rebalance the equation in the Arab-Israeli problem," said Mr Abu Laben.

As the Pope made evident, that imbalance also infects talks taking place in Washington, where Palestinian negotiators are struggling to assert their claim to a part of Jerusalem.

"Only with a just and lasting peace - not imposed but secured through negotiation - will the legitimate Palestinian aspirations be fulfilled.

"Only then will the Holy Land see the possibility of a bright new future."

Palestinian National Authority
The Vatican

webTitle: The Pope's speech at Yad Vashem

fields.headline: The Pope's speech at Yad Vashem
fields.trailText: The words of the ancient Psalm, rise from our hearts: "I have become like a broken vessel. I hear the whispering of many - terror on every side - as they scheme together against me, as they plot to take my life. But I trust in you, O Lord: I say, 'you are my God."' (Psalms 31:13-15)
fields.body:
The words of the ancient Psalm, rise from our hearts: "I have become like a broken vessel. I hear the whispering of many - terror on every side - as they scheme together against me, as they plot to take my life. But I trust in you, O Lord: I say, 'you are my God."' (Psalms 31:13-15)

In this place of memories, the mind and heart and soul feel an extreme need for silence. Silence in which to remember. Silence in which to try to make some sense of the memories which come flooding back. Silence because there are no words strong enough to deplore the terrible tragedy of the Shoah. My own personal memories are of all that happened when the Nazis occupied Poland during the war. I remember my Jewish friends and neighbours, some of whom perished, while others survived. I have come to Yad Vashem to pay homage to the millions of Jewish people who, stripped of everything, especially of human dignity, were murdered in the Holocaust. More than half a century has passed, but the memories remain.

Here, as at Auschwitz and many other places in Europe, we are overcome by the echo of the heart-rending laments of so many. Men, women and children, cry out to us from the depths of the horror that they knew. How can we fail to heed their cry? No one can forget or ignore what happened. No one can diminish its scale.

We wish to remember. But we wish to remember for a purpose, namely to ensure that never again will evil prevail, as it did for the millions of innocent victims of Nazism.

How could man have such utter contempt for man? Because he had reached the point of contempt for God. Only a godless ideology could plan and carry out the extermination of a whole people.

The honor given to the 'just gentiles' by the state of Israel at Yad Vashem for having acted heroically to save Jews, sometimes to the point of giving their own lives, is a recognition that not even in the darkest hour is every light extinguished. We remember, but not with any desire for vengeance or as an incentive to hatred. For us, to remember is to pray for peace and justice, and to commit ourselves to their cause. Only a world at peace, with justice for all, can avoid repeating the mistakes and terrible crimes of the past.

As bishop of Rome and successor of the Apostle Peter, I assure the Jewish people that the Catholic Church, motivated by the Gospel law of truth and love, and by no political considerations, is deeply saddened by the hatred, acts of persecution and displays of anti-Semitism directed against the Jews by Christians at any time and in any place.

Let us build a new future in which there will be no more anti-Jewish feeling among Christians or anti-Christian feeling among Jews, but rather the mutual respect required of those who adore the one Creator and Lord, and look to Abraham as our common father in faith.

It makes us cry out: "I hear the whispering of many - terror on every side - but I trust in you, O Lord: I say, 'You are my God."' (Psalms 31:13-15)

fields.headline: Don't hold your breath
fields.trailText: Jack Straw is due to announce some concessions on the much criticised freedom of information bill today. They are not worth that much.
fields.body:
So Jack Straw is due to announce some concessions on the much criticised freedom of information bill today. They are not worth that much.

The biggest change is the decision to stop local authority and quango chief executives being able to withold information from the new information commissioner. But the main thrust of the bill is unchanged - ministers want the final say on whether you the public have the right to know. And generally when it comes to how the government reaches decisions on your life, they don't want you to know how they came to take them.

Jack Straw's cosmetic move is aimed to try and convince the 200 Labour MPs who, like the Guardian, don't think much of his bill either. He hopes they won't vote against him next month - and would like to suggest that he is a radical at heart.

In fact he is keeping his powder dry because he knows that his measure will be massacred when it gets to the House of Lords - who can see that the bill is pathetic compared to what's on offer in Wales, Scotland, Ireland and the United States.

The Liberal Democrats will be pressing the government for key changes - notably giving the commissioner the right to overrule ministers on the release of information.

Meanwhile, Mr Straw himself has been told by the Home Office press office to "accept reluctantly" a request from the Guardian for an interview on the subject. Mr Straw continually boasts that he can show us his ministerial red box - because there will be nothing in it which would be a real secret.

Unfortunately it has recently included an embarrassing memo on the Guardian's coverage on the Freedom of Information bill. We have committed that appalling sin of treating him with "disdain" and we evidently refuse to use "the Home Office line to take" in the paper. No wonder Jack can't risk open government.

fields.headline: Gordon's plan for women
fields.standfirst: Mothers may get part-time working Rights
fields.trailText: Thursday, 2pm: Political correspondent Lucy Ward on the canape war for women in the heart of government
fields.body:
In the sumptuous first floor drawing room at No 11 Downing Street yesterday, chancellor Gordon Brown circulated amongst canape-munching journalists chewing over the details of his latest Budget. Such media receptions, in which the clink of champagne glasses underlies the chat, are not unusual; the difference here was that every journalist was a woman.

The Treasury's decision to use its first post-Budget event of the millennium to highlight the latest economic package's benefits for women is unprecedented. True, Mr Brown may have looked faintly embarrassed as female reporters congratulated him on slashing VAT on sanitary products, but the reception, plus his appearance on Radio 4's Woman's Hour, represent a genuine advance for a wide policy agenda affecting women. The Treasury, if not the government as a whole, is learning to address a female audience directly, without using the typical 10 Downing Street trick of referring to "families", or mothers.

The potential gains are, of course, greater than a few more free lunches for journalists. Mr Brown's budget was hardly awash with initiatives directed specifically at women, though it did include an increase in the Working Family's Tax Credit to help out low-paid women on maternity leave and a £100 increase in the maternity grant.

The Women's Budget Group, an informal think tank of economists, social policy experts and trade unionists which advises Mr Brown on policies affecting women, dismissed the package rather harshly as a "missed opportunity", but urged the government to move on other reforms now moving centre-stage as never before. The possibilities are real: the chancellor announced a review of maternity pay and leave, to be conducted by trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers and likely to take in an existing review of a new entitlement to parental leave.

Women ministers are confident that, with newly energised lobbying might feeding into the consultation, landmark change to Britain's maternity rights - the worst in the EU - is achievable. Harriet Harman, the former women's minister who now lobbies from the backbenches on women's issues, says: "It is significant that this review is being handled by the DTI, which lays down rights, rather than the education and employment department, which could only provide guidelines."

A new right for mothers to return to their jobs part-time after having children is also now a real possibility, as the Guardian discloses today. Though some campaigners criticise the government for remaining over-cautious on workplace change, a combination of more women ministers and tougher lobbying from women's groups has put the issue of the balance between work and home life firmly on the agenda.

The government, of course, is not merely holding receptions for women journalists and knocking VAT off Tampax out of the goodness of its heart. Labour party strategists are well aware that women voters played a key role in its 1997 general election landslide - there were far more female swing voters than male. Last week, a presentation was held at Downing Street on women's views of the government, reflecting the eye Tony Blair now has on the next election. It is safe to predict Gordon Brown and friends will be talking to, and about, women increasingly as polling day approaches.

fields.headline: Watts Towers
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the restoration of the Californian architectural folly on the web
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the restoration of the Californian architectural folly on the web
fields.body:
1. The Watts Towers, probably Los Angeles's most eccentric landmarks, are to be restored as part of a regeneration drive for the city's turbulent suburb of Watts.

2. The towers, which bear a strange resemblance to Antoni Gaudí's Parc Guell and Sagrada Familia in distant Barcelona, were built entirely of waste material, and are the work of one man, an Italian immigrant named Simon Rodia.

3. Restoration work will coincide with the Democrat party convention to be held in LA, for the first time in 40 years, this August. An invitation to inspect the structures will be sent to the White House once the project is complete.

4. Condemned as structural hazards by the city council, the towers were saved by Watts residents, and are now registered as a state historic park.

5. They are an important focus of identity for the area, still scarred by the Watts riots of August 1965, which left 34 dead, and the suburb in ruins. The towers were unscathed.

6. Certainly, they are an improvement on the other defining landmarks of the City of Angels - Disneyland and the Hollywood sign.

7. Today, although the demography of the area is changing in favour of the Latino population, the Watts summer festival is still a focus for black solidarity in Los Angeles. The festival's director, Tommy Jacquette, condemns the regeneration plan as an attempt to create a white-friendly "Hollywatts".

8. In Britain, the tradition of the architectural folly is well established. But this kind of maverick art is surprisingly widespread; witness Nek Chand's rock gardens in Chandigarh, India.

9. It is hoped that the towers will become a major tourist attraction. There is, after all, no reason why a tower built by rank amateurs and repeatedly condemned as structurally unsound shouldn't draw visitors. (Ask Pisa city council.)

10. London too is well acquainted with the notion that a city can build a ludicrous structure with no apparent function and expect the crowds to pour in.

webTitle: BMW announces lower Rover redundancy figures

fields.headline: BMW announces lower Rover redundancy figures
fields.trailText: BMW said today that between two and three thousand jobs will be lost following the Rover sell off despite union fears that up to 10,000 could face redundancy.
fields.body:
BMW said today that between two and three thousand jobs will be lost following the Rover sell off despite union fears that up to 10,000 could face redundancy.

The announcent came after a "very positive" meeting between trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers and BMW bosses at the firm's head office in Munich. The German car giant pledged to keep job losses caused by the Rover sell-off to a minimum.

Mr Byers said he was encouraged by the outcome of two hours of talks in with BMW chairman Joachim Milberg and extracted an agreement that BMW will work with a "Rover task force" set up to create new jobs in the area around the firm's Longbridge plant.

The area will be hardest hit because of the expected huge cut-back in production at the Longbridge factory in Birmingham.

Thousands of redundancies had seemed inevitable but Mr Byers says he will salvage as many jobs as possible. However, Mr Byers said that no figure could yet be put on the number of jobs to be lost.

More discussions will be held between BMW, the Government and the taskforce, while the deal selling parts of Rover to Alchemy is not expected to be tied up for another month.

Meanwhile, it has emerged that BMW is on the verge of selling the Rover research and development centre at Gaydon in Warwickshire to Ford.

The centre employs more than 3,500 workers and carries out work for the Land Rover plant at Solihull, which Ford is also buying.

fields.headline: Smith v Trimble
fields.trailText: David Trimble
fields.body:
David Trimble

Born in October 1944, he was a lecturer at Queen's University in Belfast before entering politics in his mid-twenties. Considered a firebrand and hardliner, he played a junior role in the Ulster Workers' Council strike which brought down the first power-sharing executive in 1974. Then, he belonged to William Craig's far-right Vanguard Party. Later, Trimble joined the mainstream Ulster Unionist party, rising swiftly through the ranks and being elected MP for the safe seat of Upper Bann in 1990.

Elected leader in 1995 - defeating long-time rival John Taylor - he has played a leading role in the Northern Ireland peace process, slowly abandoning his former hardline stance against any cooperation with the republican movement. In the protracted negotiations over the Good Friday agreement, he emerged as First Minister - and the first Unionist to shake hands with the leaders of Sinn Fein.

Martin Smyth

Active in politics since 1965, he will turn 70 in June next year. An unwavering opponent of sharing power with republicans, he has consistently argued against Unionist involvement with any party with paramilitary links. A bluff and amiable enough man, he is squarely in the religious tradition of Ulster Unionism, as a Presbyterian minister (ordained 1957) and a long-serving Grand Master of the Grand Orange Lodge of Ireland.

As MP for Belfast South since 1982, Smyth has made relatively little impact in the Commons, save to growl his displeasure whenever British ministers talk of compromise, or cooperation with Dublin. He is the party spokesman on health and family issues, and lists among his interests foreign affairs, religious liberty, and human rights.

fields.headline: Organ removal
fields.standfirst: The chief medical officer for England, Professor Liam Donaldson, today announced new guidelines governing the way doctors ask permission to remove and retain the organs of dead patients, following recommendations from the Royal College of Pathologists. Matt Wells explains
fields.trailText:
Why are these new guidelines being introduced?
They have been drawn up following the revelation that two hospitals in England, Alder Hey children's hospital in Liverpool and Bristol royal infirmary, removed thousands of hearts, lungs, brains and other organs from dead patients without relatives' explicit consent. The case of Stephen White, a 10-day-old baby who died from a heart defect eight years ago, raised particular concern. Stephen's organs were disposed of at Alder Hey without his parents' knowledge.
fields.body:
Why are these new guidelines being introduced?
They have been drawn up following the revelation that two hospitals in England, Alder Hey children's hospital in Liverpool and Bristol royal infirmary, removed thousands of hearts, lungs, brains and other organs from dead patients without relatives' explicit consent. The case of Stephen White, a 10-day-old baby who died from a heart defect eight years ago, raised particular concern. Stephen's organs were disposed of at Alder Hey without his parents' knowledge.

How did this happen?
It was thought that telling parents exactly what happens to a relative's body during and after a postmortem examination was too distressing. But the Royal College of Pathologists has accepted that this "doctor knows best" attitude is no longer acceptable, and relatives should be able to make informed and rational decisions.

Why are organs removed anyway?
Postmortems are carried out when there may be any doubt about the cause of death - particularly important, for example, in young children. Organs are removed and examined as part of the autopsy process.

How do they come do be retained?
When agreeing to a postmortem, relatives also unwittingly gave their consent for doctors to retain or dispose of organs as they saw fit. Many were retained for research purposes.

Has anyone been called to account for the scandal?
Frank Taylor, chairman of the Royal Liverpool children's hospital trust, was sacked on February 16 after the Stephen White scandal emerged. Health minister Lord Hunt today appointed Judith Greensmith, currently chairman of Liverpool health authority, to take his place. The NHS executive in the north-west of England has been charged with ensuring the hospital trust puts robust measures in place to prevent such a scandal happening again. An independent inquiry into Alder Hey is already under way and will report later this year. Parents have called for a police investigation.

What do the new guidelines say?
Relatives of dead patients who undergo postmortem examinations must be informed about what tissue and organs are to be removed from the body, and they should be asked how they wish the organs to be disposed of. In some cases, the organs had been routinely retained for research - relatives must now give their express consent. Better teaching and training is also needed for doctors and other hospital staff.

What has the reaction been?
Ian Cohen, the solicitor representing families' support group Pity II, set up in the wake of the Alder Hey scandal, said the guidelines should become law. Liberal Democrat science spokesman Dr Evan Harris agreed: "Existing statute law, or lack of it, dates from a time when 'doctor knew best' and these recent incidents show that lack of consultation with relatives causes more grief than allowing relatives to be fully involved and informed."

fields.headline: Chelsea go for second best
fields.standfirst:
Lazio pip Vialli's men to take top spot for the quarter-finals
Poyet 44 | Inzaghi 54, Mihajlovic 66
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Chelsea 1 - 2 Lazio
fields.body:
Chelsea learned the hard way last night that there are prizes for second place - and they are not very pleasant.

Lazio's impressive win here consigned Gianluca Vialli's side to the runners-up spot in Group D and a quarter-final tie against one of the other heavyweights left in this competition - Barcelona, Bayern Munich or even Manchester United - when Friday's draw is made.

Chelsea, without a single Briton in their starting line-up, only needed a point to qualify top of their group but instead were outclassed and left reeling by the first European home defeat in their history. The dismissal of Fernando Couto for a second yellow, following an outrageous lunge on Tore Andre Flo, offered scant consolation.

Chelsea's cause was not helped by the absence of their captain Dennis Wise to injury; nor by the fact that Lazio's position in the group brought them into last night's tie seeking victory.

Attacking from the start is not Lazio's normal game, but the Italians set about their unaccustomed task with energy and imagination - plus an unhealthy amount of play-acting. The referee Victor Manuel Melo Pereira was in danger of losing control long before he allowed Matias Almeyda to escape without a caution for a late lunge at Flo on 22 minutes.

After just three minutes the Dutchman produced a reaction punch away when Simone Inzaghi fired a volley goalwards. Three minutes later De Goey again did well to hold out a Veron shot that bounced just in front of him. Dejan Stankovic followed that with a header just over the bar, before De Goey was forced to dart from his line to interrupt Inzaghi's breakaway.

But they were in dangerous territory until a minute before the break, when a Poyet special gave them some much-needed breathing space. Bringing the ball forward, Chelsea's captain for the night - playing his 100th game for the club - unleashed a high-powered strike from 25 yards which bent from left to right and beat Marchegiani into the top corner.

fields.headline: Births, engagements and death
fields.standfirst: Chelsea field a team without a British player. So? The lack of local engagement runs deeper than that.
fields.trailText: Chelsea field a team without a British player. So? The lack of local engagement runs deeper than that.
fields.body:
Many people are upset about the fact that Chelsea's team that succumbed to Lazio on Wednesday night did not contain a single English or British player. It's "a nonsense" according to at least one prominent commentator on Radio 5 Live.

It's understandable that questions will be asked when clubs such as Chelsea, Arsenal, Liverpool and Newcastle field teams full of foreigners. Yet it's hard to pin the responsibility for it on anyone in particular. It is not part of Gianluca Vialli's job description to operate a quota system in his team. He is charged with winning trophies and if he does so then who is to say that he should have bought more English players - especially considering the performance of the one he has invested in?

The row about foreigners is really to do with a more general alienation of the biggest clubs from their fans. Chelsea, to take the most prominent example, have never fielded teams that in any way 'represent' their local area. The club's first manager was a Scot and their early teams set a trend for importing from Scotland that was maintained until the departure of Craig Burley and John Spencer in the Gullit era.

The difference now is that other ties that bind clubs to their immediate communities - never strong in Chelsea's case anyway - have also been loosened. Even if the old stories about players travelling to the match on the bus are overplayed, there is no doubt that the top stars have become more remote from the fans, and even from journalists.

The players' lifestyle and their more frequent moves from club to club increasingly place them in a world of their own. Although Chelsea, forever contrary, can at least point to a high degree of stability in the presence of Petrescu, Di Matteo, Leboeuf, Zola and Vialli himself since 1996 or earlier.

The clubs themselves have compounded this sense of alienation through their pricing policies, their obsession with marketing and flirtations with the stock market. At the very biggest clubs, traditional community-oriented activities such as hospital visits and coaching in local schools have taken a very poor second place in the clubs' priorities to commercially-driven events. Chelsea, following Ken Bates's ambition to become 'the Manchester United of the south' have opened their first megastore outlet away from the ground - in Guildford, Surrey.

United like to point to the large number of locally born players in their all-conquering team. Yet they share with Chelsea and a host of other wannabee corporate giants a lack of engagement with anything else that relates to the local area or to the real life of so many of their fans. That is a much more serious failing for the long-term future of the game than the birthplaces of Chelsea's Euro-pretenders.

webTitle: Halifax buys into St James's Place

fields.headline: Halifax buys into St James's Place
fields.standfirst: www.halifax.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Halifax said yesterday it is to spend £760m on buying a 60% stake in life assurance and pensions group St James's Place in an attempt to grab a bigger share of the lucrative "higher net worth" market.
fields.body:
The Halifax said yesterday it is to spend £760m on buying a 60% stake in life assurance and pensions group St James's Place in an attempt to grab a bigger share of the lucrative "higher net worth" market.

The bank has acquired 15.8% of the St James's shares from its largest shareholder, Prudential - the company that only a few months ago was being tipped by some as likely to mount a takeover bid for St James's Place.

St James's specialises in life insurance, pensions and unit trusts, and has 350,000 customers, typically earning in excess of £40,000 a year. It runs J Rothschild Assurance, which has a 1,000-strong salesforce providing financial advice to high net worth customers.

The deal forms the latest plank in the Halifax's strategy of attempting to reduce its dependence on its core savings and mortgage activities. As well as representing "a diversification in terms of customer type," the acquisition also boosts the bank's share of the life and pensions market.

"It is a very exciting way for us to increase our presence in the higher net worth area," said Halifax's chief executive, James Crosby, who conceded that this had been "not the strongest area of our operations".

The two companies said they were joining forces to combine personal advice with the opportunities offered by new technology.

St James's will remain an independently managed and separately listed public company, and will start a private bank utilising the Halifax's "Intelligent Finance" product range and technology platform. Intelligent Finance is the internet bank unveiled by the Halifax last month which is due to go live in July.

Halifax said the recommended partial offer to buy 60% of the shares at 300p each values the group at £1.26bn and represents a premium of 30% over Tuesday's closing price.

 Prudential yesterday announced it was transferring £12bn worth of institutional fund management mandates to Deutsche Asset Management following a strategic decision to focus its asset management business on unit trusts, pooled life and pension funds, and specialist bond fund management.

fields.headline: Bringing Amazon to book
fields.trailText: O'Dixion DigiCopier DG1-12X | Amazon.com (Get Big Fast) by Robert Spector
fields.body:
Amazon.com (Get Big Fast) by Robert Spector Random House £18.99

Amazon is still the corporate superstar of the internet age. It virtually invented the dot.com culture. But, nearly five years on, the jury is out on whether it will dominate the world or be devoured by its own hubris.

Driven by the "maniacally focused" Jeff Bezos, its market capitalisation hit $28bn at one point last year. Yet in the third quarter of 1999 it made a loss of $197m on sales of $356m.

No one can question the sheer scale of Bezos' achievement in creating the web's first global brand out of such a fragmented industry as book publishing. At the end of 1999, according to Forrester Research, it was rated the best website for music, videos, toys and games as well as books even though it had had less success in becoming the dominant brand in non-book areas.

Yet there is always this feeling that it could fly a little bit too high and, like Icarus, fall from the sky with melting wings. Failure could come from the financial markets getting fed up with the company's failure to make a profit in an area where huge scale is needed to compensate for thin profit margins. Or because Amazon's click-thick loyalty is hi-jacked by fledgling competitors. One such company, Buy.com, is programmed to scan Amazon's prices and automatically undercut them. And no one can undercut Amazon's prices more effectively than book publishers themselves - if they ever managed to get their act together.

Brand loyalty to Amazon isn't like that to Coca Cola - embedded in the product - it is attached to a quality and reliability of service that has to be kept up 24 hours a day.

It will if Bezos has anything to do with it, and it's worth reading this book (despite its frequent bobbysoxing approach and lack of an index) just to see why driven entrepreneurs like him are different from the rest of us. One close observer called him "the most single-mindedly focused person I have ever met - to his detriment, it's all he cares about".

If future historians want to know why Amazon got there first rather than, say, a UK-based electronic alternative such as Bookpages (which provided access to a cool 1.2m books but was bought up by Amazon) they need look no further than Bezos. He has managed to keep the company afloat partly because so much of the equity capital is kept by him and his family but also because his cashflow is helped by the fact that Amazon often receives the money for books before it has even ordered them. This gives it up to 33 days use of customers' money before having to pay suppliers.

That's an old and proven business model. Bezos has yet to prove that his new Get Big Fast philosophy will make Amazon.com a permanent global force - or just a big corporate carcass for the second movers to chew over.

webTitle: Anthony Mann: Man of the West

fields.headline: Anthony Mann: Man of the West
fields.trailText: Mann ...never glorified violence but set it within the context of his stories. He was a film-maker who, at his best, could be compared to anyone in matching the power of his images with his blunt version of psychological truth
fields.body:
When Anthony Mann died in 1967, he was planning a Western King Lear, with sons replacing the daughters. This long-cherished project might have turned out to be a classic, since no director of Westerns made them nearer to classical tragedy - and Mann had a feeling for landscape to equal John Ford. The best also reveal in their protagonists an acute sense of human fallibility and self-doubt.

Many of the Westerns directed by Mann in the 50s, such as Winchester 73 and The Man From Laramie, starred James Stewart. Not only did they give the actor a new lease of life; they remain outstanding within the genre. But the greatest of all, Man of the West, made in 1958, starred Gary Cooper. He was Link Jones, a reformed gunfighter who is forced to betray his new-found pacifism by annihilating one by one the gang who used to be his comrades.

The film brings to the fore all Mann's preoccupations and knits them perfectly together. Lear is paralleled by the fact that Lee J Cobb's gang leader regards Link as his favourite son and, before he realises what is happening, welcomes him back with open arms.

Link is travelling from a community he has helped build to Fort Worth to find a teacher for the new school. His train is ambushed and robbed by his former colleagues. Stranded, he is forced to return to the gang's old hideout for shelter. There he gets into a fight with one of his old friends that ends in him stripping the man of his clothes. They are both humiliated - the crook for obvious reasons, Link because he has had to resort to a violence he has come to hate. If he wants to save himself and his new life, he realises he has to deny everything he now holds dear.

The finale is inevitable: Cooper versus Cobb, and one of them will surely die. Both actors give extraordinary performances. Cooper, in real life getting sick with the cancer that was to kill him three years later, makes one last, successful effort to prove he could be a consummate screen actor and Cobb contributes a dignified performance that does not entirely preclude our sympathy.

Mann's direction is immaculate, making Reginald Rose's clearly allegorical, and sometimes forced, screenplay seem even better than it is.

Mann's career started with low-budget thrillers, progressed to Westerns, and ended with epics such as El Cid and The Fall of the Roman Empire. He never glorified violence but set it within the context of his stories. He was a film-maker who, at his best, could be compared to anyone in matching the power of his images with his blunt version of psychological truth.

webTitle: Dench to play Iris Murdoch in Eyre film of novelist's last years

fields.headline: Dench to play Iris Murdoch in Eyre film of novelist's last years
fields.trailText: A Hollywood studio is to make a film about Iris Murdoch's slow decline and death from Alzheimer's disease, based on her husband's heart-rending books about their last years together
fields.body:
A Hollywood studio is to make a film about Iris Murdoch's slow decline and death from Alzheimer's disease, based on her husband's heart-rending books about their last years together.

Dame Judi Dench will play the novelist and Oxford philosopher, who was often described as the most brilliant woman in England. The film will be written and directed by Sir Richard Eyre, the former artistic director of the National Theatre, whose own mother died of Alzheimer's six years ago.

Iris: A Memoir, John Bayley's surprise bestseller about the last years of the couple's 43-year marriage, and his subsequent book, Iris and the Friends, told how, close to the end, the woman who dominated English letters for nearly half a century could not remember her own name. She would frequently disappear from their Oxford home at night and once jumped from their car on their way back from a funeral.

Sir Richard said he was very surprised when the head of Sony Pictures, John Calley, approached him about bringing the books to the screen.

"It's not quite what you expect from Hollywood, which is very cheering in its own way," he said. But he admitted to having doubts about whether they could make a film that could do justice to the beauty of Bayley's unsparing portrait of what the disease does to its victims and those who care for them.

"One of the things I find so moving about John's books is they are about a love story. The sense of obligation he felt to take care of someone he loved became a kind of joy for him in the end. I'm afraid I can't say that was the case for me with my mother," he said.

Unlike Murdoch, who began showing symptoms only a few years before she died, his own mother suffered for 20 years. "It's a terrible thing. No one really knew what Alzheimer's was then, they thought she had pre-senile dementia. I hate it when people say 'I must be getting Alzheimer's' when they forget something. It is an awful thing to witness. You watch the sense of self just disappear."

Bayley, 74, who is about to marry Audi Villers, a Norwegian widow and "dear friend" of Murdoch's, has given the film his blessing.

Sir Richard said that although he has not yet finished the script he hopes to shoot in Britain in the autumn.

"We want to find a way of making a coherent film that is bearable to watch, which in itself is a difficult task. This is a film which will not have an unlimited audience but it is a studio film, so that will help to bring it to a wider audience."

webTitle: Leadership contest plunges unionists in crisis

fields.headline: Leadership contest plunges unionists in crisis
fields.trailText: David Trimble is today facing a challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionists from a leading opponent of the Good Friday agreement. The Rev Martin Smyth declared that he would stand against Mr Trimble during a meeting of the party's council this weekend.
fields.body:
David Trimble is today facing a challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionists from a leading opponent of the Good Friday agreement. The Rev Martin Smyth declared that he would stand against Mr Trimble during a meeting of the party's council this weekend.

The challenge brings Mr Trimble's leadership to its most critical stage since he took the Ulster Unionists into a power-sharing government with Sinn Fein last November, and polarises the battle within the party between supporters and opponents of the Good Friday deal.

Supporters of Mr Trimble immediately dismissed the challenge as an unnecessary distraction, but Mr Smyth claimed to represent a growing body of opinion in the party. Mr Trimble's comments in Washington on St Patrick's Day, when he suggested the unionists could return to government with Sinn Fein before the decommissioning of IRA arms, provoked anger in the anti-agreement faction of the UUP.

Launching his challenge today, the South Belfast MP, who contested the leadership against Mr Trimble in 1995, said it was "time for a more vigorous promotion of Ulster Unionist policies". Mr Smyth, who is a former Grand Master of the Orange Order, was backed by the dissident Ulster Unionist MP William Ross, who said his colleague would unite the UUP and the wider unionist community.

But a close ally of Mr Trimble, the Fermanagh and South Tyrone MP Ken Maginnis, insisted the party leader would "not be toppled". But Mr Maginnis admitted: "His position internally will be weakened, his eye will be taken off the ball and we will have to engage in a reunification of the party after the contest."

Tony Blair, the prime minister, immediately lent tacit support to Mr Trimble. At a summit of European Union leaders in Portugal, he said: "It's obviously a very clear choice for people and the Ulster Unionist party will make its mind up, but I have got a very great deal of respect for David Trimble and the enormous courage he has shown in trying to give people a peaceful future in Northern Ireland."

Mr Smyth's leadership challenge comes during a week of tension in the Ulster Unionist party in the run-up to its council meeting in Belfast on Saturday.

Anti-agreement unionist Jonathan Bell quit the party last Friday after Mr Trimble's comments in Washington. Mr Trimble, however, insists he has not shifted from party policy set last November prior to the formation of the province's devolved power-sharing executive.

Mr Trimble has repeatedly said in recent days that he would be prepared to go back into government with Sinn Fein, provided that there was a clear commitment from the IRA to a timeframe for the start and completion of decommissioning.

As well as the challenge to his leadership on Saturday, Mr Trimble is facing a difficult motion which calls for any return to government to be linked with the preservation of the name and symbols of the Royal Ulster Constabulary.

A report on the future of the RUC by the former Hong Kong governor, Chris Patten, angered many unionists by recommending that the force be renamed and reconstituted. But Mr Trimble told a Dublin newspaper today that the plan to link the executive with the battle to save the RUC was "ill-advised".

Mr Smyth today confirmed he would be backing the motion, and declared he would not return to a power-sharing administration with any party which retained an armed wing. "Many people in Northern Ireland are concerned and they want an opportunity to express that in a democratic way," he said.

"I'm not a stalking horse. I have no real desire to be leader of a party. But on the other hand, if a call comes from the party through this vote on Saturday, then I'm prepared to serve the party and the people."

fields.headline: From zero to dot.com
fields.standfirst: If you've got nothing but a great idea, can you still make it as an e-warrior?  Josephine Monroe, co-founder of the-bullet.com, explains how to do it
fields.trailText: If you've got nothing but a great idea, can you still make it as an e-warrior? Josephine Monroe, co-founder of the-bullet.com, explains how to do it
fields.body:
If the headlines are to be believed, starting a business on the internet goes something like this: you have a great idea for a site, you are rich enough to be able to quit your job, and technically advanced enough to build your own site before a venture capitalist invests a few million quid for a 10% equity stake. At this point the papers start writing about you, people visit your site in droves and you float on the stock market for £200m.

For those of us living in the real world, it's a bit more like this: you have a great idea for a site. You get hold of some software from a net magazine's free CD and have a go at building your own site. You work harder than you've ever done in your life... and no one visits your site. Certainly not an investor.

So how can someone without useful parents and the right degree make a business work on the web? First of all you need to resign yourself to the fact that it will be harder and take longer than you first thought.

But that doesn't mean it's impossible to build an empire from your bedroom. The first - and most important - thing is make sure that your idea is as robust as it can be. Spend time brainstorming to make sure it really is as brilliant as you originally thought. Identify every possible revenue stream and work out how to exploit them.

This is essential if your site is ever going to make serious money as no investor will take you on unless you can demonstrate that your idea holds the keys to the bank's vaults. You also have to make sure that you can provide your site with all the love and attention it needs: you need to supply the content - be it text on pruning roses or the best deals on discounted goods - and be able to build and manage the site and the associated business (fulfilling orders etc).

You will also need time - every entrepreneur you meet will tell you how hard they work - and the support of the people around you.

Let's assume your idea is absolutely brilliant and you know that if you could just get the ear of an investment consultant at 3i, the money would be in the bank by the end of the week. But as you have no contacts and no track record, sadly, the best way to get investment is to show that you can do it without investment.

It's sod's law, but it's true. You have to build your own site as best you can and find a way of showing that your idea works in the real world, as well as in your head.

If your idea is too complex to build without funding, focus on one aspect of the business you can build and that gives enough of an idea to investors of the full picture. It's possible to build a site with free software from magazine covers and downloads from the net. A good place to start is www.netmag.co.uk/software/default.asp which supplies free software from .net magazine, but paying for a user-friendly Wysiwyg (what you see is what you get) programme like Dreamweaver or Go Live might be a smart investment (you can download free trial versions).

Building a site takes time and is incredibly frustrating, but you will learn so much and understand your business so much better for persevering. If you need to call in a professional designer, do as you would for a decorator: go by recommendation.

You can get your site hosted for free by your internet service provider (eg Demon or Freeserve), but shop around for a hosting service that will put you on a good server (ie one that will allow your site to download quickly). It should also offer good technical support - vital if you're a small team without good technical skills. It's also worth shopping around the domain registry sites, try www.netnames.co.uk or www.uk2.net to get the best deal on a good, memorable URL. (uniform resource locator).

Now tell people about your site. Networking is the most important thing you can do. Tell the postman, tell the other people in the queue at the supermarket - tell absolutely everyone you can think of. Join a networking group like FirstTuesday, Surfs Up or Boobnight and find out what other people are doing, see if they can help out, or if you can help them. Make allies and as many introductions as you can. Evangelise about your site and convert everyone you meet. If you don't do it, no one else will. There is a good networking tradition in the internet and investors will expect you to make the most of the opportunities it can provide.

You also need to tell your potential users about the site and - as everyone will tell you - good marketing is the real driver of internet success. Think creatively about ways to do your marketing cheaply. Think about who your users are, where they shop, where they work, what they read and what other sites they might use. Is there another company that already targets your audience and whose contacts you could use? Or is there an event or seminar where you could hand out leaflets?

It's a waste of your time sending press releases to the national press unless you've got a really good story for them: simply launching another site is not news to most journalists. And don't forget to use the internet. There's a lot of ambivalence about the effectiveness of banner exchanges and reciprocal links - but they are often free and if you can scratch backs with enough sites with which you have some synergy it can help get your brand and web address into circulation.

Try to get hold of your potential users' email addresses (this is much easier if your idea is for a business-to-business application) and send them some promotional material. Make it worth their while - are there special offers you can motivate them with, or prizes you can give away? Make sure you get a good listing on the search engines. Take a look at www.searchenginewatch.com for tips on how to get a good listing and keep plugging away until you come out on top. Again, this is very frustrating but a site with a low ranking is never going to make money.

After a few months of serious marketing, you should start to get a steady flow of traffic. Hopefully this will be enough to get some advertisers on board, but it won't be easy. The big agencies like 24/7 and Doubleclick won't be interested in you unless you have several hundred thousand page impressions a month, which means you will probably have to sell some space yourself. While the income will be nice, it will be more important for showing venture capitalists that there is a genuine appetite to advertise on your site.

You're now ready to approach financiers. You will need a business plan that outlines your idea, that makes clear why you're the best person to do it and how much money you will need. Crucially, it must also tell investors how much money they're going to make. There are loads of websites and books that will help you do this (the links section of www.toptechnology.co.uk and www.bvca.co.uk - the Venture Capital association - are good places to start), but getting your plan noticed by a VC, incubator or business angel is another matter.

Getting someone to make an introduction on your behalf is a big help but if you don't have the contacts, the internet is your greatest ally. Almost all investors have websites which specify the kind of businesses they're interested in, the amounts of money they invest and the names of the people to send business plans to. Even so raising finance, despite what the headlines say, is hard. For every 100 business plans read, four meetings take place and one idea gets funded. But maybe, just maybe, it will be yours.

 Josephine Monroe, co-founder of the-bullet.com the-bullet.com

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Double trouble

It's difficult to be lovable when you're a double-glazing salesman. However pure their souls, they are damned as a species, deservedly so in the opinion of N Hameed from London. She and her husband ordered a set of windows from BAC in Sutton last November. They needed them before Christmas but the installation team turned up with the wrong units. BAC promised to contact her with a new date but two weeks later she had heard nothing and tried vainly to cancel the contract. BAC's response was written confirmation of a new installation date in January, but when the day dawned the firm denied ever having suggested it. Another date in February was confirmed by letter, then that too was cancelled and Hameed was told someone would call with an alternative. After three months of waiting and no end in sight Hameed tried for a third time to cancel the order. This time BAC agreed, but insisted on keeping her £395 deposit to offset its "considerable costs and disbursements".

 "A contract was entered into and cannot be broken," insists Geoff Coomber, BAC's sales liaison manager. "We had a problem with the manufacture of their units and the order went wrong. We offered to install the wrong units anyway while we were there in December, but that would have meant coming back to install the proper units at a later date and the customer refused." He does, he says, quite understand why the Hameeds were disinclined to take two sets of days off work to accommodate two sets of workmen, which is why he has allowed them to cancel their contract "outside their terms and conditions".

"I hear what you're saying that it's unreasonable to withold what is probably a large sum for them and a small one for us, but it's a principle involved. It's not unreasonable that they should suffer something after our extraordinary gesture in allowing them to cancel," he says. The Hameeds would be advised to consult their local trading standards authority.

Paradise lost

Earlier this month we alerted readers to a US company called Bahamas & Florida Direct which cold-calls householders and offers them discounted holiday packages. The catch? You only get to see a brochure once you've made a firm booking and given your credit card details over the phone. The idea is you get a refund if you cancel within seven days of receiving the brochure. Alas, that didn't happen for JB Dewar, whose plight we reported. She has now been joined by Michael Collins of Alnwick, Northumberland, and Patrick Manning of London. Collins had to call three times before the brochure arrived and once afterwards to obtain missing pages. "It took three weeks to arrive, so when I queried a refund I was told I was too late." Manning tried in vain to telephone the company as soon as his brochure arrived but found the number constantly engaged. A letter of cancellation sent recorded delivery has elicited no reply.

Meanwhile the Association of British Travel Agents (ABTA), which was investigating Dewar's complaint, has announced that Florida Direct has suddenly resigned its membership. "We had had a number of complaints about the company - considerably more than we might expect," says a spokesman.

 Bahamas & Florida Direct are two companies using the same name; one in the US, which sells the packages and runs the customer services, and one based in London, which processes the reservations. The US branch insists all refunds are sent out if requested within seven days, except in the case of Dewar, and refers us to Martin Furner, director of the UK company. He admits that the volume of customers and a problem with phone lines has caused difficulties and promises to look into the cases.

"There were a couple of people in the US who were telling customers that they couldn't have refunds, but they have been dismissed," he says. "Refunds have been sloppy in the US and we're telling them we can't continue to do business with them if they don't get their act together." He also admits that the US sales operators can be heavy-handed with customers: "We've persuaded them to tone it down a bit - if you ask for a refund they'll try to offer you discounts and do anything to sell the package."

The reason the firm departed from ABTA so abruptly is, he says, perfectly innocent. Because of its plans to expand through Europe, membership of the Travel Trust Association was deemed more suitable. And why make customers book before receiving a brochure? "It's how they do it in the US," he says.

Supply and demands

Peter Maguire shifted his electricity supplier from Eastern Energy to Independent Energy, then found himself being billed by both. Eastern argued that it could not terminate his account until Independent notified them of the switch. Independent, which couldn't even come up with a customer reference number for Maguire, seemed unequal to the task and continued to mumble that it had probably done so already.

 Awed by the spectre of Consumer, Independent Energy hastily contacts Maguire, admits blame and promises to refund him his excess payments. Maguire tells them he will now be sticking with his former supplier. Refund cheques arrive almost immediately along with a statement confiming he is fully paid up. Then the following day comes a billet doux from Independent demanding £90 for the next payment period!

C&W: calls still waiting

Poor Cable & Wireless is being plagued once again by phantoms - big-spending phantoms at that. Jonathan Darkin of Clapham is among those to be haunted. He had asked our favourite firm to install a cable television line in his home and was told it was routine to install a phone line as well in case it was required in the future. That line was never activated since Darkin had his account elsewhere, but that did not stop C&W billing him £20 for calls he had never made. He complained by phone and letter but the only response was another bill - this one for £504, for international calls at all hours of the night. "Whenever I speak to anyone from C&W they tell me they're investigating and will contact me on my C&W number, which doesn't exist."

Leon Kreft of Norwich, too, requires an electronic exorcism. Last November his C&W line went dead; the following morning he received a bill itemising numerous international calls that he had never made. After three frustrating calls from his BT line, an engineer was dispatched and found a crossed line was to blame. Since then the only communication from C&W has been a reminder bill and the promise of a return call - which never came.

 Customary penitence from C&W, which says the charges have now been cancelled Kreft and Darkin's accounts. "In Mr Kreft's case a fault on his line caused interference and unrecognised calls," says a spokeswoman. "Mr Darkin's incorrect bill was due to a problem with the cabinet, which routes calls into customers' homes. We apologise to both of them."

Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 0171-713 4731, send a fax on 0171-239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

Independent, which couldn't even come up with a customer reference number for Maguire, seemed unequal to the task and continued to mumble that it had probably done so already.  Awed by the spectre of Consumer, Independent Energy hastily contacts Maguire, admits blame and promises to refund him his excess payments. Maguire tells them he will now be sticking with his former supplier. Refund cheques arrive almost immediately along with a statement confiming he is fully paid up. Then the following day comes a billet doux from Independent demanding £90 for the next payment period! C&W: calls still waiting Poor Cable & Wireless is being plagued once again by phantoms - big-spending phantoms at that. Jonathan Darkin of Clapham is among those to be haunted. He had asked our favourite firm to install a cable television line in his home and was told it was routine to install a phone line as well in case it was required in the future. That line was never activated since Darkin had his account elsewhere, but that did not stop C&W billing him £20 for calls he had never made. He complained by phone and letter but the only response was another bill - this one for £504, for international calls at all hours of the night. "Whenever I speak to anyone from C&W they tell me they're investigating and will contact me on my C&W number, which doesn't exist." Leon Kreft of Norwich, too, requires an electronic exorcism. Last November his C&W line went dead; the following morning he received a bill itemising numerous international calls that he had never made. After three frustrating calls from his BT line, an engineer was dispatched and found a crossed line was to blame. Since then the only communication from C&W has been a reminder bill and the promise of a return call - which never came.  Customary penitence from C&W, which says the charges have now been cancelled Kreft and Darkin's accounts. "In Mr Kreft's case a fault on his line caused interference and unrecognised calls," says a spokeswoman. "Mr Darkin's incorrect bill was due to a problem with the cabinet, which routes calls into customers' homes. We apologise to both of them." fields.headline: Fletcher steps down at Newcastle
fields.trailText: Newcastle United plc today announced a major boardroom shuffle that will see Freddie Fletcher step down as chairman and chief executive.
fields.byline: By Football Unlimited staff and agencies
fields.body:
Newcastle United plc today announced a major boardroom shuffle that will see Freddie Fletcher step down as chairman and chief executive.

Sunderland finance director David Stonehouse will become chief executive from April 3 while John Fender, currently an independent non-executive director, will be appointed non-executive chairman.

Fletcher will end his full-time executive duties from the end of May and become a non-executive director. Meanwhile, Les Wheatley is resigning as finance director and chief operating officer to take up the role as director of finance at Liverpool.

fields.headline: The gong show
fields.standfirst: We all know that the Oscars are prone to the odd 'hitch' - the theft of one or two statuettes, say, or the disappearance of a few ballot papers. But someone has to make sure it's alright on the night.  Lucy Barrick  spoke to the man in charge
fields.trailText: We all know that the Oscars are prone to the odd 'hitch' - the theft of one or two statuettes, say, or the disappearance of a few ballot papers. But someone has to make sure it's alright on the night. Lucy Barrick spoke to the man in charge.
fields.body:
A couple of weeks ago, I spoke to Bruce Davis, executive director of The Academy Of Motion Picture Arts And Sciences: in simpler terms, as he puts it, he's the man "who makes sure everything goes smoothly with the almost year-round preparations for the Oscars". At the time, I asked him what level of intensity the aforementioned preparations had reached. He laughed and replied "You could say we're finding things to do here."

Well, they might have been busy then, but in the intervening weeks Bruce and his merry band have had to first contend with several thousand ballots going AWOL somewhere in the US postal system; and then the disappearance of a job lot of Oscar statuettes, later discovered hidden in an Los Angeles dumpster.

Davis, who's more used to working behind the scenes, had to face the cameras himself a few times to explain those little hitches. But, hey, the problems did get solved - so presumably he must be doing something right.

But what exactly is it that qualifies someone to organise the Oscars, to cope with the tantrums, the lost ballots and the missing statuettes? Even at the crack of dawn in LA, Davis is a picture of self-possession.

Promoted to his current job in 1989, Davis makes a clear distinction between his role ("I'm in charge of the paid staff") and that of the president of the academy - "the leader of the artists that make up the membership" - whose past incumbents include Bette Davis, Gregory Peck and, more recently, Arthur Hiller and Karl Malden. So, while the president gets to swan about being a glamorous figurehead for the awards and "appointing a producer, getting together a staff of writers, thinking of a host for the show", Davis and his staff are in charge of, well, pretty much everything else.

One major chore overseen as part of this grab-bag of responsibilities is the screening of all the eligible titles to Academy members, and the collection of their votes (or not, as the case may be). Studios keen to get their pictures some Oscar-winning kudos fill the pages of Screen International and Variety with over-the-top advertisements recommending films and stars "for your consideration". Does Davis think people are affected by this uniquely cunning ploy?

"Contrary to what the press sometimes likes to suggest," he chuckles, "do you really think Martin Scorsese is going to look at an ad and say 'Well, this says this guy here is the best director, so I'd better vote for him'? These are people with extremely strong views about what they do, and they take it very seriously." So are people expected to vote for their favourite work in each category, or that which they think constitutes the best "achievement"?

"I think they vote for the job of work", Davis muses. "If you're an art director and you see a marvellous example of work in your field, even if it's not your style, you'd still vote for it." Well, that's the theory.

Meanwhile, the world at large is now all-too-familiar with the kind of mishaps which can befall Mr Oscar before his big night; the question is whether Davis and his team have contingency plans in the case of a hypothetical disaster on Sunday night itself?

"We do a lot of that," he acknowledges, "from fire and flood to presenters who don't show, but that hasn't happened for many years." He also admits that "it's a very paranoia-inducing process. Imagine staging an enormously complicated Broadway show, with very little rehearsal, which goes out live all around the world and closes after one night." Under such conditions, Davis confesses, "I tend not to be very good company. I obsess over time, like: 'We only gave out two awards in half an hour and now we have 18 more and three musical numbers!'"

But Davis's biggest problem on the night - barring a repeat of Marlon Brando's infamous 1972 dispatching of a faux-Native American squaw to pick up his award for The Godfather - must be acceptance speeches over-running (don't cry Gwyneth, it's not just you). What does he do about that?

Ever the diplomat, he refuses to name names, but does remark that "the unspoken rule is this - if you're saying something witty or wise, no one's going to play you off. But if you bring out a list a mile long of people you could just as easily call up on the phone, well that's not entertainment, and it's time to strike up the band!"

Finally, I ask him the only question that really needs answering - who's going to win then?

"Most people assume I know," he coughs, "and it is absolutely true - that I do not. No one in the Academy, not even the president, has any idea of the winners until those envelopes are opened on stage."

But he must have a personal favourite?

"Yes. Yes, I do. And, whatever else I'm going to do, I'm certainly, definitely not going to mention them."

 The Oscars ceremony will be shown live on Monday morning from 1am on Sky Premier, plus live coverage throughout the night on Film Unlimited.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the transfer deadline day tittle-tattle on one easy-to-read page
fields.trailText: The Sun Arsenal want West Ham winger Trevor Sinclair as a £6m replacement for Barcelona-bound Marc Overmars. Arsene Wenger will offer Davor Suker and Nigel Winterburn as additional bait.
fields.body:
The Sun Arsenal want West Ham winger Trevor Sinclair as a £6m replacement for Barcelona-bound Marc Overmars. Arsene Wenger will offer Davor Suker and Nigel Winterburn as additional bait.

Opta Soccer Manchester United are lining up a big-money bid for Internazionale's Alvaro Recoba. The Uruguayan international has scored eight goals in nine Serie A starts this season.

Bryne defender Ragnvald Soma is a target for Middlesbrough. Bryan Robson will make a £600,000 bid for the Norwegian Under-21 international next week. Robson may also move for Torquay United defender Wayne Thomas.

Leicester will make a pre-deadline move for Crystal Palace striker Clinton Morrison.

Liverpool are ready to pay £3m for Tranmere's 18-year-old goalkeeper Joe Murphy. They will try to sign him before today's transfer deadline, but are prepared to wait until next season.

Daily Mail Alex Ferguson will offer Tottenham Nicky Butt as part of Manchester United's £14m push for the services of Sol Campbell.

Fulham are set to join Sunderland and Middlesbrough in the £3m race for the signature of Everton's Scottish international midfielder Don Hutchison. Sunderland have already had a £1m bid rejected.

Daily Star Wimbledon will today sign Spurs keeper Espen Baardsen for £3m. The 22-year-old is frustrated at being second choice behind Ian Walker at White Hart Lane and is ready to replace Neil Sullivan, who is a target for Arsenal, Manchester United and Celtic.

Teddy Sheringham is certain to quit Manchester United in the summer. West Ham, Charlton and Fulham are ready to match the two-year contract offered by Real Mallorca, Celta Vigo and Sporting Lisbon.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Nicole Kidman and Rupert Everett poised to commit, Helena Bonham-Carter signs for lovestruck ghost role, David Fincher considering The Panic Room, and Oliver Stone and Kevin Costner play movie musical chairs
fields.body:
 Nicole Kidman and Rupert Everett could star as a glamorous couple at large in 1920s Paris, Variety reports. The pair are said to be poised to commit to USA Films adaptation of Everybody Was So Old, currently being given a final polish by ace screenwriter John Guare (Six Degrees of Separation). Everybody Was So Old is based on the acclaimed biography by Amanda Vail about Gerald and Sara Murphy, a wealthy New York couple who became muses for the "lost generation" of the Left Bank. The Murphy's were painted by Picasso and are thought to have directly inspired characters created by both John Dos Passos and Ernest Hemingway.

 Helena Bonham Carter will play a lovestruck ghost in the independently financed comedy-drama Till Human Voices Wake Us. The Truly, Madly, Deeply-esque production is about a dead woman who haunts the life of her childhood sweetheart.

 Having recently fallen out of the frame on the Spiderman picture, David Fincher is rumoured to be considering directing The Panic Room, a siege thriller about a mother and son held hostage in their apartment by a bunch of runaway criminals.

 Having once collaborated so memorably on JFK, Oliver Stone and Kevin Costner currently appear to be circling each other in a protracted round of movie musical chairs. The pair were originally going to work together on Stone's torrid love-story Beyond Borders, with Costner starring opposite Catherine Zeta Jones. Then Zeta Jones jumped ship to take a supporting role in Steven Soderbergh's Traffic. Costner bailed from the project and begun negotiations to star in both Traffic and Disney's elephantine Pearl Harbor. With Beyond Borders apparently dead in the water, Stone dropped the project and begun developing a moderinsed remake of A Star is Born, starring his Any Given Sunday discovery Jamie Foxx. The latest reports, though, suggest that Costner has drifted back to Beyond Borders on the condition that Stone signs on as director. Hollywood deal-making, it appears, has truly descended to the level of gauche playground flirting.

fields.headline: Skills shortage may cost Europe £37bn
fields.standfirst: Can the might of Microsoft convince the EU of the desperate need to train IT professionals? asks  Steve Shipside
fields.trailText: Can the might of Microsoft convince the EU of the desperate need to train IT professionals? asks Steve Shipside
fields.body:
Between now and 2003 Western Europe stands to lose € 380 billion (£232.3bn) due to the shortage of skilled IT staff. That's the message Microsoft hopes to have preached from the EU presidential pulpit as Portugal takes over leadership of the European Union.

The figure comes from studies undertaken by researchers Datamonitor, IDC, and Goldman Sachs which, put together, read like a rather grim good news/bad news joke both for the IT industry and the economy in general. The good news, according to a Goldman Sachs report entitled The Shocking Economic Effect Of B2B, is that business to business (B2B) e-commerce has the potential to increase GDP by 5%over two decades. Better yet says Datamonitor, productivity gains alone from IT could boost EU GDP by 1.5% through 2002.

The bad news is that those figures are dependent on the European countries coming up with an estimated 1.7 million IT professionals who are currently nowhere to be found. As well as losing out on productivity, the EU is set to miss out on € 60bn (£36.7bn) in tax revenue (personal and corporation) over the next three years unless it plugs the skills gap.

The punchline to the joke is that figures from IDC see demand for IT professionals in the EU topping 13.07 million by 2003, while the supply of same is expected to reach 11.33 million at best. The argument of Microsoft and much of the IT industry is that if the EU is going to put full employment at the top of its wish list, then for the sake of commerce and of its own coffers it should focus on plugging the skills gap.

True, only 5%of the EU workforce is employed in IT, but with an average annual wage of € 48,000 (£29,341), compared with the average annual wage of € 28,700 (£17,543), they contribute heavily in tax. Ironically, as the skills shortage continues, and those wages rise, their individual worth to the EU increases correspondingly. In short, expensive though it may be to train IT staff, their return, both direct and indirect, makes it eminently desirable to cultivate them as the cash cows of GDP.

These were the figures announced to 150 representatives of the EC, national governments, policy makers, growth companies and ITC companies' assembled in Brussels at the summit on technology, innovation, and skills training earlier this month. The purpose of the summit was to develop a call to action to be presented to the special European council in Lisbon addressing impediments to European competitiveness and employment where, it is hoped, measures will be considered to redress the potential lost opportunities of the IT skills gap.

With such figures highlight ing the public interests at stake, it came as little surprise to see public/private training partnerships being proposed as the solution, along with certification, tax incentives, and reforms to the education systems of member states.

In order to encourage the entrepreneur culture, the summit also called for bankruptcy law reform to stop failed ventures being so harshly penalised, and investment incentives to encourage the venture capital community. Tax breaks on equity holdings, and the simplification of pensions/NI to allow IT workers easier roaming around Europe were also listed as core elements of a future strategy. The recommendations seemed to largely find favour with those assembled, which was lucky really, since despite being billed as a summit "to develop a call to action" it turned out that Microsoft (the sponsor) had opted to streamline the consultation process. So streamlined in fact, that the entire Call To Action had been completed, and, indeed, printed, before the summit began.

Only the Lisbon summit will tell to what extent the Call To Action is taken on board, but Microsoft may not find it as easy to set the agenda when faced with the upper echelons of the Eurocracy. The last speaker of the day was Allan Larsson, the EC's director general for employment and social affairs. Evidently stung by the inference of the statistics which were being bandied about, he clearly rebutted any implication that the EU might have neglected the issues of the skills gap in the past. Sadly that was the end of any clarity.

After absolving Brussels, the bureaucrat continued to talk with a lucidity and confidence and gravitas that very nearly masked the lack of content or commitment.

If there was disquiet at Microsoft's control of the agenda, it was largely rationalised by the need to add weight to the issue at the highest level. It remains to be seen whether the bulk of the world's largest company is enough to tell with the powers that be in Portugal later this month.

webTitle: Oscar theft suspect walks free - for now

fields.headline: Oscar theft suspect walks free - for now
fields.trailText: LA County prosecutors have released one of the two men they arrested for the theft of 55 Oscar statuettes over the weekend
fields.body:
LA County prosecutors have released one of the two men they arrested for the theft of 55 Oscar statuettes over the weekend. Roadway Express docker Anthony Hart, 38, was allowed to walk free late Tuesday night due to a current lack of evidence linking him to the robbery. He remains at large, said LA County spokesmen, "pending further investigation". Meanwhile, his suspected partner in crime, Roadway Express driver Lawrence Ledent, 38, continues to cool his heels in prison. Both men had been arrested by police late on Saturday night and both have since been fired by their employers, Roadway.

Hart's get-out-of-jail-free coup is rumoured to have exposed a rift between the LA County prosecutors office and the Los Angeles Police Department. An LAPD spokesman was last night reported in Mr. Showbiz as pointing out that "we do the investigation and it's their job to charge them. They have given us no reason why they have let him go."

Amid all the confusion, Ledent's attorney, Jay Joffe, continues to protest his client's innocence. "Mr Ledent did not steal these Oscars," claims Joffe. "Mr Ledent is a dupe in this matter. The Oscars were placed in his truck without his knowledge." Ledent has pleaded not guilty to a charge of grand theft and his hearing is set for April 18. In a true-life tale that seems destined for Hollywood treatment itself, the stolen statues were uncovered and returned to the authortites by an impoverished 61 year-old garbage man named Willie Fulgear, who may qualify for a $50,000 reward. But there's just one fly spoiling this ointment. Three of the Oscars are still missing.
