In a true-life tale that seems destined for Hollywood treatment itself, the stolen statues were uncovered and returned to the authortites by an impoverished 61 year-old garbage man named Willie Fulgear, who may qualify for a $50,000 reward. But there's just one fly spoiling this ointment. Three of the Oscars are still missing.

webTitle: David Lynch to produce "crude and bad quality" cartoons for web

fields.headline: David Lynch to produce "crude and bad quality" cartoons for web
fields.trailText: The weird and wonderful career of David Lynch takes another curious twist with the news that the director of Blue Velvet and Wild at Heart is to develop a series of cartoon shorts for an American entertainment website
fields.body:
The weird and wonderful career of David Lynch takes another curious twist with the news that the director of Blue Velvet and Wild at Heart is to develop a series of cartoon shorts for an American entertainment website.

Entitled Dumbland, the cartoon series will begin as a set of fifteen films each running about three minutes in length, with further instalments screened every fortnight. Dumbland will be created using Flash, the most common mode of website animation, and will screen later this year on Shockwave.com. Describing the tone and content of the cartoons, which Lynch will script and oversee, the director was typically teasing and elusive. "It's going to be crude but sophisticatedly crude," explained Lynch. "It's very dumb and very bad quality."

The Lynch deal was announced yesterday at the Yahoo! Internet Life Online Festival in Los Angeles and highlights the film-makers continued interest in visual storytelling. Despite being widely regarded as one of America's most significant directors, Lynch originally trained as a painter and still continues to exhibit his work. At the height of his fame, he wrote and illustrated a weekly comic-strip entitled The Angriest Dog in the World, which focused on a snarling hound tethered in a dreary back-yard as disembodied voices chatted in the house nearby. When American newspapers eventually dropped the comic-strip in 1992, Lynch confessed that it was one of the biggest disappointments of his career.

webTitle: The high-school teacher who stumped Bradman - twice

fields.headline: The high-school teacher who stumped Bradman - twice
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Who was the only wicketkeeper to stump Donald Bradman in his career? asks Brian Edwards
fields.body:
Who was the only wicketkeeper to stump Donald Bradman in his career? asks Brian Edwards

Actually Bradman was out stumped 11 times in first-class cricket - twice in successive innings in 1927-28 - but never in Tests. George Duckworth and Arthur Wood, who did play for England, stumped him in first-class matches. And EA "Bill" Baker of Victoria pulled off a remarkable double in a Sheffield Shield match against South Australia at Adelaide in 1946-47: he stumped The Don in both innings. Baker was a teacher at Upwey High School outside Melbourne, and in his form at the time was Murray Hedgcock, now a distinguished sportswriter who covers events in England for The Australian newspaper. Hedgcock remembers his headmaster Bill Woodfull - himself a former Australian Test captain - announcing the latest score from the MCG to an afternoon assembly, and adding that "Mr Baker has 17 not out", to much applause.

Bradman was out hit wicket only once in his entire career - in the first Test against India at Brisbane in 1947-48. He had made 185, though, before he broke his own stumps while playing one from opposing captain Lala Amarnath. And he was run out only once in Tests, by England's Jack Hobbs at Adelaide in 1928-29, after scoring 58. In all first-class matches he was only out this way four times.

What is the highest Test score that didn't include any fours? asks Steve Telfer

The highest individual score without a boundary is 84, by Australia's Bill Lawry, in the second innings of the first Test against England at Brisbane in 1970-71. His opening partner Keith Stackpole made up for it in the first innings, with 25 fours and a six in his 207.

Which current international cricketer has the initials VVS? asks George Corston

It's Vangipurappu Venkata Sai Laxman of Hyderabad and India. He cracked a memorable 167 at Sydney in the third Test of the recent series in Australia, but was dropped from the side shortly afterwards, after a disappointing match against South Africa.

Which county was bowled out for 14 in a first-class match in 1983? asks Peter Tully

It was Surrey, bowled out in 14.3 overs by Essex at Chelmsford in May 1983. Openers Alan Butcher (2) and Grahame Clinton (6) both got off the mark, then there were six successive ducks on the scorecard - Surrey were 8 for 8 - before Graham Monkhouse (2) and Sylvester Clarke (4) got the remaining runs. Norbert Phillip took 6 for 4 and Neil Foster 4 for 10. Following on 273 behind Surrey easily averted defeat with 185 for 2 in their second innings: their captain, Roger Knight, now secretary of MCC, made 101 not out this time around.

Which famous player was Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's only first-class wicket? And what was the outcome of Dennis Lillee's last ball in Test cricket? asks Rob Robinson

Conan Doyle's only wicket was WG Grace (he later wrote a poem about it). And Lillee's last ball in Tests resulted in a wicket: Wasim Bari of Pakistan caught by Wayne Phillips. That was at Sydney in January 1984 - the last Test for three alltime Aussie greats in Lillee, Rod Marsh and Greg Chappell.

Have South Africa ever beaten Holland in any form of cricket? asks Huw Edwards

Their only meeting in an official one-day international was in the qualifying rounds of the 1996 World Cup, at Rawalpindi. It was, as you'd probably expect, a one-sided affair. South Africa ran up 328 for 3 in their 50 overs, with openers Gary Kirsten (86) and Andrew Hudson (161) putting on 186. Holland replied with 168 for 8: their top-scorer was 47-year-old Nolan Clarke with 32. Some 23 years previously Clarke had scored a century for Barbados against Mike Denness's England touring team.

I recently bumped into a Stephen Warke, who said he'd played cricket for England. However, when I told my workmates this I was nearly laughed out of town. Can you shed any light on the matter? asks Anna Mapes

Stephen John Simon Warke, who's now 40, certainly played international cricket - but not for England. He won numerous caps for Ireland, and also captained them.

Who was the West Indies spinner of Indian (not African) heritage who played a few Tests for West Indies in the 1990s? asks Trevor Utting

You may be thinking of Dinanath Ramnarine, the Trinidad & Tobago legspinner who played in two of the Tests on England's tour of West Indies in 1997-98, taking nine wickets. His only other Test cap to date came in New Zealand this winter.

Which batsman was Ian Botham's first Test wicket? asks Richard Bolton

It was Greg Chappell, Australia's captain at the time, at Trent Bridge in 1977. He inside-edged a shortish ball into his stumps to give Botham, who finished with 5 for 74 on debut, the first of his 383 Test wickets.

How can I get past issues of Wisden Cricket Monthly? I was looking for the article on John Cameron in December 1995 which is mentioned in his obituary in this month's edition? asks Nicola Tildesley

Look no further. Details of available back issues are given each month in the magazine: in the April WCM they're on page 59. The good news is that December 1995 is still available, and costs only £1 (most of the other issues cost £2.80). You should send a cheque, payable to Wisden Cricket Magazines Ltd, to Wisden, 25 Down Road, Merrow, Guildford, Surrey GU1 2PY. Back issues should soon be available on wisden.com - watch this space.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: You don't have to believe in little green men to work here. But it helps

fields.headline: You don't have to believe in little green men to work here. But it helps
fields.standfirst:
Peter Farrelly, creator of some of Tinseltown's grossest movies, tells Sam Delaney why he feels so at home in Hollywood
Film Unlimited
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Peter Farrelly, creator of some of Tinseltown's grossest movies, tells Sam Delaney why he feels so at home in Hollywood.
fields.body:
'Usually I tell people that I woke up one morning and just decided that I wanted to write," says Peter Farrelly. "But, seeing as we're here for a while, I'll give you the real version."

As you'd expect from a man who created such comic spectacles as Dumb and Dumber and There's Something About Mary, Farrelly at first comes across as a bellowing hurricane of energy and gags. Suddenly, seriousness falls over his face as he explains the origins of his screen-writing career. "When I was at high school I had a girlfriend who I was crazy about. We had our ups and downs but, to cut a long story short, she ended up falling out of a moving car while we were juniors at college. She broke her neck and died instantly. It made a big impact on me. Three years later, when I still wasn't over it, I decided that it would help if I wrote something down about her. That's how it started."

It seems odd that such a tragic event would help produce movies defined by their slapstick and engagingly juvenile humour. But then, there are several things that are unlikely about Peter Farrelly. To an extent, he plays the role of comedy writer/director to perfection: at 42, he is still floppy-haired and goatee-bearded. He wears the baggy cotton clothes of a teenage skateboarder and peppers his conversation with gags as he sits cross-legged and shoeless in his London hotel room. This, presumably, is the Peter Farrelly who has his characters drink urine and electrocute dogs. Then there's the other Peter Farrelly - the one who loses eye contact with you when he speaks about the death of his girlfriend, his horrific brush with a suicide and his teenage encounter with a UFO.

This is the Peter Farrelly who wrote The Comedy Writer, a new novel so touching, honest and cringingly believable that one can hardly believe it came from the same pen that wrote the movies. "Ah well," he comments says. "A movie is just about entertainment. Writing a book is about finding the truth. You want it to be real. When you go to a movie you're likely to sit through it unless it's really horrendous. So you've got the viewer for two hours. But if a reader is about 50 pages into a book and starts to suspect that it's a bunch of baloney, they're not going to go on. And even if they do, what have you achieved if they didn't believe it?"

In his quest for realism, Farrelly had his novel's hero, Henry Halloran, replicate many of his own experiences as a young man in Hollywood. The recently dumped Halloran turns his back on a dead-end sales job in Boston and moves to California with high hopes of selling a screenplay. Within days of arriving, he tries, and fails, to stop a woman jumping off the roof of a building. When he writes an article about the experience for the LA Times, he is contacted by the suicide victim's deeply strange sister, who latches on to him and hinders his bungling attempts to penetrate the film industry.

In a sense, it's a cautionary tale for aspiring screenwriters everywhere, although Farrelly is keen to play down his own Hollywood struggles. "I had less to lose than the character in the book," he points out. After his girlfriend's death, he became determined to find a focus in life. "By the time I was 24, I remember feeling that I would have really disappointed her," he says. "I was working as a salesman but I was horrible at it. I was nothing. So I started to pray every night. My prayer was: 'God, show me a sign of something I can do and that I will love.' After a while I got it into my head that if I wrote about her and my days at high school and college, I would see something that I would like to do."

He soon discovered a passion for the very process of writing and took what seemed like an audacious career decision. "Where I grew up, people didn't become writers," he laughs. "In my mind, it would have been just as easy to become governor. I didn't tell anyone at first because I was embarrassed by it. When I did confess, I would walk into bars and guys I knew would shout, 'Hey, Pete! C'mere! Tell Charlie what you're going to do! Fucking Hemingway here's gonna write a book!' It was a very hard thing to defend because the odds were that it wouldn't work out."

Things worked out far quicker for Farrelly than for his fictional counterpart. During his first nine years in Hollywood, he made money out of writing without actually making a movie. "It's a lot easier to sell scripts than get them made." But there was one crucial similarity between Farrelly's early days in Hollywood and those of his fictional character. "The suicide really did happen. But I had to trim it down for the book because if I told the real story no one would believe it.

What really happened was I was walking down the street near where I worked in LA and I saw a woman on a building. I was the only person around and I managed to get her down by sending the security guard up to her. I talked to her for a while and asked if she'd like to have a cup of coffee with me. She didn't want to hear it and drove away. I took her licence plate number, called the police and told them that this woman was going to kill herself and they had to contact her family or something. They said they couldn't because it would violate her civil rights. Two days later I was walking along the same street when I saw her up on the same roof. Again, I was the only person around. As soon as I saw her, she jumped. It was too weird - I couldn't write that in a book."

That ghastly coincidence is not lost on Farrelly. "I've had a few strange things like that happen to me," he says. "And because of that I'm very aware of... erm... signs."

In The Comedy Writer, Henry Halloran briefly mentions that he saw a UFO when he was young. This is another of the autobiographical details. "I did see a UFO," explains Farrelly. "I've never told this before in an interview. First of all, I'd like to say that that if I hadn't seen a flying saucer, I wouldn't believe it. But I did. And I won't deny it either."

Late one night in 1975, in his home state of Rhode Island, Farrelly was driving along with a friend when a huge rectangular object approached the car. "It was about 300 yards above us," he remembers. "It was huge and there were millions of lights on the bottom. It hovered down the highway and right over our car. The next day I was driving into school when there was this announcement on the radio saying that if anyone had seen a UFO, they should call this number. So I called it and said, 'Yeah, I saw it last night. What was it?' They told me they were just taking a poll. So I told a lot of friends about it and they said I should find out who the people were. So I called back about a week later and the phone number had been disconnected. At the time, and for years afterwards, I thought perhaps it was a secret government weapon. But that was 25 years ago and what I saw that night is still not on public record, so I have to believe it was some sort of UFO."

The sighting has influenced Farrelly's perspective on life ever since. He believes that "we are in prehistoric times now... there are things we have not discovered yet". He also applies this open-mindedness to his career. "I don't exactly believe in fate," he says. "But you've got to realise that it's sometimes not so bad if you don't get what you want."

Nowadays, he pretty much has everything he wants. He is married with one child and another on the way and, with his brother, Bobby, continues to create some of the biggest-grossing comedies of all time. Their latest effort, Me Myself and Irene, stars Jim Carrey and is released later this year. Unlike Henry Halloran, who allows career setbacks to crush his hope, Farrelly puts his own success largely down to a willingness to "stick it out" in Hollywood. Nonetheless, he insists that certain occurrences were somehow inevitable. "Back in 1990, my brother and I tried to be staff writers on Seinfeld," he recalls. "I was very annoyed that they didn't hire us because I knew we would have done a good job. But thank God they didn't! Where would I be now? Writing jokes every day of the week? I write two months per year now, and I find that hard. Things work out for a reason. At least, they have for me."

 To order a copy of The Comedy Writer for £7.99 (rrp £9.99) plus 99p UK p&p, freephone 0800 3166 102 or send orders, payable to The Guardian CultureShop, to 250 Western Avenue, London, W3 6EE.

fields.headline: Trimble faces leadership challenge
fields.trailText: An Ulster Unionist MP today formally launched a challenge to the leadership of David Trimble.
fields.body:
An Ulster Unionist MP today formally launched a challenge to the leadership of David Trimble.

The Rev Martin Smyth, who represents South Belfast, said he was acting because it was "time for more vigorous promotion of Ulster Unionist policies than all the in-fighting that is going on, because of the departure from it."

The former Orange Order Grand Master of Ireland said he had the backing of a number of people in the party and would be producing supporters at a press conference in Belfast tomorrow.

The former Orange Order Grand Master of Ireland said he had the backing of a number of people in the party and would be producing supporters at a press conference in Belfast tomorrow.

webTitle: Changes 'will make it harder to join Emu'

fields.headline: Changes 'will make it harder to join Emu'
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's Budget has made it even harder for the country to join the euro, economists said yesterday.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's Budget has made it even harder for the country to join the euro, economists said yesterday.

Public opinion is already against monetary union and policies outlined by the chancellor on Tuesday would do little to help the British economy get into line with the euro zone, they believe.

Mr Brown announced big spending commitments for health and education and Treasury forecasts show the present budget surplus will turn into a deficit in three years or so.

"I don't think it helps," said Gareth Williams at ABN Amro bank. "There is a fairly substantial increase in spending coming through around 2002-04. It's hard to see in terms of interest rates how the gap between the UK and Europe is going to close that easily."

The leading short-term interest rates are 6.0% in Britain and 3.5% in the euro zone. The two must converge if Britain is to join Emu. But if Mr Brown pumps too much money into the economy the Bank of England will take it back out with high interest rates.

The very success of delivering sustained economic growth may reinforce the public's opposition to the euro.

Jeremy Hawkins at Bank of America said: "If the budget translates into the economic story the chancellor's forecasting, there's going to be little in the UK economic picture to make people want to join Emu."

webTitle: Outback faux pas Prince Philip stumbles on

fields.headline: Outback faux pas Prince Philip stumbles on
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special reportAustralia and the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Prince Philip can still put his foot in it. In Bourke, a town 400 miles from Sydney, two more slightly off-colour remarks by the Duke of Edinburgh left aides, weary of "Philip gaffe" headlines, a tad embarrassed.
fields.byline: Will Woodward  and  Christopher Zinn  in Bourke, New South Wales
fields.body:
Prince Philip can still put his foot in it. In Bourke, a town 400 miles from Sydney, two more slightly off-colour remarks by the Duke of Edinburgh left aides, weary of "Philip gaffe" headlines, a tad embarrassed.

On a visit to Buster's cotton farm, Steve Filelti gave the duke a device used to measure water depth in soil, which he explained was called a Piezometer.

"A Pissometer?" asked the duke. "No, no, no," replied the cotton farmer. "I'll spell it for you."

In Australian argot "Back of Bourke" means the middle of nowhere and at the Back O' Bourke Fruit Farm, the duke commented on excessive food packaging. "Oh, you're going in for this business of keeping people out of the food," he said. "No way can you open the bloody thing."

His slips came on the third day of the royal visit after he and the Queen had travelled nearly 1,000 miles to spend 90 minutes in Bourke, once branded Australia's most racist town following race riots in 1997.

Since then the 3,500 residents, of whom around 30% are aborigines, has worked to rebuild the town's image and it is now regarded as something of a success story due to its efforts at reconciliation.

webTitle: Health service failures face hit squads

fields.headline: Health service failures face hit squads
fields.standfirst:
Hit squads to go into failing hospitals

The future of the NHS: special reportNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The health service faces a last chance to save itself, the biggest NHS union admitted last night as the government started to spell out the tough terms behind its unprecedented £20bn boost for health spending over the next four years.
fields.body:
The health service faces a last chance to save itself, the biggest NHS union admitted last night as the government started to spell out the tough terms behind its unprecedented £20bn boost for health spending over the next four years.

Failing hospitals will be fined and could be taken over by hit squads of managers seconded from successful units.

As ministers announced that the first £660m of extra cash would be handed out next week, Unison, the union representing health staff from managers to cleaners, said it acknowledged that the British people wanted to see "major improvements" in services in return for the government's act of financial faith.

Bob Abberley, the union's head of health, said: "Unison recognises that this is the last- chance saloon for the NHS."

The broad goals of New Labour's attempt to turn the health service from a political liability into a winning election card were outlined to MPs by Tony Blair in his first domestic policy statement since becoming prime minister.

Declaring that reform was vital to bring underperforming hospitals up to the standards of the best, he produced a litany of figures to demonstrate apparently inexplicable unevenness of performance across the NHS - including operations costing twice as much in some units as others.

Change would demand new realism on the part of the health professions, Mr Blair warned. They would be expected to "strip out unnecessary demarcations, introduce more flexible training and working practices and ensure that doctors do not use time dealing with patients that could be treated safely by other healthcare staff".

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said later that the new cash for the service would be allocated on a quarterly basis, with performance closely monitored and cash withheld if performance targets were missed.

"Those that are unable to deliver will still receive the bulk of their allocation, but will have more support and, if necessary, intervention," Mr Milburn said. "They will have the opportunity to make up any lost allocation in one period by upping their performance in the next."

The plan was described by Kenneth Clarke, a former Tory health secretary, as "mad" and a startling increase in central diktat that went way beyond the competence and capability of the Department of Health.

Ministers will be relying on the new commission for health improvement, which starts on April 1, to work with underperforming hospital and community trusts. Downing Street denied that it was planning to mirror its education reforms by going as far as to send in private sector companies to run failing trusts - preferring to use NHS expertise - but it said it had no objection to taking advice from private sector consultants.

Mr Blair confirmed that he would be taking charge of the reform programme, chairing a special cabinet committee that would also include Welsh and Scottish ministers and setting up five new units in the health department to develop strategies under the headings partnership, performance, professional change, patient care and prevention.

William Hague, the Tory party leader, dismissed all this as cliches and waffle. But he instructed his frontbench to match, without qualification, the government's commitment to increased funding.

More worryingly for the government, the Labour peer and fertility expert Lord Winston - whose reported remarks on the state of the NHS helped fuel perceptions of a winter crisis in the service - questioned the use of performance indicators to distribute funds.

"In poor inner cities, because of the background of ill health, outcomes are quite different from what they might be in a good rural area," Lord Winston said on BBC radio. "That sort of issue makes it very difficult to compare trusts. Straightforward league tables will not do."

The Healthcare Financial Management Association, representing NHS finance managers, warned that trust and health authority debts would have to be cleared "before any fresh spending commitments are made". Mr Milburn last night put the level of debts at just under £200m. But other estimates suggest that "historic" debts, carried over from previous years, may be several times that figure.

fields.headline: The best country excursion scene
fields.standfirst: A Clockwork Orange
fields.trailText: A Clockwork Orange.
fields.body:
Night. Alex (Malcom MacDowell) and his droogs swerve across the road in their sports car, attempting to hit as many pedestrians as possible en route. As they progress into the countryside, Alex's voiceover provides a running commentary.

"The Durango 95 purred away real horrorshow, a nice, warm vibraty feeling all through your guttiwuts. Soon it was trees and dark, my brothers, with real country dark. We fillied around for a while with other travellers of the night, playing hogs of the road. Then we headed west. What we were after now was the old surprise visit that was a real kick and good for laughs and lashing of the ultra-violent."

Eventually, Alex and company arrive at an isolated penthouse. The lights are on inside. Giggling, the boys clamber from their vehicle and advance upon the house in single file.

In the house, Frank Alexander (Patrick Magee) sits typing. The doorbell rings.

"Who on earth could that be?"

His wife (Adrienne Corri) moves towards the front door.

"Yes? Who is it?"

Alex whimpers from outside.

"Excuse me, Mrs, will you please help? There's been a terrible accident."

Mrs Alexander inches open the door and peeps outside.

See also: Deliverance, The Edge, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre

Don't see also: Carry On Camping

Pointless trivia: The manuscript that Patrick Magee is working on at his desk before the invasion of Alex and his droogs is titled A Clockwork Orange

fields.headline: Ex-Rover chief to head MG
fields.standfirst:
Staveley's Chris Woodwark takes hot seat
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: A former head of Rover and Rolls-Royce cars will be introduced today as chief executive of the MG Car Company in an attempt to give credibility to the team taking over Longbridge and to reassure a demoralised workforce worried about thousands of job losses.
fields.body:
A former head of Rover and Rolls-Royce cars will be introduced today as chief executive of the MG Car Company in an attempt to give credibility to the team taking over Longbridge and to reassure a demoralised workforce worried about thousands of job losses.

Staveley Industries, the diversified group, is expected to announce via the stock market that Chris Woodwark, its chief executive since May 1998, is quitting to front the MG management team being put together by Alchemy Partners, the venture capitalists acquiring the bulk of Rover from BMW.

Mr Woodwark's appointment comes amid increasing signs that the government is reconciled to Alchemy's takeover of Rover though union leaders still claim other potential buyers, including two global manufacturers, are waiting in the wings.

Mr Woodwark is a car industry old hand who worked for Rover from 1971 to 1993. He joined Chrysler in 1964 and is a former Land Rover managing director, as well as chief executive of Rolls-Royce Motors and head of Cosworth Engines - both sold by Vickers to Volkswagen.

Alchemy, headed by turnaround specialist Jon Moulton, hopes his appointment will reassure ministers, unions, investors, motor industry experts and the City that it has the experience to run the rump Rover business.

The MG Car company's chairman is to be Brandon Gough, 62, an experienced industrialist who holds the same post with security printers De La Rue who is retiring from the chair of water group Kelda.

Graham Hallworth, aged 41and co-architect of the revival of decorating-furnishings group AG Stanley acquired by Alchemy, is to be finance director.

The appointment will be confirmed as Stephen Byers, industry secretary, flies to Munich for bridge building talks with Professor Joachim Milberg, BMW's chief executive.

Mr Byers will take a significantly softer line than last week when he accused BMW of lying by keeping secret its plans to sell Rover while the government was lobbying Brussels to clear a £152m aid package to safeguard Longbridge.

Tony Woodley, chief union negotiator at Rover, said after meeting Mr Milberg: "We are in contact with two of the major global manufacturers, people with the finance, the experience and the ability to keep a real car company together."

Union officials held out the the hope that Alchemy was just BMW's preferred option but senior DTI sources said it accepted the German car group had made an "understandable commercial decision" and the deal with Alchemy was in effect "water under the bridge".

Before he flew to Munich, Mr Byers said: "The meeting will be an opportunity to look for and plan for the future.

"I hope that BMW will agree to work with the task force and help them achieve their objective of economic regeneration and job creation in the West Midlands."

The MSF manufacturing union estimated 9,500 jobs will be lost within weeks with redundancies all Rover plants: 2,500 at the Longbridge assembly plant, 1,500 at Swindon, 500 at Cowley, 2,000 in the powertrain section spread between Longbridge and Solihull, 2,000 at Gaydon in Warwickshire and 1,000 administration jobs spread between Gaydon and Warwick.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 Festering media feuds add greatly to the gaiety of the nation, and now the Piers Morgan v David Yelland battle has ended (in victory to old baldy at the Sun), what better to delight us all than an outbreak of hostilities in Fleet Street's equivalent of the battle of the Somme. A sober and relaxed Kelvin MacKenzie appeared at the UK press awards beano on Tuesday night, to present the sports writer of the year prize to Matt Dickinson of the Times. "And the winner is . . . Janet Street-Porter!" he roared, at the expense of the woman he once got rid of from L!ve TV. Egged on by the audience, the ex-Sun editor asked: "Does anyone want to hear a joke about Janet?" and related a tale about the Independent on Sunday editor storming into the office of then chief executive David Montgomery and shouting: "That c***'s got to go." Monty supposedly replied: "Which c*** would that be?" Kelvin then got halfway through another joke about Janet and her former lover, yoof TV host Normski, before saying: "Oh no, I'd better not," and taking his leave.

 Also at the press awards was Mirror editor Piers Morgan. Piers was quoted in the UK Press Gazette on November 26 last year, saying that if his paper didn't win the scoop of the year award for the Blair baby story (which cost him £50,000), he'd resign. Sadly he didn't win (the News of the World got it for the Archer story), so we ring Piers's office to ask when he's going to bite the bullet. "Yes he's in, who's calling?" asked his secretary. It's the Guardian Diary. "No, he's not in." Oh dear. Well, Piers has more than enough reasons to resign at the moment, so he probably doesn't need any more.

 The first item in today's Diary reminds me there are far too many obscenities in public life these days, so we should all applaud Ross Newbigging for reporting Labour's Falkirk East MP Michael Connarty to the police for "foul and disgusting language" last Saturday, according to the Herald. "It was a warm day and an office window was open," said Mr Newbigging, whose father's shop is below the MP's constituency office. "I heard a tirade of abuse being shouted by Connarty. It stopped, but then started again, and by then my mother had come out and I didn't want her to hear that." F***ing poor show.

 Sadly, Mr Connarty was not the only MP to get into trouble with his neighbours. Suffolk Central Tory, Michael Lord, owns land in Willington near Bedford, and despite the field being home to the rare great crested grebe (whose mating dance is such a treat), Mr Lord has twice tried and failed to get permission to build 35 houses there. On Sunday, according to Theobald's news agency, Mr Lord turned up with a JCB digger, starting fires and clearing bushes. Details are sketchy, but the following all turned up at the field: around 50 local residents, fire engines, the police, Anglia Television, and the mayor of Bedford. Mr Lord's car received a brick through a window, and tyres on the JCB were slashed. If only Mr Lord had returned our call we could have found out his side of this story.

 My colleague Matthew Norman's secondment to the Frank Dobson campaign ended abruptly, after he was held responsible for scripting Dobbo's foolish "redheads" PR blunder. Matthew is now on tour throughout Labour's heartlands in the stylish lime-green new Beetle lent to him by Volkswagen. For some reason VW expect the Beetle back next week, but Matthew plans extensive testing of the car's hand-brake turning abilities at Oxford's Blackbird Leys housing estate.

 How much damage has the Conservative party done to the once-proud international reputation of this country? An aquarium in Texas held a poll to name its largest and most ferocious shark - and the winner out of 10,000 votes was Tory. O tempora! O mores!

webTitle: Putin's art - being all things to everyman

fields.headline: Putin's art - being all things to everyman
fields.standfirst: Presidency frontrunner with no manifesto charms dejected scientistsRussia: special report
fields.trailText: For many of the citizens of Zhukovsky, the town that once represented the pride of socialist Russia's aviation achievements, acting president Vladimir Putin represents the reawakening of an ill-defined sense of hope.
fields.body:
For many of the citizens of Zhukovsky, the town that once represented the pride of socialist Russia's aviation achievements, acting president Vladimir Putin represents the reawakening of an ill-defined sense of hope.

Zhukovsky has endured harsh changes since the collapse of the Soviet Union a decade ago. Parts of the prestigious aviation institute - where all of Russia's prototype aircraft were once tested, and which used to be under constant CIA satellite surveillance - have been converted by entrepreneurial former scientists into a cake factory.

Some leading rocket scientists have been forced by dwindling state funding to seek work in the building industry. Others have gone to work for a nearby chocolate plant producing Mars bars.

As the townspeople decide how to vote in Sunday's presidential election, the privations and indignities of post-Soviet existence have attracted growing numbers of Zhukovsky's voters to Mr Putin.

What they like is his promise to resurrect Russia as a great power - though with just three days to go until the national poll, information available to the electorate about precisely what Mr Putin proposes to do once he becomes president remains slim.

He has published no manifesto and has set out no economic programme, nor has he explained, except in the broadest of terms, how he plans to run the country. Rather, he has assiduously avoided alienating potential voters by associating himself with precise ideologies or firm commitments.

Instead, in an open letter to the electorate, he struck uncontentious emotive chords, stressing the need to impose law and order and to restore national dignity.

The inherent vagueness of this electoral non-platform has paid off - winning him a universal appeal which cuts across divides of age, education and background.

There is no sense of electoral frenzy in Zhukovsky, a hour's drive from Moscow. The only political posters on the streets are remnants from December's parliamentary elections. But without even needing to orchestrate a formal campaign, Mr Putin has already won the support of an extraordinary diversity of voters here, each of whom firmly believes him capable of achieving a range of irreconcilable feats.

As he dealt dominoes to his colleagues in a locker room of one of the aviation institute's run-down annexes, Victor Ivanovich, 55, the building's caretaker, explained why the former KGB apparatchik would be getting his vote.

"He's like Stalin. He knows how to get the country into shape, and he will restore order," he said, slapping the dominoes on to the table with tattoed hands. "Putin is a strong man. Only he can help us."

It was not Mr Putin's authoritarianism, but his liberal instincts which appealed to Mikhail Nesterov, aged 38, a former aerodynamics academic who was forced to abandon his job when money ran out at the institute, and to turn instead to supervising apartment-block building projects.

"I like the fact that he's fluent in German. His mastery of a foreign language is a good sign - it suggests he's open to western, liberal ideas," he said.

Yelena Paltsova, an English teacher at the town's main secondary school near by, said that she was delighted by Mr Putin's intelligence.

"He's an educated man who can talk without notes on any subject," she said. Listing the areas she believed Mr Putin planned to tackle, she added: "He wants to cut down the country's bureaucratic apparatus, he wants to stop our money from flowing abroad and plans to develop the country's industrial strengths.

"He won't get caught up with the dirty money of untrustworthy business interests. Moreover, he's got support from abroad - from Tony Blair and from China."

Until the 1990s, Zhukovsky was considered so sensitive to the Soviet Union's security that the town was closed to outsiders; today the local airfield still remains off-limits to foreigners. Outside its gates, Vladimir, 45, a test pilot with 20 years' experience, said that Mr Putin was the man best equipped to reinvigorate Russia's economy.

"Sometimes the base can't afford the fuel to get the planes in the air," he said. "Conditions for workers here have got much worse. I'm entitled to retire, but with a pension of 400 roubles (£10) a month and two children to feed, I can't afford to stop working. It will take a while, but I believe Putin is capable of improving things."

Looking at the hazy rhetoric that has come from Mr Putin, it is hard to understand where this optimism stems from. In his open letter to the country, he laid bare the problems facing Russia, but hardly attempted to explain what he would do to resolve them.

Instead many voters appear to have invested their hopes in him because he is a new face, untainted by the past. They have chosen to see in him only what they want to see.

Admitting that his support for Mr Putin was at heart instinctive, Andrei, the foreman at a nearby building site, said: "After Yeltsin, it's enough that he is young and energetic. I don't know what he plans to do with the country - we'll know that after the election. But he is the man we need."

Not all of the city's residents have been won over by Mr Putin's charms, however. Some are dismayed by the lack of any realistic alternative to a man who has a lead in the polls of almost 40%. Such people are preparing to register their protest by voting against all the candidates.

Others are alarmed by the prospect of a former spy ruling the country. Irina Samovolnova, the director of the local school for the last 21 years, admitted: "I'm worried for the children's sake that Putin may restore the culture of the KGB. I don't want them to grow up under that system."

fields.headline: Kingfisher takes the e-road
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: More than £650m was added to the value of the Kingfisher stores group as it outlined plans for an e-Kingfisher division which will operate five separate internet sites.
fields.body:
More than £650m was added to the value of the Kingfisher stores group as it outlined plans for an e-Kingfisher division which will operate five separate internet sites.

The company said it had poured £50m into e-commerce developments in the past year and planned to invest £60m in the coming 12 months to develop the five branded internet business units. Chief executive Sir Geoff Mulcahy said: "Each will be capable of being floated in the future."

Details of the new web business, to be headed by a main board Kingfisher director, will be revealed at the end of May. But the new units will focus on DIY, electrical goods, home and family, and health and beauty - cashing in on its B&Q, Comet, Woolworth and Superdrug brands.

The fifth unit will look for e-commerce investment opportunities where Kingfisher believes it can add value. The first such investment deal was also announced yesterday: a minority stake in Thinknatural.com, a health and beauty e-tailer which Sir Geoff said "would complement the Superdrug offer".

Kingfisher has a significant internet presence through its French LibertySurf joint venture with Groupe Arnault. LibertySurf, an internet service provider, was floated on the Paris bourse last week and Kingfisher's 40% stake is valued at more than £1bn.

Kingfisher, like most retailers, has been out of favour with investors in the past 12 months. The shares touched 930p last year but have since slid back dramatically. Yesterday's details of the e-commerce initiative, plus a strong set of profit figures, pushed them ahead nearly 10%. They closed up 48.25p at 534p.

The company's annual profits, up 25.5% to £734m, were at the top end of City expectations. Turnover, boosted by acquisitions, was up 45% to £16.7bn but like-for-like sales, which exclude the impact of new space, were also ahead by 5.1%.

Sir Geoff said sales in the current year were showing "encouraging growth", but he did not provide figures.

Kingfisher's shares tumbled this year after the group's Christmas trading statement was interpreted by analysts as a warning that the retailer's profit margins were under pressure. But yesterday the company said its gross profit margins were stable and that the only area where there had been problems were in music retailing, where rivals had been using loss-leading prices.

Sir Geoff said Kingfisher had now negotiated better terms from its music suppliers.

The group, which is a substantial pan-European retailer operating in 15 countries through fascias such as the French Darty electrical retailer and Castorama DIY, also announced agressive expansion plans for its traditional stores.

It opened 120 outlets internationally last year and expects to inaugurate another 160 in the coming 12 months.

Sixty of the new stores, which should create 2,000 jobs, will be in Britain.

www.kingfisher.co.uk

webTitle: E-crime and net raiders cost US $10bn

fields.headline: E-crime and net raiders cost US $10bn
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Computer fraud and theft were responsible for an estimated $10bn [£6.4bn] in losses in the US last year, according to a new survey. The figure is double that of the previous year and is blamed on the vast increase in the use of the internet.
fields.body:
Computer fraud and theft were responsible for an estimated $10bn [£6.4bn] in losses in the US last year, according to a new survey. The figure is double that of the previous year and is blamed on the vast increase in the use of the internet.

The survey suggests that many businesses and individuals are complacent about the risks of computer crime; some may even be unaware that they were the victims of fraud.

The Computer Security Institute (CSI), which conducted the survey, said the losses were caused by industrial espionage, malicious hacking and fraud. The San Francisco-based institute contacted 643 companies and public bodies in its survey.

It comes in the wake of last month's spectacular hacking attacks against Yahoo!, eBay, Buy.com and other major internet sites, which demonstrated how easily malicious hackers are able to disrupt the operations of many large companies.

The US president, Bill Clinton, convened a special meeting of computer security experts at the White House immediately after the attacks, and the conclusions of this survey are likely to put further pressure on the government to step up its security efforts.

The CSI's editorial director, Richard Power, said, in terms of computer crime, the situation was "going from bad to worse".

However, many cyber-security experts feel it is inevitable that the dynamic growth in internet business will bring a correspondent surge in internet crime.

"Isn't e-commerce booming?" asked Mr Power. "Then e-crime is booming. The more commerce that goes on-line, the more crime that goes on as well."

One of the main worries of the companies was the fear that their employees were the likeliest to offend. Of those surveyed, 81% believed that disgruntled employees posed a fraud threat or had enough access to place viruses in the system.

Three out of four companies feared that they were vulnerable to hackers.

Despite the high fear of computer crime, the survey found that very few companies were actively seeking to improve their on-line security; there is roughly one computer security executive for every 1,000 computers used in private industry. Of the companies surveyed, 74% reported theft of information, data sabotage or denial of service. However, the costs of denial of service attacks are hard to estimate.

In the survey - conducted with the cooperation of the FBI, 59% of the companies reported attacks from the internet, while 38% registered attacks from internal computer systems.

Bruce Gephardt, who heads the FBI's northern California computer security branch, said that there was a shortage of people assigned and qualified to deal with computer crime. However, there are signs that companies are beginning to wake up to the realities of computer crime: after last month's attacks, the FBI's scanning tool was downloaded 4,223 times in one day, compared with 170 on a day before the attacks.

"If the FBI and other law enforcement agencies are to be successful in combating the continuing increase in problems," said Mr Gephard, "we cannot always be placed in a reactive mode, responding to computer crises as they happen."

What worries the FBI is that much of the financial damage caused in the previous year was carried by "16-year-olds", who were hacking into and disrupting systems just to prove they could do it.

Experts fear that it is only a matter of time before many more professional criminals see the possibilities for blackmail and extortion as the internet expands.

Many new companies are vulnerable to these threats, as they place a premium on speedy response to customers seeking their services.

One incidental form of computer crime reported to be on the increase was the simple, old-fashioned theft of laptops.

According to the survey, laptops have become better designed and lighter to carry, they have also become easier to carry away.

FBI's national computer crime squad
Advisory commission on internet commerce
US Internet Fraud Watch

fields.headline: Liffe puts its future online
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: London's derivatives exchange, Liffe, is to split itself in two to carve out a niche in the online business-to-business market. The exchange, which a year ago was battling for survival, plans to group its technology-based activities into a new structure, Liffe.com.
fields.body:
London's derivatives exchange, Liffe, is to split itself in two to carve out a niche in the online business-to-business market. The exchange, which a year ago was battling for survival, plans to group its technology-based activities into a new structure, Liffe.com.

"We had to reinvent ourselves last year and we are going to reinvent ourselves this year," Liffe chairman Brian Williamson said yesterday.

The centre of Liffe's push into the business-to-business market is Liffe Connect, the electronic system which has replaced the pit trading that once characterised Liffe.

Liffe believes the Connect system gives it an "engine with the capability to be applied to a much wider market beyond financial services" at a time when the internet is creating groups "which are beginning to look like markets" and seek the skills of an exchange.

"If Liffe Connect can cope with the most complex on-exchange financial transactions then it follows that its potential exists far beyond Liffe's products and indeed derivatives.

"E-business provides enormous opportunities as people increasingly need a high-quality trading engine for matching transactions and clearing them properly."

Liffe is in talks with a number of potential partners for Liffe.com. It declined to give details and said its operations could cover sectors as diverse as automotive manufacturing, aerospace, pharmaceuticals and food manufacturing.

Chief executive Hugh Freedberg said separation of the technology-based business and the core exchange operation would enable Liffe to widen its business horizons.

But the separation would take place "without disconnection". The two operations would be "complementary and generate business for each other".

The business-to-business market was expected to grow from £1,000bn next year to £2,500bn in 2004, he added.

News of Liffe.com, which might seek a stock market listing once it is running, came alongside full-year figures which showed Liffe was still in the red last year, recording a loss of £22m, although Mr Williamson said he expected it to return to profit in 2000.

The group cut it costs from £212m in 1998 to £113m, due in large part to the switch from open outcry to electronic trading and the cut in staff numbers from 1,200 to 652. But income was down from £139m to £85m as the exchange increased the nominal size of its euro contract - which cut trading volumes - as it also cut transaction fees.

webTitle: Grow up, Cherie: men don't clean

fields.headline: Grow up, Cherie: men don't clean
fields.standfirst:
She's 45 and she thinks men will take equal shares in housework

Blairs' babe: special report
fields.trailText: What an optimistic Pollyanna is Mrs Cherie Blair: 45 years of age, and she still believes that with a little more social engineering, men can be made to take "equal shares" of housework and childcare. Women, she has complained, still do three times as much housework as men and are twice as likely to look after elderly relatives.
fields.body:
What an optimistic Pollyanna is Mrs Cherie Blair: 45 years of age, and she still believes that with a little more social engineering, men can be made to take "equal shares" of housework and childcare. Women, she has complained, still do three times as much housework as men and are twice as likely to look after elderly relatives. A shocking breach of inequality, which must be altered. But hasn't Mrs Blair heard of neo-Darwinism? Hasn't she read Anne and Bill Moir's splendid textbook, Why Men Don't Iron, which spells out, with detailed, scientific evidence, just why men never have, and never will, take a "fair share" of homecraft or childcare? Men's brains are just not wired up that way; they are ill-adapted for carrying out caring and sharing domestic duties at the same level as females.

Mrs Blair, it seems, is basing her protests on outdated, 70s "social conditioning" feminism. This presupposed that virtually all human behaviour was the result of social conditioning, and that all human behaviour could be altered by social and cultural change. Bring little boys up like little girls and we will have a new generation of men who play with dolls, dress in frocks and prefer consensus to conflict. Bring little girls up in a gender-neutral way and they will stop spending their money on silly things like cosmetics, breast enhancement and Versace handbags. Seventies feminism developed out of Simone de Beauvoir's dictum that "one is not born a woman - one becomes one". Post-De Beauvoir, we employed the word "gender" to replace the word "sex": sex underlines biological differences, whereas gender implies that the differences between men and women are merely societal.

But De Beauvoir was wrong: one is, except in rare cases of chromosome disorder, born a woman. Female-ness is not a "social construct". It is biologically determined from an early stage in foetal development. It is not "society" which makes a girl into a woman, or a boy into a man: it is the structure of chromosomes. Males and females are born not only with different genitalia and reproductive equipment: their brains function differently.

Men will never do the same amount of housework as women (with some exceptions) because their brains are not programmed for domestic detail. Although males virtually always perform better on spatial tests - there is a direct correlation between spatial ability and the male hormone, testosterone - they also have "tunnel vision" when it comes to the arrangement of domestic space. Men quite literally don't "see" domestic disorder in the same way, just as, when sent to the cupboard to fetch a packet of sugar, they do not have the same capacity as women have for finding any given item.

By the same token, there is evidence that males can tolerate more dirt and more squalor. From infancy, it has been observed that boy babies will tolerate a soiled nappy longer than girl babies - females are from the start, more fastidious, and fuss more about being clean. Anecdotal evidence in everyday life will corroborate this, for most people. If you live with a bunch of men, the loo stays uncleaned because guys don't care that much whether it is clean or not. Women do.

And gay men, do, too, yes. But homosexuality in men is probably also determined in the womb. This, incidentally, is why moral theologians within the Christian churches are arguing for more acceptance of homosexuality: because homosexuals may be born that way, and therefore it is God's plan for them to be as they are. The argument of biological determinism can also be an argument for tolerant thinking.

As for caring for the elderly, the neo-Darwinists would say that males have less investment in doing so, since, everywhere, men have shorter lives than women. It is women, on the whole, who live to be very old: therefore it is in our interest to promote a caring ethic for the elderly. In this, we do unto others as we would have others do unto us. This may be a little mechanistic, and neo-Darwinism does rather dim the more attractive aspects of altruism, but there you are: we have to live with the evidence these boffins put before us.

Of course, it is entirely praiseworthy for Mrs Blair to encourage her husband to take paternity leave to look after his children - babies are much more important than politics, in the eyes of any mother - and of course we all want the workplace and society to treat mothers and families kindly. Quite right. Moreover, since we will be short of skilled workers in the future, employers will need to treat mothers and families more generously. That is all achievable.

But have men share the care of the home and the family equally? I don't think so. And most of us, by the time we have reached the age of 45 have accepted the fact.

Post-De Beauvoir, we employed the word "gender" to replace the word "sex": sex underlines biological differences, whereas gender implies that the differences between men and women are merely societal. But De Beauvoir was wrong: one is, except in rare cases of chromosome disorder, born a woman. Female-ness is not a "social construct". It is biologically determined from an early stage in foetal development. It is not "society" which makes a girl into a woman, or a boy into a man: it is the structure of chromosomes. Males and females are born not only with different genitalia and reproductive equipment: their brains function differently. Men will never do the same amount of housework as women (with some exceptions) because their brains are not programmed for domestic detail. Although males virtually always perform better on spatial tests - there is a direct correlation between spatial ability and the male hormone, testosterone - they also have "tunnel vision" when it comes to the arrangement of domestic space. Men quite literally don't "see" domestic disorder in the same way, just as, when sent to the cupboard to fetch a packet of sugar, they do not have the same capacity as women have for finding any given item. By the same token, there is evidence that males can tolerate more dirt and more squalor. From infancy, it has been observed that boy babies will tolerate a soiled nappy longer than girl babies - females are from the start, more fastidious, and fuss more about being clean. Anecdotal evidence in everyday life will corroborate this, for most people. If you live with a bunch of men, the loo stays uncleaned because guys don't care that much whether it is clean or not. Women do. And gay men, do, too, yes. But homosexuality in men is probably also determined in the womb. This, incidentally, is why moral theologians within the Christian churches are arguing for more acceptance of homosexuality: because homosexuals may be born that way, and therefore it is God's plan for them to be as they are. The argument of biological determinism can also be an argument for tolerant thinking. As for caring for the elderly, the neo-Darwinists would say that males have less investment in doing so, since, everywhere, men have shorter lives than women. It is women, on the whole, who live to be very old: therefore it is in our interest to promote a caring ethic for the elderly. In this, we do unto others as we would have others do unto us. This may be a little mechanistic, and neo-Darwinism does rather dim the more attractive aspects of altruism, but there you are: we have to live with the evidence these boffins put before us. Of course, it is entirely praiseworthy for Mrs Blair to encourage her husband to take paternity leave to look after his children - babies are much more important than politics, in the eyes of any mother - and of course we all want the workplace and society to treat mothers and families kindly. Quite right. Moreover, since we will be short of skilled workers in the future, employers will need to treat mothers and families more generously. That is all achievable. But have men share the care of the home and the family equally? I don't think so. And most of us, by the time we have reached the age of 45 have accepted the fact.

fields.headline: FTC looks into Detroit deal
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: US anti-monopoly regulators have launched an investigation into the online marketplace designed by the three largest American car makers.
fields.body:
US anti-monopoly regulators have launched an investigation into the online marketplace designed by the three largest American car makers.

The federal trade commission is understood to be looking at whether the scale of the component buying system could allow Detroit's "big three" to fix prices.

Ford, General Motors and DaimlerChrysler announced the joint operation last month to improve the efficiency and cut the cost of their components and materials purchasing.

Sources close to the car makers were surprised by the preliminary approach by the FTC because they had approached the regulator before announcing last month's deal.

One company executive suggested that the investigation had been driven by suppliers' fears. "They are worried that we are going to use this as a club to drive them to within an inch of their business lives," he said, but acknoweldged that the size of the deal and the market power of the three leading car makers increased the odds of an official investigation.

The car makers believe they have little to fear. When announcing the new venture, they all indicated that they were confident of regulatory approval. Their arguments rest largely on the fact that the new procurement system will be independent from its founders and involve other car makers. The FTC, which refused to confirm its inquiry yesterday, is likely to look at the entire structure of the online car parts marketplace.

There are several existing online services which could compete against the new venture. Suppliers have also indicated that they could set up their own operation.

However, any rival is unlikely to touch the buying power of the "big three", which adds up to some $240bn a year. Company executives said the FTC investigation was unlikely to delay the establishment of the new operation.

fields.headline: The mobile economy
fields.standfirst:
The Budget gave global corporations a huge boost - and if they want to move on, they can

Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: British people are no longer taxed on their income, but on their immobility. Only those who cannot move are obliged to pay. This, though almost everyone seems to have missed it, was the real message of this week's Budget. Income tax remains unchanged, but the tariffs on business are collapsing. Capital gains tax has been slashed. The "withholding tax" imposed on financial corporations will be abolished. The biggest lorries - but only the biggest - will be exempted from much of the duty they now pay.
fields.body:
British people are no longer taxed on their income, but on their immobility. Only those who cannot move are obliged to pay. This, though almost everyone seems to have missed it, was the real message of this week's Budget. Income tax remains unchanged, but the tariffs on business are collapsing. Capital gains tax has been slashed. The "withholding tax" imposed on financial corporations will be abolished. The biggest lorries - but only the biggest - will be exempted from much of the duty they now pay.

For big business, Britain is already one of the world's most luxurious tax resorts. In 1979, corporation tax stood at 52%. After successive Conservative and Labour cuts, it has been reduced to 30%. This, Gordon Brown boasted last year, is "now the lowest rate in the history of British corporation tax, the lowest rate of any major country in Europe and the lowest rate of any major industrialised country anywhere, including Japan and the United States". Mr Brown claims that he wants to wage war on tax havens. But, under his guidance, Britain is becoming one of the worst.

It is not hard to see why this is happening. More mobile than ever before, big businesses can bully governments into relieving them of their responsibilities. If a state won't cut the taxes it levies, they threaten to disinvest, and move to somewhere which will. By these means they have been able to shift the burden of taxation, worldwide, from the rich to the poor and middle- incomed. Fifty years ago, corporation taxes in the United States rendered more than 30% of federal revenues, which was more than the union received from personal taxation. Now they account for just 12%, a quarter of the amount delivered by personal tax. While the Confederation of British Industry clamours for cuts in corporate taxes, it has also lobbied against cuts in consumer taxes. It wants the money spent, instead, on public infrastructure, providing lucrative contracts for business.

Personal taxation has not been growing evenly. The highly paid, like the corporations which employ them, are mobile, and can play one state off against another. The poor are forbidden to move, so their taxes remain as high as their weakened democracies allow. They pay their immobility tax, and reap the insecurity caused by this global race to the bottom.

The great corporate tax rebate, in other words, mirrors the great corporate handout. Before it came to power, Labour hinted that it would stop doling out money to big business. But it reckoned without the protection racket big companies now operate in Britain, threatening to clear out and take the economy with them if they don't get what they want. Last week it gave £530m to BAe, to persuade it to build its new jet here rather than elsewhere. Some economists have suggested that the subsidies corporations receive from governments now outweigh the total tax they pay.

Big business has further reduced its contributions by means of ingenious tax avoidance strategies. Rupert Murdoch's British holding company, Newscorp Investments, has managed to pay no net British corporation tax on the £1.4bn in profits it has made since 1988. As companies move their transactions on to the internet - a shift encouraged by this week's Budget - their business will become both more opaque and even more mobile. They will install their servers where taxes are lowest, disguise their trade in goods as a trade in services, and even launch their own virtual currencies. The British inventor of one internet currency - beenz - appears to understand the implications. "I wouldn't want to be working for the Inland Revenue when it happens," he says.

The tax burden, in other words, is shifting to those who are unable to move their assets either offshore or out of the old economy and into cyberspace. While the beggar-thy-neighbour economics that Gordon Brown practises hurt rich countries, the poor are wounded still more gravely. With little else to offer, poor countries end up giving everything away in a desperate attempt to undercut their rivals and attract "investment". If, in other words, taxation is not to become wholly regressive all over the world, we will have to revolutionise the means by which the rich are charged.

Some innovative schemes have been proposed. The "Tobin tax", for example, would penalise short-term financial speculation. If it were collected internationally, it could fund, for example, the United Nations, and pay for development and emergency programmes. War on Want calculates that a 0.25% tax would raise an annual £250bn. The "total consumption tax" proposed by Professor Robert Frank would exploit the gap between richer people's incomes and savings, levying steep tariffs on the purchase of luxury goods. Land taxation would make use of one of the few assets big business can't move. Some people have proposed a "bit tax", imposed on all electronic communications. This, though, is surely just as likely to punish the impoverished internet anorak (or, for that matter, the information-hungry Guardian columnist) as the tax-exempt corporate predator.

But it seems to me that we need to be still bolder. Perhaps it is time to give serious consideration to the idea of a global corporation tax.

The corporations have, so far, succeeded in globalising everything except their obligations. Their rights have been harmonised, while their responsibilities have been shed. They have ensured that international bodies such as the World Trade Organisation establish only maximum standards for corporate behaviour, rather than minimum standards. We need to turn this formula around, obliging corporations to respond to human needs. And among the measures we should force on them is a fixed rate of business tax, payable by companies wherever they trade.

This would not be easy either to implement or to enforce. It would hand a formidable advantage to countries playing outside the rules, as corporations would flock to them just as they flock to tax havens today. But it is possible to conceive of a system of sanctions, rather like the sanctions imposed today upon countries seeking to protect their markets.

None of this could work without the democratisation of global treaty-making: prior parliamentary approval of all national negotiating positions, for example, and referenda on important decisions. But this needs to happen anyway: corporations have been able to extract such advantages from globalisation only because they have been able to keep the public out of international decision-making. Governments will reassert their control over corporations when people reassert their control over governments.

Global taxation will be troublesome and politically hazardous. But whether we intervene or not, corporate taxes will converge worldwide, but downwards, rather than upwards. If business is not forced to redistribute its wealth, then the rich will roam the world, free of obligations, while the rest of us will be left to support society, the state and even the corporations through an ever more onerous immobility tax.

webTitle: Single parents gain benefit of budgetary largesse

fields.headline: Single parents gain benefit of budgetary largesse
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Lone parents were among the biggest winners from the Budget, new figures from the Institute for Fiscal Studies showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Lone parents were among the biggest winners from the Budget, new figures from the Institute for Fiscal Studies showed yesterday.

The IFS said the average single parent family would gain an extra £6.11 a week, even after allowing for higher duty on cigarettes, petrol and alcohol. After no-earner couples with children, who were £8 a week better off, single parents gained most.

But in return, Mr Brown announced intensified efforts to encourage them to work once their children are at school. From April next year, all lone parents claiming benefit with children over five will be required to meet a personal adviser at the employment service and will be, in the chancellor's words, "encouraged to take up new choices". Previously interviews had been voluntary.

Mr Brown added a £15 cash bonus for lone parents who take up training, but unlike the New Deal for young people, lone parents do not have to take up one of the three options offered.

Bharti Patel, director the Low Pay Unit, warned the government not to make New Deal participation compulsory for lone parents without increasing "in work" financial support. "Lone parents on benefit face special circumstances. They are not the same as other unemployed people; their costs are higher. The financial support for them when they start work needs to be much greater."

The Treasury's figures, which don't allow for the impact of changes in indirect taxes, show a working single parent with one child between £250 and £300 a year better off, despite losing the additional person's allowance from April, which used to slice nearly £200 off their annual tax. For a working singe parent with two children, incomes will rise by £550 to £600 a year.

Most of the increase comes from measures affecting all low income families with children - £4.35 a week extra on working families' tax credit and the child support component of other benefits. But lone parents tend to be poor, so the impact is more marked.

fields.headline: Crossing the borders
fields.standfirst:
No one objects to immigrants if they are of the right sort - skilled workers who will contribute to their new country's economy

Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Just as Gordon Brown relaxes work-permit rules for IT specialists from outside the European Union, Germany's Gerhard Schröder suggests "green cards" for software engineers from South Asia and Russia. Republican Congressmen not renowned for their liberalism want to double the 115,000 "foreign expert" visas issued by the US.
fields.body:
Just as Gordon Brown relaxes work-permit rules for IT specialists from outside the European Union, Germany's Gerhard Schröder suggests "green cards" for software engineers from South Asia and Russia. Republican Congressmen not renowned for their liberalism want to double the 115,000 "foreign expert" visas issued by the US.

All that and antipathy to asylum seekers ... The disjunction is obvious. Certain migrants are a "burden"; aliens with skills make us richer. Is this selfish liberalism at passport control the way forward? There are 364,000 more hi-tech American jobs than workers to fill them; within a few years Germany will be 500,000 workers short. So are we going to see airports channelling arrivals with ever greater discrimination?

For all the fuss over Romanians on British streets, immigration into the EU is well down from its early 90s peak. Dire forebodings were heard at the end of the cold war - you get them still from intrepid reporters on the gunwhales of Italian patrol boats off Brindisi. But the threatened tides from the east and north Africa did not break, perhaps because of tougher controls on migration, Schengen and all. Experts suggest we have entered a period of lower but more clandestine movement.

Net migration, incomers over leavers, contributes 0.18% of the annual growth in UK population; 0.25% in Germany where the indigenous population is shrinking by 0.1% a year. The "stock" of foreign-born people in Germany was about 7.3m in 1996 compared with 3.5m in France and 2m in the UK. The table shows foreign-born workers as a proportion of the labour force - Austria and Germany are more hospitable than their reputations suggest.

Won't those proportions have to rise if labour market deficits are to be filled? Europe is about to be "demographically marginalised" meaning the population growth to take place in the next quarter century will occur elsewhere. Europeans are ageing - life expectancy at birth is 80 years for women and 75 years for men. European women are not likely to respond to state inducements to have more children, even if governments offered the cash. So distinct labour shortages loom. Right-wingers and private pensions providers love to stoke the fire under the "pensions crisis". In fact there is no difference between the macro- economic impact of "pay as you go" pensions (which is what the Germans have) and funded schemes, where a private company promises to pay you an annuity in future. In both cases, those in work must reduce their consumption to provide pensioners with the wherewithal to live. The demographic question is where those workers are to come from.

The difference between the EU and the US is that the latter goes on growing. The US will have 394m people by mid century, up from 272m now: 80m will come from immigration. That is the official projection; it implies higher annual intakes of migrants. Legal migration into the US is running at just under a million a year with an additional 275,000 illegals. It is now of course not culture or colour neutral. The American future is Hispanic, except that old fears about "takeover" by enchilada eaters have never been realised; for most second generation, Spanish-surname Americans, English is what they speak.

During the same half- century the German population is set to fall by 20m to 60m, prompting shock horror stories about missing binmen. If we need computer staff now, tomorrow it's going to be care workers for our elderly and the day after even pilots, said one commentator in anguish the other day.

Leftwingers and economists sometimes contrast capital's free and easy movement with obstacles to the flow of labour. But people are not commodities; they live by customs and beliefs as well as markets. Only ultras argue for no restriction on immigration, so the question becomes one of quotas. How are they most fairly arranged? Canada - a relatively open society as the table shows - decides through open debate in public forums, embracing business, unions, the churches and NGO activists. The Americans have a bureaucratic process, designed to "make citizens". Nearly half a million immigrants swear the oath of allegiance each year.

Some test of utility inevitably gets applied. Research for the US National Academy of Sciences showed immigrants "raise the incomes of US-born workers" by at least $10bn each year. But that is no great amount, given the size of the American economy. It conforms to John Salt's summary that the net economic benefit of mi gration is small (+1 to -1) though much stronger in specific areas such as Miami or specific trades such as farming or silver-service waitering. A Danish study backed conventional wisdom: the migration of skilled people adds value to the receiving country. (It did not ask about the originating country.)

Perhaps says Professor Salt - of University College, London - we should revise traditional categories of movement. Europe lives with an increasingly complex pattern of "brain exchange" not all of which (in this internet age) needs involve movement or resettlement of bodies. Experts predict - surprise - the emergence of a two-tier migratory system. At one level distinctions between long-stay tourists, business travellers, temporary residents, experts, secondees start melting. At another level governments get ever stricter about the movement of the poor.

Perhaps says Professor Salt - of University College, London - we should revise traditional categories of movement.
