At another level governments get ever stricter about the movement of the poor. Useful links Refugees in Britain: special report The issue explained: How to claim asylum

fields.headline: Double whammy, but no knockout
fields.standfirst:
Inflation is the biggest risk to the Blair-Brown masterplan aimed at winning the next election

Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: There was a spring in the cabinet minister's step as he headed into the Commons yesterday to hear the prime minister deliver the second half of the Brown-Blair double whammy of the Budget's NHS cash spectacular. It may prove to be the first step to a second election triumph.
fields.body:
There was a spring in the cabinet minister's step as he headed into the Commons yesterday to hear the prime minister deliver the second half of the Brown-Blair double whammy of the Budget's NHS cash spectacular. It may prove to be the first step to a second election triumph.

"What Gordon has done is force the Tories to choose between matching our spending plans or sticking to their own promise to cut taxes. They've been trying to have it both ways and were doing quite well until yesterday," he explained.

A few minutes later Tony Blair made the same point with brutal clarity when he taunted William Hague with the same choice across the dispatch box: what would it be, tax cuts or extra spending on the NHS?, he repeatedly asked.

Mr Hague later retaliated by calling the NHS statement clichés and waffle. But Mr Blair will make his challenge again and again from here to the general election his chancellor had uppermost in his mind in Tuesday's Budget. His press spokesman, Alastair Campbell, had cleared the decks a week earlier by admitting that taxes have risen under Labour - to finance the better public services voters say they want.

Melting left-wing hearts

That is now the ground on which the election will be fought. Will it be on local election day, May 3, 2001, as Foreign Office minister Keith Vaz suggested, four years on from Tony Blair's last landslide?

Or a month later, say June 14, after pollsters have scrutinised those local results (as Margaret Thatcher did in 1983)? Or will Mr Blair wait until October so that the fruits of Mr Brown's fifth budget - the next one - have been fully appreciated by voters. When those likely tax cuts have had time to "fructify" in their pockets, as Norman Lamont likes to put it.

It is easy to understand why the cabinet minister was cheerful yesterday. By its own lucky standards Labour has taken some beatings since Christmas, over the NHS and asylum, over the crisis of confidence among its "heartland" voters, last week over Rover cars.

"For one reason or another, we're unpopular in Wales and Scotland, in the north-west (over the Synchrotron research project move to Oxford), in London over the mayor and now in the West midlands over Rover," one former minister complained yesterday, ticking off disaffected regions on his fingers.

But Mr Brown's description of the state of public finances must have melted the hardest leftwing heart. Even Ken Livingstone's verdict was generous yesterday (though he wished Gordon had acted sooner to relax spending). As for past Labour chancellors - Denis Healey, Roy Jenkins and Jim Callaghan are all alive and well - how they must have contrasted it with their crisis-ridden years. At this stage in both the 1964-70 and the 1974-79 Labour governments, early increases in spending were being reversed in the wake of sterling crises from which neither ever recovered.

Yet Labour MPs, trade union leaders and party activists are not wholly euphoric. Nor are the Tories and Liberal Democrats demoralised by Tuesday's coup. Labour worries and Tory opportunities both focus on key target groups: pensioners - who had expected more and are still sore at Mr Brown's preference for targeting help rather than increasing the universal state pension; the regions, manufacturing industry, both still hurt by the high pound.

Mr Brown said disappointingly little about all of them in his 51-minute statement. That might explain the muted atmosphere on the Labour benches despite the 35% boost he promised the NHS. Where does he go from here?

One interpretation of the four-year NHS bounty is that it was a knee-jerk reaction to the flu epidemic during the winter that brought confidence in the service - not the NHS itself - to the brink of collapse. From this perspective, Labour had no choice but to bring forward a big part of its second comprehensive spending review once the media was full of stories about cancer operations being cancelled and patients being moved hundreds of miles across Britain in search of intensive care beds.

The alternative view, promulgated by Treasury officials, is that, far from being a panic measure instigated by No 10, the refinancing of health had long been planned. Certainly Messrs Brown, Blair and Alan Milburn (still at the Treasury when they started the project) talked well before the prime minister sat down for breakfast with David Frost in January - and promised to match EU spending on health if the economy and NHS modernisation stayed on course.

Instead of being a sticking-plaster job for the NHS, Gordon Brown's Budget was the start of a long government campaign intended to result in a second Labour election victory in May 2001, the fourth anniversary of Tony Blair's landslide in 1997.

Labour strategists carefully timed the second comprehensive review for this year - even though the first three-year-programme is not even a third completed - in the belief that it would give them momentum for a prolonged reelection campaign.

City opinion divided

Crucial to the entire strategy is that the economy continues to perform well. The forecasts in the Treasury's red book assume that growth will be around 3% this year, above its estimated long-run trend of 2.5%, but smack in line with the consensus view of independent economists.

However, the driving force for Britain's expansion in 2000 will be consumer demand, with exports depressed by the strong pound and a current account deficit at levels not seen since the ill-fated Lawson boom of the late 80s. The main risk to the chancellor's rosy scenario is that buoyant demand spills over into higher inflation, forcing the Bank of England into aggressive increases in interest rates.

City opinion is divided on this issue. The doves believe rates will not go much higher, perhaps only to 6.5%, while the hawks see the ceiling as being 7.5%. The latter would not be helpful for the Blair-Brown masterplan, since keeping Middle England sweet would not be made any easier by sharply rising mortgage payments in the run-up to an election. One of the reasons for modest Tory cheer this week is that next month voters will feel the loss of mortgage tax relief and married couples allowance in their pay packets - the result of last year's budget.

Its impact will be felt days before this year's local elections on May 4, when Mr Livingstone also looks all but certain to become mayor of London. No wonder Labour MPs are still edgy.

"Tuesday's budget helps us," said one Tory optimist. "It all underlines the fact that Gordon Brown tells only half the truth." The chancellor's abandonment of "double counting" on his NHS figures is a tacit admission that ministers now accept it was a mistake to spin the 1998 spending review as "£21bn for the NHS". It was not half that amount.

The Budget statement set out the extra billions which will be spent on the NHS over the next four years - but did not total them, as the 1998 CSR exercise did to achieve the much-disputed £21bn, dubbed "creative accountancy" by critics.

Yesterday Alastair Campbell parried reporters' questions for 10 minutes as he avoided putting an official figure on it - and avoided admitting a mistake last time. "It's a presentational point," he insisted.

Assuming that economic conditions remain benign and there is no Wall Street-inspired global stock market crash, the government is well placed for stages two and three of its pre-Budget fiscal strategy - the comprehensive spending review (CSR) in July and the preelection Budget in the spring of 2001. The reason for this is that the Budget arithmetic is based on the cautious assumption that the trend growth rate is not 2.5% but 2.25%.

Over the past 12 months, the combination of faster growth and these conservative predictions was to leave Mr Brown with a much bigger Budget surplus than expected. Even allowing for the Budget increase in health and education spending, the surplus is expected to come down only from £12bn in 1999-2000 to £6bn in 2000-01 and £5bn the following year. But the likelihood is that during the next 12 months estimates of the size of Mr Brown's surplus will be revised upwards.

The independent Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) believes he already has enough in the bank to give education the same sort of four-year increase promised to health, while increasing all other spending by 2.5%. This will allow David Blunkett and Alan Milburn to pump out a stream of announcements in the autumn and winter designed to show that Labour is delivering on its key pledges.

The IFS says that the Budget deal for health and the extra money for education make a mockery of three-year spending plans and that Mr Brown is now saddled with three-year totals which are reassessed annually and can only ever be increased. "It is the worst of all possible worlds. You can only have flexibility in one direction - upwards. It is pretty difficult to sell spending cuts to voters," said one tax expert.

That may be so, but the big increases in spending are already putting Mr Hague on the spot, by forcing him to accept that a future Conservative government would stick to Mr Brown's plans or slash public spending. Some Tories insist they can have their cake and eat it, but it will be hard to persuade the electorate.

Shooting Hague's fox

Politically, it makes sense for Labour to deal with spending this year, because it takes time for any changes to feed through into schools and hospitals, and leaves scope for next year's Budget to deal with tax and benefits. One analyst thought it unlikely Mr Brown will plump for a preelection "giveaway" because it would appear tacky.

But there will certainly be the scope, and the temptation, to shoot Mr Hague's fox by doing what the Conservatives did in 1992 - announcing tax cuts in the Budget one day and launching an election campaign the next.

If the public finances are heavily in the black next year, Mr Brown could hit all the traditional old Labour constituencies by increasing pensions and widening the 10p tax band. He could also woo Middle England with a further cut in the basic rate of income tax - although activists and MPs would not like it.

Behind the election calculations lies another never far from Mr Brown's heart: how can he take maximum credit for Labour's successes and succeed Mr Blair as prime minister? The "build 'em up and knock 'em down" Tory tabloids have been piling on the praise this week. One Labour MP admitted: "I think the Budget's healed the divide in the party. We trust Gordon more than we do Tony."

But that's for later. For the next year, the first and second lords of the Treasury will be focused on the common enemy - William Hague.

fields.headline: Red box, red face
fields.standfirst: 'Less tax on tampons!' My, how we thrilled to those words in Gordon Brown's Budget speech... only he didn't say them.  Dave Hill knows why
fields.trailText: There's been a little bit of sniggering behind Gordon Brown's back and it's all rather unfair. It concerns his complete failure to mention to the House what was by far the most radical item in Tuesday's Budget: his reduction of VAT on sanitary towels and tampons from the full luxury rate of 17.5% to a mere 5%, the lowest EC rules allow.
fields.body:
There's been a little bit of sniggering behind Gordon Brown's back and it's all rather unfair. It concerns his complete failure to mention to the House what was by far the most radical item in Tuesday's Budget: his reduction of VAT on sanitary towels and tampons from the full luxury rate of 17.5% to a mere 5%, the lowest EC rules allow.

Female MPs, though pleased by a measure for which women have long lobbied, have been rather entertained by the reticence of the bachelor with the big red box. Could it be, they speculate, that the Chancellor is not only prudent but also a proper prude?

OK, we cannot rule it out: scrutinise Gordon for signs of candour about such matters or even a weakness for low humour and his top-to-toe propriety will quickly strain your eyes. But even though he failed to flaunt his fiscal liberation of menstruation management, we shouldn't really give him a hard time. After all, he is a man - and all sorts of men, however reconstructed, are yet to shed their squeamishness about the flow of discharge and all that womanly... stuff.

Not good enough, I know. But imagine, for a moment, that you had been him on Tuesday morning, all alone in your bachelor flat, tinkering with your speech. Imagine him practising his lines before his shaving mirror in those severe Kirkcaldy tones. None of the names of those, er, products would have formed easily on his lips. Even the veiled "sanpro" would have been a struggle. The forthright approach might have seemed very fine in theory, but fraught with political risk. What if Middle England were offended? What if the gentlemen twerps on the Tory backbenches had giggled? What if Gordon had blushed? The sketchwriters would have run riot. Far safer to take the coward's way and let the good news slip out in the small print later.

It's in the culture, see. Boy presbyterians with clergymen for dads are especially unlikely to have grown up in homes where the strange paraphernalia of the monthly cycle is laid out on display. I doubt if many of us fellows did. I must have been nearly 20 before I went to the kind of household where jam jars full of Tampax stood brazenly above the toilet and the floors of female bedrooms were littered with Lil-lets.

We learn from early on that periods are not our business. Our alienation from them deepens when we are spotty youths and the matter of who's "on" and who is not is one of the many things that make girls so mysterious to us. Only when we blunder towards sexual intimacy do we become at all acquainted with the complex implications of periods, including their resilient taboos. In adulthood, these can put even a very worldly fellow on the spot: should he observe them or dishonour them? Should he make polite inquiries or is it better not to ask?

Men and women alike (so far as I can tell) have all sorts of feelings about sexual engagements when the going may get sanguine. Erica Jong once placed on the page the gorier possibilities, depicting a male protagonist tugging out a tampon with his teeth. Pretty sick or pretty thrilling, according to preference and mood. It's also the nearest some guys will ever get to flossing.

Of course, most male encounters with Always and all that are consumer ones. Again, attitudes vary. Some refuse to go near them, even to bung a box of regulars in the supermarket trolley. Others make their purchases with apparent confidence but few, I'd wager, do so with absolute ease. The first man I saw buying tampons for his wife was a senior member of a grown-up cricket team I'd just become old enough to play for. Watching him fluster with a carrier, I felt an unfamiliar pity. As a sportsman, he was respected as tough and competitive. Now, in my callow eyes, he seemed suddenly unmanned.

Twenty-five years on, I'm occasionally asked to make such purchases myself and see my willingness to do so as a mark of virtue. Yet I can't completely shake off my male anxiety. I may not think I look a wimp shopping for my partner's sanpro. But what's the checkout woman thinking? And what about the bloke behind me in the queue? That's why I feel for prudent Gordon in his bashfulness. After all, he's been brave enough to slash the VAT in the first place. And if he'd rather talk of staunching the curse of inflation than any other kind, let him leave it at that.

 For a full report on Tuesday's Budget, visit

fields.standfirst:
Now it is the NHS which has to deliver
The future of the NHS: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Thirteen years ago a previous prime minister intervened in a "health crisis" without knowing what to do. Like Tony Blair, Margaret Thatcher made her initial intervention in a January television interview. Like Tony Blair, she was horrified by the wide variations in performance in different parts of the country. Like Tony Blair, she set up a review. But that is where the similarities between the two reviews end.
fields.body:
Thirteen years ago a previous prime minister intervened in a "health crisis" without knowing what to do. Like Tony Blair, Margaret Thatcher made her initial intervention in a January television interview. Like Tony Blair, she was horrified by the wide variations in performance in different parts of the country. Like Tony Blair, she set up a review. But that is where the similarities between the two reviews end.

There are three obvious differences. The current health crisis does not compare with the "bankruptcy" facing the service in 1987. Next, unlike Margaret Thatcher, Tony Blair signalled yesterday he would be consulting widely and openly with all interested parties - professionals, patients and community groups. Not for him the secret conclave of five people who dreamed up Margaret Thatcher's "internal market" without even consulting fellow ministers, let alone the health service. Third and most important, the Thatcher review concluded with the offer of a mere .00005% increase in health spending. Mr Blair's begins with a record four-year increase promising an extra 6% annually.

William Hague scored some clever debating points in yesterday's confrontation in the Commons, but in doing so he came near to painting himself into the same dangerous corner that his predecessors did in the 1940s. Just as they opposed the creation of the NHS - which took years for the party to live down - so Mr Hague appeared to oppose the government's plan to modernise it. Yet modernisation is what the NHS needs.

The prime minister is right to try to carry the service with him. Carrying the troops - managers as well as medics - is crucial if the reforms are to work. Much of the framework is already in place. The National Institute for Clinical Excellence is one year old but needs more teams to assess new drugs and medical procedures. It has had too slow a start. A new inspectorate - the Commission for Health Improvement - begins next month, ensuring doctors become more accountable under the new system for clinical governance. There are new national service frameworks to improve cancer, heart disease and mental health treatment. Where the government is making a mistake is in the excessive central controls which the health secretary set out after the prime minister had spoken. The idea that the performance of all 100 health authorities would be continually monitored, with quarterly penalties and rewards according to performance, is not just absurd but impossible.

The prime minister's programme involved five Ps: closer partnerships, better performance, fewer professional demarcation boundaries, better patient care, and more emphasis on prevention. We would endorse all five, but add a sixth, following the report yesterday by the commissioner for public appointments: an urgent review of patronage. There is nothing wrong in principle in appointing councillors on to health authorities and hospital trusts - indeed they add a much needed democratic element - but it should not be in the hands of the health secretary, as the report amply demonstrates. Cronyism has run rife, with 284 Labour appointees, 36 Lib Dems and just 23 Tories.

But voters ought to see the fairness in a prime minister who has delivered the cash asking the service to deliver the performance. This is a major gamble by Mr Blair, but it's one that he fully deserves to win.

webTitle: PwC says error hides big loss to business

fields.headline: PwC says error hides big loss to business
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday intensified his attack on the government for increasing Britain's overall tax burden when he claimed that business would be forced to pay billions of pounds more than the chancellor forecast in his Budget.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday intensified his attack on the government for increasing Britain's overall tax burden when he claimed that business would be forced to pay billions of pounds more than the chancellor forecast in his Budget.

Taxes on business would rise by £30bn over the lifetime of the current parliament, blowing a hole in Tony Blair's claim that such taxes were falling, the Tory leader told the Commons.

To underline his point, Mr Hague seized on claims by the accountancy firm PricewaterhouseCoopers which estimated that two measures in the Budget would cost multinational companies several billion pounds a year, rather than the £300m estimated by the Treasury.

In an overnight Budget report, PwC said that the Treasury had committed a "simple error" in its calculations over the impact on business of the controlled foreign companies and double tax relief. Double tax relief has been used for the past 30 years by American and Japanese companies legally to avoid tax on income from various European operations.

The two measures are designed to crack down on multinational companies hiding their overseas profits to avoid paying British tax. One well known multi national told PwC yesterday that the changes in the Budget would cost it at least £1bn. "There are far more attractive regimes in countries such as Denmark and Spain ... the chancellor will drive out business from the UK," said PwC.

Mr Hague, who is determined to place tax at the heart of the Tories' election campaign, asked the prime minister whether he was "completely confident" about the chancellor's figures in the light of PwC's claims. Mr Blair said he believed the accountancy firm had misunderstood the Budget. "We have asked them to discuss them with us," he told MPs.

The prime minister's remarks were dismissed by Peter Wyman, a partner at PwC who raised doubts about the taxes. "This is not a misunderstanding, we understand Treasury press releases perfectly clearly," he said. "We have extreme concern over the way in which [these] changes will affect international companies."

Nicholas Dee, chairman of the Confederation of British Industry's tax committee, said the CBI would be "protesting vigorously" to the treasury about the proposed changes.

Apart from hitting companies' balance sheets by more than the Treasury estimates, the tax would deter British companies from investing abroad and act as a barrier to cross-border mergers, he said.

fields.headline: The quiet equaliser
fields.standfirst:
Leading tax experts read between the lines and find subtle moves towards wealth redistribution
Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's leading team of independent tax experts yesterday added weight to Gordon Brown's reputation as a believer in quiet wealth redistribution when it said that the poorest people in Britain were the biggest winners from Tuesday's Budget.
fields.body:
Britain's leading team of independent tax experts yesterday added weight to Gordon Brown's reputation as a believer in quiet wealth redistribution when it said that the poorest people in Britain were the biggest winners from Tuesday's Budget.

The Institute for Fiscal Studies said that the new tax and benefit alterations announced in the Budget reinforced the impact of the three previous packages by targeting most of the government's help on those on low incomes while top earners had been left relatively unscathed.

Although Gordon Brown said in his Budget speech that Labour's actions had helped to take 1.2m children out of poverty, the chancellor was reluctant to concede yesterday that he had embarked on a redistribution of wealth and rejected claims that his Budget was a return to the old Labour values of 20 years ago.

"We are New Labour and we are pursuing New Labour policies, as everybody knows," he told BBC Radio 2's Jimmy Young programme.

However, the detailed breakdown of the Budget by the IFS showed that there has been no evidence of the Blair government's pandering to the rich, with the top 40% of earners left untouched by changes.

The impact of higher stamp duty to be imposed on the purchase of luxury homes was not taken into account by the IFS in its analysis, but with the levy on a £500,000 house sale due to rise by £2,500 to £20,000, those planning to put their properties on the market will feel the pinch.

According to the IFS figures, the most important changes in the Budget were the increased support for children, worth £4.35 for each child under 16; the increased generosity of the yet to be introduced children's tax credit; help for people making the transition from welfare to work - including a £100 jobs grant and an extension of the New Deal options to all adults; support for pensioners via a 50% increase in the winter fuel allowance; and the decision to increase the rate only on cigarette duties by more than the rate of inflation.

The overall impact of these measures meant that the poorest tenth of the population saw their weekly income rise by 3% - worth around £3 per week.

The next poorest decile was the second most favoured group, seeing a gain of some 2.5% a week. The IFS said this was worth slightly more than the increase to the poorest group in cash terms.

By family type, the IFS said that the biggest beneficiaries of the Budget had been a non-earning couple with no children, who would see their weekly income rise by around 4% as a result of the changes.

Single parents were the next most generously treated group, with a single earner couple with children and both single pensioners and pensioner couples modest gainers.

While the cut in the top rate of income tax from 83% to 40% and the reduction in the basic rate of income tax from 33% to 23% meant that high earners gained most from Conservative tax policies, the IFS said that the cumulative effect of the four Labour budgets since 1997 had been to help the poorest groups.

The two deciles at the bottom of the income scale have seen by far the biggest increases in their weekly incomes with rises of more than 8%. The next two poorest groups have seen smaller increases, while the fifth, sixth and seventh income deciles have enjoyed only negligible increases as a result of Budget changes. The richest decile has seen its weekly income reduced slightly as a result of fiscal measures which have in cluded the abolition of mortgage interest relief and the married couples' allowance - as well as the introduction of new means-tested tax credits aimed at the working poor and their families.

By family type, non-earning families with children have seen their weekly incomes rise by 10% while single parents have had an increase of 6%-plus. Single pensioners and single earning couples with children are the next most favoured groups, gaining around 4-5% a week.

Further down the pipeline, the IFS said that there were more redistributive measures to come. These included the possible tax credit for pensioners, which is just about to go out to consultation, the integrated child credit - which replaces the child element in income support, the working families tax credit, child tax credit and the disabled persons tax credit from 2003.

On top of all that, the chancellor is planning a new employment tax credit which is designed to extend the principle of giving in-work support to families with children to all low-paid workers.

Mr Brown admitted the government was redistributing wealth through the Budget, saying: "We're redistributing to entrepreneurs by the capital gains tax cut ... We're putting money into entrepreneurs, we're putting money into tackling child poverty.

"We're giving a balance that is right, so that there is fairness and enterprise in our society," Mr Brown said.

Challenged on his acknowledgment of wealth redistribution - which he seldom mentions - Mr Brown stressed that nobody was being harmed by the government's policies. "There is nobody suffering from what we are doing because we have managed to make great advances on unemployment," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

fields.headline: Rebuke for Labour on NHS 'cronyism'
fields.standfirst:
The future of the NHS: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday promised an overhaul of the way in which candidates are chosen to sit on the boards of health authorities and trusts after an independent inquiry found the NHS had become politicised by the recruitment of a flood of Labour supporters to top positions.
fields.body:
The government yesterday promised an overhaul of the way in which candidates are chosen to sit on the boards of health authorities and trusts after an independent inquiry found the NHS had become politicised by the recruitment of a flood of Labour supporters to top positions.

In a damning report, published yesterday, Dame Rennie Fritchie, the commissioner for public appointments, called for the overhaul after concluding that political affiliation had been more important than merit in some appointments to health authorities and NHS trusts.

The inquiry, which followed Conservative accusations of cronyism over the replacement of some highly experienced trust chairpeople with Labour councillors, also found that the appointments process itself had been politicised through the practice of automatically consulting MPs on candidate shortlists.

The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, yesterday called the findings "a truly damning indictment" of how Tony Blair's government had "corrupted the management" of the NHS.

The report is a serious embarrassment for the health secretary, Alan Milburn, and for his predecessor, Frank Dobson, who is now Labour's candidate for London mayor.

Dame Rennie pointed out that while the politicisation of the appointments had begun under the Conservatives, it had "gained new momentum" since Labour took power in May 1997.

"Much of this stems from the wish of the then secretary of state for health, Mr Dobson, to increase the presence on NHS boards of representatives from the community and the accompanying decision to seek nominations from MPs and local authorities," she concluded.

Though Mr Dobson had stressed that appointments should be made on merit, representation seemed to have become the "primary consideration", the report found, with the drive to raise the numbers of women and ethnic minority candidates sometimes taking precedence over the needs of the board.

Dame Rennie found that, of all the local councillors appointed to health authorities and NHS trusts between May 1 1997, and November 11 last year, 284 were from the Labour party, 36 were Liberal Democrats and 23 were Conservatives.

Launching the document yesterday, she said: "It is clear that there have been instances where a person's political association has been a decisive factor in their early selection and appointment and that decisions have not always been based on merit.

"The public need to know that people who are appointed to run NHS boards are there on merit and are fit for the purpose.

Mr Milburn yesterday promised a shake-up of the appointments system to devolve decisions on local appointments out of the hands of ministers and into the power of local health organisations.

However, he defended moves to increase the representation of women and ethnic minority candidates on health bodies.

Yesterday's report, delayed by three months so that all the evidence could be published, includes more than 20 recommendations for improving the appointments process for chairs and non-executive directors of NHS bodies.

It proposes an end to the practice of systematically consulting MPs over shortlisted candidates, and of seeking nominations directly from local authorities.

Steps should be taken to speed up the process and to stop the introduction of last-minute entrants to the process - another trend attacked by the Tories who complained that Labour placemen were being parachuted in.

Mr Dobson strongly defended his record on improving representation. He said: "The proper procedures were followed in every case and no recommendation should have arrived on my desk unless the NHS officials and an independent assessor were satisfied that the person concerned was up to the job."

The NHS confederation, which represents NHS trusts, health authorities and health boards, backed Dame Rennie's call that merit based on an agreed job description should be the "overriding consideration" in appointments to health boards.

webTitle: Rail watchdog will double penalties on operators

fields.headline: Rail watchdog will double penalties on operators
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Penalties are to be doubled for train companies failing to meet punctuality and reliability targets when new franchises are awarded by the shadow strategic rail authority later this year.
fields.body:
Penalties are to be doubled for train companies failing to meet punctuality and reliability targets when new franchises are awarded by the shadow strategic rail authority later this year.

The penalties will be matched by a doubling of incentives if companies improve their performance as they will be urged to do so by the SSRA's chief executive, Mike Grant.

On present evidence, companies can expect to be fined around £30m a year. The authority's latest figures show that firms were fined £15m last year, of which £12m was for bad punctuality.

Publishing details of the new guidelines for companies, Mr Grant said: "Changes in service standards and performance, going well beyond the proposals I have seen so far, are needed to create an overall journey experience which meets passenger expectation from enquiry to arrival."

Mr Grant said that he had identified a number of weaknesses and was seeking to rectify them in the new contracts.

Negotiations with train operators shortlisted for the first group of franchises, which include Chiltern, Connex South Central and the Great North Eastern Railway, are now under way. The SSRA made it clear that new 20-year contracts would not be awarded unless the operators agreed to the tougher conditions.

Yesterday's move by the SSRA follows industry criticism that the authority has not been as tough with the train companies as the rail regulator has been with Railtrack.

Following the threat of fines by the regulator, Railtrack's performance has considerably improved in the past 12 months. It has promised to maintain the improvement.

Under the SSRA's plans, train companies will have to produce individual improvements, which will be monitored and published regularly by the authority. Its ultimate sanction is to remove the franchise and put in its own managers to run it. In effect, this would be the first step towards returning the railway to public ownership - a move which would not be welcomed by the government. But the SSRA has nearly reached this position several times in the past two years.

The SSRA admitted it was hoping to establish a partnership with the rail companies.

On the issue of overcrowding, it is asking the firms to invest more in rolling stock and to run longer trains to meet the 25% increase in passengers since privatisation.

It is promising passengers a seat if they travel more than 20 minutes by train but accepts that it cannot guarantee one. It is unlikely that that widespread passenger overcrowding, particularly on London commuter services can be quickly improved.

While welcoming Mr Grant's move, some industry insiders said last night that a doubling of penalties was not tough enough. They said that, with a 20-year franchise, the rail companies were "still getting off lightly".

fields.headline: Cigarette scam took £178m, court told
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: A gang of international smugglers made £178m by evading duty on more than 100 lorry loads of cigarettes, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A gang of international smugglers made £178m by evading duty on more than 100 lorry loads of cigarettes, a court heard yesterday.

The gang used fake documents to fool customs officials into believing the cigarettes were being exported to destinations outside the European Union, avoiding excise duty in Britain, it was alleged. But the cigarettes were really sold on at full price within the EU, mainly in Spain, it was claimed.

The smugglers allegedly were able to siphon off the excise duty of more than £1m on each of the 119 lorry loads instead of paying it to the exchequer. But the gang was caught after customs officers mounted a surveillance operation, tipping off authorities in Spain who seized two lorries containing 11m cigarettes, Exeter crown court was told.

The millions of pounds the gang made were laundered through a network of companies and reinvested in real estate and fleets of cars, it was claimed.

Alun Jenkins, prosecuting, said the ringleader of the tax dodge was businessman Roger Weston, of Theydon Bois, Essex, who denies conspiring with others to evade duty between October 1995 and April 1997.

The cigarettes came from a bonded warehouse in Epping which Weston owned, and which was run from a base at the London Industrial Freight Terminal, it was claimed.

"I am not suggesting that Weston has £178m tucked away in his back pocket, but his cut was substantial, he made an absolute fortune," Mr Jones said.

He said Weston was "like a chameleon" in the way he hid the money, and he and his accomplices were "ingenious people". Weston had half-a-dozen aliases and set up a string of bank accounts and holding companies.

Robin Parry, 48, quit his job as an accountant in 1995 and set up a company called Watkin Boat Sales in Salcombe, Devon, Mr Jenkins said.

Weston delivered 19 bags full of cash, including one payment of £90,000 made up entirely of Scottish £5 notes, to Parry. Between January 1997 and June 1998 he deposited £3.43m in cash at a branch of Lloyds bank in Kingsbridge, Devon, saying it was from selling boats.

Parry, who took a substantial commission, then transferred the money back to Weston through the Sol Bank in Spain, the court heard.

"Weston and Parry were at opposite ends of a telescope, at one end you see Weston at the other you see Parry, a gang," Mr Jenkins said.

Weston had known assets of £6m - including 34 holiday flats in Spain, a £1m home in Essex, fleets of cars, and a boat.

Brian Spellacey, 62, recruited as a UK agent for one of Weston's companies, made out an order under a false name for 11m Sunset cigarettes, Mr Jenkins said.

The authorities became aware of the scam in April 1997 and launched a surveillance operation, and in October 1998 the Spanish authorities made 11 arrests.

The Spanish end of the conspiracy was run by Juan Chaves, Mr Jenkins said. "We don't know how many people were involved, but there were a lot," he added.

The gang used fake documents to fool customs officials into believing the cigarettes were being exported to destinations outside the European Union, avoiding excise duty in Britain, it was alleged. But the cigarettes were really sold on at full price within the EU, mainly in Spain, it was claimed. The smugglers allegedly were able to siphon off the excise duty of more than £1m on each of the 119 lorry loads instead of paying it to the exchequer. But the gang was caught after customs officers mounted a surveillance operation, tipping off authorities in Spain who seized two lorries containing 11m cigarettes, Exeter crown court was told. The millions of pounds the gang made were laundered through a network of companies and reinvested in real estate and fleets of cars, it was claimed. Alun Jenkins, prosecuting, said the ringleader of the tax dodge was businessman Roger Weston, of Theydon Bois, Essex, who denies conspiring with others to evade duty between October 1995 and April 1997. The cigarettes came from a bonded warehouse in Epping which Weston owned, and which was run from a base at the London Industrial Freight Terminal, it was claimed. "I am not suggesting that Weston has £178m tucked away in his back pocket, but his cut was substantial, he made an absolute fortune," Mr Jones said. He said Weston was "like a chameleon" in the way he hid the money, and he and his accomplices were "ingenious people". Weston had half-a-dozen aliases and set up a string of bank accounts and holding companies. Robin Parry, 48, quit his job as an accountant in 1995 and set up a company called Watkin Boat Sales in Salcombe, Devon, Mr Jenkins said. Weston delivered 19 bags full of cash, including one payment of £90,000 made up entirely of Scottish £5 notes, to Parry. Between January 1997 and June 1998 he deposited £3.43m in cash at a branch of Lloyds bank in Kingsbridge, Devon, saying it was from selling boats. Parry, who took a substantial commission, then transferred the money back to Weston through the Sol Bank in Spain, the court heard. "Weston and Parry were at opposite ends of a telescope, at one end you see Weston at the other you see Parry, a gang," Mr Jenkins said. Weston had known assets of £6m - including 34 holiday flats in Spain, a £1m home in Essex, fleets of cars, and a boat. webTitle: £200m to clamp down on tobacco smugglers

fields.headline: £200m to clamp down on tobacco smugglers
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: An emergency package to contain a "crime wave" in tobacco smuggling was announced by Dawn Primarolo, the Paymaster General, yesterday as new figures revealed more than one in three cigarettes will soon be purchased illegally.
fields.body:
An emergency package to contain a "crime wave" in tobacco smuggling was announced by Dawn Primarolo, the Paymaster General, yesterday as new figures revealed more than one in three cigarettes will soon be purchased illegally.

Customs staff tackling the illegal trade will be doubled to 2,000, new X-ray scanners introduced in ports and airports and cigarette smugglers will face similar penalties to drug smugglers. Pub and club landlords will risk their licences if they allow premises to be used to sell smuggled cigarettes and tobacco.

Fines of £5000 will be introduced for anyone caught possessing and/or dealing in smuggled cigarettes. The big smugglers will face seven years in jail.

From next year all cigarette packets will carry a prominent "UK Duty Paid " mark - but ASH, the anti-smoking organisation, pointed out yesterday that the mark would be easy for criminals to counterfeit and would not allow investigators to trace the origin of smuggled goods.

Ministers have set low targets for Customs and Excise, asking the organisation to recover some £2.3bn of the estimated £7.5 bn that the Exchequer is set to lose by 2003.

This is less than a third of the revenue lost - but it will cost taxpayers only £209m to achieve this target. Figures released in the Treasury Red Book reveal how serious the situation is. In 1998 Gordon Brown got £8.2bn from tobacco duty, and last year this figure is estimated to have dropped to £5.7bn.

This year the projected revenue is £7.4 billion - including the 5% increase announced yesterday - £800 million below the 1998 tax take.

Ms Primarolo said that smugglers were gangs of hardened criminals who used the profits to fund more criminal activity, rather than "Jack the Lads" doing a few friends a favour.

Around two-thirds of those caught smuggling cigarettes through the port of Dover already have convictions for offences ranging from fraud to drug smuggling and violence, she said.

Later the Tobacco Alliance, which represents 26,000 independent retailers throughout the United Kingdom, welcomed the new measures but claimed that the government was still not tackling the cause of the crime.

Paul Mason, national spokesman for the alliance, said: "Yesterday's tax rise means it will be business as usual for Bootleg Britain. Until now criminal gangs have run rings round an under-resourced Customs and Excise."

webTitle: Clintons relish vist to Taj Majal

fields.headline: Clintons relish vist to Taj Majal
fields.standfirst: The India-Pakistan conflict: special report
fields.trailText: President Clinton made an urgent plea for India and Pakistan to resume their dialogue over Kashmir yesterday, as Indian security forces waged a fierce gun battle with two militants holed up in an army building in Srinagar, Kashmir's   summer capital. In an address to India's parliament, Mr Clinton ruled out mediating in the conflict.
fields.body:
President Clinton made an urgent plea for India and Pakistan to resume their dialogue over Kashmir yesterday, as Indian security forces waged a fierce gun battle with two militants holed up in an army building in Srinagar, Kashmir's summer capital. In an address to India's parliament, Mr Clinton ruled out mediating in the conflict.

Only India and Pakistan could work out their difficulties, he said. "I can think of no enduring solution to this problem that can be achieved in any other way."

He would take the same argument to General Musharraf, Pakistan's military ruler, at their meeting on Saturday, he said.

His remarks, which came two days after unidentified gunmen killed 35 unarmed Sikhs in a Kashmiri village, were overshadowed by a fresh battle between Indian troops and separatists, who India claims are backed by Pakistan.

The gunmen stormed the army base in Srinagar on Tuesday. Paramilitary troops bombarded their own building for 24 hours with mortars and machine guns before planting explosives on the roof. They later recovered two corpses.

In an interview with ABC News, Mr Clinton claimed: "Elements within the Pakistani government supported those engaged in violence in Kashmir."

Mr Clinton renewed his call for India to sign up to the comprehensive test ban treaty on nuclear proliferation. "Most of the world is moving towards the elimination of nuclear weapons. That goal is not achieved if any country in any region moves in the other direction," he said.

Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee said India's minimum nuclear deterrent was based on a security assessment - India's relationship with its neighbours had been "eroded".

At the Taj Mahal in Agra, Mr Clinton posed with his daughter Chelsea in front of the Mughal mausoleum and declared: "I've wanted to come here all my life."

webTitle: Taj Majal backdrop for Clinton plea to save environment

fields.headline: Taj Majal backdrop for Clinton plea to save environment
fields.standfirst: The India-Pakistan conflict: special report
fields.trailText: President Clinton made an urgent plea for India and Pakistan to resume their dialogue over Kashmir yesterday, after Indian security forces waged a gun battle with two militants holed up in an army building in Srinagar, Kashmir's summer capital.
fields.byline: Luke Harding  in New Delhi and Tom Raum in Agra
fields.body:
President Clinton made an urgent plea for India and Pakistan to resume their dialogue over Kashmir yesterday, after Indian security forces waged a gun battle with two militants holed up in an army building in Srinagar, Kashmir's summer capital.

In an address to India's parliament, Mr Clinton ruled out mediating in the dispute over which country should have Kashmir. Only India and Pakistan could work out their difficulties, he said. "I can think of no enduring solution to this problem that can be achieved in any other way."

He would say the same thing to General Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's military ruler, at their meeting on Saturday, he said.

His remarks came two days after unidentified gunmen killed at least 35 unarmed Sikhs in a Kashmiri village. Soon after that, gunmen stormed the army quarters in Srinagar.

Indian paramilitary troops found themselves bombarding their own building for 24 hours with mortars and machine guns before planting explosives on the roof to dislodge the men. They later recovered two corpses.

India accuses Pakistan of backing such militants, including those who massacred the Sikhs on Monday, saying the aim was to drag the US into the conflict.

In an interview with ABC News, Mr Clinton endorsed India's view in part, saying: "Elements within the Pakistani government supported those engaged in violence in Kashmir."

Pakistan says Indian security forces were behind the Sikh killings, hoping they would discredit the rebel groups trying to wrest Kashmir from Indian control.

Mr Clinton described New Delhi and Washington as "natural allies", but he renewed his call for India to sign the comprehensive test ban treaty on nuclear proliferation. "Most of the world is moving towards the elimination of nuclear weapons. That goal is not achieved if any country in any region moves in the other direction," he said.

Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee said India's minimum nuclear deterrent was based on a security assessment - India's relationship with its neighbours had been "eroded".

At the Taj Mahal in Agra, Mr Clinton posed with his daughter Chelsea and declared: "I've wanted to come here all my life." Asked if he was awed by the sight, Mr Clinton replied: "How could you not be?"

But he used the Mughal mausoleum - its walls damaged by pollution - as a backdrop to urge greater environmental cooperation between India and the US and tougher action on global warming.

"Pollution has managed to do what 350 years of wars, invasions and natural disasters have failed to do," he said. "It has begun to mar the magnificent walls of the Taj Mahal."

Mr Clinton asked India not to let growth get in the way of preserving the environment. "Give us a chance to work with your scientists to prove you can achieve even greater economic growth and make the environment cleaner."

Emphasising the need to curb greenhouse gases blamed for global warming, he conceded the US bears a heavy responsibility because it is the biggest producer of these gases.

"The United States will never ask India or any other developing country to give up its economic growth in order to reduce pollution," Mr Clinton said.

The president announced $200m (£125m) in grants for clean energy projects in India, as well as the easing of sanctions on enenergy cooperation, which were imposed after India's 1998 nuclear test.

 Tom Raum is a correspondent for the Associated Press

webTitle: If America wins the war, Europe must make the peace

fields.headline: If America wins the war, Europe must make the peace
fields.standfirst:
Hugo Young in Washington The view from the Hill is that we have failed in Kosovo

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Outside the Balkans, the place where Kosovo matters most is Washington. This is not just because American boys are risking their lives there, though a hundred sudden body-bags would finish off Al Gore's presidential campaign. The reason people talk about it here far more intensely than in London is because they know it could yet be a strategic disaster: and, if it is, they'll be inclined to blame the Europeans. America won the war, Europe was meant to make the peace. That's how Washington sees Kosovo, a year on from the miles-high bombing. "It's a serious crisis now," a senior state department official told me. On the Hill, they're less circumspect. "There's real anger with Europe," said a congressional aide.
fields.body:
Outside the Balkans, the place where Kosovo matters most is Washington. This is not just because American boys are risking their lives there, though a hundred sudden body-bags would finish off Al Gore's presidential campaign. The reason people talk about it here far more intensely than in London is because they know it could yet be a strategic disaster: and, if it is, they'll be inclined to blame the Europeans. America won the war, Europe was meant to make the peace. That's how Washington sees Kosovo, a year on from the miles-high bombing. "It's a serious crisis now," a senior state department official told me. On the Hill, they're less circumspect. "There's real anger with Europe," said a congressional aide.

Europe hasn't done well. Even Britain, worried about over-stretch, has been pulling troops out of Kosovo, as the US continues to put more in. Pledges on a civilian police force are woefully unkept. The infrastructure isn't being rebuilt anything like fast enough, for reasons that are as much fratricidal as external. But the external failures enrage the Senate, where half the latest US pledge, for $2,000m, may be made conditional on the president certifying that the other allies are meeting their commitments. If they don't, there's talk of US withdrawal from Kosovo in 18 months' time. The Great Hegemon is selective in the responsibilities he wants to undertake.

It's less bothered than it was about the Europe's own defence policy (ESDP). After a year of wrangling about the ambitions Tony Blair and Jacques Chirac set in train at St Malo, Washington's alarms have subsided. Tory spokesmen, who toured here last autumn and came back saying not a single American favoured ESDP, have been confounded. Patient diplomacy, notably by the British, has produced words to satisfy the US that Nato's mission survives intact. Hardly anyone still says we had our pockets picked by the French, enfeebling the alliance. Everyone I spoke to now wants ESDP to work, which wasn't always so.

What troubles them is: will it? What troops, exactly, will make up the 60,000 that have been nominally committed? What about the back-up, the heavy lift, the communications, the air power? Where's the meat on the table? There's no sign of Europe spending more on defence, especially the biggest bit of Europe - Germany - where defence takes only 1.4% of GDP and Chancellor Schröder is promising tax cuts. The Pentagon watches with sceptical interest. "I note that France and Britain are in budget surplus," said a senior source there. In a capital where defence spending is on the rise, there's real fear - as there is in parts of Europe - that ESDP will turn out to consist of more brass-hats, more offices, more committees, not getting very far in their reinvention of the wheel.

Europe can't afford to let that happen. It would be calamitous for Nato, especially in Washington, and of this calamity Europe's sluggardly show in Kosovo is in danger of being a harbinger. There are people here, especially new-generation Republicans, who have no instinctive belief in the Atlantic alliance. If Europe bottles out in Kosovo, and then shows that all the flam about ESDP has been little more than Blair proving his European credentials and Chirac scoring cherished points against the US, the disillusionment will be close to terminal.

It wouldn't, I think, be instantaneous. If there had to be a Nato war for Montenegro, the US would surely step up to the task. The stability of Europe is still seen as a vital US interest. But we're not living with the cold war any more. The structures of threat and power have changed. Political seepage will at some stage begin to erode support for a Europe that cannot find the collective will to do enough for itself. Worse than no ESDP will be one that turns out to be an empty pretence.

Fears of a European army - that vaporous construct of the erratic President Prodi - are beside the point: a hallu cination of which Washington seems to have rid itself sooner than simple-minded William Hague. The danger is that Europe won't be able to assemble even a regiment fit for the tasks it has solemnly laid on itself.

At its worst, this could turn out to be the pre-history of a slow decoupling: not yet conscious, certainly not desired, sincerely disavowed in the Pentagon and State department, but in danger of becoming a consequence of hegemonic attitudes in the dominant world power. These are, after all, already on vigorous display. Land mines, Kyoto, the international criminal court, Nato enlargement, the test ban treaty, United Nations dues: all attest to the frailties of a world order only available on American terms - America exempting itself whenever it wants. Europe faces the difficult choice of lying down in front of this, or, where it can, doing something for itself.

The hardest challenge may come from America's national missile defence (NMD) plans, discussed here on Tuesday. The US looks as though it will deploy a system Europe thinks unnecessary and unworkable. Fylingdales could become a target. This could itself make Europe more vulnerable if Iran or Iraq got long-range missiles. If US policy required another war against Iraq, would Europe, in those circumstances, join in as willingly as in 1990? If the US went to war notwithstanding, what protection would she offer London or Paris against Middle East nuclear attack? In short, how can anyone be sure, as they begin to decipher the calculus of NMD, that European and American security interests will remain the same?

One answer is to say that Europe must fold itself into the protections of NMD: missiles as well as radar on the moors, the scrapping of vital treaties with Russia, redoubled coupling. If NMD turns out to be technically more feasible than now suspected, that is a logical option. But who can believe in the greenish Germans and separatist French, or even the acquiescent British, agreeing to such an American escalation on their soil, even for their speculative benefit? From where would the Euro-billions for NMD suddenly become available?

The moral is that at least Europe has to provide the resources for ESDP. It is the only route to credibility on the field that matters most to the continent, its own back-yard. From being deeply suspect, as a source of US-EU distancing, a serious European defence policy has now become the minimum guarantee of a sustained alliance. It is also a back-up if coupling begins to wane. The people running Nato, not least George Robertson, know this very well. The challenge is to national leaders. Not even Blair is willing to talk honestly about higher defence spending. But that is what must come. The peace dividend was taken, in spades. Now some repayment has to start, to keep the Hegemon happy and simultaneously prepare for his retreat.

fields.headline: Budget: some credit, more debit
fields.trailText: The annual analysis of the Budget seems stuck in a time-warp. Two-thirds of people in Britain don't smoke, most don't drink beer or spirits other than occasionally, so why the emphasis on the duties attaching to these products?
fields.body:
The annual analysis of the Budget seems stuck in a time-warp. Two-thirds of people in Britain don't smoke, most don't drink beer or spirits other than occasionally, so why the emphasis on the duties attaching to these products? Growing pensioner numbers and the fact that young people are reverting to renting rather than buying housing means that mortgage changes are becoming increasingly irrelevant to many. And with house prices averaging around £100,000 in the UK, why feature a woman who is buying a house worth £275,000? The vast majority of people live in towns and cities where owning a car is plain daft; many sensible people rent at weekends when they need a car and save hundreds of pounds each year, yet 2p on petrol or a rise in car tax is seen as life-threatening.

The Budget is a macro-economic tool. By focusing on individuals, none of whom can be average in a country as diverse as this, the whole picture is distorted.
Stuart Skyte
Oxford

 The decision to raise taxes on cigarettes by 25p is disappointing given the mounting evidence of a link between smoking and poverty. Those earning a good salary will pay the additional cost, while people on low incomes will struggle to find the extra money and, given the added stress, could end up smoking more.
Sam Semoff
Liverpool

 Does Gordon Brown know anybody trying to raise a family on £30,000 a year in the London area? A typical young family relying on a single income has already been priced out of the housing market and must be wondering if the government is looking to drive them to bring up their children in the cramped conditions of a small flat comparable only to the space allowances of 19th-century slums. The removal of the married person's allowance on top of the scrapping of Miras means this group is the only one that has been made worse off by the Budget.
Adam Firth
Shoeburyness, Essex

 The announcement that there is to be no real change in the tax treatment of cars may win a few votes, but this government is ambivalent on the pollution and misery caused by traffic congestion. How councils can be expected to implement the changes envisaged by recent papers on reducing child road deaths with this background message of unabashed automania is anyone's guess.
Cllr Laurence Mann
Richmond upon Thames
lnmann@cix.compulink.co.uk

 This was a disappointing budget for most pensioners. Inflation is running at 2.3%, yet pensioners get an increase of 1.1%. An extra £50 per household winter fuel allowance, worth 96p a week for a single pensioner, is no compensation for the miserly 75p rise in the state pension.
Cliff Fuller
Gloucester

 As a pensioner in my seventies, living on a state pension and small occupational pension, both based on 1975 levels, and occupying a band B house, I calculate that the Chanceller's largesse will just about cover the increase in my council tax bill.
JM Carter
Huddersfield
jmmc@cwcom.net

 My inflation-linked pension is going up by 1.1% in April. My inflation linked petrol is going up by 2.5%. Funny stuff this inflation.
John Loader
Ely, Cambs
john4jul@waitrose.com

 Gordon Brown said he is putting up the price of petrol and beer "in line with inflation". Beer, which in most places costs about £1.50 to £2 a pint, is going up 1p. Petrol, which ranges from about 75p to 85p a litre, is go ing up by 2p. Did Mr Brown do any maths at school?
Krystyna Wiczkowska
Manchester
krysia@ukgateway.net

 The day after the Budget and even the television guide (G2, March 22) seems politically charged. On BBC1 the schedule was: 9.30pm Budget Response; 9.35 True Lies.
Dr Matt Jones
London
always@acm.org

 Despite the unprecedented increases in health spending, I wager some letters will still be from whinging cynics. Are these people incapable of giving credit where it's due?
James Rogers
St Albans, Herts

 Mr Hague accuses Labour of increasing taxes by stealth. The Tories invented stealth taxes, with Norman Lamont a leading proponent of staged tax rises. More subtly, Tory underfunding, where they postponed essential health and infrastructure spending to buy short-term popularity by keeping taxes down, was, in itself, a stealth tax. For hundreds of thousands of patients, who face long periods on waiting lists or cancelled operations, this stealth tax has become a pain tax, or a stress tax paid by their families. Some have been forced to mortgage their homes to buy private treatment because operations like cardiac bypass surgery often involve waiting periods of a year or more.
Ken Daly
Pro Euro Conservative party

 Middle England has consitently said it would be willing to pay more tax so the NHS and schools can receive extra funding. William Hague, despite a "listening tour" of Britain has cocked a deaf 'un.
Dick Smith
Sandhurst, Berks

webTitle: Godly and godless fight for the moral high ground

fields.headline: Godly and godless fight for the moral high ground
fields.trailText: If the whole ugly spectacle of the recent Section 28 debate has shown anything, it is that people are no longer afraid to speak out against religion and its leaders (Comment, March 22). A C Grayling's call for opinion to be sought from "the richness of thoughtful, educated, open-minded" people, rather than from those "with avowedly ancient supernatural beliefs" is long overdue.
fields.body:
If the whole ugly spectacle of the recent Section 28 debate has shown anything, it is that people are no longer afraid to speak out against religion and its leaders (Comment, March 22). A C Grayling's call for opinion to be sought from "the richness of thoughtful, educated, open-minded" people, rather than from those "with avowedly ancient supernatural beliefs" is long overdue. Religion is not some benign force; it is a psychological and intellectual distraction from the problems of the world.

Here in the cathedral city of Dunblane, the Christian community showed more concern for explaining God's long tea-break on the morning of March 13, 1996, than looking for ways to prevent any such atrocity ever happening again, most notably a ban on the personal possession of handguns. Added to Grayling's list of anti-moral church activities should stand all those occasions when the church fails to take a lead on the major issues of modern life, whilst whining about gay sexuality or preaching to married couples that their duty is to have children.
Sandra Uttley
Dunblane, Perthshire

 It is deplorable that bishops with no knowledge of psychology can legislate on a matter relating to the psychology of sexuality. AC Grayling's comments on church history, however, are unfairly selective. The liberal wing of the church is aware of the blind alleys in the moral maze. The Bishop of Edinburgh has written a book,

Godless Morality, saying that it is better to leave God out of the moral debate and to find good human reasons for sup porting the system we advocate. The church still has a role for those of us who refuse to believe that the universe is an accident.
Dr Alan Sheard
North Ferriby, E Yorks
gilalsrd@surfaid.org

 AC Grayling says "we" have become used to giving a platform to the church. Substitute the word "media" and then there is focus for a campaign. BBC news programmes routinely trot out a bishop to pontificate on any subject in the news about which some moral question has arisen. Would it be such a great task for their researchers to work up a list of "thoughtful, educated, open-minded" people willing to be consulted on these matters?
Barry Thorpe
Cheadle, Cheshire
BThorpe@hgreen.softnet.co

It is a pity that Dr Grayling fails to make any reference to the great contribution of Christian leadership in vital campaigns. Where would we be now without such leadership in the abolition of slavery, the development of workers' rights, and the anti-apartheid movement?
Janet Nightingale
Rowley Regis, W Mids

 I am in the business of trying to make sense of how people have understood "God" and of using those ideas, images, myths and metaphors in a constructive way. I am by no means alone. I expect Dr Grayling will say that we're not a proper Christians, thus proving to his own satisfaction that he's right about "churchmen".
Rev John Camp
Bedford

fields.headline: Shivering and sighing
fields.trailText: Sarah Boseley (Paternity suits you, Sir, March 22) wonders whether Tony Blair will be entitled to paternity leave when he becomes a father again in May. In fact, MPs awarded themselves three weeks' paternity leave paid at almost £1,000 a week, though they voted against paid leave for the electorate.
fields.body:
Sarah Boseley (Paternity suits you, Sir, March 22) wonders whether Tony Blair will be entitled to paternity leave when he becomes a father again in May. In fact, MPs awarded themselves three weeks' paternity leave paid at almost £1,000 a week, though they voted against paid leave for the electorate. The real question is whether Mr Blair will have the nerve to ask for the money.
Richard Gregory
Editor, Families Need Fathers
fnfhq@care4free.net

 Reading the overwrought entries in Sylvia Plath's diary (G2, March 18-21), I could not help remembering the words of Dorothy Parker: By the time you swear you're his, shivering and sighing,/And he vows his passion is infinite, undying -/Lady, make a note of this: one of you is lying
Pamela Edwards
Hoddesdon, Herts
EJackandPam@aol.com

 Sylvia Plath diaries - final instalment (March 21). Can we rely on that?
Dr Neville Goodman
Bristol
Nev.W.Goodman@bris.ac.uk

 If Sarah Bridge (Letters, March 21) thinks Susan Kramer's website is objectionable, the MP for Lichfield's site includes a gallery of 14 photographs of the MP in various poses.
Edward Ashley
Lichfield

 Re Quick Crossword (Letters, March 22): I thought it was just me having bad brain days. Thank goodness someone has spoken out.
Anita Evans
Carlisle, Cumbria
raevans@lingfoot.demon.co.uk

 Long may Reg (Bunthorne) reign! The Guardian is the rich fertile oasis of imaginative crossword puzzling, with Messrs Araucaria and Bunthorne at the head of some of the most creative compilers.
Dave Tilley
Manchester
david.tilley@cwcom.net

webTitle: Liver standards are rising, but Blair is breaking up

fields.headline: Liver standards are rising, but Blair is breaking up
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: I have been reading a new book called I'm On Me Mobile, by Andrew Rippon and Andrew Ward (Robson, £4.99), a collection of remarks overhead on mobile phones.
fields.body:
I have been reading a new book called I'm On Me Mobile, by Andrew Rippon and Andrew Ward (Robson, £4.99), a collection of remarks overhead on mobile phones.

One of the best came at Gloucester magistrates court in January 1994, when the defendant's phone rang. "Can't talk now," he said. "I'm in the dock."

It's clear from the book that a mobe offers the perfect excuse for getting rid of an unwanted caller. All you need to do is shout: "You're breaking up! Yeah, breaking up!" very loudly, then switch off. One man even taped breaking up noises and played them from a cassette machine whenever his boss called him.

Yesterday, sitting in the press gallery of the House of Commons, I realised that Tony Blair is breaking up. Individually his words make sense, but there is something missing: where there should be plain English, we just get a crackle.

"What was that?" we want to shout down from the gallery, "you're breaking up. I'll call you back."

For instance, he came under persistent pressure from William Hague over tax. How was it, the Tory leader asked, that a government that had promised no tax rises at all had "totally and cynically broken its promises?"

"He is quite wrong!" said Mr Blair, which he always says when Mr Hague is quite right. "The average family is better off. The average family is 460 years better off. And the family with children is 850 years, er, pounds, better off."

"Years, years," the Tories started to mutter, so they sounded as if they were saying "hear, hear". But the prime minister was not finished. He talked about sustaining public debt, no more boom and bust, stronger growth and more employment, and added triumphantly, "rising liver standards!"

He's right. In my youth liver was horrible, full of a nasty tubular gristly stuff that sort of snaked through the meat like a tapeworm. The meat itself was grey, crumbly and tasted of battery acid. Now, thanks to rising liver standards, it tastes good and goes beautifully with onions and crispy bacon. I had a very nice piece for my lunch yesterday (ooh, you are offal, but I like you), though I'd absolutely no idea that I had Mr Blair to thank for it.

Next the prime minister made a statement about how the NHS should spend the extra money Gordon Brown gave it this week. Once again he seemed to be breaking up. In a very short talk he gave us 17 verbless sentences.

When you hear these you know you are getting not a plan but a wish-list. Verb-free sentences sound terrific, but contain no potentially embarrassing commitments. "Record number of hospitals being built. Nurses returning to the NHS. Casualty departments being modernised."

He announced five new "challenges". This contrasted with Mr Hague's "guarantee". Oppositions offer guarantees, which imply "we'll do it". Governments throw out challenges, which mean "you can do it yourself, we give up".

If a used-car dealer offered you a one-year parts and labour guarantee, you'd be pleased. If he said: "I now set out for you the maintenance challenge," you would go elsewhere.

In Mr Hague's most effective passage he scorned Mr Blair's use of resonant cliche.

"The prime minister told us: 'We must all work together.' A brilliant idea! 'All must come up to the standards of the best.' You're right there! And, 'Together, we must find the answers.' Inspirational!"

"We are told that by July there will be a 'timetable for delivery'. We thought 1999 was the year of delivery, but today there is a timetable for a timetable!"

As I said, we are going through a tunnel, and Mr Blair is breaking up.

webTitle: Galloway to Hain: We'll see you in court

fields.headline: Galloway to Hain: We'll see you in court
fields.trailText: Peter Hain's parsimony with the truth about the Big Ben to Baghdad flight (Letters, March 21) is miserly. The facts are these. After weeks of daily cooperation with the Foreign Office, we were ambushed by Mr Hain acting - we must-suppose - on behalf of his new American friends.
fields.body:
Peter Hain's parsimony with the truth about the Big Ben to Baghdad flight (Letters, March 21) is miserly. The facts are these. After weeks of daily cooperation with the Foreign Office, we were ambushed by Mr Hain acting - we must-suppose - on behalf of his new American friends. In a little over 24 hours over a weekend, he demanded we cut the number of journalists, aid workers, doctors, religious leaders etc on board from 207 to 104, then to "30 to 40" then "20 or so". That weekend he first said he would put the flight to the UN sanctions committee as he was "bound to do", then that he would not, then again that he would.

When, in the teeth of opposition from my comrades, I surprised him by acceding to all his demands, he came back giving me three hours to comply with a new raft of demands from the US representative on the sanctions committee. These were the reclassification of a typhoid vaccine as a potential weapon, a bewildering array of new aviation questions and, crucially, a demand for the precise purpose of each of the 29 people who would be on board. All of this is in writing and available for inspection and was widely reported.

In the face of these new demands, we called a press conference, announced our refusal of these terms, the postponement of the flight and the commencement of a legal case against the government for putting all of this - unlawfully we contend - to the sanctions committee in the first place. Hain's letter now claims there was no significance in these new demands and that he obtained UN clearance as soon as we postponed the flight. Peculiar, you might think, as we refused to answer the long list of new demands we were given three hours to deal with. In any case we have seen no such UN clearance and neither has anyone else. We will, however, see Mr Hain in court.
George Galloway MP
