webTitle: Serb lawyers get ransom for freeing Albanians

fields.headline: Serb lawyers get ransom for freeing Albanians
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Serbian lawyers are reaping exorbitant sums to arrange for the release of Albanians from prisons in Serbia, in what appears to be a ransom racket supported by the government of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.
fields.body:
Serbian lawyers are reaping exorbitant sums to arrange for the release of Albanians from prisons in Serbia, in what appears to be a ransom racket supported by the government of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

Albanian families are making contact with the Serbian lawyers at a makeshift "prisoners' bazaar", which is held on Saturdays on the open road near one of Kosovo's borders with Serbia.

The lawyers take the names of the Albanian detainees, most of whom where hurriedly transferred to Serbia after the Kosovo war, in exchange for a telephone number in Serbia that the families can later ring to find out the price and an approximate release date.

The money, which the families hand over at the bazaar during a subsequent visit, far exceeds normal lawyers' fees: it is assumed that most of the fees go to judges and other Belgrade nominees. In a system as centralised as Serbia's, business on this scale must be pre-approved by the ruling Socialist party, which Mr Milosevic heads.

When the Yugoslav army and Serb police pulled out of Kosovo in June after 78 days of Nato bombing, they took thousands of Albanians with them. Most were being held for "terrorist" crimes. Their families call them hostages, but if Mr Milosevic originally intended to use them as a political bargaining chip, they now appear to be up for sale. Forty-two men were released from Serb jails in the first week of March.

"We collected DM105,000 [£33,000] to get seven men from our village out," said Isuf Berisha, 37, outside the offices of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) in Pristina this week. His brother, Idriz, was in a group of 25 men who had been released from jail in Pozarevac, 40 miles south-east of Belgrade.

When the ICRC vehicles arrived shortly afterwards, wives, mothers and other family friends merged into a throng of hugs and kisses. They then set off to their villages in a noisy cavalcade of honking cars and buses. Some waved the Albanian flag, as though it were the end of a victorious football match.

Joy is rare in Kosovo now that the euphoria of the liberation from Serb rule has faded, but the prisoners' homecoming provided a brief fillip.

"Until midday yesterday, we didn't know we were going to be freed," Idriz said the next day. "We were taken from prison to the courthouse in Pozarevac. The trial only took five minutes. We continued to deny we were terrorists, but the judge gave us a 15-month sentence. As we had already spent 18 months in detention, he then released us."

Isuf interrupted his brother's story with a chuckle: "Actually, I was the one who was a fighter in the Kosovo Liberation Army. Idriz never was."

"We got out because of the money. If the money hadn't been paid, the trial wouldn't have happened and we would still be in prison. Three other men from the village haven't been released. They have already been sentenced, and if their families could find the money they would probably be released too," Idriz said.

Further down Dejne's muddy main street, Samedin and Myhedin Bytyqi, two brothers in their late 40s, were inspecting the damage caused to their home while they were in prison.

"I never expected it to be so bad," said Samedin, as he showed the storehouse that the family had converted into living quarters after their house was burnt down. "Our main problem now is getting used to the light," he said. "We were held in a dimly lit room all day and only had exercise for 15 minutes a week."

The exact number of Albanian detainees in Serbia is unclear.

The Serbian ministry of justice has published a list of almost 2,300 names and the ICRC has registered about 1,700 detainees. But Albanian human rights groups in Pristina claim there may be secret prisons and the number could be as high as 7,000.

Nato has been accused of failing to insist on prisoner releases when it negotiated the "military technical agreement" which led to the end of the bombing.

An unnamed Pentagon official was quoted recently as saying that Washington had decided to drop any mention of prisoners because it knew the alliance was desperate to stop the bombing. "It was a bare-bones document that we were confident the Serbs would accept," he said.

While the strategy may explain the omission to the west, in Kosovo it is of little solace.

"There is some realisation that this is not a statistical side bar - it is an open wound in Albanian society," said Nic Sommer, the ICRC press officer in Kosovo. "[But] a lot of trafficking is going on."

fields.headline: Limits for Lisbon
fields.standfirst:
The EU must keep its ambitions in check

The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: By all accounts, the summit starting today in the Portuguese capital will be one of the most focused for a while. It has been assiduously prepared. This week the trade secretary Stephen Byers paid a surprisingly successful visit to Paris to get the French on side. For the past few months the savants of the Foreign Office have been schooling Antonio Guterres's government, holders of the EU presidency
fields.body:
By all accounts, the summit starting today in the Portuguese capital will be one of the most focused for a while. It has been assiduously prepared. This week the trade secretary Stephen Byers paid a surprisingly successful visit to Paris to get the French on side. For the past few months the savants of the Foreign Office have been schooling Antonio Guterres's government, holders of the EU presidency. Stand by - Romano Prodi anticipated the communiqués on these pages the other day - for the marriage of e-Europe and "social" Europe. This union has lately become the third way made flesh. The Blairites have successfully exported Britain's confidence that enterprise and market dynamism are not only compatible with egalitarianism lite, but a precondition of progressive social policies. The faith took a bit of a knock over Longbridge, but even Gallic variations on the theme are now audible. So the prime minister ought to return home from Lisbon trailing clouds of glory, a vision of and for Europe personified. If he does not, it will be two reasons, neither new.

The first seems to strike the inhabitants of the UK more readily than people in other member states. It is the gap between EU rhetoric and delivery. Mr Prodi's promises on linking schools and guaranteeing the public internet access are fine and dandy but he knows, as we know, that Brussels lacks the tools and the wherewithal to implement them. Unless nation-state governments push hard, not much will happen. So the Commission should stick to its knitting, making the single market work in telecommunications, air transport, energy, rolling those playing fields as level as can be. Part of its game must also be wisdom and patience over enlargement, where the gap between the expectations of such candidates as Poland and the likely extent of EU structural and budget reform grows into a scandal.

The second, perennial problem is that Europe needs continuously to be sold to the people. The EU's score card over, say, the sale and breakup of Rover might well be positive in the Commission's favour. But this episode in deindustrialisation needed to be punctuated by ministerial explanations, preaching the relevance of Europe to the transformation of national economies. Ministerial reluctance is, of course, a by-product of the government's ambiguity about joining the euro. The budget has, if anything, pushed that decision even further into the future.

fields.headline: The archbishop's agenda
fields.standfirst:
Will Westminster be closer to Canterbury?

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: "I do not believe these are gloomy times for the Catholic Church in our country," Cormac Murphy-O'Connor declared at his installation as Archbishop of Westminster yesterday. This was a triumph of faith over fact. The new archbishop must be well aware of the following facts: mass attendance has fallen by 22% in the last decade; the number of priests is falling - in 1998 there were 5,600, compared with 7,021 in 1980 - and will continue to fall because applications for the priesthood are trailing off.
fields.body:
"I do not believe these are gloomy times for the Catholic Church in our country," Cormac Murphy-O'Connor declared at his installation as Archbishop of Westminster yesterday. This was a triumph of faith over fact. The new archbishop must be well aware of the following facts: mass attendance has fallen by 22% in the last decade; the number of priests is falling - in 1998 there were 5,600, compared with 7,021 in 1980 - and will continue to fall because applications for the priesthood are trailing off. Behind the statistics lies the slow unravelling of a Catholic culture of deference and obedience; the vast majority of Catholics ignore their church's teachings on issues as diverse as contraception and confession. The daunting task which has now fallen to this genial 67-year-old is to stem the decline and revitalise this outpost of a global institution.

All the evidence would suggest that Archbishop Murphy-O'Connor is unlikely to be any more successful than his predecessor. His tenure is most likely to be as caretaker. He will hope to match his predecessor's diplomatic skills in steering a path between an increasingly interventionist and illiberal Vatican and those in the pews who are voting with their feet.

There are two neglected areas where he can make a distinctive mark. First, by a more vigorous leadership of his new diocese, which was badly neglected under the monastic Basil Hume. Second, by the improvement of relations with the Church of England. Dialogue between the two churches was stymied by the Anglicans' decision to ordain women in 1992 and it was an open secret that Dr George Carey and Cardinal Hume did not get on. This is an area where the new archbishop might be able to deliver the goods before he is due to retire at 75. He has plenty of experience as a former chair of the Anglican-Roman Catholic International Commission and the added bonus of a good rapport with Dr Carey.

webTitle: Baghdad says Iran is behind blast

fields.headline: Baghdad says Iran is behind blast
fields.standfirst:
Iraq: special report
More about Iran
fields.trailText: The Iraqi government yesterday said that an explosion in a residential area of Baghdad was a mortar attack, and blamed Iran. State media said the blast killed six people and injured 38. Some of the injured, including children, were said to be in a critical condition.
fields.body:
The Iraqi government yesterday said that an explosion in a residential area of Baghdad was a mortar attack, and blamed Iran. State media said the blast killed six people and injured 38. Some of the injured, including children, were said to be in a critical condition.

The site of the blast was a building housing mainly Palestinian refugees. Reports said those who were killed on Tuesday evening were three Palestinians and three Iraqis.

Western journalists were refused permission to visit the scene, but Baghdad television showed coffins being removed from what was clearly a residential rather than a military site.

The security forces claimed to have found an Iranian 6Omm mortar and two unexploded bombs near the site. An Iraqi security spokesman said Baghdad held Iran responsible for "this flagrant aggression".

Iraq claimed last week to have shot down an Iranian reconnaissance drone near the border, and the following day Iran said that the Iraqi-based Mojahedin e-Khalq, the main Iranian opposition group in exile, had killed two of its soldiers, also near the border.

The lifting by the US last week of selected sanctions against Iran has angered the Iraqi government.

webTitle: Battered Iraqis get by on a wing and a prayer

fields.headline: Battered Iraqis get by on a wing and a prayer
fields.standfirst: Some things can be mended, but not the knowledge deficit Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: After 10 years the sanctions on Iraq have still to be lifted, and the standard of living in a country which had been among the wealthiest in the Middle East, has gone backwards. Daily life is tough for just about everyone except the elite and those who have got rich by smuggling in goods from Turkey, Syria, Lebanon and Iran.
fields.body:
Mustafa al-Aana, a medical student in Baghdad, can identify an automobile's year and make at a glance, and so can every other driver in the Iraqi capital.

It becomes easy after a while because there are few models newer than 1990, the year President Saddam Hussein sent his army to invade Kuwait, United Nations sanctions were imposed on his country and the world stopped for ordinary Iraqis.

Car identification is an obsession. Drivers point out Austins, Vauxhalls and Chevrolets. One driver reeled off the cars to either side of him: "Toyota Crown '87. Honda '89. Volkswagen '92".

The vehicles keep running with bastardised spare parts and lots of ingenuity. The main thoroughfare, Rasheed Street, looks life a moving junkyard, with some of the cars dating back to the early 1960s. Mr Aana drives a battered Datsun '79, which long ago ceased to have any paint on the bodywork or any tread on the tyres.

Spare parts are hard to come by because of sanctions, and for three months last year Mr Aana drove without brakes. He demonstrated his stopping system, a combination of crashing down the gears and pulling on the hand brake.

"Now, I have a good brake system. Do not worry," he said, peering through the windscreen, which had four big cracks. Above the windscreen hung a little prayer: "Our God is great because he is the creator of the materials of this car. Thanks for God."

Car breakdowns in the middle of the road are frequent, but Mr Aana claimed that, even though the driving was high speed and aggressive, there were few accidents, because people knew they would have difficulty repairing their cars. Within minutes of that remark, he said calmly: "We may have an accident." The traffic lights. had cut out, a frequent hazard in Baghdad because of the power shortage.

He hurtled towards the mass of cars stuck at the junction, but his newish brakes, put in by his dentist cousin, worked.

After 10 years they have still to be lifted, and the standard of living in a country which had been among the wealthiest in the Middle East, has gone backwards. Daily life is tough for just about everyone except the elite and those who have got rich by smuggling in goods from Turkey, Syria, Lebanon and Iran.

The sanctions have hit the middle classes badly, but it is the poorest who are taking the brunt. Children selling in the street or begging are a distressing sight. Infant mortality rates have soared, the sanitation system is a health hazard and diseases and infections that had been eradicated, such as cholera, diphtheria and polio, have returned. Medicine and medical equipment, subject to sanctions, are in short-supply. The Iraqis claim that 1.2m people, many of them children, have died as a consequence of the sanctions regime.

Mr Aana, 26, in the fourth year of studies at Baghdad's Almustanseria University, lives with his parents - one an engineer and the other a teacher - and his brother and sister, in a four-bedroom, two-storey house in the al-Anleria district.

He is dressed in trainers, neatly pressed jeans and a fake designer-label shirt. He is full of enthusiasm for life. He gets up at 7am and travels to university by buses that are in an even worse state than the cars, pouring out black smoke. "The pollution is killing us," he said.

In the evenings, he shuns the pool tables popular with his contemporaries and watches little television, preferring to divide his time between the mosque and study. "I have my dinner, I pray to my God and I go to bed." Electricity is rationed to three hours on for every three hours off, leaving much of the city in total darknesss apart from an occasional oasis of light where someone wealthy has a private generator. Mr Aana studies by paraffin lamp.

He is imbued with a war-time spirit that makes him defiant about sanctions. "Our grandfathers did not have electricity. We can go back to bikes. We will not die of hunger. We can eat one date. We can eat bread and we will not die. It is not a problem," he said. The main problem, he said, was knowledge. Almost all his textbooks were out of date. Books and periodicals as well as computers are banned under the sanctions regime. His main textbook, Davidson's Practice of Medicine was updated every four years, he said, but the copies the university had were dated 1980.

Rationing cards provide citizens with monthly flour, rice, sugar, tea, cooking oil, beans, cheese, soup, soap and detergent, but in such small quantities that, according to one resident, families ran out in about eight days. "It is not enough. There is little protein, carbohydrates, so little sugar and poor quality detergent," Mr Aana said.

Just about anything else, including medicine, is available in the markets, but at such inflated prices that they are beyond the reach of all but the wealthiest. The family income is supplemented by an overseas relative. Mr Aana is better off than many, but even for him the shops of Arasat, Baghdad's dowdy and dusty equivalent of Fifth Avenue, are just a dream.

When he finishes his studies, he can expect little material reward as long as the sanctions remain in place. Inflation, running at Weimar Republic levels, has made salaries almost worthless. Ten years ago, one Iraqi dinar was worth $3.3; today $1 buys 1,900 dinars.

Wads of notes, a foot thick, are needed for even simple purchases. A doctor who 10 years ago would have earned the equivalent of about $300-$400 now takes home the equivalent of $1.50, enough to fill a car with petrol.

With salaries almost worthless, why bother studying? "I do it for my country. It needs doctors," Mr Aana said. He seemed to mean it. Two disastrous wars and 10 years of economic sanctions have not weakened the Iraqi people. They may not like President Saddam but the sanctions have united them against the west. Their sense of nationalism has strengthened.

"Here in Iraq, we can live with no brakes. I can live with no brakes," Mr Aana said.

fields.headline: City of dreams
fields.standfirst: What do you do when every day is an exercise in survival? You queue. Serbia's women have been queuing for 365 days now, since the Nato bombardment began, but while they've been standing in line, they have not been standing still.  Helena Smith reports from Belgrade
fields.trailText: What do you do when every day is an exercise in survival? You queue. Serbia's women have been queuing for 365 days now, since the Nato bombardment began, but while they've been standing in line, they have not been standing still.  Helena Smith reports from Belgrade.
fields.body:
If female fortitude could be measured in queues, then in Serbia it would be serpentine. Serb women have got good at queues. Nice, neat queues that will have curled their way around a block before dawn. You see them, gracious figures in the sub-zero early light, standing tall as trees in bobble hats. They just stand there, for one, two, three, even four hours, for a pint of milk, a can of oil, a sack of sugar.

Across Belgrade, food queues are proliferating, spreading as fast as the mirthless mood in a city brutalised by war, besieged by despair, broken by Nato's bombs. It does not take long to discover that, under Slobodan Milosevic's rotten regime, Yugoslavia is disintegrating. It is bitten by the mafia, unravelling at the seams. And no one knows this better than its women. For, against all the odds, it is women who are, somehow, keeping together the tattered social fabric of this outcast Balkan blip.

"The crisis has proved yet again that women have better survival methods than men and it has brought them out of the private into the public sphere," says feminist novelist Jasmina Tesanovic. "Men, if not violent, have become depressed."

The phenomenon is first encountered in the queues. Like the coarse Golab toilet paper that has come to represent everything that was wrong with Tito's communism in the bad old days, the queues have come to symbolise everything that is wrong with Serbia under the tutelage of Europe's last real tyrant. Serbian men, some of the best Balkan patriarchs, are back home, hangdog faces in an alcoholic blur, too disoriented and depressed to stand in line.

"Women may be the first to be fired, the first to make sacrifices for their children, but they are keeping this country alive," says Brankica Grupkovic, a 41-year-old human rights lawyer. "Like every woman, I used to worry about ageing. Now there are so many more painful problems because every day is an exercise in survival at the most basic level."

Time is not treating Serbia well. Half its population live below the poverty level, with daily soup kitchen meals jumping from 18,000 to over 100,000 in recent months. Infant mortality is on the increase, as are the invisible poor, prostitution, domestic violence, professors selling smuggled petrol on sombre streets. Such is the spiral of decomposition that, according to the UN, 25% of Serbian women feel it would be "irresponsible" to bear children in their nation in its present state. Unlike Kosovo, where the UN mission has ensured that vulnerable persons' lists and 24-hour hotlines now abound, Serbia proper has more or less had to go it alone since international economic sanctions were first imposed eight years ago.

With average monthly wages now hovering around £20 (a haircut costs £4), growing numbers of women have taken to sweeping the streets, cleaning offices or bartering on Serbia's burgeoning black market. You see them by the busload, in the middle of the night, travelling the long, rough road to Bulgaria, Romania and Hungary to buy the goods - cheaper cloth, paper towels, underwear. And you see them dreaming of change.

"There will be no revolution here because the sanctions have destroyed the middle class," says Grupkovic, a divorcee who has learnt to survive by refurbishing apartments, a strategy that has seen her move four times since 1995. "My salary was $2,000 in 1990. I used to go to Rome twice a year to buy my wardrobe. Now it's less than $300 and I haven't bought any clothes in years which, of course, impacts on your self-confidence."

Five hundred thousand of Serbia's brightest and best have fled; those who have stayed have an over-riding sense that things will get worse before they get better. Repression is growing and Milosevic, now despised by the overwhelming majority, shows no sign of going away. But there has been a change, a dramatic shift in gender roles not even he can erase: Serbian women have been empowered by the very hardship that has moved them into the public domain.

It is a power shift that has pitted them against Serbia's patriarchal system and turned them into Milosevic's silent foe. For the first time ever, many want to challenge the system, to break out of the old moulds, just as the ANC women's league did years ago during the dark days of apartheid.

"Why should we be exluded, like second-class citizens, and not have a voice in matters of life and death when we are so obviously keeping this country together?" Grupkovic asks. "For far too long, we have been separated from power by an invisible wall, but we are no longer willing to be invisible, we make up 54% of this population and we have to be heard."

Voting is not compulsory in Yugoslavia and most women have rarely used the right. Feminists say they could now play a catalytic role in ushering in democratic changes - if given the chance. Although Yugoslavia has come a long way since 1978 when the Coatian writer Slavenka Draculic set up its first feminist group (causing some men to want to chain her in Zagreb's main square), prejudice is still deep-seated.

"There is this very strong sense here that if you're a feminist, you're either lesbian or divorced," sighs Ivana Alexic, a campaigner for women's rights. "Serbian women have been taught to be passive and told not to vote. They have no idea about their own human and political rights, and that has been reflected in the decline of female representatives at all political levels."

The response has already been enthusiastic. Since Yugoslavia's descent into civil war, it has been women who have been behind the vast majority of pacifist and civic initiatives, often crossing ethnic lines in the process. "There has been a tremendous solidarity among women that has not been related to ethnic or national identity," Jasmina Tesanovic points out. "They have covered each other with false names and nationalities, risked lives, written letters, given promises and kept them. Today, 70% of all our new non-governmental groups are created by women."

Last month, 80 such organisations gathered to discuss ways of mobilising women across the beleaguered state. "We've got a two-prong strategy to raise gender awareness by educating women in the media, trade unions and other liberal professions, and lobby for more involvement on a political level," Alexic says.

Time is of the essence. There are fears of another crackdown on dissidents before crucial local elections are held in April. "For a long time, we knew what we didn't want but not what we wanted," Grupkovic says. "Now we know we want democracy, we also know the only way of getting it is by galvanising women into action."

With the resumption of air links to Belgrade, it is hoped help will also come from feminists abroad who have yet to experience Belgrade's bad kind of queues.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.standfirst: Quotes of the week
fields.trailText: Quotes of the week.
fields.body:
"Cherie Booth is a sensible, well-balanced woman. But to call for the prime minister to abandon his duties and take several weeks' paternity leave hails from the wilder side of crazed feminist dementia. There may be a few in the country who would prefer the PM to skulk in his Downing Street flat changing nappies, rather than governing the country, but there can't be many"

Peter Oborne takes issue with Cherie's wish for her husband to follow the example of his Finnish counterpart and take time off when their fourth child is born, Express

"I would go crazy if he turned down £4 million - I'd have ripped his hair out"

Posh Spice takes a materialistic rather than aesthetic view of husband David Beckham's new crewcut, denying that he has lost his contract with Brylcreem, Daily Mail

"I am too much of a coward to have myself plumped up. I once sacked an agent who told me to have my eyes done. I expect I will end up doing it because everybody does. Anyway, it's not as if I'm a sex bomb. Men don't fall in love with me, or only the young ones - I have had to tell some young actors to calm down"

Kristin Scott Thomas, Daily Telegraph

"As we divorce sex from reproduction, the motto will be 'Make money, not love'. Sex will be an industry - and I don't just mean pornography. We will all approach sex as consumers. Women worked very hard to argue that they should be seen as human beings, not as objects, but this new commercial approach means that people will become their own objects. If a woman has cellulite or her breasts are too big, she will want to change them. We will be our own products, and buyers of other products, and sex will be colder and more humourless"

Irma Kurtz, Cosmpolitan's agony aunt, makes pessimistic predictions for the future of sex, Times

"I had a passion for cola sweets but that seems to have passed. Now it's all tomatoes and Ribena"

Kate Winslet shares the details of her pregnant cravings, Express

"If you have shocks in your life - and this was a shock - you have to decide how to cope. You say: this is our child whom we adore and admire. What do we do about this? The only response is: if this is what you say, darling, then that, of course, is how it must be"

Actor Simon Ward on his reaction to his daughter, Sophie, coming out as a lesbian, Daily Telegraph

webTitle: Castle repairs force clan chief to sell family land

fields.headline: Castle repairs force clan chief to sell family land
fields.trailText: Their motto is Hold Fast, but yesterday the clan MacLeod announced it is letting go of one of Scotland's best known and most dramatic mountain ranges, the Cuillin Hills on the Isle of Skye.
fields.body:
Their motto is Hold Fast, but yesterday the clan MacLeod announced it is letting go of one of Scotland's best known and most dramatic mountain ranges, the Cuillin Hills on the Isle of Skye.

The mountains, known as the Black Cuillins, are being sold at an asking price of £10m to pay for repairs to the family seat, Dunvegan Castle, and for a number of tourism projects.

The 29th clan chief, John MacLeod of MacLeod, said disposing of the land was the most difficult decision he has had to make. The mountain range has been in the clan's ownership for around 1,200 years.

"Ultimately, I consider the protection of existing jobs and the creation of new employment to be more important than acres," he said. "I really believe, however, that continued freedom of access for all to these spectacular hills must remain an integral part of the process."

The Black Cuillins, with their distinctive jagged formation, dominate the Skye landscape. They are home to a number of rare species of plants and animals and offer some of the most challenging mountaineering in Britain. The plot for sale covers 35 square miles and includes more than 14 miles of coastline, two salmon rivers, farm land and the mountain range.

It is understood that repairs to Dunvegan Castle will cost around £6.5m. The castle, the oldest continuously inhabited stronghold in the British Isles, is one of the areas key tourist attractions.

Guy Galbraith, head of the selling agent, FPD Savills,in Edinburgh, said they had already identified a number of potential buyers with a passion for Scotland, its scenery and environment.

"The buyers we will be speaking to will not, in our opinion, be overly sensitive to the price, considering that this is a once in a lifteime opporunity to acquire a property of national importance to Scotland."

However, the sale took tourism chiefs, conservationists and mountaineering groups by surprise and there was concern that the range might go to a foreign buyer with little understanding of the sensitive access and environmental issues.

It emerged that the National Trust for Scotland had been alerted to the sale and had to request a brochure when it learned of the sale yesterday.

"It's a big surprise, a real shock," said George Anderson of Scottish Natural Heritage. "We weren't expecting this at all. Obviously the place is of huge importance both in natural heritage terms and for public recreation and it also has a knock on effect to the economy of Skye."

A National Trust spokesman said the mountains fitted the criteria for purchase by the organisation and it would be studying the particulars, but added: "We can't fund a purchase like that out of the petty cash."

webTitle: Boy paralysed in road accident to get £5m

fields.headline: Boy paralysed in road accident to get £5m
fields.trailText: A 10-year-old boy whose family fought a six year battle for compensation after he was left paralysed from the neck down by a road accident won a £5.1m settlement yesterday - a record for his type of disability and the third highest award made in a personal injury case.
fields.body:
A 10-year-old boy whose family fought a six year battle for compensation after he was left paralysed from the neck down by a road accident won a £5.1m settlement yesterday - a record for his type of disability and the third highest award made in a personal injury case.

Faisal Luhar, who now breathes only with a ventilator, was left with devastating injuries after he ran into the path of a car moving at 40 mph in a 30mph zone while out shopping with his father, Yusuf, in November 1993. His injuries were so bad he is thought to have survived only because an ambulance with an accident and emergency consultant on board happened to be near at the time.

The first solicitor the family consulted told them they had no case and Mr Luhar was even sued by the driver's insurers, who argued that he should have held on to the boy more tightly. At the trial, lawyers for the insurers argued that the driver, Paul Fox, had not been driving too fast and that the accident would have happened if he had been observing the speed limit.

But the driver was held liable for the accident and the insurers' claim against Mr Luhar failed. The family's solicitor, Stuart Henderson, of Irwin Mitchell in Birmingham, said: "It's quite a common thing in child accident cases for parents to be sued. Can you imagine how you'd feel? You feel guilty enough because of the accident, then you're told you're responsible. Often the case against the parent is so slim, but insurance companies still insist on bringing the case."

The settlement agreed between the two sides was approved at the high court in Birmingham yesterday. It will provide 24-hour care, buying Faisal medical and educational equipment, and compensating him for loss of future earnings. The boy's lawyers argued that Faisal, who has a high IQ, would have had a professional career. His round-the-clock care by two skilled workers at a time (eight carers in all) costs £175,000 a year.

Faisal, who was injured crossing the road at Small Heath, Birmingham, spent more than two years in the regional spinal injuries unit in Southport, Merseyside. He had injuries to his spinal cord which left him tetraplegic, confined to a wheelchair and dependent on a ventilator.

He attends Wilson Stuart special school in Perry Barr, Birmingham, and since returning home to Moseley in July 1996, has been cared for by Yusuf, 45, and his mother Maimuna, 42, with help from NHS carers. The cost of his care will now come from the settlement.

Mr Luhar, an immigration counsellor, said: "We're just relieved that it's all over and we can get on with our lives. We've no joy or elation at the award. The point of this litigation was to offer Faisal the security that he will be looked after, and us the peace of mind that he would not have to enter an institution in later life."

Faisal's claim was brought with the help of legal aid, but in future it may be still harder to fight such cases since legal aid will be withdrawn next month from personal injury cases. Accident victims wanting to sue for compensation may have to use solicitors on a no win, no fee basis.

Mr Henderson said of Faisal's case: "I don't know how many firms would have taken it on a no win, no fee basis." He said the case had been "high-risk" because of the issues of whether the driver was driving too fast and whether the accident would have happened anyway, even at 30 mph.

Mr Luhar, speaking of his son's loss of independence, said: "One incident which brought home the enormity of what happened was when he said to me, 'If I could only wipe the tears from my eyes with my own hands, that would make me so happy'."

webTitle: Life for obscene caller who turned killer

fields.headline: Life for obscene caller who turned killer
fields.standfirst: Factory worker had made 80 threatening calls before going out on night he murdered woman walking home from nightclub
fields.trailText: A factory worker with a previous caution for indecent exposure made 80 threatening phone calls to women on the night he murdered a secretary, police disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
A factory worker with a previous caution for indecent exposure made 80 threatening phone calls to women on the night he murdered a secretary, police disclosed yesterday.

Paul Hunt, who had attended the same primary school as his victim, was last night beginning a life sentence after a jury at Bristol crown court found him guilty of killing Jenny King, 22, as she returned home from a Friday night out in October 1998.

Friends and relatives of the dead woman sobbed and applauded as the jury returned its unanimous verdict after four and a half hours deliberation at the end of the 12 day trial.

Ms King's father, Ray, said he could find no quotable words to express his "total contempt" for the killer.

"Jenny has no future. He callously took that away. It is obvious to all who have been present at this trial that he is not just a murderous liar but evil personified. According to the evidence, if it is to be believed, this is a person who within 12 hours of murdering my daughter was playing pool with his mate, and who within 18 hours was out on the town again. He has brought eternal shame on his family and tainted them and his friends with his web of deceit and lies."

Ms King disappeared in the early hours of October 31 1998 after leaving Chaser's night club in Kingswood, Bristol, to walk to her home in Warmley a few miles away.

Her brother, Andrew, who had met her in the club that evening, gave her £5 for a taxi, but she did not take one.

Her disappearance prompted a huge police search, and her semi-naked body was discovered three days later in a copse a few hundred yards from her home.

She had been beaten about the face and strangled with one of the legs of her trousers.

The killer had stamped on her abdomen, and had stuffed her underwear and part of her trousers into her mouth to stop her screaming.

Forensic experts recovered tiny green fibres from her clothing that were later found to match a Ralph Lauren shirt recovered from Hunt's home. The pattern on the soles of a pair of shoes belonging to Hunt were found to match prints left on Ms King's body.

The big breakthrough for police came with the discovery of a set of house keys during the search of the thick undergrowth where the body was found. Hunt was persuaded by his fiancee to ring Crimestoppers to report the loss of a similar set on the night of the killing.

Hunt, now 22, was arrested when the keys were found to fit the front and back doors of the house in Warmley where he lived with his mother Teena.

Prosecutors told the court that on the night of the killing Hunt had woken his mother at around 3.30 in the morning by banging on the back door of the house because he was locked out.

Hunt, an only child whose father left home when he was five, had spent the evening drinking in a city centre nightclub with two friends but, after downing eight pints of lager, left the club alone at around 1.30 in the morning to make his way back to the Warmley area. His girlfriend had decided not to join him on his regular Friday night out because she was feeling unwell.

In evidence he told the jury he could not recall ever meeting Ms King and said that if he had killed her he would not be standing there "putting her family, friends and relatives through what they are going through".

That was, said the judge, Mrs Justice Hallett, "a wicked and bare faced lie". The evidence against him was overwhelming and as it mounted up he had continued to protest his innocence.

She told him: "Jenny King was a lovely young woman with everything to live for. She died at your hands, tragically young, because she rejected your sexual advances.

"I also suspect the reason you got close enough to make sexual advances to her was because she recognised you as someone from her childhood, someone she trusted."

It emerged in court that Hunt had in the past received cautions for indecent exposure and making obscene phone calls, and in the six months leading up to the killing had made around 4,000 threatening phone calls to women in the Bristol area from his home in Warmley.

The women were apparently chosen at random.

Detective Superintendent Bill Davies, who led the police investigation, said there was no evidence that Hunt had made any such calls to his victim.

"Jenny was a lovely young lady. She was well liked in the community, a vivacious young girl. She was brutally murdered by Hunt because she was in the wrong place at the wrong time."

fields.bodyText: A factory worker with a previous caution for indecent exposure made 80 threatening phone calls to women on the night he murdered a secretary, police disclosed yesterday. Paul Hunt, who had attended the same primary school as his victim, was last night beginning a life sentence after a jury at Bristol crown court found him guilty of killing Jenny King, 22, as she returned home from a Friday night out in October 1998. Friends and relatives of the dead woman sobbed and applauded as the jury returned its unanimous verdict after four and a half hours deliberation at the end of the 12 day trial. Ms King's father, Ray, said he could find no quotable words to express his "total contempt" for the killer. "Jenny has no future. He callously took that away. It is obvious to all who have been present at this trial that he is not just a murderous liar but evil personified. According to the evidence, if it is to be believed, this is a person who within 12 hours of murdering my daughter was playing pool with his mate, and who within 18 hours was out on the town again. He has brought eternal shame on his family and tainted them and his friends with his web of deceit and lies." Ms King disappeared in the early hours of October 31 1998 after leaving Chaser's night club in Kingswood, Bristol, to walk to her home in Warmley a few miles away. Her brother, Andrew, who had met her in the club that evening, gave her £5 for a taxi, but she did not take one. Her disappearance prompted a huge police search, and her semi-naked body was discovered three days later in a copse a few hundred yards from her home. She had been beaten about the face and strangled with one of the legs of her trousers. The killer had stamped on her abdomen, and had stuffed her underwear and part of her trousers into her mouth to stop her screaming. Forensic experts recovered tiny green fibres from her clothing that were later found to match a Ralph Lauren shirt recovered from Hunt's home. The pattern on the soles of a pair of shoes belonging to Hunt were found to match prints left on Ms King's body. The big breakthrough for police came with the discovery of a set of house keys during the search of the thick undergrowth where the body was found. Hunt was persuaded by his fiancee to ring Crimestoppers to report the loss of a similar set on the night of the killing. Prosecutors told the court that on the night of the killing Hunt had woken his mother at around 3.30 in the morning by banging on the back door of the house because he was locked out. His girlfriend had decided not to join him on his regular Friday night out because she was feeling unwell. In evidence he told the jury he could not recall ever meeting Ms King and said that if he had killed her he would not be standing there "putting her family, friends and relatives through what they are going through". That was, said the judge, Mrs Justice Hallett, "a wicked and bare faced lie". The evidence against him was overwhelming and as it mounted up he had continued to protest his innocence. She told him: "Jenny King was a lovely young woman with everything to live for. She died at your hands, tragically young, because she rejected your sexual advances. fields.headline: Business partner sought for school
fields.standfirst:
Business schools - As Manchester hails £11m deal that cost council nothing, Surrey invites private firms to help run successful secondary

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The private sector yesterday made further inroads into state education when Tory-controlled Surrey county council invited companies to apply to become a partner in the management of a successful secondary school.
fields.body:
The private sector yesterday made further inroads into state education when Tory-controlled Surrey county council invited companies to apply to become a partner in the management of a successful secondary school.

Although the government has encouraged the privatisation of failing schools, this is thought to be the first example of a company being brought in to run an establishment that Ofsted described as "an improving school with many more strengths than weaknesses".

Estelle Morris, school standards minister, yesterday gave the green light to an extension of the privatisation programme when she told MPs: "What I want to get away from is the private sector only having involvement where there is a huge level of failure."

The experiment is at France Hill school in Camberley, Surrey. The council was concerned about falling pupil numbers as the school was squeezed by two more successful neighbours.

Finance officers saw no prospect of its being able to pay back a £300,000 budget deficit without unacceptable cuts in education standards.

Under the new plan, the school would opt out of local authority control and become a foundation school with a business partner providing extra financial support in return for nominating five of the 21 governors.

It would specialise in business and arts education. Links with an international business school would help pupils to become "global citizens with attitudes and values that prepare them for possible life and employment in an international environment".

Surrey was the first council to invite a private company to manage a failing school, Kings' Manor in Guildford. It was renamed Kings' College and is now run by the 3Es company, which controls the governing body and runs the school on a performance-related contract.

Surrey's deputy education director, Steve Clarke, said the proposals for France Hill would make it easier to attract a private sector partner. "We have a responsibility to all schools in the county. We can't be seen to be helping one over and above two others with which it is in competition."

A private sector partner could provide new drive and persuade parents that the school was being given a genuine new start. It would also be better placed to attract commercial sponsors, he said.

The county's education chairman, Andrew Povey, said the plan was an extension of the privatisation of Kings' Manor. "France Hill isn't a failing school but it is failing to attract enough children to manage on its budget.

"We think this school needs some extra help in forward planning and marketing and we think that's easier to do by bringing in a third party."

Ms Morris avoided commenting on the specific Surrey proposals, but she told MPs on the education select committee: "If we are talking about a new way to manage a school, and the private sector wants to be involved - as long as it isn't for profit - I think we ought to be open to that."

Later she told journalists that the government drew a distinction between profits and a management fee. "People need to be paid for what they do. What we want to avoid are the fears of some teachers that private companies will make decisions to take profits rather than invest in schools."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said France Hill's problems were caused by competition between the secondary schools in Camberley.

"Backed up with unfettered parental choice, the two neighbouring schools have become oversubscribed and intend to increase their planned admission numbers. Thereby France Hill, despite having a good Ofsted report in April 1999, has lost pupils and suffered successive budget cuts.

"However, Surrey has to keep all three schools open to meet overall demand for school places. It is a classic case of the market creating problems rather than solving them."

Surrey is facing a battle over plans to make up to six teachers at Kings' College redundant. The National Union of Teachers is threatening legal action, saying the plan breaks employment law guaranteeing public sector jobs.

webTitle: Pupils benefit from a head for figures

fields.headline: Pupils benefit from a head for figures
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Almost 2,000 Manchester children are about to move from a tatty, leaking ruin into a gleaming, new £11m school which has not cost council taxpayers a penny.
fields.body:
Almost 2,000 Manchester children are about to move from a tatty, leaking ruin into a gleaming, new £11m school which has not cost council taxpayers a penny.

Parrs Wood high school is the result of a governors' initiative thought to be unique in British education.

As part of a toughly-negotiated deal, the school handed over part of its large site, in the south of the city, to developers in return for the new building, £800,000 for furniture and £250,000 towards the restoration of a grade II listed Georgian house next door.

The developers were also persuaded to throw in an all-weather sports pitch.

"I had to dig deep to find the entrepreneur within me," said Iain Hall, the school's head for 10 years. "I had to play a hard ball quite often."

"Mr Hall was a tough negotiator," admitted Peter Warden, surveyor on the scheme for the Leeds-based company Thornfield developments. "He was as hard as they come."

Thornfield will build an 11-screen cinema, bowling alley, bingo hall, health club, hotel, pub and restaurant on its part of the site.

As part of the deal, a student accommodation tower block has been flattened and the school has taken over a neighbouring field studies centre. "We have ended up with a bigger site than we started with," said Mr Hall.

The old school was built in 1969 from prefabricated concrete. By the mid-90s it was crumbling and repair bills were soaring. The governors knew they had to replace the building - but they realised cash-strapped Manchester could not foot the bill.

"We persuaded the city's chief executive to pay for a full-page advertisement in the Estates Gazette asking for developers to express interest," said Mr Hall. "Some people said no one would turn up. In the end 37 developers arrived in June 1996 to hear my presentation"

Building work began in February last year. "We have ended up with a scheme to be proud of," added Mr Warden.

A new science block is already in use and the whole building will be ready by May 1. The interior, with colours chosen by pupils, features some of the brightest walls to be found in a British school - vibrant blues, sunburst yellows, salmon pinks and searing purples.

The Georgian house will become an arts centre and the school, the only one in Manchester with a sixth form, is to apply for planning permission for a nursery.

The scheme was supported by Keith Bradley, the Labour MP for Withington, whose 11-year-old son attended the school for one day before transferring to the fee-paying Manchester grammar school.

Mr Hall said he would be the last staff member to move to the new site. "I've promised I will wait till the bulldozers advance towards me," he said.

Meanwhile he is selling off parquet flooring to ex-pupils at £1 a block. A sign in the old building's entrance reads: "Make us an offer for any part of the school."

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: Ancestors walked like gorillas
fields.body:
Ancestors walked like gorillas

Humans evolved from tree-dwelling ancestors who walked in the same way as modern gorillas and chimpanzees, new research shows.

Researchers at George Washington University, in Washington DC, report in the journal Nature, today, that they have found a bone in the wrist of Australopithecus, the ancestor of modern humans, that shows it was descended from creatures which walked with their bodies slumped forward and their knuckles to the ground.

Knuckle-walking allowed large apes to use their hands to walk with but keep long fingers to help them with tree climbing.

The discovery is another piece in the jigsaw of the emergence of human-like creatures from the forests of Africa, according to Leslie Aiello of University College, London, who also writes in Nature.

"It tells us that sometime way back in the dawn of time, the common ancestor of humans and apes walked on its knuckles.

"It puts paid to some alternative ideas - that they were climbers or bipedal from the beginning, or that they dog-paddled in the sea."
Tim Radford

Body of pensioner exhumed

The body of a pensioner was exhumed amid tight security yesterday in a police investigation of the deaths of six residents of a care home.

The remains of George Fowler, 86, were removed from Surville cemetery near St Helier, Jersey, in the Channel Islands.

Graveside prayers were led by the Rev David Shaw before the three-hour exhumation began just after 4am under floodlights but concealed by a screen and tent. The road to the cemetery was sealed off, and officers with dogs patrolled the area.

Mr Fowler, who had lived and worked in Jersey for many years, had been a resident at Carnarvon Lodge care home for the elderly in Clacton, Essex, for six weeks before his death last July.

Essex police were given permission by the Jersey authorities to exhume his body in a joint investigation with Essex social services of the alleged mistreatment of residents at the home, which has been closed since last October.

Acting Detective Superintendent Dick Madden of Essex police said it was a "sensitive occasion" for those involved, and that the exhumation had been a "dignified ceremony".

Mr Fowler's body had been taken to a mortuary at Jersey general hospital for a postmortem, the results of which would not be known for six or seven weeks, he said.

Police have said the aim of the postmortem was to seek support for information they had about his death.

Mr Fowler's family did not attend the exhumation but were expected to attend the re-internment at the cemetery, scheduled for 11am today.

The Essex police investigation into Carnarvon Lodge started in February last year and is now concerned with six deaths including that of Mr Fowler. The bodies of four of the people concerned had been cremated.

Four people have been remanded in custody on a variety of charges connected with the deaths of pensioners at Carnarvon Lodge. A man, 46, who has not been named, is on bail pending further police inquiries.

Yoko Ono sends love to bed-in

Four couples who embarked on a bed-in to win £10,000 and a holiday to Canada, have been sent a basket of flowers by Yoko Ono.

The bed-in, begun 14 days ago in Liverpool, was organised by Radio City 96.7FM to recreate John Lennon's call for world peace and mark what would have been his 60th birthday.

To win, the couples are required to stay in bed all day - with the exception of 10-minute breaks every two hours So far, no one has dropped out.

Ono's gift of roses and freesias came with a card reading: "Imagine all the people living in peace. Lots of love, Yoko."

Participant Samantha Woods said: "We could not believe it when the flowers arrived. It was really kind to think of us and send her encouragement."
Helen Carter

Ex-soldier awarded £745,000

A former private in the Royal Pioneer Corps who was attacked by a corporal was yesterday awarded £745,000 in damages by the army.

Leslie Hughes was thrown through a first floor window, severely injuring his arm, and later suffered a mental collapse after the incident at the West Moors barracks in Dorset.

Mr Justice Sachs, agreeing the settlement at the high court in London, said: "It is a sad and lamentable story which blighted this claimant's life at the age of 18."

Timothy Ryder, for Mr Hughes, told the judge that his client was assaulted in 1989 after going to collect his orders for the day.

Mr Hughes was grabbed around the waist and pushed out of a window, severely cutting his right arm.

He said Mr Hughes had still not fully recovered from the assault which had also triggered chronic paranoid schizophrenia. "He will remain unemployable and in need of out-patient and at times, in-patient, care."

Mr Hughes, who now lives with his father in Blackpool, Lancashire, said after the short hearing: "It has taken a very long time to reach a settlement but I am very happy with the result today."

A Ministry of Defence spokesman said the compensation was "acceptable".

fields.headline: Care cuts 'hitting nine in 10 elderly'
fields.trailText: As many as nine in 10 elderly or disabled people who receive home care services have suffered cuts in the help they get, a survey yesterday suggested.
fields.body:
As many as nine in 10 elderly or disabled people who receive home care services have suffered cuts in the help they get, a survey yesterday suggested.

Charities warned that tens of thousands of vulnerable people would be unable to go on living in their own homes unless the government intervened to prop up the creaking community care system.

The survey revealed the extent of cutbacks in care services in the three years since the Lords ruled that local authorities were entitled to take account of available resources in deciding on provision of support. The ruling, known as the Gloucestershire judgment, allowed an authority's social services department to assess an individual as needing help - but to withhold it on grounds that others had greater needs.

Even though ministers have stressed that health and social care agencies should aim to provide seamless services, social care will receive nothing from the extra £2bn announced for the NHS in the Budget.

The survey was carried out among Needs Must, a coalition of more than 30 social welfare charities campaigning to overturn the Gloucestershire judgment. More than 1,500 service users completed the questionnaires. A reduction or withdrawal of services was reported by 90% of people who had help with housework, and by 89% receiving meals. Cuts were also reported by 79% who were getting help with dressing, 72% getting bathing assistance and 70% receiving help using the lavatory. Of those surveyed, 59% reported problems getting adaptations and equipment for their home. More than half of these said they were refused help outright.

One respondent, from west London, said: "My mother is 86, with Alzheimer's disease, and has been on a list for over five years for an accessible bath or sit-in shower. She has been unable to bathe for five years. She has to be strip-washed at the sink in the kitchen."

As the survey sample was self selecting, the extent of cuts is likely to be overstated. But government figures confirm that fewer people are receiving home care services and "meals on wheels".

Latest statistics, for 1998, show a drop of 7% in just 12 months in the households in England receiving home help or care, although the level of provision remained the same - suggesting that the 447,000 households with support were getting more of it.

Lord Ashley, president of the Royal National Institute for Deaf People, said disabled people had been "first in the firing line" for loss of services. "Unless early action is taken by the government, many disabled people may [be] forced to go into institutions, at enormous personal cost, and tremendous financial cost to society."

webTitle: British feared Soviet plot to kidnap Nazis

fields.headline: British feared Soviet plot to kidnap Nazis
fields.standfirst: Secret papers reveal alarm over Spandau prisoners
fields.trailText: Britain believed the Russians were planning to kidnap the seven most senior surviving Nazis from Spandau prison after the end of the second world war, top secret Foreign Office papers released at the public record office yesterday reveal.
fields.body:
Britain believed the Russians were planning to kidnap the seven most senior surviving Nazis from Spandau prison after the end of the second world war, top secret Foreign Office papers released at the public record office yesterday reveal.

The British authorities in Germany became alarmed that the Soviet Union wanted to seize Albert Speer, Rudolf Hess and Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz, for their propaganda value and military knowledge soon after the Russians had imposed the Berlin blockade in July 1948.

The seven top Nazis at Spandau had all been sentenced to life at the Nuremburg war crimes trials, and had been guarded by a different allied power each month, until the agreement lapsed amid the tension of the cold war.

Whitehall was so alarmed by the prospect that it even considered removing the prisoners. Among those held were Hess, Hitler's number three; Speer, Nazi armaments minister; and Doenitz, naval commander in chief.

In July 1948 it was the Soviet Union's turn to guard the prisoners and Major General EO Herbert, officer commanding British troops in Berlin, warned Whitehall that since there were 40 to 50 Russian soldiers and the Soviet zone was nearby it would be easy for them to seize the prisoners.

"It is not possible for me as commander of the troops to right a situation which has been deliberately contrived by the Russians without deploying all my troops; even then I could not guarantee that the prisoners would not escape. Accordingly I have not taken, and do not propose to take, any special action to meet the emergency."

Pat Dean, a senior Foreign Office official, replied to the British authorities in Berlin that Whitehall was not too troubled by the fate of most of the prisoners but was seriously alarmed at the prospect of losing two of them in particular: "We cannot afford to allow Speer or Doenitz to escape or to fall into Russian hands.

"Speer as you know is a very able man and there is no doubt that the Russians would find him most useful if they could compel or induce him to work for them. Apart from his technical and organising skill, which is of the highest order, there was and probably still is considerable sympathy for him in Germany for ever having been tried and I have very little doubt that he could exercise very strong administrative and political influence if he ever felt inclined to do so," Mr Dean wrote in August 1948.

"Doenitz would be important to the Russians in two ways. First he is the last fuehrer, and there can be little doubt that he is potentially a highly attractive leader to a number of the worst elements in Germany.

"In addition he carried with him to the end, and probably still does, the loyalty and devotion of a large number of submarine crews, and with the knowledge at our disposal of the way in which the Russians have been experimenting in this field we should feel exceedingly unhappy if the Russians were to get hold of him."

The Foreign Office considered the possibility of removing them "in the event of there being real trouble in Berlin" but also looked at returning each of the "seven major war criminals" to the allied powers that had originally captured them. This would have given the Russians Erich Raeder, a former head of the German navy, while Britain would keep Doenitz, and the Americans Speer.

The British continued to worry about the possibility of the Russians seizing Doenitz and Speer throughout 1948, but by December their fears receded.

webTitle: RC archbishop in plea for unity

fields.headline: RC archbishop in plea for unity
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The new leader of the Roman Catholic church in England and Wales, the Most Rev Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, made a plea for Christian unity as he was installed as Archbishop of Westminster yesterday.
fields.body:
The new leader of the Roman Catholic church in England and Wales, the Most Rev Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, made a plea for Christian unity as he was installed as Archbishop of Westminster yesterday.

During a blaze of ceremony lasting 100 minutes at Westminster cathedral in London, the former bishop of Brighton and Arundel, chosen by the Pope last month to succeed the late Cardinal Basil Hume, greeted religious leaders with a call for Christians to "speak with one voice, to give witness to [Jesus Christ] in this strange and wonderful new world in which we live. I pledge myself to do so with my whole heart."

Still looking bemused by his unexpected elevation at the age of 67, the new archbishop, towering over his fellow bishops, spoke with wry and gentle wit of his hopes for leading a revival in the church, which has seen a 22% fall in attendance at mass among Britain's 4m Catholics in the past 10 years.

"I have no time for prophets of gloom," he said. "I do not believe these are gloomy times for the Catholic church in our country. When the skies are dark, the light shines more brightly."

Of national religious leaders only the Chief Rabbi, Jonathan Sacks, was not in the cathedral. He was watching the service on television in Archbishop's House next door.

The new archbishop thanked him - as well as George Carey, Archbishop of Canterbury, Robert Runcie, former archbishop of Canterbury, and heads of the free churches and of other denominations - for coming.

In the congregation were leading lay Catholics including Cherie Blair, the prime minister's wife, Paul Murphy, Welsh secretary and the most senior Catholic government minister, Michael Ancram, chairman of the Conservative party, Charles Kennedy, Liberal Democrat leader, and other MPs as well as lords and MEPs. The royal family was represented by Princess Michael of Kent.

As the service ended the archbishop emerged to greet the crowd outside the cathedral. He was upstaged momentarily by Mrs Blair, who plunged towards the crowd in full walkabout mode, waving and shaking hands.

"Sure, he's a handsome man," an elderly Irish nun could be heard saying, while beside her the cut glass voice of an English woman remarked: "He's got such wonderful Irish charm."

The archbishop knows that in the eight years before he reaches retirement age he will be expected to keep both these strands of British Catholicism united.

fields.headline: Chaplain wins sex bias claim
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A prison chaplain who claimed she felt "emotionally raped" after an argument with a Roman Catholic priest has won a claim for sex discrimination at an industrial tribunal.
fields.body:
A prison chaplain who claimed she felt "emotionally raped" after an argument with a Roman Catholic priest has won a claim for sex discrimination at an industrial tribunal.

Margaret Chilton, a Roman Catholic chaplain, discovered that male colleagues at Walton prison, in Liverpool, were paid £10 an hour while she was paid only £25 for a 20-hour week.

Miss Chilton was also refused permission to use cell keys while male colleagues were given access to keys to the cells of the 1,500 prisoners. When she complained, she was dismissed.

The tribunal at Liverpool ruled the prison service discriminated against Miss Chilton, 57, a theology graduate, because she was a woman.

She had complained to the prison chaplain, Father Gerard Burns, and the prison governor that she was being treated differently because of her sex. Fr Burns refused to issue her with cell keys and began shouting at her.

"Father Burns had reduced me to tears by way of his shouting at me, she said.

"When I tried to speak I was told that he could ask me to do as many hours as he saw fit. It was a complete violation of my rights which could be described as emotional rape."

The tribunal panel ruled that Miss Chilton had suffered discrimination. It added: "Even on the basis of Fr Burns's own evidence we would be bound to find that there had been unlawful discrimination against Miss Chilton."

Compensation will be decided at a later date.

A second claim that Miss Chilton had been victimised by the prison was dismissed.

Miss Chilton said later: "I feel that I have been put through a long ordeal, both at the prison and in the tribunal, because I am a woman. It was more like I was on trial rather than the prison service. They attempted to brand me as a manipulative, scheming woman, which is the ultimate in sex discrimination."

webTitle: TV newsreader invested in 'crooked' ostrich firm

fields.headline: TV newsreader invested in 'crooked' ostrich firm
fields.trailText: Fiona Armstrong, the former ITN newsreader, appeared in a promotional video for an ostrich breeding firm which conned investors out of millions of pounds, a court heard yesterday. She was so impressed she bought two birds.
fields.body:
Fiona Armstrong, the former ITN newsreader, appeared in a promotional video for an ostrich breeding firm which conned investors out of millions of pounds, a court heard yesterday. She was so impressed she bought two birds.

On the second day of the trial at Leicester crown court the jury heard she was among the lucky few who saw a return on the investment. The four men accused of running the scam allegedly defrauded more than 2,000 people, laundering money through an offshore bank account in the Caribbean.

The Ostrich Farming Corporation was set up above a video shop in New Ollerton, Nottinghamshire, in 1994, and run by Allan Walker and Brian Ketchell, later joined by Kevin and Russell Jones. They promised profits of up to 2,000% over 10 years for buying an ostrich for as little as £1,400.

Julian Baughan QC, prosecuting, said that in 15 months in business, before winding up, the firm had a turnover of more than £21m.

Walker, 57, and Ketchell, 49, both of Newark, Nottinghamshire, Russell Jones, 42, of Cantley, Doncaster, and Kevin Jones, 41, are accused of skimming off more than £5m.

All four deny conspiracy to defraud between December 22 1994 and April 7 1996.

fields.headline: Minister debunks family myth
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: The traditional nuclear family probably was always a myth, the home secretary said last night when he stressed that the government would not "preach" about marriage. While marriage did offer a better chance of a stable environment for children, other kinds of family "can in the right circumstances do well for children", Jack Straw said.
fields.body:
The traditional nuclear family probably was always a myth, the home secretary said last night when he stressed that the government would not "preach" about marriage. While marriage did offer a better chance of a stable environment for children, other kinds of family "can in the right circumstances do well for children", Jack Straw said.

His comments will be seen as an attempt - after the section 28 row - to shore up the government's compromise, for statutory guidance for schools, which brackets marriage with other stable relationships. The compromise, an amendment to the learning and skills bill, has been attacked by groups wanting official recognition of the primacy of marriage, and campaigning to keep section 28, which they say stops promotion of homosexuality.

Mr Straw, himself raised by a lone mother, said some believed it was no longer feasible or desirable to prop up the traditional family.

But he told the audience at a London event of the Institute for Public Policy Research, that the government was committed to supporting families whatever form they took. "This government will not preach about marriage, nor tell people how to sort out their lives and loves."

fields.headline: MP describes sword killing
fields.standfirst: Court told how councillor died in attack on surgery
fields.trailText: The desperate attempts by an MP and his assistant to fend off an attacker wielding a samurai sword were played out in court yesterday when Cheltenham MP Nigel Jones gave his first public account of the savage assault which ended his friend's life.
fields.body:
The desperate attempts by an MP and his assistant to fend off an attacker wielding a samurai sword were played out in court yesterday when Cheltenham MP Nigel Jones gave his first public account of the savage assault which ended his friend's life.

His palms severely lacerated as he tried to grasp the three and a half feet long blade, Mr Jones wrestled with the attacker before escaping to raise the alarm. His friend and assistant, Liberal Democrat councillor Andrew Pennington, was unable to fend off the attack.

Mr Pennington, 39, fell under a succession of blows to his stomach, chest and back, and only when the councillor was motionless in a pool of blood did the attacker casually stroll out of the constituency office.

The man accused of the killing, Robert Ashman, appeared at a committal hearing before Cheltenham magistrates yesterday. Reporting restrictions were lifted at the defence's request.

Dennis Scully, prosecuting, told the court how Ashman, 49, of Cheltenham, had on the day of the attack called at his parent's house. There he studied a book on human anatomy before taking his father's samurai sword and heading towards the MP's surgery.

The court heard how Ashman had made numerous visits to the MPs surgery on a variety of matters, most recently about a legal dispute surrounding the repossession of his former home.

"After about five minutes Mr Ashman began to ramble and spoke about a conspiracy between Cheltenham council and Lloyds TSB of which he was the victim," Mr Scully said.

Mr Jones and Mr Pennington appealed for calm but Ashman then drew the sword.

Mr Jones said in a statement that he pulled out a sword with a blade about 3ft long from his coat.

"He said: 'I'll tell you what I'm going to do, I'm going to do this.' He emphasised 'this' and was wide-eyed. He lunged at me and pointed the sword low towards my stomach. I grabbed hold of the blade, which was about 12 to 15 inches from me ... I held it with both hands and we fell on to the sofa with his body on top of me ... I can recall him growling and saying 'Yes, Yes' in quite a loud and disturbing manner. His eyes were bulging."

Mr Pennington died following the attack. Ashman was arrested near the scene of the attack and gave himself up without a struggle

He is charged with the murder of Mr Pennington, and the attempted murder of Mr Jones.

The court heard how Mr Jones received 50 to 60 stitches for serious cuts to the palms of his hands. A tendon in one finger was damaged and he lost the top of his little finger on his right hand.

Ashman's father, Geoffrey, said his son had visited him on the day of the attack. In a statement he said: "He did not seem upset about anything or anyone else, he did not seem preoccupied by anything.

"Later that evening while listening to the radio I heard the news that Cheltenham MP Nigel Jones had been attacked. I thought 'Cheltenham is going downhill'. I thought 'oh shit' because I knew Robert visited Nigel Jones."

Roger Everest, defending, then said he would be making a submission to the court today on whether the evidence against Ashman could sustain a charge of murder. "I accept there's a case to answer on the attempted murder charge."

The case continues today.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Sex attack at royal's school
fields.body:
Sex attack at royal's school

Three girls have been sexually assaulted at the Swiss school which Princess Beatrice is due to attend later this year, it emerged yesterday. The pupils at Aiglon College in the Alps were in a bedroom when the attack happened last Thursday. Police are investigating.

Man charged over acid case

A 47-year-old man will appear before Exeter magistrates today in connection with a doorstep acid attack on student Beverley Hammett, now 23, when she was babysitting at a house in Seaton, Devon, in 1996. A police spokesman said a man from Yeovil, Somerset, had been charged with counselling and procuring grievous bodily harm by another.

Anger at textile jobs switch

Textile jobs are being axed because of retailers' "thirst" for the cheapest option abroad, a report yesterday suggested. The GMB union, which is protesting at job cuts caused by Marks & Spencer sourcing more work overseas, joined forces with War on Want to publicise poor pay and conditions of workers in countries such as Indonesia and Sri Lanka.

Classics in the nursery

Musical toys for babies which play Beethoven and Bach were launched by toy maker Fisher-Price yesterday. The company said the toys were designed to stimulate and soothe babies, and provide relief for parents fed up with nursery rhymes.

webTitle: Speaker wins £10,000 damages over sex slur

fields.headline: Speaker wins £10,000 damages over sex slur
fields.trailText: The speaker, Betty Boothroyd, has been paid more than £10,000 in damages over suggestions that, before becoming mistress of the House of Commons, she was the secret mistress of a late Labour peer.
fields.body:
The speaker, Betty Boothroyd, has been paid more than £10,000 in damages over suggestions that, before becoming mistress of the House of Commons, she was the secret mistress of a late Labour peer.

The former chorus girl settled two libel claims against the Express newspaper and the Spectator magazine over articles by journalist William Cash that implied she had "overseen disreputable weekend parties at the country home of Lord Walston and had been his mistress".

Miss Boothroyd worked as a secretary to the millionaire socialist peer Lord Walston for several years from 1962.

The articles - headlined House Mistress and Secrets of Madam Speaker - referred to Miss Boothroyd's "interesting role as the understudy chatelaine of Newton Hall", Lord Walston's stately home near Cambridge, where she was alleged to have acted as a "stand-in weekend hostess" at drunken parties.

It was also claimed she acted as a surrogate mother to Lord Walston's six children while his wife, Catherine, conducted her 13-year affair with Graham Greene which was to become the subject of his novel The End of the Affair, now a film starring Ralph Fiennes.

In a statement from Miss Boothroyd's office, the speaker insisted that implications that she was the mistress of Lord Walston were entirely untrue.

"The two publications and Mr Cash have accepted that any such suggestions would be wrong. In addition, the two publications and Mr Cash are paying Miss Boothroyd a substantial sum in damages and all her legal costs. Miss Boothroyd has decided to pay the damages to charity."

Both publications have since printed apologies for the articles by Cash, son of the Eurosceptic Tory MP Bill Cash, published last month.

A spokesman for Miss Boothroyd said: "The speaker was very upset when she saw what the two articles had said about her.

She worked as Lord Walston's secretary for several years before entering parliament and, as Lady Walston became increasingly ill with the cancer that eventually killed her, her duties in London and Cambridgeshire became more onerous.

"At no stage, however, was her relationship with Lord Walston other than entirely proper and she remains a firm family friend of the late Lord and Lady Walston's children. She would have had no hesitation in pursuing her claim in the high court for damages and an injunction and, if necessary, taking the case to trial."

He added: "The speaker can now put this unpleasant episode behind her, secure in the knowledge that the defendants have publicly accepted the need to repair the damage done to her reputation."

Both the Express and the Spectator confirmed they had paid £5,000 each in damages to various charities chosen by Miss Boothroyd.

Harry Walston was made a Labour life peer in 1961 and became a junior minister under Harold Wilson. Since his death aged 78 in 1991, Miss Boothroyd has continued to live rent free in a cottage close to the Walston family home.
