fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report, page 9, March 21, headed, Couple jailed for neglect of 5 children, we incorrectly quoted Allan Bowman, in his capacity as chairman of Brighton and Hove area child protection committee, as saying, "shortcomings have been identified and put in place ..." According to the press office of Brighton and Hove council what he said was, "There has been an independently chaired inquiry which identified errors and shortcomings and made a series of recommendations for all the agencies involved. The independent chair of that inquiry has confirmed that the agencies have indeed acted upon her recommendations."
fields.body:
In a report, page 9, March 21, headed, Couple jailed for neglect of 5 children, we incorrectly quoted Allan Bowman, in his capacity as chairman of Brighton and Hove area child protection committee, as saying, "shortcomings have been identified and put in place ..." According to the press office of Brighton and Hove council what he said was, "There has been an independently chaired inquiry which identified errors and shortcomings and made a series of recommendations for all the agencies involved. The independent chair of that inquiry has confirmed that the agencies have indeed acted upon her recommendations."

On the sentences passed on the couple, Mr Bowman said, "I recognise that for the public these sentences may seem wholly inadequate, but I also recognise the constraints faced by the judge. I applaud the seriousness of the judge's remarks about the significance of neglect ..."

 In an article about universities and ethical investment, page 13, Guardian Education, March 21, we misspelt the name of the green officer of Cambridge University Student Union. It is Per Klevnäs (not Ter Klevnos). Apologies.

 There was an unfortunate slip in our version of Sylvia Plath's poem Lady Lazarus, page 19, Guardian Weekend, March 18, in which "Bright as a Nazi lampshade" became "Bright as a Naxi lampshade"

 In our report of the British Press Awards, page 1, yesterday, the phrase "informative and eminently readable critique" was our summary of the judges' remarks about the work of Nick Davies, reporter of the year, and not a direct quotation from their statement.

 Mishearing department, from page 11, yesterday, "There would also be regular reports prepared of each bird's progress and its prodigy." We should have said progeny (unlike the last time we misused prodigy; on that occasion we meant protégé). Collins Millennium recommended.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: EM.TV makes racing start
fields.body:
EM.TV makes racing start

German online broadcaster EM.TV & Merchandising yesterday confirmed its involvement in formula one motor racing when it bought 100% of the shares in Speed Investment for $712.5m (£451m), giving it a 50% stake in Slec, which owns all F1 activities.

The purchase price involves a stock component of 10m shares that will be placed on behalf of investors in Speed. EM.TV is also talking to Slec about acquiring a further shareholding in Formula One "within one year", it said.

Before this transaction 12.5% of Slec was held by a unit of Morgan Grenfell Private Equity, and 37.5% by American investment firm Hellman & Friedman. The remaining 50% is held by the Ecclestone family trust.

Glycosciences rises 147p

Oxford Glycosciences yesterday said it had filed patent applications over a total of 800 proteins, having identified them as active in causing disease. Its most recent filings focus on breast cancer and brain disorders including depression, schizophrenia and dementia. News of the applications sent shares up 147p to £18.05. Oxford Glycosciences hopes to have filed 1,500 applications by the end of the year.

EC demands accounts shift

The European Commission wants public companies to introduce separate accounts to assist EU inquiries into the granting of state subsidies, competition commissioner Mario Monti told the economic and monetary committee of the European Parliament yesterday.

The commission wants separate accounts for public companies which handle monopoly activities as well as competitive activities, he said. The proposal would give the commission an instrument to examine allegations of cross-subsidiation - subsidy payments giving public companies an unfair competitive advantage.

Chelford looks ready to soar

Shares in Chelford, the latest vehicle for the man behind AIM-listed stars Knutsford and Oxygen, are expected to soar when first trading in the company begins this morning. Michael Edelson, Oxygen's chairman, is floating Chelford as a cash shell in order to allow a privately owned business offering "substantial capital growth" a route to market. The shares are being placed at 2p each and will give Chelford a market capitalisation at the placing price of £2.1m, raising £840,000 net after expenses.

webTitle: Man U may hive off website

fields.headline: Man U may hive off website
fields.standfirst: Club considers flotation to tap value of its internet assets
fields.trailText: Manchester United is understood to be considering hiving off its multi-media division, centred around the manutd.com website which the club hopes will soon be able to broadcast games live on a pay per view basis.
fields.body:
Manchester United is understood to be considering hiving off its multi-media division, centred around the manutd.com website which the club hopes will soon be able to broadcast games live on a pay per view basis.

The plan, which could include a flotation of the business, is one of the options being studied to crystalise the value of its internet assets.

A number of companies with internet expertise are thought to have made proposed investments of cash and expertise in return for an equity stake in its new media interests.

Former BSkyB chief executive Mark Booth, who persuaded United chief executive Martin Edwards to sell the club 18 months ago and now runs internet investment company EPartners, is rumoured to have made an informal approach. However, the company denies an interest and the furore surrounding BSkyB's bid for the club and the subsequent Government decision to veto the takeover makes a new deal unlikely. Sports website specialists Sportal and MSN, the Microsoft-owned content company, are also rumoured to have expressed an interest.

Sources close to United claim the club is prepared to "think radically" about how to exploit its web assets but emphasise that plans are at an early stage and unlikely to be finalised before the renegotiation of the Premiership broadcasting rights in the summer.

United hopes that some of the rights, like pay per view and internet, will be "unbundled" allowing individual clubs to retain control of their content. Manutd.com is run by TransWorld International, a sports media division for Mark McCormack's IMG.

Advisers to United will need to overcome a number of hurdles to accommodate any new investment, not least potential opposition from fans. Media companies' ownership of football clubs is an increasingly thorny issue. BSkyB owns a 9.9% stake in United and similar interests in five other top sides. Rival broadcasters NTL and Granada have also invested in Premiership sides. The government is monitoring the situation closely, and Channel 4 news last night claimed it could ask regulators to intervene if competition rules are threatened.

One possible route would be to spin off its multi-media assets into a separate vehicle, allowing outside investment but retaining a majority stake.

A United spokesman last night declined to comment on "market speculation".

Analysts at Warburg Dillon Read said in a recent research note that the European champions' worldwide fan base makes it "the ultimate content provider". Manutd.com, the official club website set up last summer, receives 8m hits per month. That number is likely to increase sharply if United wins control of the rights to telecast its matches live to countries overseas when the Premiership broadcasting deal is renegotiated in the summer.

The investment bank estimates that manutd.com and extra revenues expected from the forthcoming broadcasting rights renegotiation are worth at least £1 per share. The research helped the club's valuation to pass £1bn, though profit taking has knocked the shares back from a high of 438p this month. Last night they closed up 4p at 384p.

webTitle: Celltech slashes product development to cut costs

fields.headline: Celltech slashes product development to cut costs
fields.standfirst: www.celltech.co.uk
fields.trailText: Biotechnology group Celltech, which has just joined the FTSE 100, is radically slimming down its development pipeline as it strives to break even this year.
fields.body:
Biotechnology group Celltech, which has just joined the FTSE 100, is radically slimming down its development pipeline as it strives to break even this year.

The company is axing half the potential products it inherited from Medeva, with which it merged in January. It also confirmed it was in talks to sell Medeva's vaccine manufacturing business, which employs 700 people in Speke, Liverpool.

Celltech's finance director Peter Allen said: "We've had a long, hard look at things and we've chosen what we want to take forward."

Among the projects to be dropped is an investigation into the use of nicotine to treat inflammatory bowel disorders. Celltech's finance director Peter Allen said: "It was viewed as not being a particularly compelling project. We didn't find a lot of support for it, even within Medeva."

Celltech is ending work on a slow-release version of methylphenidate, Medeva's blockbuster treatment for attention deficit disorder. A treatment for hepatitis has also been abandoned.

Annual results yesterday showed that Celltech's losses remained broadly unchanged at £38m, while Medeva's profits collapsed from £71m to £42m because of a slump in sales of methylphenidate which recently lost its patent protection.

Celltech's shares fell 100p to £11.00, having slipped from £18 in the general biotech sell-off over the last week.

Analysts expect the combined company to break even this year, then make profits of up to £60m in 2001, helped by sales of Chirocaine, a new long-lasting anaesthetic and two other products set to reach the market.

fields.headline: Gas demerger creates bid target
fields.standfirst: BG International
fields.trailText: BG International, the fast-growing gas producer and supplier, could swiftly become a takeover target after the planned autumn divorce from its parent in a £12bn demerger, experts said yesterday.
fields.body:
BG International, the fast-growing gas producer and supplier, could swiftly become a takeover target after the planned autumn divorce from its parent in a £12bn demerger, experts said yesterday.

But BG executives hope that the long-awaited demerger plans will reward the group's 1.2m shareholders by creating two dynamic companies capable of holding their own within the FTSE 100.

Transco, the heavily regulated gas pipelines business, is already planning to turn itself into a multi-utility open to strategic alliances with telecoms groups and takeovers of parts of water companies.

Advanced plans to buy a water group - thought to be either Pennon or Kelda - broke down some months ago when the international business objected, illustrating the need for a demerger first heralded by last year's restructuring.

"We were beginning to see we were making either/or decisions," said David Varney, the BG chief executive who is to step down after the demerger with a £500,000 payoff.

"But both businesses needed to make their own decisions ," he added. "We would have been constrained if we kept both businesses within the same company." Phil Nolan, set to be chief executive of the stand- alone Transco group, said its aim would be to build the networks for supplying services rather than the products themselves. "The public wants the streets to be dug up only once," added Mr Varney.

The international business, to be headed by the present chief executive of BG International, Frank Chapman, has increased its pre-tax earnings tenfold in the past three years to £356m, and plans to expand its role overseas as a power generator and supplier of domestic gas.

It also sees itself as a combattant of urban pollution, no tably in the third world, via gas-powered or hybrid vehicles such as taxis and buses.

Dick Giordano, the BG chairman who will chair BG International, said its growth potential well beyond its role as an explorer and producer may attract bidders. "We would have to listen," he added, "if a suitable company with a fat wallet" approached BG.

Equally, he said, the international business was open to acquisitions or alliances but had no plans. Analysts speculated that groups such as Shell, ENi of Italy and Repsol of Spain could emerge as potential bidders. BG shares rose 31p, or just under 10%, to close at 337p.

fields.headline: Mitsubishi braced for £1bn takeover
fields.trailText: Mitsubishi Motors indicated yesterday that it is ready to accept a £1bn alliance with DaimlerChrysler that would create the world's third-biggest car manufacturing group.
fields.body:
Mitsubishi Motors indicated yesterday that it is ready to accept a £1bn alliance with DaimlerChrysler that would create the world's third-biggest car manufacturing group.

Under a deal, expected to be formally unveiled by the end of this month, the struggling Japanese car maker has reportedly agreed to sell a 33.4% stake to the German-American conglomerate, giving it in effect a majority shareholding.

With a combined production capacity of 6.5m units per year, an alliance would be exceeded in size only by General Motors and Ford.

In the clearest sign yet that a deal is imminent, Mitsubishi, Japan's fourth-biggest car maker, said its board had authorised company president Katsuhiko Kawasoe to negotiate a tie-up with a foreign firm.

According to local media reports, the heads of the two companies outlined a basic agreement during talks in Kyoto at the weekend that would effectively cede control to DaimlerChrysler.

No details of the financial arrangements have been revealed, but a 33.4% stake - the minimum required for a veto over board decisions - is worth £1.2bn at current share prices. The company's biggest shareholder is Mitsubishi Heavy, which has a 27% stake.

The two companies are also said to have agreed to develop jointly a fuel-efficient car that will be able to travel 100km on three litres of petrol.

Neither party would confirm the reports. "We've been discussing numerous topics with numerous firms and nothing has been decided," a Mitsubishi spokesman said.

The Japanese car maker, which is groaning under a £10bn debt burden, is also known to have talked with Ford during its search for a ucash-rich foreign partner.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.body:
Those Lastminute.com investors who didn't even have time to make hay while the sun shone on the glamour stock - prevented from trading until a week after the offering - must now be pleased that they were limited to such small stakeholdings.

Shares in the internet travel company fell again yesterday, down another 32p to 287p, 92p below the initial offer price and 260p below the heady heights that Lastminute touched on its frenzied first day of trading. Those small investors sitting on a paper loss should console themselves with the knowledge that the oversub scription limited them to 35 shares each. Lastminute.com is merely the most high profile (this week) of the hi-tech outfits suffering on the stock market. Psion, at the beginning of the year being touted as a world beating British prize fighter, looking every inch a champion as it climbed into the (telephone) ring, shed another 287p yesterday, following a loss of almost £6 on Budget day, to reach £46.10.

Perhaps Psion's decline is merely a very necessary injection of common sense into the communication company's stock market standing after its share price climbed to the dizzy heights of £72 three weeks ago, having spent its first two years in existence bobbing along quite happily below £10 per share.

Overall its a torrid time for new-tech: as it has been since shortly after the FTSE decided to join the frenzy and launch its Techmark index, which again yesterday failed to reach positive territory.

Smaller tech stocks suffered too: Interactive Investor fell 27p to 202p as investor interest waned in spite of yesterday's strategic alliance with thestreet.co.uk - though the stock is still above February's 150p-per-share offer price.

Gaming Internet lost 8p to 58p over fears that changes to the tax regime for bookmakers could hit the booming internet betting sector. Yesterday's Budget outlined alterations to gaming duty, the levels of which have encouraged bookmakers to move to offshore internet-based operations.

Even the more established information and technology stocks are suffering. Reuters shed 43p to £13.70, as investors registered their disappointment at news that the group's finance director, Rob Rowley, is to become chief executive of its Reuterspace internet business.

A cheerier outlook was presented by the retailers. Kingfisher rose 48p to 534p, after the high street group revealed solid full year figures and, ironically, an accelerated e-commerce strategy.

fields.headline: Property groups
fields.trailText: With the price of a rather average terraced house in Fulham rising by more than £410 a day and estate agents getting fatter by the week, it seems almost ridiculous to talk of bargains in the property market.
fields.body:
With the price of a rather average terraced house in Fulham rising by more than £410 a day and estate agents getting fatter by the week, it seems almost ridiculous to talk of bargains in the property market.

Yet that is exactly what is on offer among the quoted property companies, even though their financial performances are coming in at record levels.

Yesterday it was the turn of Slough Estates, Britain's largest industrial property group, which produced a 27% profits rise to £128m in 1999 while housebuilder Barratt's profits rose 23% to £50.5m.

Such performances were sufficient to earn both a strong rise in share price: Slough was up by 9p to 322p and Barratt climbed 20p to 225p.

Yet Slough's shares are still running at a huge discount to asset value - shares ended 154p below the net assets.

Although Slough says it has no intention of excercising its right to buy back 10% of its shares - permission to do so will be granted at the annual meeting - the company may soon be in a minority in being able to resist the bargain its own equity appears to offer.

Earlier this week, for example, Nick Leslau, head of AIM-listed Prestbury group, said he would consider starting to buy back shares. He said: "As dis counts to NAV [net asset value] increase, companies will have little alternative but to sell assets or buy in their own shares. Why buy someone else's assets when you can buy your own at a large discount?"

Property company shares are trading at a discount to net asset value wider than that of the recession of the early 1990s, when a large slug of newbuilds were empty. But now there are not heaps of va cant properties - indeed, Slough says demand is well in pace with the space being created by newbuilds.

Indeed, Slough argues that far from the traditional widening of the gap between asset and share values, the company sees little reason to alter the balance of its long term approach because of what it interprets as a fashionable bubble.

fields.headline: Hutchison dumps Vodafone holding
fields.standfirst: Market forces  David Teather
fields.trailText: The appetite for shares in Britain's biggest telecoms company Vodafone-AirTouch was in evidence yesterday when 925m shares in the business were placed in less than 90 minutes.
fields.body:
The appetite for shares in Britain's biggest telecoms company Vodafone-AirTouch was in evidence yesterday when 925m shares in the business were placed in less than 90 minutes.

The shares were sold at 349p by Hutchison Whampoa, the Hong Kong conglomerate. The company found itself holding Vodafone paper after the British company bought German rival Mannesmann earlier this year in which Hutchison had a 10% stake.

Hutchison has pocketed £3.2bn from the placing and still owns another 3.5% which it has undertaken not to divest for at least six months. The deal was described as the biggest ever single placing and the Vodafone share price dipped 5% before rallying to close 10p lower at 367p.

A Vodafone spokeswoman said the company was delighted by the market's response.

The placing was executed by Deutsche Bank and Goldman Sachs, which also had a good day. They are expected to have taken a commission of up to 3%. The shares are understood to have been bought by a broad range of institutions.

It has been a lucrative year for Hutchison. It received a strong premium when it sold mobile phone network Orange to Mannesmann and, as it took Mannesmann shares, gained another after Vodafone pitched in. If it hangs on to its remaining shareholding in Vodafone it will also end up back with a stake in Orange once it is relisted on the stock exchange. Then the fun begins again with new buyers queuing up.

Analysts said that Hutchison had likely judged that its 5.1% share in Vodafone was not enough to exert any influence over the company and so had decided to exit. The gain will also please investors in the company when it reports earnings today.

The results will include a HK$118bn (£9.6bn) exceptional gain on the sale of Hutchison's stake in Orange to Mannesmann.

The previous biggest share placing was back in 1988 when the Kuwait Investment Office sold some £2bn worth of shares in the then British Petroleum.
fields.bodyText: The appetite for shares in Britain's biggest telecoms company Vodafone-AirTouch was in evidence yesterday when 925m shares in the business were placed in less than 90 minutes. The shares were sold at 349p by Hutchison Whampoa, the Hong Kong conglomerate. The company found itself holding Vodafone paper after the British company bought German rival Mannesmann earlier this year in which Hutchison had a 10% stake. Hutchison has pocketed £3.2bn from the placing and still owns another 3.5% which it has undertaken not to divest for at least six months. The deal was described as the biggest ever single placing and the Vodafone share price dipped 5% before rallying to close 10p lower at 367p. A Vodafone spokeswoman said the company was delighted by the market's response. The placing was executed by Deutsche Bank and Goldman Sachs, which also had a good day. They are expected to have taken a commission of up to 3%. The shares are understood to have been bought by a broad range of institutions. It has been a lucrative year for Hutchison. It received a strong premium when it sold mobile phone network Orange to Mannesmann and, as it took Mannesmann shares, gained another after Vodafone pitched in. If it hangs on to its remaining shareholding in Vodafone it will also end up back with a stake in Orange once it is relisted on the stock exchange. Then the fun begins again with new buyers queuing up. Analysts said that Hutchison had likely judged that its 5.1% share in Vodafone was not enough to exert any influence over the company and so had decided to exit. The gain will also please investors in the company when it reports earnings today. The results will include a HK$118bn (£9.6bn) exceptional gain on the sale of Hutchison's stake in Orange to Mannesmann. The previous biggest share placing was back in 1988 when the Kuwait Investment Office sold some £2bn worth of shares in the then British Petroleum.

fields.headline: Rhyme to go home
fields.standfirst:
The Poetry Places scheme installed poets in football grounds, high street stores, even prison sex offenders' units. Now it's sending them back to their ivory towers. Maev Kennedy mourns the end of an era
Books Unlimited

fields.body:
The instant museum piece

Last year Bernardine Evaristo was poet-in-residence at the Museum of London. This is an unpublished poem, Routes.

Time has frozen this midwinter night. Outside

the pavement coated with a transparent skin,

I retreat into down, sensing the vibration

of polar sheets creeping south, burying

us a thousand feet under blue ice, diverting

the river out of the Vale of St Albans

into the London Basin. Welcome home. Welcome

first citizen, chasing reindeer over the hip joint

with France, tropical and glacier cycles, waves

of migrators - your long trek north, from below

the Sahara, circling a camp fire by the Thames

the hair of wolves over tight backs; dread-

locked beards, un-polished eyes, your slow,

heavy mouths chewing fresh rhinoceros, roasted,

no spices; unaware that you are dislocating

from France as you eat, that the Channel is rising,

that my heated body floats above a London of birch

and pine forest, of open grassland where gangs

of straight-tusked elephants gather in Trafalgar

Square, hippopotami wallow in the brown marshes

of Pall Mall and from Marble Arch I gaze longingly

on sheets of marigold, meadowsweet, mint.

Unless some wealthy philanthropist surfaces with a craving for couplets at checkouts and quatrains on bin bags, the most successful and popular campaign in the history of British poetry is about to come to a full stop.

Over the past two years, Poetry Places, a scheme organised by the Poetry Society to get poets out of their ivory towers and into the workplace, has brought poems to the public in the most unlikely places: poems on greaseproof wrappers in Wigan chip shops, poems printed on refuse sacks in Norfolk, poems on spikes among the plants in a botanical garden, and poems on walls, bus shelters and beaches.

The two-year programme, the brainchild of outgoing Poetry Society director Chris Meade, attracted the highest ever arts lottery grant for literature: £450,000. But now the time is up and the money is gone; the final grants have been allocated, and the last poets-in-residence are taking their places. They include: Benjamin Zephaniah, who will shadow Michael Mansfield QC through his court appearances, and, if the clients agree, through his private consultations; James Crowden, who will work at Wheal Jane tin mine in Cornwall; Christine Hemp, who will be in Lambeth, south London, trying to hold a poetic line between police officers and young people judged at risk of becoming offenders; and Antrim-born poet Brendan Cleary, who will take up a post in one of the oldest working cinemas in the country, the 1910 Duke of York's in Brighton, where they hope to put poems on screen between films.

The project has generated unprecedented publicity for British poetry: when Peter Sansom became Marks & Spencer's poet-in-residence, the news went round the world. Sub-editors vied in atrocious, punning headlines: "Shall I compare thee to a summer sale?" wrote one, while the Star composed an entire verse: "I wandered lonely through the crowd/At my local M&S/When all at once I saw a bard/Among the pants and vests." The Wall Street Journal carried a story on the chip shop poets, Peter Street and Steven Waling, while the media in Canada, India, Japan and Korea reported on Anglo-Czech poet Andrew Fusek Peters being helicoptered to the gas platform off Great Yarmouth where he worked 12-hour shifts like the crew. And the scheme's millennium poet, Simon Armitage, got more admiring reviews for his 1,000-line new year poem, Killing Time, than the Dome itself, where he has been in residence. Indeed, he got rather more sympathetic reviews than the millennium poem by poet laureate Andrew Motion.

Morag McRae has run the scheme with fellow poet Christina Patterson from an attic in Covent Garden, and calculates that at least 10,000 people have come into direct contact with a living, published poet, who has turned up in their doctor's waiting room, supermarket, or mobile library. Ian McMillan, who was already club mascot at Barnsley FC, became an online poet in Yorkshire, reading, writing and talking poetry in a specially designated poet's train carriage, and Roger McGough took up his post as internet poet-in-residence at BT before Christmas.

Altogether, 124 poets have worked at 146 centres - including a prison and the crypt of Worcester cathedral - for periods lasting between a few days and six months. In a north London tattoo parlour, poet Patience Aghabi and the tattooist gave one client an entire Shakespeare sonnet wrapped around his upper arm. "It's been wonderful. The public reaction has been astonishing and terribly touching, and the poets themselves feel they have benefited enormously," says McRae.

All the poets who took up the full residencies, from those with only the slenderest of published volumes to superstars such as McGough and Zephaniah, were paid the same: £5,000 for six months, part-time. That's peanuts to many of the firms' employees but, for many poets, it was the best-paid work they'd ever had. Uniquely, Kevin McCann had one of the toughest of all the residencies extended for three months because all sides agreed there was more work to be done. Liverpool-based McCann had already worked in Birmingham prison, and for Poetry Places went into the vulnerable prisoners' section in Wymott jail. He has previously worked with murderers and men convicted of crimes of extreme violence; now he is working mainly with sex offenders, including men who have raped children, who are themselves in grave danger from fellow prisoners.

"There is a powerful, 'There but for the grace of God' factor," he says. "Men have told me the most tragic, awful stories you could imagine about their own early years - stories you can hardly believe - and later the probation officers or prison officers say, 'Yes, that's right - that's what happened'. At one point I became really quite depressed - terribly aware of the roots of violence. I'd be walking through a shopping centre and hear somebody shouting at a child, and the hairs would stand up on the back of my neck."

The men McCann works with are sweeping the boards in the annual Koestler awards for prison writing: one man, brought back to the ability to read, write and even speak after a brain haemorrhage by learning a verse of Blake's Tiger Tiger each week with McCann, has written three prize-winning poems. "Most of them are now writing things as good as you'll read in any small press poetry publication," he says.

Instead of heaping praise on everything they write, McCann demands the inmates learn about formal structure and style, metaphor and simile. "I have found a sharp, savage contrast in working with these men. I have taught at Liverpool University, offered some tentative delicate criticism to a student, and provoked outrage that I have completely misunderstood their genius," he says. "Whereas I've said to these men, 'Apart from the first verse, everything else you've done has got to be binned', and they've thought about it and said, 'OK, mate', and come back the next week with the whole thing redone. Their approach is inspiring - and on the weeks when I go in and hear six really good poems, it's just a brilliant place to be."

McCann's prison residency will come to an end, along with the rest, but McRae sees no reason why companies can't continue to sponsor in-house poets themselves. "We did rather hope that might happen - but it hasn't," she says. "We think it's been a great success. It has certainly reached, and touched an enormous number of people, and maybe given them some new ideas about poetry and even life. But it's not going to change the world. It's only poetry, after all."

In the chorus of approval for the scheme, there was bound to be a sour note, though. One of the earliest, most successful residencies was that of poet Lavinia Greenlaw at one of the country's most successful law firms, Mishcon de Reya, where she emailed a daily poem to employees. Greenlaw became enthralled by the baroque legal language that has appeared in some of her new work, and also tapped an unsuspected lyric vein among the lawyers.

Almost everyone agreed that the experiment had been a triumph - except one, unnamed, senior partner, who gave his own assessment of the project in the journal Commercial Lawyer: "I am pretty sure no new work came in as a result of it," he wrote.

fields.headline: Shooting stars
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot visits Liverpool's new festival of video art
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot visits Liverpool's new festival of video art.
fields.body:
Two slobbish faces are in close-up on adjacent video monitors in the Tate Gallery, Liverpool. One belongs to a bloated football fan, the other to a dealer on the floor of a futures exchange. Both men have hard, unblinking eyes. But it is the mouths that command attention. One is clamped shut with tension while the other - the dealer's - is rotating so violently that he seems in danger of dislocating his jaw. Everything is in slow motion, so we can see across the glistening expanse of his tongue to the back of his throat.

Not a pretty sight. Thankfully, his head turns sideways when the mouth jerks open to convey some apparently urgent information across the trading floor. At the same time, our fan in the stands is roaring too. Not that we can hear anything. We just see these great orifices gaping in unison, as though strange sea creatures were calling through the deep.

Artist Dryden Goodwin has drawn out the build-up to this release of emotion, heightening our sense of expectation with taut, echoing background music. We've had to wait for it - and Wait is the title of his contribution to The Other Side of Zero, a special post-millennium version of Liverpool's biennial Video Positive festival.

Goodwin's clever games with the notions of anticipation and release seem an appropriate introduction to a festival that puts forward as one of its themes "the passage of time in a speeded-up universe". At a time when technology is impinging on our lives in ever-faster ways, the artists here are using it to slow things down - "allowing us to see things we couldn't see in any other way," says Eddie Berg, director of Fact (Foundation for Art and Creative Technology) and something of a pioneer in this field.

He staged the first Video Positive exhibition in the late 80s, when much of the British art world saw electronic work as marginal and gimmicky; now the work of just about every Turner prizewinner involves video installation. "It's become mainstream," says Berg. "So a festival like this has to look at how we can approach video in a different way." Hence The Other Side of Zero, a suitable opportunity to pause and take a step back from the much-hyped cutting edge of technology.

The nine works on show (on three different sites) have at least one thing in common - a stripped-down style in which flashy, virtuoso displays are noticeable by their absence.

Goodwin's Wait shares a gallery with two pieces whose subjects are either static or moving extremely slowly. In AK Dolven's haunting Looking Back, three old women walk backwards across the same Norwegian landscape, projected on to three giant screens. They travel with such glacial slowness that you begin to wonder if they are risking hypothermia. It takes a while to realise that one of them has stopped mid-screen. She scans the surroundings she knows so well before backing gingerly towards the edge of the screen. First she becomes a shadow; then she disappears. The others are not far behind her. All that's left is the landscape: dramatic, indestructible, timeless.

If Dolven's videos have a painterly quality, Monika Oeschler's work is distinctly cinematic. Here are seven female poker players, perched on stools in a garish club. A camera positioned in the centre of the table rotates slowly to pick up what action there is so that viewers feel as though they are on a gentle merry-go-round.

Unlike the impassive men this viewer has played poker with, these women (all carefully choreographed actresses) allow some mobility to infiltrate their facial muscles. But are the dimpling smiles and dagger-like eyeballings from beneath fluttering lashes just a more feminine way of bluffing? If the eyes are the window of the soul, poker players keep the curtains drawn.

Oeschler sets about prising the curtains apart, affording us chinks of light as the group dynamics unfold. Long, varnished nails dig into soft green baize near an ashtray filled with cigarette butts. One woman flutters a fan, another twirls a lipstick between elegant fingers, yet another twiddles with her beads while the tension mounts. Dialogue is sparse, and peppered with poker terms such as "call" or "pair of queens", but, compared with the other two exhibits in the Tate, the film is positively loquacious. So how can Berg claim that another theme of his festival is "the power of the human voice as a primary point of connection"?

He points me in the direction of two other galleries, where there are works with a much more aural content. There are no faces at all in Ugo Roninone's sound installation at the Bluecoats Arts Centre - just two stark, wintry talking trees, either side of a white wall. It could be a set for a Beckett play. But, instead of his words, we have an endlessly repeated snatch of dialogue from what sounds like a B-movie.

Through microphones, threaded like Christmas lights through the lacquered branches, two American male voices discuss why one of them has a broken heart. The woman responsible is called Vera. It's mildly amusing the first time you hear it, and almost mesmeric by the 10th. By the 20th time, though, I felt in need of something a little less stylised and more down-to-earth.

 The Other Side of Zero is at the Tate, Bluecoats Arts Centre and the Open Eye Gallery, all in Liverpool, till May 1. Details: 0151-709 2663.

fields.headline: Just bite on the bacteria
fields.standfirst: Jim Giles on the genetic engineering that could make a big hole in drilling
fields.trailText: Jim Giles on the genetic engineering that could make a big hole in drilling
fields.body:
Few medical breakthroughs arouse such excitement as one that promises to end trips to the dentist. Cavities don't kill, but we've all been to the dentist and most of us hate it.

Professor Jeffrey Hillman's new treatment won't put dentists out of a job, but it could leave them with a lot less to do. And the people who have most to lose are worried. "Some dentists don't believe it will be successful. They see it as a threat," says Hillman.

The university of Florida researcher has come up with a brilliantly simple way to tackle tooth decay. Using the genetic engineering techniques best known for creating GM food he has engineered a harmless version of the bacteria that rots our teeth.

The villain of the piece is Streptococcus mutans, a naturally occurring bacteria that lives in our mouths. Streptococcus mutans is busy on your teeth right now, happily feeding itself on whatever sugar it can find. It provides us with some benefits - producing important vitamins and giving protection against nastier bacteria - but our teeth pay the price. In return for keeping it alive, the bacteria produces lactic acid which attacks tooth enamel and causes cavities.

Hillman manipulated Streptococcus DNA to remove the gene responsible for producing lactic acid. The new bacteria - known as an effector strain - thrives on sugar but, unlike the original bacteria, does not produce lactic acid. If this strain were used to replaced the original strain on our teeth the majority of cavities could be prevented.

The new strain was tested first on rats who, like humans, suffer the effects of the Streptococcus mutans. No only did the effector strain colonise the rat's teeth, it actually dominated the original strain. Ironically, feeding the rats with a high-sugar diet helped the new strain replace the old one and hence reduced the amount of lactic acid. The long-term prospects are also good - the new strain appears to be stable and to stay permanently on teeth.

Clinical trials start this year and Hillman is confident that they will confirm the safety and effectiveness of the new strain. But convincing the authorities to license his treatment may not be his biggest challenge. After a slow start, opposition to GM technologies is taking off in the US. The idea of gargling with a genetically modified bacteria is unlikely to appeal, regardless of what clinical trials prove.

Hillman is confident the public will see the benefits. "This approach is really a lot more natural than most of the antibacterial approaches in use today. Over the next 100,000 or so years, natural selection would act on Streptococcus mutans to reduce its virulence and on humans to increase their resistance to Streptococcus mutans. This therapy is an attempt to speed up this process by doing in the lab in 20 years what it would take nature 100,000 years."

If Hillman's idea does pass the clinical trials and a sceptical public can be persuaded, the treatment could be in use in two to three years. "The ideal application would be to treat infants when their first teeth appear. They normally acquire Streptococcus mutans via contaminated saliva from their mother," says Hillman. "The child would simply visit their dentist for a squirt of solution on their teeth."

Since the new strain dominates over the old this initial treatment should last for a lifetime. And the work with rats suggests that adults - who already have Streptococcus mutans on their teeth - will be protected by the same simple process.

Streptococcus isn't the only bacteria that causes decay, but it is reckoned to be responsible for the majority of cavities. And even if it doesn't eliminate tooth decay, it might leave dentists with a little more time on their hands.

Streptococcus mutans is busy on your teeth right now, happily feeding itself on whatever sugar it can find. It provides us with some benefits - producing important vitamins and giving protection against nastier bacteria - but our teeth pay the price. In return for keeping it alive, the bacteria produces lactic acid which attacks tooth enamel and causes cavities. Hillman manipulated Streptococcus DNA to remove the gene responsible for producing lactic acid. The new bacteria - known as an effector strain - thrives on sugar but, unlike the original bacteria, does not produce lactic acid. If this strain were used to replaced the original strain on our teeth the majority of cavities could be prevented. The new strain was tested first on rats who, like humans, suffer the effects of the Streptococcus mutans. No only did the effector strain colonise the rat's teeth, it actually dominated the original strain. Ironically, feeding the rats with a high-sugar diet helped the new strain replace the old one and hence reduced the amount of lactic acid. The long-term prospects are also good - the new strain appears to be stable and to stay permanently on teeth. Clinical trials start this year and Hillman is confident that they will confirm the safety and effectiveness of the new strain. But convincing the authorities to license his treatment may not be his biggest challenge. After a slow start, opposition to GM technologies is taking off in the US. The idea of gargling with a genetically modified bacteria is unlikely to appeal, regardless of what clinical trials prove. Hillman is confident the public will see the benefits. "This approach is really a lot more natural than most of the antibacterial approaches in use today. Over the next 100,000 or so years, natural selection would act on Streptococcus mutans to reduce its virulence and on humans to increase their resistance to Streptococcus mutans. This therapy is an attempt to speed up this process by doing in the lab in 20 years what it would take nature 100,000 years." If Hillman's idea does pass the clinical trials and a sceptical public can be persuaded, the treatment could be in use in two to three years. "The ideal application would be to treat infants when their first teeth appear. They normally acquire Streptococcus mutans via contaminated saliva from their mother," says Hillman. "The child would simply visit their dentist for a squirt of solution on their teeth." Since the new strain dominates over the old this initial treatment should last for a lifetime. And the work with rats suggests that adults - who already have Streptococcus mutans on their teeth - will be protected by the same simple process. Streptococcus isn't the only bacteria that causes decay, but it is reckoned to be responsible for the majority of cavities. And even if it doesn't eliminate tooth decay, it might leave dentists with a little more time on their hands.

fields.headline: The gospel of the web
fields.standfirst:
Nick Ryan on the holy wars fought in cyberspace between religious movements and their critics
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Nick Ryan on the holy wars fought in cyberspace between religious movements and their critics
fields.body:
August 12 1995 was a Saturday much like any other in the urban sprawl of Arlington, Virginia. Except that an alert went out over email and on Usenet groups to say that 10 people - including two federal marshals, two computer technicians, one a former FBI agent, and several attorneys - were raiding the home of former Scientologist Arnaldo Lerma.

Leading the raid was Helena Kobrin, a senior lawyer representing the Church of Scientology. She was well known on the newsgroup alt.religion.scientology , due to her frequent postings which insisted on the deletion of files she claimed contained the Church's copyrighted materials. Another was Earle Cooney, a Church lawyer who chaired the board of Boston university.

Emails and postings flew back and forth, saying that the raiding party was seizing Lerma's computer, backups, disks, modem and scanner. A frequent Usenet poster and critic of his former brethren, Lerma was distraught. Many of his personal and business files were kept on his PC. Told that his hardware would be returned the following Monday, he was still waiting weeks later.

There had been other raids in the US and further afield, including on an anonymous remailer run by Johan Helsingius in Finland, as the Church pursued anyone it felt was posting "secret" materials.

Such confrontations are continuing - albeit in more subtle form - as pro- and anti-cultists struggle for control of the "truth" over the net.

Although a quick search on the web reveals dozens of sites discussing the term, "cult", few actually agree what a "cult" is. According to the Ontario-based group Religious Tolerance, there are at least eight different definitions, generally with negative connotations and often promoted by those in the anti-cult movement or the media.

There is evidence to suggest that cults or "new religious movements" (NRMs), as they are sometimes called, are moving to the net. On his religious movements website, Jeffrey Hadden, sociology professor of the university of Virginia, says: "The internet does provide an opportunity to immerse oneself - however deeply one may choose - in the subcultural world of new religious movements."

At a time when research has shown that 70% to 75% of US citizens believe in extra-terrestrials and UFOs, numerous NRMs have grown up surrounding this area, perhaps the best known being the late L Ron Hubbard's Church of Scientology. There are now even "anti-UFO" cults, according to Professor Irving Hexham of the university of Calgary, who runs an NRM discussion group and web site, "based on cosmic theories that threaten their version of Christianity."

Announcing one's "end times belief" on the web has become a standard practice, adds Brenda Brasher, of Mount Union College in the US. When members of the group Concerned Christians were arrested in Israel two years ago - suspected of plotting violent acts to "hasten" the coming of the Messiah - one Israeli millennial specialist was shocked that the group did not have a website. "How can any self-respecting millennialist group not be on the web?" he exclaimed.

The most shocking example of this type of web use was the mass suicide of the Heaven's Gate community (39 well-educated individuals) three years ago. They believed they were transporting themselves to a space craft tailing the Hale-Bopp comet. Dwelling communally in a small mansion in Rancho Santa Fe, California, the group supported itself designing web sites. When Hale-Bopp appeared, the Heaven's Gate community took it as a sign that their class was ready to "graduate". On their home page the words "Red Alert" flashed. The page said that Hale-Bopp was the marker for which they had been waiting. After their suicide on March 25 1997, visitors to the Heaven's Gate site found an epitaph written by one of the community, a poignant plea to the world to understand what they had done.

Many of the Christian evangelical/ charismatic movements use the web to attract newcomers. John Campbell, webmaster for the Manchester-based Jesus Army explains: "Our aim on the internet is to communicate the unchanging Christian message in a modern manner. I'm sure if Jesus was around today he'd use the internet!" The site runs a message board that Campbell says attracts a lot of good natured discussion, and a prayer request service.

On the Church of Scientology's slick official site you can take a personality test online (although you have to meet someone in person to receive the results) and visit links to more than 15,000 Scientologists. Said one British opponent of Scientology: "The battle between Scientology and its opponents has been absolutely transformed by the net."

At one point the newsgroup alt.religion.scientology was more popular than alt.supermodels, he jokes, and became the key battleground. As writer William Shaw, author of Spying In Guru Land, explains, the main reason that the Church of Scientology has a large internet presence is the high net profile of its opponents. "The CoS is very proficient at the internet now, but I believe that was only responding to very successful anti-Scientology sites on the web in the early 90s."

One of the Church's US lawyers tried to get news servers to drop the alt.religion.scientology newsgroup, which not only failed, but created an outcry online. The newsgroup was and is flooded with thousands of excerpts from a Scientology text. The Church also bought up the Cult Awareness Network (CAN) after it went bankrupt in 1996. "One of the doctrines of 'survival' of L Ron Hubbard [the Church's founder and a science fiction writer]," says Shaw, "was to attack anybody who attacked him. This was perfect for the medium. The internet is famous for its flame wars.

"It's easy to have contempt for opponents here. Any religion that thrives on being attacked - as Scientology does - will thrive on the net."

Much of the background to the war between Scientologists and their detractors can be seen at Operation Clambake set up by Andreas Heldal-Lund in Norway in 1996. Reading an article about Scientology, then seeing some of its posted teachings scared him, he says and led him to join a growing band of anti-Scientologists spread around the world.

His site includes many examples. One of the incidents he highlights was last year when Amazon.com dropped Jon Atack's book A Piece Of Blue Sky, which was critical of Scientology's teachings. There was a massive outcry from netizens and free speech advocates, and Amazon promptly reversed its decision. The site also outlines how, in 1998, Scientologists were issued with filtering software to prevent them visiting anti-Scientology sites.

Roger Gonnet, an anti-Scientology activist running a web site based in France, says: "My two sites were attacked three times each, the first with three attorneys in a row, attacking my ISP too... they even tried to attack under the guise of 'violation of trade secrets' which is a strong thing for a 'religion'."

"For many years, the Church of Scientology has taken action to protect its scriptures from abuse," says a spokesperson. "It is in pursuit of its First Amendment right of free religious exercise that the Church has brought legal action to enforce existing copyright and trade secrets laws on the internet."

Many of the most visible web presences surrounding cults and NRMs seem to host "anti" organisations. Sites such as the Cult Information Centre include definitions of a cult and descriptions of "mind control" techniques. The American Family Foundation is one of the main anti-cult groups in the US, and houses a huge site. Triumphing Over London Cults specifically targets the International Churches of Christ in great detail, and features testimonies of for mer members, audio recordings of leaders and links.

Another site, www.cyberpass.net/truth/essay, discusses the experience of "survivors" of Siddha Yoga, while at www.trancenet.org/moonism, Ingo Michehl talks of his experiences as a student member of the Moonies. Walkaway outlines how fundamentalist Christians can leave their groups, while www.ex-cult.org talks about life after being in a cult. You can even find exit counsellors and so-called cult "experts" online (such as Rick Ross).

Shaw asks: "Are new religious movements using the internet to disseminate their message? I think they're remarkably quiet on the internet, as it goes. I don't think people who are seriously interested in winning souls are that into it."

He says the anti-cult groups need and utilise the net most effectively: "People in cults don't need 'virtual' communities. They've got their own virtual communities in the cults they've joined. But people who've left cults are often desperate to recreate the experience they've left... however hostile they are to the religion they were in. They joined cults because they wanted to save the world from evil. They join anti-cult groups to do the same thing. The web provides the perfect opportunity."

webTitle: Rooted in the past, but focused on the future

fields.headline: Rooted in the past, but focused on the future
fields.trailText: Skipping between three languages, Danny holds the floor. Under a roof of reeds, seated on rush matting, he ensures that the visitor, his grandparents and other young men from the village all feel part of the conversation. His tongue savours words in English, Tok Pisin and the local language, Kepai. He loves it, you can tell. He is practising for his future.
fields.body:
Skipping between three languages, Danny holds the floor. Under a roof of reeds, seated on rush matting, he ensures that the visitor, his grandparents and other young men from the village all feel part of the conversation. His tongue savours words in English, Tok Pisin and the local language, Kepai. He loves it, you can tell. He is practising for his future.

His grandfather, the revered village chief and part-time pastor, watches him carefully, his glances showing pride. The 19-year-old has been brought up by his paternal grandparents. His grandmother harvests two younger granddaughters in her arms, their eyes wide at Danny's homecoming. They reach out to touch his shoes. Grandmother purrs: her husband, her grandson, the visitor and the young men, all in her home. A new vegetable garden, new crops, a truck to get them to market.

But as she holds the girls tight, perhaps she senses that Danny is moving on from them; that he won't come home and settle down when he leaves school. His eyes and gestures are full of the future, rooted in the village but encompassing a wider world.

Deep in the central highlands of Papua New Guinea, the village is a grower's dream. Pockets of rich, deep soil abound in these mountains and valleys. With the permanent spring weather, carrots, cauliflowers and cabbages grow alongside bananas, pineapples and sweet potatoes. Drop a seed, turn your back and pick the crop. A great place for subsistence-level organic food-growing, which is why the highlands has sustained a large population for centuries.

But it is also a nightmare if you want to transport your produce. The outside world did not know these communities existed until the 1930s, because the rugged terrain prevents easy access except by aircraft. But Danny knows of the growing towns on the coastal plains, has studied drought problems, read of his country's huge food imports. It seems easier and cheaper to ship in rice to these areas than to organise and transport home-grown but perishable food from the thousands of isolated village valley gardens in the highlands. Danny is determined to find a way; his education has convinced him that his product is healthy, plentiful and sustainable.

His grandparents know that setting up the garden, growing new crops and maintaining the soil fertility are matters that Danny will soon pass on to his friends in the village. The real struggle will be the rest of the job: moving the crops and marketing them. Since Danny was born his mother has spent most of her life working in towns on the coast. He sees her occasionally. She has given him the belief that he can bridge the gap, but there is no money to set up the venture. Fees have had to be raised for the 12 years he has been in school.

Danny jumps up, sweeps aside a cloth curtain that conceals his corner of the small house, and fetches paper and a pen. It is the universal student bedroom: papers, books, a radio, pens and rulers, all set out on the earth floor. Not a stick of furniture, no anglepoise lamp, but the essentials are there. He sits by his grandfather's feet, and sketches out the garden: drain lines, nursery area, compost heaps, erosion barriers and water channels. Grandfather asks about pests. Danny turns to the visitor; they talk of mixed cropping, rotations and healthy seeds. Grandmother asks about beetroot; she once heard that it is good for the blood.

Finally a juicy ripe pineapple is sliced, and six fresh sticks of sugar cane arrive. Danny says grace. The air is full of sweetness. Departing handshakes are sticky affairs.

Through the village, past the round huts,the latrine and the haus man . This place, once the preserve of the men, is now a warm, smoky, thatched pub of a place for all the family after church. Dogs, cats, pigs and babies mingle among the legs. Danny moves between the groups of people, hugging, smiling, clasping hands. The first boy from the village to go so far in education.

Danny is ecstatic. The visit home has been part of his dream; he had a sleepless night worrying about it. He sleeps soundly on the trip back to school, the battered bus jolting between sealed and broken roads. The late afternoon rain pours down during the last hour's walk down to the school. He has missed supper, and bed beckons. Danny looks tired but happy. Double advanced mathematics first thing in the morning.

fields.headline: A Tribute to Egon Wellesz
fields.standfirst:
***
Wigmore Hall, London
fields.trailText: Viennese-born Egon Wellesz (1885-1974) was a pupil of Schoenberg's, and a friend and contemporary of Alban Berg and Anton Webern. After Hitler's rise forced his exile, he settled in Britain, where he taught at Oxford University. His own music ranged widely - he wrote three operas, nine symphonies, string quartets and song cycles - but it's hardly ever heard today.
fields.body:
Viennese-born Egon Wellesz (1885-1974) was a pupil of Schoenberg's, and a friend and contemporary of Alban Berg and Anton Webern. After Hitler's rise forced his exile, he settled in Britain, where he taught at Oxford University. His own music ranged widely - he wrote three operas, nine symphonies, string quartets and song cycles - but it's hardly ever heard today. This tribute, organised under the auspices of the Anglo-Austrian Music Society, revived three major works, all composed in Britain: a string quartet, a vocal work - a setting of Gerard Manley Hopkins - and an octet.

The impression left by these disparate works is puzzling. The Fifth String Quartet (1943) is audibly the work of a Schoenbergian, though there's far more emphasis on expressive melody than expressionist gesture, the quartet, with its subtitle, In Memoriam, was consciously designed as a leave-taking, and, in the Hopkins setting, begun the same year, he started to wipe the slate clean.

Yet the 1947 octet seems to hark back to central Europe - although to the neoclassicism of Hindemith rather than the second Viennese school. It's bluff and rather too determinedly perky; whether there's more in it than this rather dutiful performance discovered, was hard to judge, but then, sadly, this isn't music any of the performers are going to play very often. Some of Wellesz's larger-scale works might provide a better sense of his stature.

The Fifth String Quartet (1943) is audibly the work of a Schoenbergian, though there's far more emphasis on expressive melody than expressionist gesture, the quartet, with its subtitle, In Memoriam, was consciously designed as a leave-taking, and, in the Hopkins setting, begun the same year, he started to wipe the slate clean. Yet the 1947 octet seems to hark back to central Europe - although to the neoclassicism of Hindemith rather than the second Viennese school. It's bluff and rather too determinedly perky; whether there's more in it than this rather dutiful performance discovered, was hard to judge, but then, sadly, this isn't music any of the performers are going to play very often. Some of Wellesz's larger-scale works might provide a better sense of his stature.

webTitle: I want to be a journalist, not a secretary

fields.headline: I want to be a journalist, not a secretary
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

Since finishing my studies in media I have been unable to get a related job and have been temping for 18 months. I have knowledge and work experience in journalism, research, radio and production. For some reason, I don't even make it to the shortlist. I feel as though potential employers see me as a secretary and nothing else. How can I get both feet in the door.

Name and details supplied

The solution

It never ceases to amaze me how narrow-minded employers can be. Getting over the once a secretary, always a secretary barrier is often difficult, but when you have a wealth of relevant experience, as you do, you could be forgiven for thinking it would be easier than you've found it so far.

There is no easy solution, but I have a couple of ideas that might help:

 Change your job title and description. Instead of calling yourself a secretary in those applications, call yourself a production assistant or even personal assistant. Play down the clerical aspects of your job, and play up key areas such as liaison with production companies, researchers, journalists, etc. If you do any research yourself, play that up too.

 Get some help with your applications. It might not be your job title which is hindering you - it could be your application style. Are you being careful to match your skills and experiences directly and blatantly with the person specification? For instance, if there are five items within the person spec, list your own skills under those same five headings. If you are a graduate, you should be able to go to any university careers centre for help, or check out the bookshops. One useful book is 'From CV to Shortlist' by Tony Vickers but there are several others.

 Utilise the company you are in now. Try and find a mentor who would be prepared to help with your applications and perhaps even give you relevant ongoing work experience to bolster your current work role. They may even be able to help you get that break you need when a vacancy arises.

Finally, don't give up! There are plenty of ex-secretaries in top media roles - if they can do it, you can too.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

• This article was amended on 3 March 2010 to anonymise the interviewee, at her request.

webTitle: City professional firms to face OFT inquiry

fields.headline: City professional firms to face OFT inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Merger mania and high fees prompt review of exemptions from Competition Act

Department of Trade and Industry
fields.trailText: The City's leading law firms and accountancy practices are to be investigated by the Office of Fair Trading (OFT), the chief commercial watchdog, it was announced last night .
fields.body:
The City's leading law firms and accountancy practices are to be investigated by the Office of Fair Trading (OFT), the chief commercial watchdog, it was announced last night .

This inquiry comes just weeks after the 1998 Competition Act came into force and is thought to have been triggered, in part, by the accelerating pace of mergers among big firms of solicitors and accountants.

Ministers have ordered a review of the clauses which can allow professionals to claim exemption.

Both the Treasury and the Department of Trade and Industry have requested the review, which ought to be complete by the end of this year. John Bridgeman, head of the OFT, said the "prime focus" will be law and accounting, although the exemptions apply also to engineers, surveyors, architects, teachers, doctors, dentists, nurses and midwives.

The act provides for fines totalling 10% of turnover where firms have engaged in price fixing, but professions can apply to the Trade and Industry Secretary for exemption.

As yet, none has done so, although they are exempt where price-fixing is required by law.

Professional services are worth £25bn a year, and the treasury is concerned that the high fees charged by large practices specialising in commercial work, may have a distorting effect on the economy.

The OFT will focus on three types of restrictive practice. Firstly, it will look at "disproportionately tight standards" applied to those wishing to enter a profession.

Secondly, it will examine the rules restricting advertising and price competition, such as rules prohibiting the publication of charges in advertisements.

Thirdly, it will look at acts of parliament requiring the public to use "qualified professionals for certain transactions when other appropriately qualified people could do the job".

Peter Owen, head of professional standards at the Institute of Chartered Accountants for England and Wales, said "of course we will co-operate", but that big firms did compete on price and quality.

The OFT made it clear last night the review would take into account the need for professional bodies to police their members' standards in order to protect the general public.

webTitle: EU leaders launch internet drive to create jobs

fields.headline: EU leaders launch internet drive to create jobs
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and his EU colleagues last night launched an ambitious initiative to harness the internet to help drive economic reform across the continent as they arrived in Portugal for the so-called "dot.com" summit.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in  Lisbon  and  Michael White
fields.body:
Tony Blair and his EU colleagues last night launched an ambitious initiative to harness the internet to help drive economic reform across the continent as they arrived in Portugal for the so-called "dot.com" summit.

The leaders also manoeuvred to ensure that disagreements over Austria do not overshadow their summit on jobs. Its Portuguese organisers said they did not expect all leaders to join the Austrian chancellor, Wolfgang Schussel, for today's traditional "family photograph".

Unprecedented diplomatic sanctions were imposed on Vienna by all other 14 members of the EU after Jörg Haider's far right Freedom party joined Mr Schussel's coalition government. Portuguese officials insisted last night that the main business of the summit was too important to be overshadowed by the Austrian crisis.

Downing Street wants to use the summit to secure agreement on social and economic reform.

Mr Blair was expected to discuss the BMW crisis with the German chancellor Gerhard Schröder, as well as holding talks last night with the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, about the stalemate in the Northern Ireland peace process.

Putting the debate about the euro to one side - and hoping to avoid rows over tax and the national veto - the prime minister is expecting to see the two-day event go very much his way.

Britain is saying that the summit is a golden opportunity to seize the opportunities offered by internet technology and e-commerce to make EU economies more competitive and cut stubbornly high unemployment - 15m, or 10% across the union.

Leaders are expected to pledge to provide internet access for all schools by 2001, more money for high-tech research as well as promoting welfare reforms to make labour cheaper and more flexible.

Conservatives in Britain reacted with scepticism. Figures produced for the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, by the Commons library yesterday, suggested that meeting the EU's targets for "digital literacy skills" for all unskilled and jobless workers would cost Britain around £700m.

It is typical of the "statist, high tax, interventionist mentality which is preventing the EU keeping up with the US - let alone overtaking it", Mr Maude said yesterday.

webTitle: BT to set up 50 e-advice shops

fields.headline: BT to set up 50 e-advice shops
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British Telecom yesterday announced government-backed plans to create up to 50 regional centres to attract a wave of "new economy" companies to the UK and promote the country's role as the European hub for e-commerce.
fields.body:
British Telecom yesterday announced government-backed plans to create up to 50 regional centres to attract a wave of "new economy" companies to the UK and promote the country's role as the European hub for e-commerce.

The £70m initiative from BT Elocations - a new division of the group - is designed to help foster the growth of "clusters" of hi-tech, internet-based companies throughout the UK, and not just in the golden south east.

Sir Peter Bonfield, BT's chief executive, said Britain needed to adjust swiftly to the new economy to retain its position as Europe's premier location for inward investment, attracting 23% of the EU total.

The initiative, backed by the Invest in Britain Bureau, the IBB, aims to establish one-stop advice shops for would-be overseas investors in business and technology parks in the UK's 15 regions, including Northern Ireland.

Patricia Hewitt, the e-commerce minister, said it should exploit Britain's leading role in wireless telephony and digital television by providing newcommers with "a physical place and a virtual network."

Andrew Fraser, the chief executive of the IBB, said the UK must be ready to accept the next era of investment after the establishment of a network of call centres.

The aim is to staff the new centres with multi-skilled staff - including people speaking a range of languages.

webTitle: Mothers may get part-time working rights

fields.headline: Mothers may get part-time working rights
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Working mothers could get the automatic right to return to their jobs part-time after taking maternity leave, under plans being considered by the government.
fields.body:
Working mothers could get the automatic right to return to their jobs part-time after taking maternity leave, under plans being considered by the government.

Female ministers are pressing the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, to bring in the reform, which would delight vocal campaigners for a better balance between work and family life.

In a move announced in this week's Budget, with an eye on winning women's votes, Mr Byers will consult on improving maternity pay and rights. There is also strong pressure for a new right to unpaid parental leave for both mothers and fathers to be paid.

Employment minister Margaret Hodge and women's ministers Lady Jay and Tessa Jowell, are thought to back the change, although Mr Byers is wary of a negative reaction from employers.

Campaigners say the review marks an opportunity to improve the maternity deal for British mothers, who are entitled to the equivalent of 8.6 weeks off on full pay, compared with a European average of 22 weeks.

Lucy Anderson, a TUC equal rights officer, said: "The most effective way to keep women in touch with the labour market after having children is to increase the coverage of statutory maternity pay and maternity allowance."

One senior female minister said: "We are digging in our heels on this and we are being heard."

Clear signals from female ministers, particularly in the Treasury and Department of Education and Employment, that such an entitlement is within reach emerged in the same week that Cherie Booth called for improved rights for part-time workers and more job sharing as a part of a drive towards more family-friendly employment.

However, while pressure groups and unions would welcome the reform, employers will be concerned about the burden on business. Government sources say the most resistance is likely to come from medium-sized companies, because many larger firms already have the scope to offer part-time deals. The smallest organisations are regarded as flexible.

Ministers and sources at the cross-departmental Women's Unit believe that change is necessary if the government's commitment to address the work-life balance is to have meaning.

One source said: "We know that, while the economy is strong, it is a seller's market and employers are having to offer flexible working arrangements as part of recruitment packages to recruit the right people. But if things get tighter, those advantages could be taken away again and women could be left with no negotiating power."

Women's ministers point out that, deprived of the chance to return to work part-time, many women - particularly in low paid jobs - opt not to go back to work.

This adds to the benefits bill and weakens the link between women and the workplace - which ministers believe is important in bringing mothers back to work at a level suitable for their skills and experience.

Mr Byers is being lobbied on the issue as the regulations for implementing the European directive on part-time work are finalised. No timescale has been set for his review of maternity pay and rights.

Female ministers hope that the scope of the consultation will be as wide as possible, and Treasury sources indicate that payment for parental leave will be included.

fields.headline: MPC checks for inflation pressures
fields.standfirst:
Budget 2000: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Bank of England signalled yesterday that it would be re-examining the chancellor's Budget in case it puts upward pressure on inflation and interest rates.
fields.body:
The Bank of England signalled yesterday that it would be re-examining the chancellor's Budget in case it puts upward pressure on inflation and interest rates.

The monetary policy committee was aware of the broad outline of Mr Brown's projections for growth and the public finances when it met earlier this month and left borrowing costs on hold at 6%.

The Bank of England's rate-setting committee concluded that "the impact on future activity and inflation seemed to be failrly small".

However, minutes of its meeting published yesterday showed that the MPC thought "more analysis would be needed once full details of the Budget were known".

Despite the tax cuts and spending increases announced on Tuesday, the Treasury insists that fiscal policy remains tighter than envisaged at the time of last year's Budget and should have no adverse impact on interest rates.

But City analysts pointed out that policy was now considerably looser than if Mr Brown had not cut taxes and increased spending.

"Ahead of the Budget, the chancellor faced the usual calls to tighten fiscal policy further to reduce upward pressure on interest rates and to help stem the strength of sterling," said David Walton, of Goldman Sachs, the American investment bank.

"While we expected the chancellor to reject these calls, he did it in a much more emphatic manner than we anticipated," he said.

Mr Walton calculates that the fiscal stance will ease by 0.6% of output in 2000-01 at a time when domestic demand is already growing rapidly. "The MPC is unlikely to be comforted by this. Nor are we."

Michael Saunders, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney Citibank, said Mr Brown's decision to take his foot off the fiscal brake increased the risks of overheating.

"At the margin, this will add to pressure for higher base rates," said Mr Saunders.

"Fiscal policy is being driven by the aim of boosting the government's popularity in the countdown to the general election [expected to be held in May 2001] rather than to rebalance the economy."

Complaints that the price of the chancellor's fiscal largesse would be paid by industry were echoed by Kate Barker, the chief economic adviser to the Confederation of British Industry. "Given the size of the budget surpluses envisaged by Mr Brown, it's understandable why he might want to cut taxes or increase spending, but it's just not the right time at the moment," said Ms Barker.

"It makes the chances of further interest rate increase slightly worse."

The MPC's nine members unanimously agreed to leave borrowing costs unchanged when they met on March 8 and 9, but some saw a case for a further increase to ensure inflation remained on target.

Consumer spending remained strong, earnings growth was rising and the oil price was up, the MPC's minutes noted.

However, the decision was finely balanced and there was time to wait for more data which were at present clouded in millennium "fog".

There was also a danger that more expensive borrowing costs would boost sterling on the foreign exchanges, and there was uncertainty about the impact of the Budget.

The minutes record: "It was not possible to do a full analysis of the Budget yet so it might be prudent to wait before a firm conclusion on the implications for inflation."

Other MPC members saw no need for an increase in rates this month.

They noted that although domestic demand was stronger and trade weaker than in February, there was no clear implication for inflation as these factors were offset by others in the economy.

They also thought that the Budget suggested a tighter fiscal stance than previously anticipated by companies and individuals - and that there were risks of a sharp reversal of the oil prices and an American stock market crash which would exert downward pressure on inflation.

"Given that interest rates had increased 100 basis points in four steps over the past six months, it was sensible to wait and see how the economy reacted, particularly given the short-term inflation profile," the minutes noted.
