webTitle: How to sack your bank manager

fields.headline: How to sack your bank manager
fields.standfirst:
They charge us £400 a year for the privilege of looking after our money. So, asks Emma Brockes, is it possible to live without a bank account?
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: They charge us £400 a year for the privilege of looking after our money. So, asks Emma Brockes, is it possible to live without a bank account?
fields.body:
The key to living without a bank account is envelopes. Every surface of Lena Stewart's home in Stirling, Scotland, is occupied by a complex network of files and folders, wallets and ring-binders. There's one for the TV licence, one for the gas, electric and telephone bills, one for food and one for travel.

Stewart, a voluntary worker, has been without a current account for 10 years, over which time she has developed a system that gives her a level of financial control that she doesn't believe would be possible if she involved herself with conventional banking.

It is estimated that 1.5m households in Britain do not have a bank or building society account. One fifth of these belong to the country's poorest families, but there is a further one sixteenth who earn average incomes and have chosen, out of the hatred that only financial institutions can inspire, to opt out of investing in them.

The advantages are largely cardiovascular. After a series of verbal skirmishes with his bank manager, during which he was referred to as a "pony-tailed, cockney card-dealer", Keith Whincup became so angry that he felt himself blowing up like a cartoon character.

The 56-year-old from south London lost his business as a Renault dealer in the early 1990s, a fact he attributed to the bank reneging on its promise of an overdraft. He has since gone bankrupt, suffered a heart attack and, in lieu of keeping a bank account, has chosen to set up a series of jam jars into which he deposits £10 notes on a weekly basis.

"It took some adjusting to," he says. "But you get used to it. I do occasional television appearances to advise on financial exploitation and am paid in cash. You pay your bills in cash at the post office and although they sometimes charge you an extra fiver, it's better than entrusting your money to the banks."

In 1993, Brian Jones lost his business owing to what he believes to have been bank errors. He not only withdrew from all forms of organised finance, but launched a campaign against Barclays that has elevated him, in some circles, to the status of a superhero: Credit Avenger.

"I tried asking them respectfully to sort out my problems," he says from his home in Bristol. "I wrote 360 letters. I kept saying to myself, 'What am I doing wrong?' I was brought up to respect my peers and I couldn't believe if you rang up with a problem, they wouldn't deal with it."

Jones dealt with the impasse by setting up an organisation called Safe, Security Against Financial Exploitation, and attracting formerly affluent, disgruntled bank customers to the cause. He dressed up as the Grim Reaper and marched into Barclays head office, rigged an 18ft billboard bearing the legend "Tell me where I can find the chairman of this bank" to the roof of his car, christened it the Grief Wagon, and drove it around London. He threatened to drop in on the chairman of the bank during his Christmas dinner and, wherever he went, he left stickers reading: "I am Brian Jones, I'll be back."

Jones is at the extreme end of the anti-banking fraternity. A more measured withdrawal is to join an organisation like Lets, the Local Exchange Trading Scheme that has 450 branches and 40,000 members across the country. To some, Lets represents the weirdy-beardy, communitarianism end of non-banking. It advertises itself with the motto "Enjoy wealth without money", which sounds like a prelude to some kind of religious recruitment drive, but is an entirely literal compression of its bartering and exchange system.

"Our members come from all different kinds of background," says David Robertson, the administrator of Lets Scotland. Members don't have to hate the banks to join the group - many of them, including Robertson, maintain current accounts on the side, while trying to confine their financial dealings to local trading circles - ie exchanging ironing or lawn-mowing duties for cake baking and babysitting. "A member may not have a current account, but they will have a Lets account to the value of £200 and that is good enough for us," says Robertson.

That £200 worth of credit is referred to as "local currency" and can be exchanged at bazaars and Lets trade outlets for food, furniture or services that might otherwise require officially recognised credit. And they have fun with it too. For example, Robertson has a row of plants for sale on his window sill, which, to keep fellow members amused, he has marked up in "groats".

"The thing that makes the system sustainable is that it has a cross section of society within it. There are those who offer to do ironing and gardening, as well as those who can fill in a tax form. It shows that you can get by without a bank account."

This is not financial necessity, but a way of life entertained by people who believe that strengthening the local community means giving its members a wider set of economic choices than are offered by profit-making banks and building societies.

It is aided by credit unions, low-income investment houses that lend money at low interest rates and encourage customers to transfer a minimum of £10 a month from their envelope system to an account.

"You are cutting off your nose in spite of your face by boycotting the banking systems," says Neil Walkling, principal money researcher at the Consumers Association. "So many transactions rely on automated credit that to be out of the loop is a severe disadvantage. Customers hostile to the main high street banks might look beyond them to smaller, Scottish banks or places like the Halifax."

For those who don't, the problems encountered are cruel and obvious. Lena Stewart has to pay all her bills by postal order, which costs her an added fee for each cash conversion. "When I try to cash a cheque in a shop they charge as much as £5 to do it," she says. "If the gas board overcharges me, they'll say they don't do cash refunds so that it always takes a lot of to-ing and fro-ing before I get my money."

Keith Whincup thinks of these problems as a small price to pay for the larger benefit of screwing the banks. The only account he would consider opening is with a foreign institution like American Express, which, after years of research, he believes to be less mercenary than the British banks. Meanwhile, he is happy to rely on the superior banking services of his jam jars.

fields.headline: Weighty ambitions
fields.standfirst:
Nash Ensemble/ Martyn Brabbins
Purcell Room, London
fields.trailText:
Nash Ensemble/ Martyn Brabbins
Purcell Room, London
fields.body:
Vivid images of dispersal and desperation dominated the second concert of the Nash Ensemble's New Music Series. Thomas Adès's Catch and Oliver Knussen's Mask featured parts for walkabout instrumentalists: Richard Hosford was the elusive clarinettist in Adès's quartet, while Philippa Davies combined theatrical and technical accomplishment in Knussen's clearly imagined solo work.

But Richard Causton's Rituals of Hunting and Blooding for (stationary) ensemble, commissioned and premiered by the Nash under Martyn Brabbins, was the most immediately arresting piece of the evening. The first movement, Terror of the Hunted, opened with gestures of violence and volatility, with Hosford's screaming clarinet line grating against Simon Limbrick's menacing cowbells and drums.

Despite the movement's apparently frenzied increase in activity, with clarinet and piccolo enhanced by trumpet and trombone wails, the music remained curiously static. The texture was dominated by insistent, irregular percussion rhythms, which seemed to grind the momentum of the surrounding parts to a standstill. Causton's depiction of "terror" was broad-brush and strangely undynamic - like a freeze-frame photograph of a hunt rather than an animate, vital battle sequence.

The Blooding of the second movement provided a complete contrast, with mellifluous vibraphone replacing the opening movement's staccato. Within The Blooding's soft-hued harmonic palette and sense of detachment, John Wallace's concluding flugelhorn solo provided the richest commentary on the preceding pursuit. Like a dissonantly transformed hunting horn, Wallace's instrument no longer sounded the call to the kill, but lamented the victims of the chase.

Mezzo-soprano Jean Rigby was reunited with Brabbins and the ensemble in James Macmillan's song cycle Raising Sparks, as this team gave its first performance in 1997. The work sets texts by Michael Symmons Roberts, with whom Macmillan collaborated on his Proms commission, Quickening, last year. There are some impressive moments, such as the melismatic violin solo surrounded by a shimmer of harp chords and florid piano figuration at the end of the third song.

This was a committed performance, but there is sometimes an oppressive weightiness about these settings. Macmillan's operatic vocal writing and transparent instrumental imagery create a music that cannot escape the centrifugal symbolism of the poetry. Sally Beamish's wordless expression of mourning in Between Earth and Sea was less ambitious but just as affecting: an elegiac, salt-kissed study in weightless melody for flute, harp and viola.

fields.headline: A view to die for
fields.standfirst:
Queuing for Everest
Sheffield Crucible Studio
***
fields.trailText: The theatre is a blinding, dazzling white. Around the edges of the empty space, the detritus of a climbing expedition. In the centre, a discarded camera, a snapped rope and the outline of a prone body, just like you get in a murder investigation.
fields.body:
The theatre is a blinding, dazzling white. Around the edges of the empty space, the detritus of a climbing expedition. In the centre, a discarded camera, a snapped rope and the outline of a prone body, just like you get in a murder investigation.

Judith Adams's Queuing for Everest, a text, not a well-made play - the bleached bones of something that has been fleshed out by director, designer, lighting, actors and choreographer - is an investigation too. It pieces together our fascination with the highest place on earth, the unending romance of that Sir Galahad of the mountains, George Mallory, the thrill of body and rock hugging each other, the nature of truth, and the way you sometimes have to climb up very high to get a good view of your own life.

Far too much, really. But you can't mock such ambition. This is not the kind of theatre you see often in the regions. It's not playing anything safe, and you can't go up the mountain without taking some risks. Adams and director Deborah Paige know that. For the audiences at stage level, there aren't even any seats. You must find your own perch.

It's a funny thing about mountains. You go up to get away from everything and find yourself surrounded by people. Think of those pictures of the disastrous 1996 season when a queue formed at the Hilary Step, as if they were waiting for a bus. For every six who go up, one doesn't come down. Everest is littered with broken dreams, dead bodies and ghosts.

The ghosts walk here and, somehow, they are much more interesting than Thea and Georges, adulterous lovers on an adventure of a lifetime. Maybe it's because you can't feel much sympathy for rich westerners who pay $64,000 to be dragged up the mountain by a poor sherpa. Maybe it's because Thea's deathless prose makes her an unlikely journalist or that Georges is so irritatingly self-obsessed. Adams lets them make mountains out of molehills. Much more resonant is the character of Georges's wife, Sophie, left behind, like Mallory's wife, and making a painful, stumbling journey in the foothills of her own anxieties.

This play is like a frayed rope. The threads of its different stories, of past and present, documentary and fiction, and its variety of styles never quite come together. It feels like a series of moments, not a seamless whole. Like its characters, it is often too self-conscious. But it's insightful too, at times capturing the beauty and brutality of the mountains and those who climb them, and the hallucinatory madness of risking all and heading into thin air.

Until April 8. Box office: 0114-249 6000.
